In this time of humanitarian emergency, as you said, Mr President, is there a greater demonstration of this European spirit than the magnificent citizen impulse that we see flourishing in several Member States to welcome and help refugees fleeing death and destruction? The European Union, dear friends, is the opposite of retreating into oneself in the rejection of the other. Wanting Europe against the rest of the world is inevitably, in the long run, pitting Europeans against each other. The Union is solidarity in openness and it is the actors and actors of change who today bring this ideal and these values to life. It is with them, Mr Juncker, it is with them, ladies and gentlemen, that we must build alliances, build bridges, re-create hope. If Europe loses them, Europe is lost. So, in the face of the challenge of refugees and migrants, remember, it was a year ago, Pope Francis in this assembly said that Europe has two responsibilities: to welcome and act on the causes of conflict.  Mr Juncker, you have had the right words and you have said them since last spring. You didn't wait. The proposals you have made here point in the direction: yes, we need a permanent distribution key for refugees in Europe. Yes, we need legal paths to the European Union, which are the only way to put an end to the deadly business of smugglers.  This Parliament, Mr President, and I conclude, can also propose concrete and immediate action in response to the emergency. On behalf of my group, I am submitting a very concrete proposal: this parliament in which we meet today, we occupy it less than 50 days a year. For the remaining 300 days, the 750 offices of MEPs that are heated and equipped with individual showers remain empty and unnecessary. We therefore propose that this second home of the The European Parliament, fully equipped, is used for the temporary reception of migrants and refugees and that plenary sessions are held in Brussels for the necessary time. (Applause) This, ladies and gentlemen, is a concrete measure that would allow our Assembly to join the gesture to the word and demonstrate through practice our commitment to the principles of solidarity and human dignity. Thank you.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Mr Juncker has simply got this wrong. As I warned in April, the European Common Asylum Policy sets its terms so widely as to say that anyone setting foot on EU soil can stay: I said it would lead to a flow of biblical proportions, and indeed that is what we are beginning to see. This has been compounded by Germany saying last week that basically anyone can come. It is a bit too late now to draw up a list, by countries of origin, of who can stay and who cannot stay. All they have to do, as they are doing, is throw their passports into the Mediterranean and say they are coming from Syria. As we know, the majority of people who are coming – and the Slovakian Prime Minister has been honest enough to say so – are economic migrants. In addition, we see, as I warned earlier, evidence that ISIS is now using this route to put their jihadists on European soil. We must be mad to take this risk with the cohesion of our societies. If we want to help genuine refugees, if we want to protect our societies, if we want to stop the criminal trafficking gangs from benefiting as they are doing, we must stop the boats coming – as the Australians did – and then we can assess who qualifies for refugee status. I noted your comments, Mr Juncker, because there is a referendum coming in the United Kingdom. I look forward to seeing you in the UK. I know you intend to spend tens of millions of pounds of British taxpayers’ money telling us what we should think. I have a feeling that the British people will warm to you on a personal level, but, as to suggesting that getting rid of a few EU regulations is going to change our minds, sorry – unless you give Mr Cameron back control and discretion over our borders, the Brits, in the course of the next year, will vote to leave. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, it is simple to sum up in one word the state of the Union: the crisis.  First, the economic crisis, which is killing our industry and our agriculture.  Then comes the diplomatic crisis. As always, the European Union has a finger on the seam of the pants in front of NATO, in Ukraine, Syria, Libya, to the great misfortune of those countries that you have destroyed and the nations of Europe overwhelmed by an unprecedented influx of illegal immigrants and Islamists. Let me express my great concern at the crazy injunctions that you have just issued to the States: 160,000 illegal immigrants to be compulsorily distributed as early as next week and you are threatening financial sanctions having the recalcitrant states, as if we were talking about common offenders. People can't take it anymore, they don't want it anymore, they who are already overwhelmed by unemployment, poverty, immigration. There is no pressure on the wealthy petromonarchies of the Middle East, who have these migrants on their doorstep. The peoples of Europe are being asked to accept immigration, this demand of the big employers. As for our farmers, they will appreciate to benefit from you only crumbs: 500 million, while we reserve 4 billion euros for illegal immigrants. Finally, the democratic crisis, of course, which is accompanied by the clear demonstration every day that your monster despises peoples, curtails their freedom, acts against their interests. So instead of thinking, you hop on your chairs like cabris, bleating: "Europe, Europe, Europe", as if increasing the cause of a problem could reduce its effects. Your Atlanticist fantasy, so pathetically visible in the title of this so-called State of the Union speech, is a failure.  Soon, this aberration that is the European Union will fall back into the oblivion of history by democracy, by the referendum I hope; it will start with our British friends. People will finally have a chance to know prosperity, security, democracy and peace.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I want to say something about the words ‘Patriots unite!’ My first impulse was to write, and to say, ‘Patriots of Hungary unite!’ because I am deeply worried about my own homeland. Then I wanted to write ‘Patriots of Europe unite!’ because I know that many patriots around Europe feel the same way. Finally, I realised that there are patriots not only in the receiving and transit countries of migration but also in the countries of origin – in African countries and in the poor Asian countries. We all have the same dream: to live in our homeland, to work for our homeland in peace, and to keep our roots and our culture’s traditions. Let us unite, let us start thinking and working together for our common dream and let us make the world a better place.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Commission, commissioners, on behalf of the Council, I would first like to thank President Juncker for his State of the Union address, for his lucid analysis of the situation, for his vision of what is at stake for the Union, for saying things as they are, but above all for his important proposals and for his initiatives in the various areas. You are right, Mr President, this is not the time for routine but for the courageous, exceptional and innovative actions which call upon this capacity in our Union, which we Europeans are capable of at truly historic moments. Alas, we are living in a historic moment, as we experienced, for example, at the time of the fall of the Wall and the reunification of the European continent.  Europe is facing a major crisis that requires it to have a real capacity for action, a real political will, a solidarity that characterizes the European spirit. President Juncker highlighted the migration and refugee situation. This is a critical moment for the Union. Recent events confirm this and are on a scale we did not suspect. They seemed to surpass us, they challenge our values and, it is true, put our instruments and rules to the test, and certainly do not allow us, today, to procrastinate or procrastinate. In the context of the Justice and Home Affairs Council in July, the Presidency has devoted all its efforts to the implementation of measures concerning, in particular, a temporary and exceptional relocation and resettlement mechanism. I do not hide from you that this task has not been easy and has not yet been sufficient. We need to go further and faster. The new proposals presented today by President Juncker are an important contribution to the ongoing process and further Council meetings are planned. We must all be aware of the urgency and the need to join forces and not divide ourselves. Europe is perfectly capable of controlling this refugee crisis which, as has been said, represents 0.11% of the population, which is not huge. Europe is able to control this crisis if it acts in accordance with its values, exceeds the downturns, in short, if it is able to show a genuine common political will.  The Presidency is working tirelessly to find solutions with all Member States. It will do everything to bring them together in close cooperation with the institutions, first and foremost, the Commission of course. This will not happen without everyone's efforts, and I will come back to it in a moment during our debate on migration and refugees in Europe. Mr President, we have had the opportunity to present the other priorities of our Presidency, which are very much in point with those mentioned by the President of the Commission. It is true that we must not forget the issues of unemployment, the recovery that must be encouraged and supported, and the problem of youth unemployment. We have an investment plan that must now be implemented courageously and quickly, as the chair said. The Luxembourg Presidency is very keen - on this point, I know that we are on the same wavelength, Mr President - to the deepening of the European social dimension. I listened well to what you said about social dumping: "for the same job, the same salary". It is important that free movement is preserved, and in order to preserve it, we must of course create this balance between social rights on the one hand and economic freedoms on the other.  We support the Commission in its efforts to stimulate the internal market, particularly in the digital sector, but it is also true that this sector will transform not only our industries and services but the way we work and, therefore, our labour market. It will therefore have a fundamental impact on the qualifications and skills that we also need to deal with urgently.  In terms of major challenges in sustainable development, i.e. the fight against global warming by mobilizing our efforts in the run-up to decisive international conferences, COP 21 is a crucial event because the stakes are high.  Let us not forget, and this has been said, that this refugee crisis is fundamentally the result of other terrifying conflict crises in the European neighbourhood. Besides, when I look at our neighbourhood, we cannot say that it is very stable. It is a neighbourhood that is plagued by crises and conflicts. Europe must therefore be an international player. Politics (CFSP) plays a fundamental role with Federica Mogherini and I believe that we must commit ourselves but also invite the international community to engage, especially at the UN level.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his First of all, thank you very much, Jean-Claude Juncker, for making it clear that Europe is more than any project, but that there is a concern, that it is fundamental, that it is about values. And perhaps this refugee problem is an opportunity to put it back in the spotlight a little bit. There is history, there are orders, there are values. That is why we must help, not only in words, but also in concrete terms. It is also true that the Member States certainly still have a great homework to do. It is also right – and I am also grateful for this – that it has been pointed out that there is a second page, namely safe countries of origin. It is also necessary to ensure that repatriation is organised, to combat smugglers. It is also true that it has been pointed out that the issue is complicated and that it is not just done with such an answer. For example, even with legal immigration, legal immigration does not solve these problems, but that this is also seen in a differentiated way. Thank you for that. Now the time was too short, and therefore I was missing something. I did not have the part that must give the answer as to how we actually finance this huge challenge and how we ensure that the citizens of Europe follow this path. This will only work if prosperity takes place in Europe, if full employment is organised. This is not just a problem for Greece. That is why we should also find another opportunity to reflect on: how do we organise growth in Europe, what about the internal market, what about our regulations, what about our energy prices, what about the question of promoting business, what about the question of promoting innovation and research? I just asked these questions, I didn't have more time. But the concern is an important prerequisite if we want to solve the other big problem. And I expect the Commission to act just as consistently.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Monsieur le Président, vous venez de faire un discours courageux en faveur de l'Union européenne, en faveur de l'union des Européens et nous vous soutenons dans cette direction.   Yes, the European Union is confronted with an existential crisis and finally, what is at stake is for us to ask what kind of people are we Europeans? This kind of crisis can only be solved by real European solutions.  So, do you have this tragedy unfolding on our borders with a humanitarian crisis out of proportion? The only solution is a real European asylum system. Do you have this increasing pressure of migration across our borders? Yes, the only solution is a real European migration agenda and stronger European development cooperation. Do you have these mounting tensions in our labour markets? You need to come back, as you thought, to an agenda for full employment in Europe, and the investment plan is certainly the main engine for this purpose.  But can we say that all Member States have the conditions to implement such an agenda? I do not think so. I do not think so as long as the euro zone is an area of divergence and not an area of convergence. That is why your plan of completing the economic and monetary union is also so important. So to conclude, we do need real European solutions, and for this we parliamentarians need to represent not only the citizens of our countries but European citizens as a whole. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I wanted me not to be able to give the blue card because we are very late and I would ask all speakers to keep to the time allotted to them because otherwise the votes would really go a long way and then we have a lot of debates this afternoon. So, contrary to the past, I will be rather rigid with respect for speaking time.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Mr Juncker that we know that the situation of those refugees who manage to arrive on European soil is dramatic. Technical and political solutions are badly needed. ‘Let us be clear and honest’ you repeated, Mr Juncker, and you referred to root causes. Well, I just want to cite now an ethical consideration far too often avoided.  The first thing that should be done by the Council, the Commission and this Parliament is to recognise that some European countries are greatly, not exclusively, but greatly responsible for the present situation, not just because of their wild invasion of Iraq, but also because they are guilty of inaction or ineffective involvement in many Mediterranean and Middle East conflicts which have given rise to what we now reap. This recognition would be a first gesture of morality and justice and it would help to better understand the other steps we should take immediately.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker spoke today of the moment of frankness, I agree, and so I say to you that Today I see a chair that is guiltily empty, that of President Tusk and many dirty consciences.  Rather than the State of the Union, should we be talking about the States of the Union, in fact, that Europe is the europe in which one measures its principles by bickering over the figures of due reception, the money for a European Mare Nostrum and the legal avenues for refugees? What kind of Europe is europe in which certain Eastern European countries forget the time when they had refugees, the time when they pretend not to know the consequences of our trade policies, the actions of our multinationals, and you do not have the courage to denounce them, let alone to denounce those of the American and Chinese multinationals? Other than TTIP, the one in which it does not recoil at the Arab countries, so-called allies, which, with the exception of the noble exceptions of Lebanon and Jordan, have done practically nothing to help their Syrian, Yemeni and Iraqi brothers, but have done much to destabilise the Middle East with the complicity of some of our governments?  What Europe is the Europe in which the economic crisis is answered by the strong towards the weak and the weak succumb to the strong? I say it, it is a hypocritical and cowardly Europe! It is because instead of addressing the causes of the problems, many people think of the Union as a public limited company and its dividends to be collected and instead it is a community of values, with quotas of rights not only for migrants, not only mandatory, but of responsibility for all. Perhaps you in some governments will try to settle for what is easy, know that the 5-star Movement will not give you peace until what is right is done!

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – Today, Mr Juncker presents a plan to distribute 160 000 migrants to the EU. Let me be the first to say this: it is not the Juncker plan, but the Merkel plan. It is Angela Merkel who, with President Hollande, wants to impose this plan on the whole of the EU through Mr Juncker. That is eu democracy in practice! Germany sees that it cannot accommodate these people and now allows the rest of the Member States to pay for the mess it has made by offering free home, free care and free money to the asylum seekers as a priority. This plan Merkel does not say: we will stop free money for anyone who knocks on the door with a sad story, no matter how implausible.  This plan Merkel is sticking to Schengen, while among these illegal immigrants there are many thousands of terrorists of the IS. I'm shutting down. Mr Juncker, go back to Mrs Merkel and explain it to her again. Show solidarity with European citizens, show understanding for their security. Close national borders and stop free money for those hundreds of thousands of fortune seekers, while 120 million EU citizens live in poverty.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – Mr President of the Commission, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Mr President of Parliament, I would like to begin by thanking mr First of all, on behalf of the Polish delegation to the EPP, I would like to express my sincere condolences.   Mr President, the situation is dynamic, and i would therefore like to say on behalf of the Polish delegation that we are from a country where parliamentarians are not from the moon, but from a specific country that has an eastern border of the Union. Thank you for mentioning that a tragic situation can also happen from ukraine. That is what you mentioned. The situation is so unclear that it is not known what the next steps will be. We share your view that not only relocation is a solution, but also a holistic approach, a whole set of tools that must be used. The situation is so dynamic that we in Poland too, aware of the humanitarian catastrophe, are in the process of debating how to increase the possibility of accepting refugees. The Prime Minister's proposal yesterday is to start the discussion with an increase, but we believe that control of the process should be in the hands of individual countries.  One more point. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. We are from a country and from countries where we understand very precisely what is happening and we want to be in solidarity with others, but we will not allow ours to be energized, possibly blackmailed with European money, because that is counterproductive. This counteracts the relevant European action. We are in favour, but we will discuss how we can help.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, when the political course we started today is over, we will be almost in the middle of the legislature and it will be about a decade since the economic crisis began. For the economy it will be a lost decade; for the social dimension, a decade of setback. It is the right time to fulfill the investiture commitment and present a triple A social; it is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration; it is time to put forward proposals – today announced them – that can move towards a European minimum wage, towards a common European unemployment benefit, towards the recovery of labour rights and towards the fight against tax dumping. As far as the humanitarian crisis is concerned, nearly 60 million people worldwide now live in refugees or displaced persons. They escape war, but flee hunger, because even today in the world there are more people who are starving than guns. And the European Union must have a strong voice in the face of the next humanitarian action conference to be held next spring in Istanbul. The Commission has already presented its communication, Parliament will make its report, the European Council will reach its conclusions at the end of the year, but they will judge us in Istanbul, not by what we say, not by what we have written, but by what we have done in our own land. If we are not here in solidarity and responsible, we will not be able to ask Istanbul to be anyone else with the rest of the displaced in the world.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In the short minute at my disposal, I would like to address the situation in Ukraine, which Mr Juncker also mentioned in his speech. What is going on russia's part against Ukraine in Crimea is not worthy of a modern society. The civilian population is suffering, the number of human lives being lost is a dismaying number. As elected politicians, it is our duty to act vigorously on this issue. From my party, we have supported both in the European Parliament, in the Council of Europe and in the Swedish Parliament the call for an end to the armed conflict and for diplomatic talks to begin. Nevertheless, let me be clear to those MEPs who are spreading falsehoods about our party. Russia must pack up here and now and leave Crimea and Ukraine – and preferably yesterday. Winter is almost only a month away, and I fear that Russia's next step is to cut off gas supplies, which will have devastating consequences for the people of Ukraine.  Regardless of political play by other MEPs, I and our party will continue to support demands for this conflict to be resolved. You have my word on that.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank and congratulate the President of the European Commission for the height of his views, vision, leadership and European spirit. All these qualities are, alas, too often lacking in European policy.  I remember your sentence whose apparent humour should not hide the cruel reality: "There is a lack of Europe in the Union and a lack of unity in Europe". Europe is not working well. Despite our joint efforts, European policy is too largely confiscated by national leaders. However, the European Council is not working well. It is obliged to decide unanimously, reviving national and sometimes nationalist tensions where the common interest should prevail. He debates in camera on migration. Its first meeting, in June, resulted in shameful and disgraceful haggling. He decides only under the pressure of events when you are on the brink. It yields to the dictatorship of urgency and, sometimes, emotion at the expense of long-term choices. Finally, it does not care about the application of its own decisions. Worse, through negligence or hypocrisy, he has just let the finance ministries, which are currently considering the EU's draft budget for 2016, cut all lines used to finance asylum and migration policy.  Yes, it is time to put Europe back in the Union and the union in Europe.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the President Juncker, I would like to thank you for your honesty. It is indeed time for honesty, and it is indeed time for more Europe. The refugee issue will become a touchstone for us Europeans. If we do not manage to do that, we can lose everything. But we can also win a lot! And I am grateful to you for not reducing the issue to a mere quota discussion, for not appreciing the contribution of the countries of the Middle East. You want to be honest, and I want to be honest, because there is not enough we do for these countries.  We need more resources, we need better cooperation. And it is not enough to refer to hotspots that are coming soon. Tens of thousands of people are currently on the Balkan route in the open air. If it rains, as is announced for today, for example, then there can be very big disasters for these people, so please act! And I believe that it would be very important to support those countries, such as Serbia, which have taken on an exemplary role here.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker, I will give you an example: Spain still has more than four million standing still and yet will unreservedly accept the proposal for refugees made by the Commission today. Out of generosity, out of solidarity, for humanity, but also because we believe that, as Europeans, we have an ethical duty to welcome all those who escape fanaticism and war because, as Mr Juncker said, we do not forget the Republicans of our civil war or all the millions displaced by the two world wars in Europe.  The European Union needs a common asylum policy , that is true , but it also needs a common foreign peace policy and an internal policy of coexistence and tolerance. We need, if I may say so, another Schengen Treaty, but a mental Schengen Treaty, which erases mental borders and erases borders in our hearts. The heartbreaking picture of a dead Syrian child on a beach in Turkey has opened the eyes of many Europeans, but let me tell you: he is not the first child to die – thousands have died before him and, unfortunately, it will not be the last.  Let me tell you: Syria's is not the only war around us; let me tell you: after the refugees, those persecuted by hunger, climate change and disease will come; and let me tell you: the distribution of people, their selection, their shipment and their reception in the countries of the European Union will not be easy, it will be a long and difficult process.  We are not facing a challenge for today, we are facing a challenge for the coming years, a challenge that will accompany us for a long time. The question isn't how many? The question is when? When is the international community going to end this war? Because as long as this war doesn't end, there won't be enough quotas for so much pain.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I extend our condolences to you and others. I also want to thank you for the speech you gave today, which goes back to the heart not of the Community method but of the European Union and of this value of solidarity without which nothing is possible. This solidarity, which is the keystone of the European Union, of the euro area and which is a value so dear to the political family to which I belong, which you so desperately need to implement the agenda that you have just set before us today.  It is also in this spirit that I would like to thank the European Commission when it prevented grexit because grexit was the unravelling of all European solidarity. But we have to go beyond that because, as you said, this crisis is not over. We will have to have the courage to address the issue of debt because all observers know that this debt is unsustainable. So let's approach it with determination and a spirit of solidarity.  In the same way, you have said your determination to move forward to make economic governance a governance that enables us to face all these challenges, including those that confuse Member States with the reception of refugees en masse. For that, Mr President, please do not just wield the stick, don't forget the carrot. Solidarity needs tools and the distribution of budgetary capacity for the euro area. Rely on the proposals of this Parliament to move forward in this area and not just on the proposals of a few finance ministers.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like once again to reiterate our pride in having always and immediately supported you, Mr Juncker, as President of the Commission. When we listen to it, we truly recognize ourselves in the values we share. and we believe in the very Europe in which you believe and we really hope that your speech, so articulate, so comprehensive, so humane, welcoming and supportive, informed of the values of Christian Europe, but also so complete, has not only partially moved.  Because while it is true that today we must throw our hearts over the obstacle and with solidarity respond to the emergency, it is also true that we must put in place all those medium and long-term instruments to prevent this tragic phenomenon, which you rightly called a first and most human issue and historical justice.  We have always, through our group leader such as Italy, as Forza Italia in the PPE, pushed to have this complete picture, we recognize ourselves in all its proposals and we really hope that the message will come complete, because from those countries they are looking at us, as so many newspapers say today: what we say must not create false illusions because, instead of responding to the emergency in a rational and useful way , we would create further tragedies and tragedies. Thank you for your approach, I wish you good work, we wish you all good work.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you said, Mr Juncker, that this is neither an ordinary nor a normal time for the Union. We are going through a historic ridge and we need strong European leadership, even collective leadership, leaders who do not graduate from some good school in Europe or the USA. It is the leader who takes on the responsibility that history assigns to him, and that is the history of today's Europe.  We have not yet overcome the internal economic and social crisis, inequalities and unemployment, and at the same time Europe is being hit externally, east and south, by the instability and conflicts of which that river of fleeing humanity is the consequence.  That is why we are asking you for strength and leadership in order to take a common European path, overcoming national logic and interests, overcoming the mediocrity that some countries unfortunately express, of selfishness, perhaps those same countries that European unity and spirit of solidarity have brought together in recent years. Mr President, we will support your proposals with the priorities indicated by my President, Mr Pittella, but we ask you to be courageous, timely, adequate, concrete and urgent so that we do not say more about Europe – as we have said a thousand times – yes, it has acted, but too little too late!

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President of the Commission, this winter begins with the collapse of two important collective illusions. Unfortunately, the commitment to Dublin II and the illusion that the countries entering the European Union, such as Greece and Italy, can manage the wave of refugees on their own have tragically collapsed. Now, we must not only increase the funding for refugee integration by much more than 1% of Community GDP, but we must proceed immediately to the mandatory division of responsibilities. There, the Commission has a say and must monitor it. But while we welcome Greece, – because in the Greek islands they end up, in Kos and Lesvos – hundreds of families with children in their arms – because the Greeks know about refugees – we must also know who are the ones who are stepping on our territory. As Europeans we must secure our borders and the host countries must be strengthened for this. But also in the Greek crisis, Mr President, the illusion that populism can provide solutions has collapsed. Now in Greece we are many who believe that the new government should have reforms as its first priority. The government resulting from the elections must be stable and guarantee a secure economic environment under the agreement. Of course 'Grexit' will not return to the table because we will not allow it to return. We will succeed, with the contribution of the European Union, as the Spanish, Portuguese and Irish have done.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, press headlines in June 2015: 'The European Union fails to agree on the distribution of 40 000 refugees', 'Spain rejects the quota proposed by the European Commission'. It is true that it has been national selfishness that has laid stones in the path of this long-awaited European solution to respond to the biggest refugee crisis of recent years. However, in order to assess the Commission's current situation, it is necessary to talk about other fundamental issues and policies. Europe will not emerge from the crisis or create jobs if we do not implement growth and investment policies and, in that sense, we welcome the first steps taken with the Juncker plan. But there is another fundamental question: where is social Europe? Where are the struggles against inequalities? Where are the initiatives on the European minimum wage and minimum income? Where are the equality initiatives between men and women? Where is the strategy to combat social dumping? Mr Juncker, time passes and Europe does not wait.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen! They have invested a great deal in raising awareness. Where we come from, who we are, where we go. That was right and necessary. The idea of Europe, the European Union political project, is our work programme. National selfishness, discouragement, lack of sincerity, contradiction between word and deed, lack of determination are our problem.  It is up to us, if we want to remember and want to, we can overcome all the challenges that have been raised. And we are currently seeing signals in many countries that encourage and give hope, with successful cooperation between civil society, NGOs and serious public participation. The waves of refugees, Greece, hunger are facts. Facts that must be the birth of a common, serious European foreign, defence, security, development policy, a common economic and social union.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I'm sorry. Europe has always been driven by constant change and adaptation to a changing world. The current refugee crisis has once again caused a situation where we either change, and then we get out of the current situation stronger and more unitedly, or we back down, give up our fundamental principles and values, but then we give up our future. We can no longer tolerate people in need of support because of bad compromises, outdated rules and calculating political leaders walking on motorways, waiting for trains that never leave, crowding in ports and becoming victims of people smugglers. The Commission's new initiatives to extend the redistribution system are important, but this is only the beginning. We have a lot of responsibility, no more time to waste. Our job is to make it clear that those who are in solidarity with refugees can count on more European solidarity. This is the moral basis on which the Union and European culture as a whole are based.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, dear President of the Commission, this issue of the immigration crisis has an advantage for us, who are Europeanists, it shows everyone that, not only in this chapter, but also in the other chapters, we need more integration and more European coordination, more Europe and not less Europe, and so I was here to bring the economic theme , which is a topic of concern to many countries such as Portugal, such as Spain, such as Ireland, as well as Greece and so many others, who have made enormous efforts - particularly in the case of Ireland, Portugal and Spain - to be in a good position today, and therefore I ask a very specific question: our Prime Minister, who has so far been the only person who has presented a vision for Europe in this context. , our Prime Minister has proposed that, in the asymmetric shock mechanism to be considered in the future, we should have the possibility of having a common fund to help the unemployed. How do you see this in the future in view of the document of the four presidents and now the document of the five presidents, the first of 2012 and now this one that was presented in June?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to thank President Juncker for his positive role in managing the Greek crisis. Next, I would like to point out that there are impressive political developments in Greece. SYRIZA is running in the elections with a softer schedule and New Democracy, my party, is making impressive political openings for cooperation immediately after the elections. I want to stress that politics is evolving in Greece but the economic crisis remains with us. If we prove after the elections that we are able to manage the crisis effectively, then we will again need the help of Mr Juncker and the institutions for a more flexible policy, in terms of taxation of farmers, taxation of small and medium-sized enterprises, taxation of the tourism sector. We must first prove that we are consistent ourselves and then we will need to relax tax policy somewhat in order to get out of the crisis with dynamic economic growth.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, in this debate I would also like to bring the voice of a sector in crisis, the farmers, who are demanding a fair price for their production, for dairy production.  There are hundreds of holdings to which an immediate response must be given by the European Commission, setting minimum intervention prices; otherwise, the dairy sector and thousands of farms, mainly in regions such as mine, Galicia, are going to disappear. That is why it is necessary to hear the voice of the ranchers who are on the streets.  We have to give an answer. The answer must be immediate; the answer must be fair. And the European Commission must 'move a file', as they say in my land. 'Move tab' and set minimum intervention prices to balance the market, which is the right thing to do.  .

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we have heard Mr Juncker's 80-minute speech, which, admittedly, even Fidel Castro would be jealous of. Speaking on the Greek issue, Mr Juncker referred to his alleged offer to Greece, the 35 billion euro package. In other words, it has once again sold "algae for silk ribbons", because these EUR 35 billion are funds that Greece is entitled to anyway from the European Union's Structural Funds for the period 2014-2020. We have also heard Mr Juncker, as the cynical representative of the Europe of lenders, threaten the Greek people if he does not submit to the Third Memorandum. You must therefore, Mr Juncker, stop acting as a member of the Troika. Mr Juncker, you must stop acting as a representative of neo-colonial German Europe. So I am telling you, Mr Juncker, that your threats against the Greek people will not pass. The sooner you understand this, the better for you and the Commission.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker, I did not vote for you a year ago. Today I thank you for your speech, because you have analysed many of the great problems of the European Union. A lot of states throw balls out. The problem is that the Council is the astro-king in Europe and serves as a perfect excuse for the selfishness of states. Without further a time, every crisis is deeper: today's humanitarian, tomorrow's migration, several years with growing territorial inequality or with poorer citizens. Every crisis will be more serious and frustrated citizens will not forgive, because they need leadership, not excuses. The nationalism of states and the weakness of each of us, of each of us, with our responsibility, generate a toxic circle, generate populism and populism generates more irresponsibility in certain states, such as Britain, or as in Hungary, or in others. And this is a tremendously dangerous drift, Mr. Juncker. Each of us must be responsible. Count on us what you touch us.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that this morning's debate is a debate of historic importance, and I would like to say that we cannot afford any form of hypocrisy here. I believe that the distinction between refugees and economic migrants is a fictitious distinction, we have a duty to save the lives of those fleeing hunger and war, from the destabilisation that we have very often helped to create.  We must not discuss here an emergency even under the emotional wave of an impact of images of human flows, we here must discuss a structural change in the Union's policies, a reform of the right of asylum, a new idea of European citizenship that can be crossed, we must discuss how to break down all the walls and how to make visibly ridiculous phrases such as 'let us help them at home' , when the homes of those people, very often, we destroyed them.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for his work I confess that I was impressed by most of your speech today. Not from the part on TTIP, I am, we Greens disagree, nothing will come of it, TTIP belongs stopped. But most of your speech, the long first part of solidarity with refugees, and the fact that the Member States must now finally act, deserves respect. It was important to note that you are serious about the fact that, as you said, it is abnormal to cut development cooperation and not increase it, that you are serious about the fact that we have the financial and material means of helping those fleeing war, and that you are serious about the fact that asylum seekers are allowed to work from the first day of their application and earn money themselves. As head of government, you have not yet wanted that. I hope that other Heads of Government will now follow you. However, we need a President-in-Office of the Council who sits here when this is discussed, and not a President-in-Office of the Council who is making the brakes on the governments, but one who is actually pushing forward a Europe of solidarity with you, with the entire Commission, and with us.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President der Kommission. Vielen herzlichen Dank, Herr President! Ich habe so lange geredet, dass ich den presidialen Wunsch, der mir zugetragen wurde, jetzt nicht zu lange zu antworten, in vollem Umfange respektieren werde. Ob mir das gelingt, ist eine andere Frage. Auch der Kommissions, president darf vom Presidenten of the European Parlaments unterbrochen werden. Ich ordne mich der Befehlsgewalt of the President dieses Hauses gerne unter. Ich wollte zwei, drei Sàtze - vielleicht auch vier oder funf - der Debatte nachschieben und zuerst einmal darauf hinweisen, dass es nicht stimmt, dass die Ratspràsidentschaft und der Rat hier nicht vertreten gewesen w.ren. Es ist ein luxemburgischer Minister yesterday - Arbeitsminister, lange Jahre zust-ndig for Migrations-, also auch Integrationsfragen. Wenn es in der luxemburgischen Regierung jemanden gibt, der wei, worber hier geredet wird, dann ist es der hier anwesende Ratspresident. Ich bin ihm auch dankbar dafar, dass er hier ist. Zweitens, weil ich zu Verteidigungsreden aufgelegt bin: Es ist nicht korrekt, den Ratspresidenten, Herrn Tusk, zu kritisieren, dass er nicht hier ist. Ich bin ja nicht sein Sprecher. Aber wo war Herr Van Rompuy denn in den letzten Jahren, als diese Debatte stattfand? Dies ist eine Debatte zwischen der European Kommission und dem European Parlament, und so ist sie auch festgelegt in den Vereinbarungen zwischen Kommission und Parlament. Herr Tusk, mit dem ich mich in den vergangenen Wochen 'ber meine Rede lange unterhalten habe ' die entsteht ja nicht einfach so, wenn sie einfach so hette entstehen messen, w're sie 'berhaupt unter den gegebenen Umst-nden nicht zustande gekommen Die Turkei hat doch etwas mit dem Problem zu tun, 'ber das wir yesterday reden. Die Anwesenheit von Tusk in der Turkei ist wichtiger als die Anwesenheit des Ratspràsidenten in einer Debatte zwischen der Kommission und dem European Parlament. (Zwischenruf) Doch, das ist so. Ich habe mit dem Presidenten des Europeischen Rates diese Debatte vorbereitet, er hat seinen Besuch in der Turkei intensiv mit mir vorbereitet, und ich mechte ihn yesterday ausdr-cklich ausnehmen aus der Kritik, die hier vorgetragen wird. Ich finde die nicht berechtigt und der Sachlage absolut nicht angemessen. Since some have mentioned the problem of Greece, I wanted to say that this 35 billion scheme, which the Commission has proposed, is obviously fuelled by the Structural Funds. Greece, under all governments, has not been able, for lack of administration and lack of sense of state, to absorb the funds that have been made available to it. What the Commission has done, under the chairmanship of Vice-President Dombrovskis, is to bring together all the Commission's administrative energies and human resources to help Greece absorb the funds over a very short period of time and according to co-financing rules that differ from those that were in force previously to enable it to do what it did not do for years and should have done. , including in recent months. On this subject, I could expand indefinitely.  I accept a lot of criticism. I am not saying that the programme that was negotiated is an aesthetic example to be replicated, but still, for the first time, as I promised the European Parliament, we have done a social impact study of the Greek programme. It was not mentioned. Not a word! If the Commission had not done so, you would of course have rightly criticised it for not doing so. We did it about Greece. It needed a political look. Do you really think that the question of whether a higher VAT rate is applied to restaurants and food chains is a technical or political issue? It was political, so we decided as politicians. It is still incredible, you must know - and if you do not know it, it is because you are not told - that the President of the European Commission had to make the basic and common sense demand to reduce the Greek defence budget. The Greek government had not proposed it. I have proposed on behalf of the Commission that the shipowners sector should be imposed in a fair and correct manner. The Greek government had not proposed it. I, a conservative and reactionary Christian Democrat, was still very surprised to have to make a two-hour argument against the Greek Prime Minister to demand that Greece properly tax the richest rather than the victims of the crisis. It was me! It was not Mr Tsipras. Yes, I talked about honesty; it's never "real" since you listen to one and not the other. I do not want to dwell on the Greek case, because otherwise you will tell me that I intervened in the Greek domestic policy debate, which I do not want to do. I salute, for the rest, good many of the remarks that Mr Tsipras made towards me, much more polite than yours, at his press conference in recent days.  Yes, the Commission is part of the former troika, but I say to you that if the Commission had not been there, the adjustment programme that would have emerged would have been much more burdensome than the one which, thanks to the Presidency of the Commission, now appears to be the most nuanced of the programmes we have concluded so far.  I would also like to pay tribute here to other countries. Ireland, Portugal, Spain and Latvia have shown, with supporting evidence and analysis of the results, that when you make the right reforms, your results are better than if you did not.  With regard to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, I have heard what has been said. I'm not naïve!  Also, ich bin nicht naiv, wenn es um das Freihandelsabkommen mit den USA geht. Ich sage nur: Wir brauchen dieses Freihandelsabkommen. Die Bedingungen, unter denen dieses Freihandelsabkommen zustande kommt, und der Inhalt der Verhandlungen, die zurzeit stattfinden, sind ja Sache nicht nur der Kommission, sondern auch der Mitgliedstaaten. Aber diese Einstellung, dass wir ab initio sagen: "Dieses Freihandelsabkommen brauchen wir nicht," dieser Darstellung kann ich mich beim besten Willen nicht anschlieen. Wir sollen anst-ndig verhandeln und auch durchverhandeln. Aber wir brauchen dieses Abkommen, und wir werden es auch haben zu Bedingungen, die dem europeischen Geist und den europeischen Prinzipien absolut entsprechen. Zur Landwirtschaft mechte ich noch etwas sagen, weil ich dies in meiner Rede nicht sagen konnte. Aber das wird Ihnen irgendwann irgendwo von irgendwem ausgeteilt werden. Ich fehle mich den europeischen Landwirten sehr verbunden. Ich habe immer zu denen geh-rt - auch als freherer Premierminister und auch als Finanzminister -, die die gemeinsame europeische Landwirtschaftspolitik verteidigt haben, weil Europa ohne die Bauern, ohne die Landwirte, ohne die Winzer, ohne die Landschaftspfleger nicht das Europa Wir derfen die Bauern jetzt nicht im Regen stehen lassen! (Beifall) Die Europeische Kommission wird das ihre dazu beitragen, dass wir diese Milchkrise - das ist eine echte existenzbedrohende Krise fer die Milchbauern - so schnell wie meglich beheben kunnen. Erste Vorschlàge haben wir gemacht, und wir hàren jetzt auf Rat und Parlament, um weitere Vorschlàge machen zu kunnen. Ich danke, Herr President, fer die sehr lange Aufmerksamkeit, die das Hohe Haus mir heute hat zuteilwerden lassen. (Beifall)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I would like to express my sincere thanks, Mr Juncker, for what you have said. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. – I have to thank President Juncker for making a speech which is so helpful to the cause of British withdrawal from the European Union. Mr Juncker wants ever more European integration in all areas; but let me highlight those points which will be of great interest to the British public. First of all he wants to open up Europe's borders to yet more waves of immigration, which he calls ‘legal channels for immigration’. He wants even greater integration of economic and fiscal policy, and economic governance of the Member States by the EU. He wants to guarantee the security of the Balkans and Poland against any military threat from Russia. If the British people want to remain in the EU then this is what is in store for them: never ending uncontrolled and unlimited immigration from Africa, the Middle East and beyond; Britain's eventual entry into the European Single Currency; and the creation of a European Army, which will absorb the British armed forces. Mr Juncker has done more to help the cause of British withdrawal from the EU than any other individual. May he keep up the good work and come to Britain to campaign in the referendum campaign.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In his first State of the Union address to the European Parliament on Wednesday 9 September, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker presented his proposals for the distribution of refugees. He wants a quick agreement between member countries to take in 160,000 refugees. Even as Europe suffers an unprecedented social, agricultural, diplomatic and economic crisis, the Commission is forcing Member States to take in "migrants" who have been turned into 'refugees', who will become permanent. The solution would have been to act courageously and go to Syria or Iraq and fight (as Russia is about to do) the terrorist group Islamic State. The peoples of Europe no longer want these policies, especially since nothing is being put under pressure on the wealthy petromonarchies to take in refugees as well. We have managed to release 4 billion euros for refugees, but only 500 million euros for our farmers. The EU and the Commission must understand that citizens no longer support these speeches and that they expect a radical change in policy. The only saving path for the peoples of Europe is the return to a Europe of sovereign, free and independent nations to end the dictatorship of self-righteousness, globalised finance and ultraliberalism.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. The words spoken today by the President of the Commission rightly emphasise the delicacy of the moment we are going through. It has some effect to hear Juncker say that 'Europe is missing and there is no union in this European Union'. In recent weeks there is a lack of values of solidarity without which the very idea of Europe is lost and there is a lack of responsibility and awareness that only together can we be able to manage situations, such as that of migratory flows, which are now structural. Today, the Commission takes on many of the reflections that characterised President Renzi's speech on the occasion of the opening of the Italian Presidency. Finally, Europe recognises that it needs unity, solidarity and less bureaucracy. That bold and human choices are needed. That we must focus on investment for growth, that we need a permanent distribution for immigration. That in order to overcome the difficulties caused by resistance from certain Member States, we need the firm support of the European Parliament.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. I fully agree with Mr Juncker that we cannot discuss the State of the Union today without addressing the issue of the migration crisis and the uninterrupted influx of refugees within our borders. Resolving this situation must become the priority on which we must focus all our energies. The European Union must show that it has reached the political maturity that it has so far lacked. It is not possible that, in the face of thousands of people dying at sea trying to escape the horrors of war, we are still making our national self-interest prevail. There must be a common political will to help these men, women and children who have no fault other than to live in territories bloodied by conflict and battered by terrorism. States that today say no to reception or that build walls along their borders should remember that, at the time, their populations were also welcomed in Europe. The distribution of binding quotas as proposed by the Commission must be approved, but we must also get to the root of the problem: the European Union must make a political effort to resolve the conflict in Syria, as well as in Libya and other war-prosying regions.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. –Living through the biggest refugee crisis we must respond to the humanitarian emergency. Unfortunately, the Council was unable to reach an agreement to distribute 40,000. The Commission proposes to boost 120,000 refugees to be distributed in the 28 Member States when Germany alone will receive 800,000 in a single year. There are supportive Member States, but others have blocked any solution and some speeches bring back racism and xenophobia. I fear that the Council will again not be up to the challenges.  We need a permanent resettlement mechanism with mandatory quotas. We need more funding for the Member States. We need more means to process asylum applications. We need an effective return policy. We are denouncing that the Council proposes a cut in the budgetary appropriations that should increase. We must also protect the future: effectively combat the self-styled Islamic State; Humanitarian and Development Aid needs to be strengthened and strategically targeted (and we must contribute to peace in Syria, and Libya, among others); we need a truly European migration and asylum policy that includes better regulation of legal immigration and combating illegal immigration, and effectively combating human traffickers.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. We need more Europe and more Union within the European Union to deal with the current difficulties and the refugee crisis. Above all, the refugee crisis must be tackled jointly by the whole of Europe. We need a solution based on solidarity between the Member States as soon as possible. And this must then be enforced consistently, if necessary, with the help of sanctions.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – I agree with the reflections expressed by President Juncker on the need to complete Economic and Monetary Union. In fact, I believe that the so-called "5 Presidents" report, the lead author of which is the President of the Commission, contains at least two fundamental ideas, namely to complete the banking union with a European deposit guarantee fund, as well as the implementation of the eurozone's fiscal capacity. However, the timetable proposed by the report is unrealistic, as many of the measures would not be implemented until after 2017. The Commission must exercise its power of legislative initiative, and even reform of the Treaties, in order to implement as soon as possible the catalogue of proposals in the abovementioned report, as well as the issuance of European public debt, the debt repayment fund and European unemployment insurance in addition to national systems. It is also necessary to define how resources will finance the additional euro area budget (European taxes, ECB benefits, etc.) In short, the citizens of the Union, and in particular those of the Eurozone, cannot wait until 2025.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The scale of the refugee crisis requires us to mobilize all the resources needed to care for the thousands of people who desperately demand Europe's help. EU governments need to support the humanitarian response we have long been calling for in this Parliament. From institutions we must ensure that governments and local communities have the money to integrate asylum seekers into their new homes. We need to be clear and realistic in allocating the funds needed to achieve this objective and the Commission must make this a priority in the EU budget by 2016. Likeever, we will not allow short-term crisis management to forecast investment in growth, improve European integration and areas such as science and technology. The recovery will only be consolidated with continuous investment. We will fight to ensure research and development by protecting, from further cuts, the European budget for the Horizon 2020 programme, in addition to the funds for the Connecting Europe programme which supports investments in cross-border infrastructure.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - "The moment of truth has come!" - is a short but clear sentence used by Juncker during his State of the Union address and it clearly demonstrates the need for more Europe and a deepening of relations in Europe. We need more cooperation between the European institutions, member states and all actors to give synergies to all more efficient and better results.  We need a strong joint diplomatic offensive in the Middle East and North Africa to solve the migrant crisis where it arises. As part of the migrant crisis, as well as the refugee crisis, it is clear how important it is to closely monitor the situation in the Western Balkans and open up a clear European perspective to these countries.  However, the migrant and refugee crisis will, sooner or later, decrease or stop, but a large number of unemployed remain and we need to strengthen our European economy. The Juncker Fund can and must play an important role in initiing European development. This will ultimately be the success or failure of this Commission.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – In 2014 we elected a political president to the European Commission and today, 2015 he delivered his first speech on the State of the Union – a political speech that this house has not witnessed for very long time; a speech that was highly emotional, and very strong in the statements. As the EU, we need to face the reality that instead of blaming and shaming, we have to find a way to work on common challenges. Refugee crisis is not a problem of one Member State, nor will it be solved by one alone. It is our common responsibility and solidarity. The weakest link is EU´s foreign and security policy which lacks tools and real political will to fight the root causes of current refugee crisis and to put an end to the war in Syria and Iraq. It is reassuring to hear the president of the Commission expressing strong solidarity with Baltic States and Poland by stating that the security of our borders is untouchable and should be perceived as such also in Moscow.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing – I can agree with many of the things from Mr Juncker's speech on the migration crisis. But I am not happy with the result, which only speaks of quotas. Without analysing what the Commission and the Council have done to date to address the root causes of migration, we cannot convince the population that we are going down the right path and that this story is not endless. In April, we asked the Heads of State and the Commission to adopt the strictest criminal sanctions against trafficking in human beings and smuggling, to cooperate with Europol, Frontex, EASO and Eurojust in the fight against traffickers and criminal networks of smugglers, to trace their financial flows and to find out how they operate so that the causes of violence and lack of development are addressed in the countries of origin in order to prevent the influx of refugees and economic migrants. , so that the UN-led negotiations are aimed at restoring government authority in Libya, we have supported the UN. We have called for intensified efforts to resolve the conflict and instability in Libya and Syria as key factors causing migration. Stability in conflict areas is crucial in terms of reducing the rate of further displacement of persons. We have not received a response to these requests today. I therefore do not consider it fair that the whole debate focuses only on quotas.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – (20) The European Union is experiencing serious economic and social difficulties, but especially humanitarian ones due to the arrival of thousands of refugees fleeing the war in Syria, Iraq or Egypt. This is one of the biggest challenges facing Europe. Since World War II we have not seen an exodus of this scale. We have a moral, civic and human obligation to temporarily welcome refugees, providing them with conditions to safeguard the primacy of respect and human dignity. It is important to ensure that all these citizens must be registered and monitored at the borders of the European Union, to trigger all existing and necessary mechanisms to ensure the highest possible level of security. 2016 will be fraught with economic challenges as well, and it is essential to deepen economic and monetary union, move towards the Digital Single Market and end the Energy Union. These three economic vectors combined with the conclusion of the EU-US International Trade Agreement will contribute decisively to a new period of economic growth and job creation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The state of the European Union can be summed up in one word: crisis. Indeed, between the economic crisis, the agricultural crisis and the migration crisis, the EU is the source of all disasters and shows every day its terrible harmfulness. Deindustrialization, mass unemployment, impoverishment, insecurity and mass immigration are now adding to an unprecedented influx of migrants. This influx is obviously the clear result of the crazy destabilization policies carried out for several years in Syria and Libya, encouraged by the EU and THE RPS officials in France. The President of the Commission is now demanding that 160,000 illegal immigrants be distributed in the coming weeks among the Member States, with bad pupils subject to heavy financial penalties. A whole program... And while only 500 million euros will be mobilised for farmers, 4 billion euros will be mobilised to take in migrants. In the eyes of the European Union, democracy is no longer... The French people are no longer sovereign and no one asks for their opinion... It is already suffering from unemployment, deindustrialization, seconded workers and immigration. The European Union will now impose migrants on it.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - Europe is in crisis, a crisis that affects all Member States of the European Union more or less. In addition to the economic and economic crisis and the increasingly serious wars in the neighbourhood, Europe is currently facing the most severe migrant crisis in its history. Speech by the President of the European Commission, Juncker, marked a week in which Europe proved it was ready to react and show solidarity.  The refugee crisis is a priority for the European Union because it is a test for our humanity. However, there is a need to make a distinction between economic and war migrants. To say that all migrants are economic is wrong and in line with populist policies that must not be supported in Europe. However, opening the doors of the European Union to all is also not right. Unfortunately, Europe does not yet have a strong enough foreign policy as other superpowers in the world. Even in solidarity, we must not forget about other important issues to which the Union is obliged to pay attention.  The Juncker Plan should be seen as a plan to revive an economy that will benefit everyone, both the population of the European Union and war refugees who need our protection. Members of the European Union need to stick together, because only in this way can the Union show the necessary solidarity and remain strong in these times of crisis.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. – There is no doubt that the European Union, sixty years after its founding, needs an adequate response to the crisis in which the most significant project in the entire history of the continent has found itself. The centerpiece of these discussions must start from the foundation of the current state of affairs; The EU is still a community of states, not a common state.  Today we see how mass movements and demands for democratization of authoritarian regimes in North Africa and the Middle East have been, for the most part, a prelude to new and renewed conflicts. Worse, developments in many countries in this large area have extended the list of so-called failed states. Persecuted people, refugees, are becoming more repulsive to many European environments, and their rights are increasingly scarce. The war in Ukraine has, no doubt, become a turning point in the European security system. In the event of a further deterioration of the economic and security situation in Ukraine, a wave of refugees from the European east can also be expected.  But the well-functioning of multilateral organisations such as the EU is not possible without respect for the multicultural concept in member states' societies, without introducing new models of integration of all traditional and new minority communities. Insofar as the noticeable militarisation of politics in one number of members, the withdrawal of social and liberal values or even attempts to criminalise the provision of humanitarian aid to refugees should not be ignored. That is why I support the view that today's Union lacks more Europe and more Union in europe like this.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The reasons for the weaknesses being demonstrated by the European Union must be correctly recognised. These weaknesses result from developments within the Union, not from unforeseen events happening outside or inside Europe. The Union is suffering from overstretch and overreach. Because of them, have emerged the dilemmas and paralysis that affect the Union as it faces the big problems of today – among which the migration crisis, the stand-off in the Ukraine, the tragic Greek muddle and the persisting high unemployment. The Union expanded its commitments and aspirations, but the political will was not really there and the means to carry them out not really available. Meanwhile its soft power outside its borders continued to increase, maintaining the attractiveness of its model, fuelling expectations as to what the Union could do for “people”. We are told that “more Europe” is the solution to this state of affairs. Many European citizens living their daily lives away from the pressures and shared assumptions of political forces involved in the European project, fail to understand what is going on. The solution to overstretch and overreach can – at least during a first phase – only be found in political and economic consolidation, not by enhancing overreach.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – (20) today we are in the European Union with a dangerous scenario revealing fatigue over the idea of common space. The borders have been diluted. For whose benefit? The benefits of freedom of movement are more evident for businesses. But people have to be first. In the agricultural sector, there is a great asymmetry between farmers, who are connected to the land, and business entities of transformation and distribution that, in periods of financial contraction, crush the prices paid to production. In addition, these entities achieve efficiency gains also presented by the market. But without farmers there are no other links in the agri-food value chain, so it is essential to ensure that primary producers are fairly remunerated for their work. Efficiency should not be the ultimate objective, but fair remuneration along the value chain and the contribution to territorial balance. Only in this way can there be equity in market participation. It is unacceptable to allow cheaper products, because produced more efficiently, from any part of Europe to compete with the producers of my country, to the point that this undermines the continuity of their economic activity. Under penalty of the tireof the common space, it is urgent to moralize its rules.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – I am personally disappointed by the speech by the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker. I expected it to focus more on topics such as unemployment, investment, foreign policy, but also helping young people. At a time when farmers are on strike, it would be appropriate to look at both the common agricultural policy and also cohesion policy, because more than a third of the Union budget goes to regional development. In his long speech, he focused on migrants - criticising individual Member States that reject redistributive quotas, appealing for solidarity but forgetting to name concrete steps by the Commission to end the war in Syria, to stabilise the situation in Libya, to specifically help people in refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan,... A year ago, when Pope Francis was visiting the European Parliament, he called on all EU leaders to take action to ensure that the Mediterranean does not become a graveyard of Europe. Unfortunately, even after a year, we have not taken concrete action against smugglers and smugglers, and people are already dying not only in the Mediterranean, but also on the mainland of Europe. We adopt resolutions on tackling the refugee crisis on a regular basis, but they are not implemented. Why this is the case, mr Juncker should have talked about it, too.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: writing – President Juncker stressed that migration is a test of European values. We must show the world that we are a proud continent that can not only guard its security, but can also show solidarity with those fleeing the threat of death and torture. I appreciate that, in addition to this current problem, he has not forgotten the dangers beyond our eastern border and has expressed his support for the citizens of Ukraine.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – The refugee crisis presents the EU with one of the greatest challenges in its history, and now the state of the Union also determines the future of the Union. I therefore welcome the Commission President's determination to finally force member states to act in solidarity with concrete measures and proposals for solutions. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the challenge of eu unity is not only external but also internal: some Member States, in particular Orban's government, are using the migration wave for their anti-European, demagogistic internal political purposes, through a xenophobe heckling campaign and measures to degrade refugees and restrict the rights of their own populations. Such political aspirations, which threaten to split Europe in two and hinder its democratic development, must be blocked. In this, the Responsibility of the European Council and of Orban's party family, the EPP, is paramount, and I urge them to act with the same determination as the President of the Commission.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – I fully agree with a large part of the positions put forward by the President of the European Commission.
