It is true that neither politically nor institutionally, the European Union cannot ignore the problems it faces. The mere operation at the 'normal' level of the European institutions is insufficient to overcome the clear obstacles to the European project. However, the future of the EU cannot be reduced to the mere call for solidarity around an underdebated cause. The refugee issue is merely the final expression of deep problems of Long-ignored European societies: the proliferation of populist, xenophobic discourse has emerged within the Union in relation to poor workers who have chosen to seek work in richer countries. Discrimination has been raised by political forces to the rank of government objective, in contempt of existing European rules. The EU must act courageously: it must adopt a cutting foreign policy capable of meeting increasingly complex external challenges, and a social policy capable of generating real prosperity and respect for rights. The call for solidarity must remain a permanent landmark, not just an act of will.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Many important and wise words have been said today about Europe's unity, dignity and solidarity. Jean-Claude Juncker said that his Europe is a baker from the island of Kos who gives bread to refugees for free, that his Europe is students welcoming refugees. Yes, this is also my Europe. However, Europe is also a society for which this situation is new and which are full of concerns. But in these societies too, there are many who remember recent history, who know that we will only meet the challenges together, who want a bold, united, strong, firmly united Europe, who are proud to be Europeans. So do not tell colleagues, politicians from our part of Europe, that Europe is imposing something on us, because Europe is us! Let us focus on a good, common, solidarity-based, Christian response to the refugee challenge.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. – We have been lost in economics for a decade and a decade of social setbacks. We must make way for endowment commitments that allow a social triple A to be presented. It is time to prevent the exit from the crisis from being at the cost of social deterioration. It is time to put forward proposals to move towards a European minimum wage, a common European unemployment benefit, a recovery in labour rights and an fight against social dumping. In terms of humanitarian aid, more than 60 million people worldwide now live displaced or refugees. They're people who escape war but run away from hunger. Because even today there are more people who are starving than guns in the world. That is why the EU needs to have a strong voice at the next Humanitarian Aid Conference in Istanbul next spring. Before, we must act, because there we will be judged not by what we promise but by what we have been able to do in our own land: if we are not supportive and responsible here, we will not be able to demand it from the world.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. – Europe is missing and the Union is missing, and you can see in its tragic inability to offer asylum to those fleeing conflict, Juncker warned in his first State of the Union speech in the name of a rather hypocritical 'frankness'. The truth is that Europe is there. Only it has become a monster that no longer resembles the "European dream" of the founding fathers. Unfortunately, what Jucker could not say is that the Union has long since died. It has died in the dogma of budgetary balance and the euro, in austerity policies, in wild liberalisations, in culpable tolerance of the mercantilist policies and excessive surpluses of the countries of the North, in the relentlessness of deficit countries, in tax havens and in the circumvention of multinationals, in casino finance, in troika diktats, in the sale of public goods, in the explosion of unemployment and poverty. , in the growing inequalities, in the collapse of wages and mini-jobs, in technocracy and in the excessive power of financial lobbies, deafness towards the needs of its citizens. That is why we do not want any further strengthening of this anti-democratic Europe, which is totally enslaved to the markets, banks and multinationals. Europe must first be refounded, putting people, rights, public goods, social and economic progress and future generations at the centre of all policies.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – Europe is in the midst of the storm of the refugee crisis. President Juncker has understood this well and is showing real statesmanship by launching proposals that can make a real difference but which we know will not be welcomed by all Member States. I fully support Juncker in terms of the mandatory distribution plan of 160,000 refugees, but also in terms of amending the Dublin Convention and the need to draw up a list of safe countries. It is now up to the European Member States to get away from their rhetoric of each-for-all and to work out a European solution. The EC has put all the cards on the table for this, it is now up to the Member States to make it happen. However, in order for the EU to return its legitimacy to its citizens, it is also imperative that a European social agenda is implemented. Unfair competition, bogus self-seism, secondment fraud, post office bus companies and, above all, the lack of a strong European response to these problems, are also eroding confidence in the EU. Here too, I expect a strong policy from the EU. Continuing to delay the implementation of the social agenda is unacceptable and I look forward to the EC's concrete proposals on this.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – Let us talk about the recent news and the gigantic demonstration of farmers last Monday. As reality shows, the CAP and its market-oriented liberalising trend, with the progressive abandonment of all public regulatory instruments, with emphasis on the end of milk quotas, has benefited agriculture and farmers at all, leading only to the sinking of the prices paid to production and the bankruptcy of thousands of farms. It is therefore a matter of concern that european governments and, in particular, the Portuguese government, which approved the end of milk quotas a few months ago, are not able to assume the need for a thorough review of the CAP and merely adopt in haste and under pressure from the struggle of European farmers a €500 million aid package which falls far short of what is needed. It should be said that this sum of EUR 500 million in aid for the whole European Union is equivalent to the cut that Portugal suffered in the financial envelope of aid for its agriculture, negotiated in 2013 for the 2014-2010 horizon.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I fully agree with President Juncker's assertion that 'there is too little Europe in the EU and there is too little union in the EU'. That is why we need a new Europe where, when we invoke solidarity, we rely on previously shared solidarity. I believe that the solidarity required the Eastern European states to assume mandatory quotas for the resettlement of refugees evokes in Romania and Bulgaria precisely the lack of solidarity with which we were treated in the process of accession to the Schengen area for political reasons which did not relate to the fulfilment of the conditionalities of the agreement. I welcome the determination of President Juncker, who said that the Schengen system will not be abolished during the mandate of this Commission. I would have welcomed her even more if it had been followed by firm assurances given to Romania and Bulgaria. The message of the European electorates in 2014, as today, is that we need a new Europe. The image that the speech about the state of the Union today is that of a new Europe as citizens want it. It is important to act now, and the EP must be at the forefront of change and the engine of building the new Europe of solidarity.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Union faces enormous challenges. The challenge of global competitiveness, the challenge of sustainability and energy sovereignty, the challenge of leadership in combating climate change, the challenge of preserving its democratic, open and tolerant identity, the technological, economic and social challenge posed by the digital society, the challenge of poverty, asymmetries and inequalities. It faces all these challenges and now faces a challenge that is an absolute urgency. The political and humanitarian challenge posed by the flows of political and economic refugees. There is a risk that the substantive and media force of the refugee crisis will eventually focus on all other issues in the State of the Union debate. But there is also the opportunity to assess the state of the Union with reference to its capacities and its incapacities to respond to the crisis. The response to the refugee crisis is a clear mirror of the state of the Union and European weaknesses must be attacked in this case and also to strengthen the Union as a project of peace, solidarity and development.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – The President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, has once again ingested himself in the political situation of Greece in this speech, repeating the tone of blackmail towards the Greek people in an attempt to condition the choice of the path that falls to them in relation to the future of their country. It is unacceptable to consider that all political forces should accept what he calls "aid" but that in practice it only means pursuing the same policies that led Greece to social and economic catastrophe. It is unacceptable for you to express that what is needed is to continue the path of so-called fiscal consolidation when the Greek people expressed in the last elections and in the last referendum exactly a distinct will. These statements are obviously more serious when we find ourselves just days away from the next elections in Greece. It is further proof of what is clearer today than ever before - the EU does not mean respect for democracy and the will of the people, but rather the imposition of the policy that best serves the great financial and economic capital. It is, and has always been, the "state of the Union".

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on migration and refugees in Europe (2015/2833(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, we have just listened to President Juncker and we all know that the situation, which was already very difficult before the summer, has taken on dramatic proportions with record numbers of refugee inflows on the three main routes: central Mediterranean, eastern Mediterranean and western Balkans. The current situation is different from the previous ones in its magnitude, the very rapid sequence of developments on the ground and the confusion in which they occur. The pressures on our reception capacities, our linguistic and administrative capacities are considerable, but beyond the numbers and institutional considerations, it is elementary to remember, in this debate, that the situation is, above all, revealing human tragedies, all different, which affect people and affect families.  In the face of such a complex situation, there is no simple answer. The situation requires a firm and coherent response from Europe that combines responsibility on the one hand and solidarity on the other. In addition, we must implement a sustainable common migration policy.  We must be prepared in the most hurry, while preserving the future and preparing global and sustainable solutions. Given the external dimension of the problem we are facing and given its impact on Europe, the Member States and the relations between them, it is essential that we realize that we will not be able to manage the situation by moving in scattered order. I can only repeat what I have already said in the previous debate. Our first concern will be people and their safety. It's a moral obligation. This obligation also falls to us under international law as well as to all other state actors present in the conflict zones from which migration movements originate or through which they transit. Second, we will need to ensure a dignified welcome for all those who could benefit from the international protection regime. I would just like to briefly recall what the President of the Commission has said about the thousands, the tens of thousands of Europeans, the European citizens who have shown a tremendous outpouring of solidarity. I believe that this illustrates Europe's capacity for solidarity and it also shows, in my opinion, a fine formula of the German President of this Europe of Enlightenment, ein helles Europa, as ein helles Deutschland. I believe that this is the Europe that we support, that we love and that we must move forward.  It will also be necessary, of course, to put in place reception capacities that are up to the challenge, both within the territory of the Union and in third countries. It will take a common effort to do this, which will not be without budgetary implications and this concerns you, of course, first and foremost. It should be remembered that on the Balkan route, the vast majority of people are eligible for international protection. On two occasions in recent months, heads of state or government have addressed the complex challenges of migration and refugees. They rightly called for the development of a comprehensive approach, focusing on three key dimensions that must move forward in parallel: relocation and resettlement, return, readmission and reintegration, cooperation with countries of origin and transit. During the month of July, the Council made progress on relocation and resettlement, and since we are already talking about emergency tools, I would like to take this opportunity to thank your Parliament for adopting the Keller report today. This adoption allows the Council to adopt next Monday the decision to relocate and, above all, and most importantly, to start relocating people who have arrived since 15 August.  But let's be clear, this is insufficient in the face of the scale of the crisis and the human tragedies we are experiencing. And that is why I welcome the Commission's presentation of these new proposals which take into account these developments and the scale of the phenomenon. I can assure you that, in the weeks and months ahead, the Presidency will do all it can to move forward on all the proposals. That is why the Presidency has convened an extraordinary Justice and Home Affairs Council next Monday, 14 September, which will review all the measures to be taken. I will not go into detail here, but there are immediate priorities: the implementation of access points (hotspots), the strengthening of the effectiveness of our return policy and our readmission instruments and above all the fight against against the smuggling of migrants by smugglers.  At the international level, we must work to strengthen cooperation with our partners in managing migration flows, particularly with Africa, the Western Balkans and Turkey. In this effort, each Member State and the Union must make their contribution in a spirit of responsibility and sharing because Europe must find a solution that touches on all issues and problems, one that truly addresses the challenges we face.  I don't hide the differences. We have stories, we have situations, we have different traditions between the Member States, but we now have a duty to overcome obstacles and focus on what we have in common. What we have in common is stronger than the differences that separate us.  (Applause) In this context, we are also counting on the active contribution of the European Parliament and I am pleased to be able to listen to your debate which will be reflected in the discussions in the Council.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I do not have to speak for a long time, because President Juncker has given you the full explanation of the plans of proposal of the Commission. I just want to use this opportunity, when three institutions are coming together to talk about this issue, to call upon the European Parliament to strongly support the Commission’s proposals today. That would be a clear signal in the preparation for the Council on Monday, where we know that some Member States still have a number of steps to take before they can agree with the Commission’s proposal. The stronger Parliament can be today in coming out with its position, the better we are prepared for the Council on Monday. There are those who sell the illusion that simply by closing all the borders and sending everybody back we could solve this problem. There are also those who maintain that by simply opening all the borders and letting everybody in we could solve the problem. These are illusions. They have the advantage of being clear in terms of proposals, but the disadvantage of being completely impossible in terms of practicality. Closing the borders and sending everyone back would mean that we take leave of our most fundamental values as Europeans. It would also mean acting in clear violation of our legal obligations. Opening the borders and letting everyone in would mean that we would put an end to the European social model as we know it, because it could not support people coming from all over the world in great, endless numbers.  For that reason, we need to make a clear distinction between those who deserve our solidarity because they flee from war and persecution, and those who might have genuine feelings about seeking a better future but should not abuse the asylum system to attain that goal. To do that, we need a combination of solidarity and responsibility: solidarity with those who need refuge, solidarity with the States who are now burdened to excess because they are the States of first arrival, notably Greece, Italy and Hungary. There needs to be European solidarity with these States – solidarity with the refugees and solidarity with the States in Europe who need it today.  That is the basis of our proposals, but also a call on responsibility: the responsibility to better guard our borders; the responsibility to make a swift registration of those who arrive at the borders so we can distinguish between those who have the right to asylum and those who do not; responsibility to create a list of safe third countries so that we can be swifter in returning people who have no right to stay; responsibility to organise the reception of refugees in a way that respects their human dignity. The combination of all these things is what the Commission proposes.  Let me end on this, before handing the floor to Federica: what we do today, and what we will be doing next Monday, is closely linked to the destiny of Europe – not just of the European Union – but to the destiny of Europe as a community of values, where we need to respect what we see is being done by countless European citizens today. We need to respect the basic humanity that makes me so proud of being European. (Applause)

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, Frans Timmermans said quite rightly that this is a defining moment for our Union. Words are important, I believe, and the refugee crisis we are facing – not only us, but the region and the world – puts our deepest values, and indeed our identity, to the test. It is a moment of truth, to see if we are really Europeans and if we are really a Union. That is what it is about: our responsibility to protect the lives of human beings, and human rights and solidarity among Member States and towards those in need. But this is also a test for our international credibility. Do not think that we can go around the word promoting human rights if we do not guarantee the highest asylum standards inside the Union. Do not even imagine that we can promote peace and cooperation among parties currently at war if we do not accept the others inside our own communities, and if we do not manage to find unity among ourselves. Our external credibility depends largely on our internal coherence and consistency. We have to be aware of that. Do not imagine that there is only an external response to the crisis, just as there cannot be only an internal response to the crisis. The two dimensions of our action – and of our identity and our response – reinforce one another or weaken one another. This is the truth, like it or not, and we have to face it. To be credible, preaching well is not enough. We must act well, we must act fast, and we must act unitedly. Today, we are presenting a communication setting out the way forward for all the external action needed to address this crisis. We all know there is no magic fix to the crisis around us, and most of the external action we can take – and we are taking – will give results in the medium and long term. Still, it is important that we do act now. I know it is difficult for politicians to explain the reason for taking actions that will pay back, in some cases, in years, but if we do not do that responsibly, generations coming after ours will face the same problem again and again. Let me say that our external action finds us united for once. While this is not enough, because we also have to find internal unity on domestic policies, it is crucial for our action. The first priority is saving lives. Commission President Juncker outlined how much we have stepped up our work in this respect, noting the many lives that it has thus been possible to save. The second task is addressing the root causes, and I will come back to that. The third, and it is just as important, is to fight smugglers and traffickers of human beings, not only at sea but all along the routes, because this is a security issue too. The financial flow around the criminal organisations and networks can finance all kinds of activities potentially relevant in terms of European and international security. Our strategy has been clear and consistent since the beginning of our mandate. We cannot focus only on the last mile of the tragedy: we must also consider all the steps of the refugees’ odyssey. Most of the people we see today coming to Europe are fleeing from conflict and persecution. This is the first issue we need to address. Four million have fled Syria. Between Syria and Iraq, more than 10 million have left their homes and are internally displaced. Let me say one thing: we have rightly focused in recent months on minorities in need of protection in the Middle East – Christians, Kurds or Yazidis – supporting their right to stay on the land, and go back to the communities, where they have been living for centuries. But let me also say clearly that it is not sufficient to protect them only when they are far away from us. We also have a duty to protect them – and all their fellow countrymen – when they become close to us. The long-term answer obviously is putting an end to the conflicts and the wars, facing the threat of Daesh, starting processes of national reconciliation. The deal we reached with Iran, although primarily a non-proliferation deal, can open the way to new possibilities, and the work in this direction, with all our international and regional partners and all the international and regional powers, has already started. Secondly, we are working with the international community – mainly with the UN agencies, with the countries of origin and transit and those who host an impressive number of refugees. We have mobilised almost EUR 4 million in humanitarian and development aid to assist displaced Syrians within Syria itself and in Jordan, Lebanon, Turkey and Iraq. There is a very specific case, which is Libya: not a country of origin, but a country of transit, and, more than that, an open corridor. That is why, as you know very well because we have debated it several times in this Chamber, so much daily and nightly effort is being invested, with the UN and Special Representative Bernardino León Gross, in trying to achieve a national unity government in Libya that could allow us to partner the Libyan authorities in the management of this corridor. Let me say too that it is going to be very important – and we are looking very much in this direction – to work to the south of Libya. If we focus only on the Libyan sea border, forgetting about the Libyan land border, we will never manage to solve the issue of the corridor. That is why I have started an unprecedented dialogue with the countries of the Sahel, and in particular – although not exclusively – with Niger. Today, as you know, we are putting forward a proposal for a trust fund for Africa to promote economic opportunities, development, security and better management of migration in a context of equal partnership with the African countries and our partners. The institutions will provide EUR 1.8 million to this fund and I expect the Member States – all of them – to do their fair share. You cannot ask for international cooperation at European level and then not put up the money for it. Remember this when we come to discuss the budget. (Applause)  We have to show coherence in our decisions. A regional trust fund for Syria has already started in recent months, and the first contract opened through the fund deals with schools and education. Let me stress this, because I believe that – as we see Syria losing an entire generation to war and exile – we have to invest in Syrian children. That is an investment not only for the future of the country and the region but also for our security, because it is the best investment we can make against terrorism and radicalisation. Thirdly – and I shall finish – we are fighting those who trade in human life: the smugglers’ and traffickers’ networks. We are doing this in partnership with countries of transit and we are doing this in the Mediterranean. Our naval operation in the Mediterranean Sea has now fulfilled the objectives of the first phase. We gathered intelligence and information on the smugglers’ routes, assets and strategies. In this first phase alone, and in the space of just five weeks, we identified 16 cases in which we would have been able to go after the smugglers, bring them to justice and capture the vessels. That is why I proposed last weekend in Luxembourg, where the Defence and Foreign Ministers were meeting, that we move to Phase 2 on the high seas, in full observance of international law, and I asked Member States to contribute to the mission, because this is also an opportunity for us to show that, when we have political will and a sense of urgency and unity, we can use the military and security tools that we already have to hand. But there is something else of which I am proud: that in these very first weeks of common action in the Mediterranean we have saved the lives of 1 500 men and women at sea through our operation. This is not the main purpose of the operation but it is an important component of it. With regard to the way forward, we will have the Valletta Summit on migration in November, bringing together leaders of the European and key African countries – those that are part of the Khartoum and Rabat processes as well as the African Union Commission and the Economic Community of West African States Commission. We will also have the high-level conference on the Western Balkan route, bringing together EU Member States, Western Balkan countries and Turkey. Both have to be addressed with the same degree of attention and urgency. To conclude, we need to realise as Europeans that this is not just a time for emotion: that is the easy part. Let me be cynical: as politicians we are not asked to express our emotions; we are asked to take decisions that are consistent and coherent with our emotions, and to be strong in so doing. Emotions are not enough. We need to act and this is the time. I hope that all the EU institutions, the Member States, citizens and public opinion – because this wave of emotion in public opinion can change, and we have to be aware of that – will finally take responsibility for, and live up to, our values, the values of our history, the challenges of the most difficult times our history has recently faced, and the potential of our regional and global role. What is at stake, as Frans Timmermans said very well, is not only the lives of human beings – though a single life is enough – but also the state of our Union. (Applause)

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as you noticed, the State of the Union speech was mostly on migration and shows what our priorities are. The President of the Commission was clear, and I want to be clear, too. The management of migration is a crash test for Europe and for the Union’s credibility. I want to express my thanks to both First Vice-President Frans Timmermans and Federica Mogherini for their opening remarks and for the excellent cooperation we had throughout the last month in putting together this ambitious and much-needed package. Today’s package is our response to an unprecedented refugee crisis happening right in front of our eyes. As the refugee crisis around Europe becomes bigger, our answers need to become bolder, more comprehensive and more ambitious.  This is the Europe we want. This is the Europe we must have. So today we are putting forward four very concrete measures that in the short- and medium-term can help tackle all the major challenges we are confronted with. The significant increase in arrivals over the summer cannot be managed by the Member States of entry alone. To address this migration we need a coordinated European approach. That is why we are now proposing to relocate 120 000 people fleeing war, persecution, oppression and chaos from Italy, Greece and Hungary according to a distribution scheme. This new proposal comes in addition to the measures tabled before the summer to relocate 40 000 persons from Italy and Greece. I expect that a vast majority of the Members of this House will vote in favour of this proposal later today and will also support in the future the new temporary relocation scheme. At the same time we have to learn the lesson that the current crisis is teaching us. Europe is not well-equipped to manage sudden and extraordinary surges of refugee inflows. We need structural solutions to face such events in the future so that we can systematically support Member States and guarantee protection for those who are really in need. That is why we propose establishing a permanent crisis relocation mechanism by amending the Dublin Regulation. In parallel with increasing our support to guarantee shelter for those in need of protection, we have to make sure that those who do not have the right to stay in the European Union are promptly returned.  As a first step, Member States shall be in a position to steadily process unfounded or unlawful requests so they can devote their human and financial resources to legitimate requests, filed by those who urgently require international protection. That is why we are putting forward today the introduction of an EU list of safe countries, including the Balkan countries and Turkey. In 2014, nationals from these countries submitted over 17% of the total of 562 000 applications filed in the European Union. These requests put a heavy burden on the European Union’s national asylum systems, while the vast majority of them were clearly unfounded. By including these countries in the list of safe countries of origin, the examination of the applications for international protection will be fast-tracked. This will increase the efficiency of asylum systems, and will allow Member States to devote greater resources to protect those in need and to return the applicants of unfounded requests faster. Currently Europe has a very low rate of return: around 40% of third-country nationals. This undermines the credibility of our migration policy. We therefore also present here today a European return programme aiming at fostering a clean-cut return policy. This communication is the occasion for the Commission to set out a list of actions to support greater operational cooperation among Member States and to stress the need to find leverage in our relations with third countries so that they readmit their nationals. I really count a lot on your support to implement this package as you have done, and I have to commend once again this House for being very supportive from the very beginning of our efforts to adopt a common European migration policy. I count on you and I thank you very much for the support you have provided thus far.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, if they do, they flee to save their lives from Daesh attacks and institutional violence. In purity they are nothing but refugees, which is why we support the Commission's proposal. It is a solidarity and determined proposal, and also urgent, since the phenomenon is urgent and has an unlimited permanence in time. He's here to stay. That is why we support the creation of a permanent, binding and Community mechanism, under Article 78(2) of the Treaty, so that we can welcome them with dignity. Solidarity of all States is necessary. We need to help those who need to be helped, to ensure respect for human rights, especially the most vulnerable, and, at the same time, we must identify the phenomenon well, to combat Daesh terrorism and institutional terrorism. We are committed to cooperation at source and to carry out the Addis Ababa agreements of July 2015. Europe provides answers and we call for a viable channel for legal emigration.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Schmit, Vice-Presidents Timmermans and Mogherini, Mr Avramopoulos, thank you very much for your work. I note full convergence between the positions that the parliamentary group that I chair has expressed and the proposals that Commissioner Avramopoulos mentioned just now: the four points of the package. I have to say, sometimes I think that the immigration dispute is a little surreal: let us put in place, let us build walls on the sea; we do, we put barbed wire and we stop thousands of men, women, fleeing war, but what are we talking about? These things are only for propaganda, does anyone really think that this will solve the issue of refugees or immigration? But let's not kid ourselves, this is just a tactic, propaganda to take votes. If we're serious, we have to get serious. The proposal presented by the European Commission is a serious proposal, which addresses the issue of the emergency, which establishes a permanent system, which is therefore ready to take action when there are other crises. Unfortunately, there will be other crises.  Then there is also the issue of economic migrants, which we must address seriously and rigorously, understanding the needs of society and the labour market in the various European countries. There is the problem of controls, which must be done in a serious way, with common rules, with common times – not that one country takes 90 days another country takes 3-6 months to ascertain the appropriateness of the asylum application. And then there is all the talk to be made, about the initiatives to be taken on Africa, which I mentioned earlier, to which Vice-President Mogherini and Vice-President Timmermans returned.  And foreign policy: the stabilisation of North Africa, the action that is being taken in Libya is fundamental, all the talk about Syria. They are non-nations, they are non-states, from where we necessarily flee, any of us would flee if we were in those conditions. We have a duty to have an all-out strategy, without demagoguery, with great realism, but with great seriousness. Now it is only a question of approving it. And here I am still addressing the European Council, I am well aware of the commitment of the Luxembourg Minister, but I would like this commitment, this sensitivity, to be the responsibility of the entire European Council.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Refugees wishing to enter the EU via Greece from Turkey via Greece must be pushed back to Turkey at sea. This does not prejudice international maritime law and the principle of non-refoulement, which prohibits the return of anyone to an unsafe port.  After all, the N-VA delegation considers Turkey a safe country. If the opposite is claimed, the European Court of Human Rights must rule on the matter. There are currently no judgments on this matter in principle. Only the push back by Italy to Libya has already been scrutinised by the Court, which is a completely different situation. Moreover, President Juncker has just said that Turkey is a candidate EU member state and is therefore a safe country. Had it not been, Turkey would not have been a candidate country.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, during the last week the refugee finally got a name, an identity and a story. Through a picture we have realised that behind each and every one of the dead refugees and migrants there are dreams and aspirations and loved ones left behind. It is our European decency that lies lifeless on the Turkish beach together with Aylan Kurdi, the three-year old toddler in his red T-shirt and small sneakers. He lost his life but he brought passion – and compassion – back to the European debate on migration and therefore we will remember him for a very long time.  After the recent tragedies, my heart fills with pride when I see citizens all across Europe taking to the streets to welcome refugees into their communities. They have shown much more backbone and humanity during the past week than most of our politicians have done over the past decade. Citizens show us what Europe and European values really are all about and what Europe can be at its best. Yet still we hear some voices among the leaders of the Member States complaining about illegal migrants.  I must admit that I am quite fed up with that rhetoric by now because how is anyone fleeing war or persecution supposed to get to Europe to seek asylum since it is us, the EU, that do not allow people to apply for asylum in our embassies or consulates? It is us, the EU, which introduced a directive on carrier liability that makes it completely illegal for any airline or shipping company to take on board anybody that does not have a visa. This is a vicious circle, a Catch-22 situation, and we are responsible for changing it.  We must review the existing asylum legislation in Europe and adapt it to this century to provide for legal and safe routes to get here. We must agree to a system of binding quotas of refugees to be accepted by every Member State, and my Group is, of course, all in favour of the proposals by the Commission. This is a defining moment for Europe and our best days are yet to come.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, four million refugees from Syria, four million Iraqis, three and a half million from Afghanistan and two million From Libya are the result of their wars, it is the result of the Iraq and Afghanistan war, of bombing Libya and of having collaborated with financing and weaponry to the war in Syria.  And when refugees are on Europe's doorstep, what do they do? Do they enable legal and secure entry routes? Do you open a humanitarian corridor? Do you give humanitarian visas? Do you activate the Temporary Protection Directive? No.  What they do is this (she exhibited reproductions of newspaper covers): "Hollande is studying beating the Islamic State in Syria"; "Cameron approves extrajudicial executions in Syria"; "Margallo calls for military intervention in Syria."  Ladies and gentlemen, when the cause is war, the solution cannot be bombs.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: , on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – President Juncker said this morning in his State of the Union work is dignity. We should give refugees, asylum seekers the right to work from the moment they apply. Because work is dignity. He also said that we must allow legal migration and he was referring to labour migration, economic migration, because - he said - we cannot fight illegal migration if there are no other forms of migration. My question to Mr Avramopoulos and Mr Timmermans is: the proposals you are now making are good and firm, and I commend you for that. But the next step, as Mr Juncker announced, to look at labour migration, cannot be taken too long. Because indeed, work is dignity. That is what I hope you will now put on the table very, very quickly.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we continue to call it an emergency, but it is clear that an emergency is no longer a question of whether it is something that has been going on for years and with which we will continue to live for the next. I believe that we are facing an epochal exodus which is caused by unholy policies on the part of western states, aimed precisely at exploitation, which is the cause of wars in these countries, from which people are fleeing with their feet raised.  We have taken a stand, we have uttered slogans, we are continuing to do so today, and I think it is clear to all of us that we have no influence, either as the European Parliament, but also as a Commission, because unfortunately everything is in the hands of the Member States. Member States which, unfortunately, are the image of the hypocrisy of the European Union, because they are warmongering states, are states that, in the name of their economic interests, in the name of neoliberalism, do not look anyone in the face. It is really sad to see prime ministers, like the Italian one, asking for humanity in front of the photo of the little Syrian boy lying on the beach, when the day before he rejoiced with the Italian war industry that supplied weapons to Syria until 2011.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, what you must call out of the question at first is that all people who need protection and help must also receive this protection and this help! There is no question about that. In the end, we are only debating how and where we help these people, and there are two concepts.  There is the concept of the united left, which includes the Social Democrats, the Greens, the Conservatives and even the Communists. And there is a different concept. And their concept is to bring everyone in. They do not ask whether they are refugees under Geneva Convention status, whether they are illegal migrants, whether they are economic fortune knights or even fighters for the Islamic State. They say bring everyone in.  We, patriotic freedom parties, say that we must shape this protection and this aid in the Arabian Peninsula itself. We need to create first reception centres there according to UNHCR standards. The European Union has already thought about this. We need to create safe zones. We must involve the Gulf states in the whole thing in order to help their Islamic brothers. And also the United States of America, which has a great responsibility for what has happened there. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, I had to hear from Mr Juncker this morning that I am not a European! Because I am not standing at a train station, and I am not calling for welcome! Why don't I call? Because I think that all of us, including the High Commissioners, have a mandate from the European electorate, from the voters of our people, to preserve and preserve the right to our homeland, the right and the identity of our peoples. And I also use the same right for the refugees.  Because the people who come here, they also have a homeland, they also have the right to their homeland and to preserve their own identity. And you can't solve the problems by integrating these people, because they don't go back. No, they have a home, they should return there one day. Therefore, they should invest in their homeland, that they have a future there and not with us.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, 260,000 migrants have crossed into Greece this year off the coast of Turkey, while 77,100 have crossed in 2014 and 43,000 have crossed in 2013. The problem is acute and requires a coherent European immigration policy. As the European Parliament co-legislates with the Council for the first time, there must be an immediate decision on a permanent binding mechanism for the fair distribution of refugees in the Member States, as proposed by the Commission. At the same time, Turkey must comply with the readmission agreements it signed with the European Union in 2011 and with Greece in October 2014. Finally, Mr President, we are honoured that the Europe of values always shows its human face to the migration problem.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Fears are constantly being stoked that too many migrants may come to Europe. Too many, Mr Juncker gave a figure this morning: 0.11% – zero comma eleven. And most refugees still come from countries like Syria and Eritrea. They are fleeing war and persecution. Against this background, the often emotional debate about so-called poverty migration has only one goal: to create a mood against all refugees. It is shameful that a large part of the Council seems to shy away from such slogans, rather than taking on the shared responsibility to show solidarity, both internally and externally. That must change now. Next week, the Council must act. Follow the Commission's current proposals!

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The great conflicts at the borders of the European Union in each case have their own security and humanitarian component, including migration. Putin's neo-imperial policies have for many years already resulted in economic migration and political exile, which have largely absorbed Poland and other countries in my region. We have shown solidarity and we will continue to do so. As regards security at our southern borders, I am pleased with the High Representative's statement on the second phase of the naval operation and diplomatic offensive. However, the forced relocation mechanism envisaged in the Communication is a non-treaty, unacceptable and counter-effective solution. It seems to me that the European Union should make great use of internal opportunities, opportunities for solidarity within the Union.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, almost 60 million refugees and displaced people worldwide, only 13% in developed countries. They represent only 0.11% of the European population. So we're going to sort the real refugees, by nationality, or worse. The improvement of the lot of some must not be at the expense of that of others. The negotiation of the list of safe countries is worrying in view of the practices of the Member States. What will become of the asylum seekers? Will they be sent back firmly with other so-called economic migrants to their country of origin, whatever they may be? What do we hope to negotiate with the dictatorships of the Horn of Africa as part of the Khartoum process? The growing opposition between real refugees and economic migrants will lead us straight into the wall. Legal channels for migrants must be opened, this is the best way to prevent the dead and smugglers. These men, women and children all have rights and these must be respected in the European Union and elsewhere.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, the State of the Union needs to be measured according to how we treat those people in Europe who are most in need and there the picture is rather mixed. On the one hand we have all those citizens who help refugees, who donate, and not just this past weekend but over the years and months in different groups. On the other hand though, we have Member States which just blame each other, which are not doing what they are supposed to do.  I think we need to decide which side we want to support, which of those two Europes we want to bring forward and promote. There I think the people of Europe have shown us the way; they are the ones who deserved the Nobel Peace Prize the European Union has won. The Member States, the governments of the Member States and the European Union should follow the way that our citizens have shown. Our citizens are much further ahead than we think they are. Let us promote their solidarity, their initiative; let us follow their lead.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Mr President, firstly I believe that the European Union’s response to the migrant crisis is completely wrong-headed. I also believe that Germany and Sweden’s position is particularly irresponsible. What do you think will happen if you say that everyone can claim asylum? It is simple: more people will come. That means more people will risk their lives crossing the Mediterranean, crossing the Aegean Sea. That means more boats, more drownings and more deaths.  Having said that, although I disagree with Europe’s response to the migrant crisis, at least we are doing something. The real scandal here is the countries that are doing absolutely nothing, and by that I mean the oil-rich Gulf states of Qatar, Bahrain, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, and in particular Saudi Arabia – the sponsor of the evil Wahhabism which is Islamic State. The fact is, they are taking no refugees whatsoever, and they are pushing their co-religionists towards Europe. If we want to stop the deaths, as Tony Abbott, the Prime Minister of Australia, has said, you must stop the boats.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have heard hypocritical and dangerous speeches. Europe seems to me to be ruled by dangerous hypocrites: first they go to war and then they are surprised that children are fleeing wars. Lift the sanctions against Syria, stop playing the war against Russia. We are talking about a business, 150 000 immigrants, a turnover of EUR 5 million per day, some cooperatives, some associations, some fake vouchers, are already rubbing their hands!  I would not like there to be minutes of silence in this Chamber in the months to come because, among so many refugees and decent people, so many criminals are landing and according to the secret services in half of Europe many potential terrorists. If we do a minute's silence, your consciences will drip blood. I would also like to read the last of the delirious demands: we need millions and millions of refugees to maintain the pensions of Europeans, you are paid to think of the 25 million Europeans who are unemployed before importing new slaves.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, what are we witnessing? To the exceptional reception of people persecuted because of their political or religious opinions, originating from countries to which we have largely participated? Or at the forefront of mass migration essentially economic, promoted methodically under humanitarian pretexts? This is of course the second version that predominates. I listened to Mrs Wikstrom talking about the heartbreaking case of little Aylan, but I ask my colleague. How are Europeans responsible for the death of this poor child whose family was safe in Turkey? The leaders are first and foremost the Americans and those of the Europeans who have contributed to the destabilization of Iraq and Syria; it is the Gulf countries that do not move a finger, as has been said, in favour of refugees; it is the Arab League that is careful not to intervene against the "Islamic State" group; it is the criminal smugglers who sell dodges by taking advantage of their trafficking; it is you who make it seem that Europe can welcome all those who want to come; it is the father of this unfortunate child who was wrong to believe your promises.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, when I first entered politics one piece of advice was given to me: never speak when you are angry. I will ignore that today.  Member States seem to agree easily on how many fish we can pick from our seas. They agree on how many plastic bags we can throw away, but when bodies of children are washing up on our shores and we still cannot agree how to deal with refugees humanely, then everything else we do seems to me to be of little use. Nothing is more urgent or more important. We like to say that we are a Union of shared values, but we are not yet a Union of shared responsibility and that is our collective failure.  Refugees are people running away from war, from death. Prime Ministers simply cannot afford to look away. Every single state must fulfil its moral and legal obligation to address the situation. Walls and fences do not work and neither does simply throwing money at the issue. We need more than band-aid solutions that serve to make us feel better before the next emergency exposes its inadequacy, and yes, we need a binding permanent distribution mechanism for people in need of protection and we needed this yesterday.  So my call to Prime Ministers is this: face down the populists, have the courage to give people fleeing the unimaginable horror the chance of a future without fear. Send an unequivocal message that Europe also stands with the voiceless. Let us be an example for the world. This is the challenge of our generation and we cannot be remembered as the ones who dithered while thousands suffered on our doorstep, or we will be the generation who failed.

name: István UJHELYI
text: – As a Hungarian, I asked for the floor to speak as a European in this historical debate. As a European, of the 500 million citizens who are concerned about the future of their children and of Europe, but more afraid for the safety of my children from the politicians who came to us before the world war than from the syrian child who came to us with his parents from the war. That is why the European Commission, which has finally acted, has given back my faith today, and I expect prime ministers to get in line and support a common solution. Juncker, Timmermans and the debates in S&D have all shown me that we need a more capable Europe. Terrible images have come from Hungary, government inertia, incitement, inhumanity, but you need to know Hungary is not equal to Viktor Orban. In Hungary, thousands of people have worked, tens of thousands of civilian volunteers, to take out refugees. Our friends are there right now, working for the government. I thank them from here, and I would like to indicate that Viktor Orban and his policies are not the solution, but the problem itself.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, we face an unprecedented situation and we must prioritise helping refugees fleeing horrific wars, both with their immediate needs and to give them hope and support for the longer term. But different countries can help in different ways and we should stop the finger-pointing. In the UK, for example, we are already providing more aid in Syrian camps than the rest of Europe put together, and offering to resettle the most vulnerable refugees directly from the camps in order not to encourage further people trafficking. Individual countries, however, should consider the impact on their neighbours when they are granting asylum. Granting refugee status does not give that person automatic rights to move across Europe, and I think this needs to be very clear because otherwise we risk jeopardising public confidence in free movement in Europe. So let us be very clear to people about their rights, and even at this difficult time we must not postpone other reforms to build our economies. Unless our countries have long-term economic plans and strength, they will not be able to support people in our own countries or those who need our help in other parts of the world.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, migration takes place because there are reasons for it and as long as it exists. No one can determine who has to migrate and who doesn't. Nor are there the good and the bad refugees, as the EU is trying to classify today. No wall, no high fence, no trench, no tear gas, no police truncheon can stop people from fleeing. And instead of repression, which is recurring time and again in the EU and in the Member States, we need a clear 'yes' to the reception and integration of refugees. Refugees must also be welcome in Hungary, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and please also in Poland, regardless of ethnicity and religion. And one more thing: we are opposed to the extension of the so-called safe countries of origin, because many people in these countries are not at all safe, like Roma in the Western Balkans, like dissidents in Turkey. This undermines the right to asylum – which we consider unacceptable – and war is not the only reason for fleeing. You have to look at that. We already believe that this litter is, to a certain extent, too short, which the EU and the Member States have thrown here.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – I would like to quote Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott, who, when asked if his country was going to accept migrants illegally from Myanmar and Bangladesh, replied: "We are not going to do something that would encourage people to get on boats. This would only complicate the problem of illegal migration." I believe that none of us believe that Prime Minister Abbott is not in compliance with common human values. We opened pandora's box and condemned Europe. In this way, we have made a policy of nullity quotas for immigrants, sending them a signal that you are welcome here, you will be taken care of. Over the years, the influx of migrants into Europe has increased by 11 times and, if we act as it is now, the European Parliament will do nothing else during the rest of the term, only to increase quotas for illegal immigrants.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! I salute the Presidency of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which First of all, I would like to warmly congratulate Commissioner Avramopoulos on the whole package that ultimately comes to him and thank him for the fact that, at such a consistent time, we are now being presented with clear proposals from the Commission. Secondly, I would like to say that it is essential that asylum standards, at least the minimum standards, are respected in all our Member States, so that refugees, wherever they arrive, also in the area of redistribution – if we decide on joint redistribution – at least come up with proper treatment and are properly accommodated. Secondly, we urgently need this crisis mechanism, because without a crisis mechanism, the European Union cannot deal with it sensibly when crises occur and when there are refugee flows that come to us because of war and hardship.  However, I disagree with you, Mrs Ernst, there is a clear definition of refugee and the right of asylum, and this cannot simply be wildly confused with labour migration, with economic migration. We must separate things properly and also work properly and give the Member States the opportunity to react accordingly according to their labour markets and not simply declare every border open. This is, after all, a state of unrest within a European Union that you would produce with it.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I do not want to repeat everything that has already been said. But I want us to send a signal from here to the local authorities working on the refugee problem, in very, very difficult circumstances – whether on Kos or on Lesbos. This is particularly true of those who are not in the EU.  The Serbian Government and the Serbian local authorities are currently doing more for our refugees than some European governments within the EU. And I think that is worth a thank you, also from this House. And the same applies, of course, to the International Red Cross, Samaritan International, as always is called the organisations that actively work there. We should also invite them here one day to say a real thank you to them, because we can be more proud of them than we are on some of the prime ministers in our own Union.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur When we use beautiful words with great intensity about humanist values, solidarity, it is often a sign of institutional weakness and embarrassment, which this time can lead to the weakening of Europe. When we chaotically admit illegal immigrants, the absolute highest proportion of which is men, will it stifle the drowning of children in boats punctured when they see border guard boats? With regard to the distribution of refugees at Budapest station, someone imagines the forced allocation of quotas, these refugees will go to Munich to Germany and these refugees will take the bus to Latvia? And there is also a threat of the removal of the Schengen area if there are no forced quotas. And what will the refugees who have obtained the status of Latvian refugee who want to go to Germany or Sweden? We will introduce border controls again so that they cannot do so? Forced distribution does not, in fact, create satisfaction for those who are refugees or those who receive these refugees, but it creates sceptics about the European project as such in society. So let us do what is essential and forget what is popular, even though we are politicians. Thank you!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Colleagues! The people have shown what Europe they want to live in: an open, solidarity-based society that helps people on the run. The Europe they want to see has nothing to do with the extreme right and the stale societies of nationalists. It is therefore time to stop adapting to their policies and their worldview. Now we must be out of fortress Europe. Repressive policies legitimise their worldview and their policies. Europe must choose. You cannot choose both barbed wire and solidarity refugee policy. That is why we support the proposals on resettlement, increased quota refugees, for finding alternatives to the Dublin system, but we cannot support the repressive measures, the return, the list of safe countries and increased military action in the Mediterranean. We stand up for a Europe that opts for the policy of solidarity and not the Europe of barbed wires.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, Commissioners, your proposals reflect the extraordinary complexity of finding the right balance between, on the one hand, the necessary solidarity with refugees and between European countries and, on the other hand, the sense of responsibility which obliges us to admit that we cannot accommodate everyone. I regret, moreover, that we are far too often witnessing a cartoonish debate between, on the one hand, proposals to give themselves an easy good conscience and then, on the other, unrealistic proposals maintaining the myth of zero immigration. The urgency is to organize migration policy because what worries our citizens is not only the magnitude of the flows, but also the fact that these flows arrive in a totally anarchic, chaotic and disorganized way, which undermines the spontaneous generosity that we can have in our societies.  It is therefore, of course, necessary to establish a common list of safe countries; so, of course, you have to have a much more aggressive return policy; we must also have controls of our external borders that are much better organised, in a solidarity way, between all countries. Then, diplomatically, we must also remind a number of countries that, while they have shown great generosity in welcoming refugees - I am thinking, in particular, of Turkey, which has a huge burden with hundreds of thousands or even millions of refugees - but that the strategic options that these countries have taken, particularly in the Syrian conflict. , are not the right ones and will increase the chaos of which we are the custodian today.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, between Greece, Italy and Hungary, in recent months, the number of refugees has risen to 700 000. If there really is a European Union worthy of such a name, perhaps we should resolve this crisis in a coordinated and supportive manner. Do you know, dear colleagues, that life jacket salespeoes have done a great deal, they are doing a big deal across the Mediterranean? Isn't that terrible? But, as Mrs Mogherini said, let us move from feelings to action, which is what we are asked to do. Let us support the European Commission's proposal and stop tearing our garments with the terrible images we are seeing all summer. We need European efficiency and, of course, peace and stability in Syria, Yemen, Afghanistan, Iraq. Efficiency and peace, that alone will resolve the issue. And, by the way, it condemns the national governments that are looking the other way when their peoples were refugees many times. And it condemns and sanctions those who fail to comply with the principles of the European Union.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Colleagues, I would like to thank you for your support. Wanting to help all of us is within us. Compassion, too. This is human, but in order to help those who are truly in need, we must first be in control of the situation at the Union's external borders. Our priority is to protect Europe's external borders. I miss answering basic questions responsibly and consistently here today, because if we do not do these things, our entire Schengen system will collapse. Is the Schengen rules on the protection of the external borders, the conditions for entering the Schengen area today, the movement within the Schengen area, the return to the Member State of entry valid today? Because if they are valid, it cannot be held to account, say, for the pressure of the media, hungary to try to comply with the valid EU rules that we have adopted here and to protect the UNION's external borders so that asylum seekers can pass through the places of entry. Most of those who want to be within the borders of the Union today... (the President withdraws the floor)

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, we heard Commission President Juncker this morning mentioning the kind people at Munich station and the kind people on the Greek islands. Commissioner Avramopoulos, you are Greek, and you really did your job this morning: we heard all about the plans. And we will see kind people, as Ska Keller said, all over Europe – in my Member State and elsewhere. However, they are asking a very simple question: what is the European Union doing? My answer to that is that the European Union is the Member States, and the Member States, which are meeting on Monday – with a Presidency that has a great sense of urgency – must understand that the plans which were presented today are credible and clear, and whatever anyone says from across the political spectrum in this House, Parliament has done its work on relocation fast and efficiently. We have done our work, but what will happen on Monday? Will we see opt-outs? Will we see dilution? Will we see the blame game on Monday? Or will we see a reaction to the biggest refugee crisis since the Second World War? The European Union is its Member States and it is its people. Let us not fail the refugees or the people of the European Union on 14 September.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: – Mr President, it must not be the case that we only see the problem of emigration in southern Europe, and we do not see what is happening in eastern Europe. After all, we all know that in the border strip between Donbass and Russia, more than one and a half million people fear for their own lives. Their lives, lives and the health of their children are no less at risk than those fleeing Syria. Poland has a very conscious policy in this regard, accepting almost one million people from Ukraine every year and issuing them with appropriate temporary visas. More than half a million such temporary visas have already been issued this year. And it is indeed important that now Poles too open themselves to the reception of these emigrants from the south, but also on such principles that will help us to receive them with dignity.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Juncker is all right, but it is important to amend the Dublin Treaty in the face of humanitarian tragedy, both for Italy and for all the other Member States of Europe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, solidarity, coordination, humanitarianism, generosity are words that capture not just what Commission President Juncker said this morning, but I think are reflected across the House today, and I welcome that. And I am sure my own country Ireland will not be found wanting in those qualities as well when taking in more refugees. I have two questions. One, Pope Francis suggested that each Catholic Diocese take in a family. Can this be incorporated into European policy, and how can it be done? And would other churches join in as well? Secondly, President Tusk has rightly condemned people smugglers as murderers, and I am at a loss as to why we cannot deal with them more effectively, and in particular confiscate their boats, because they are the real culprits in this and they need to be dealt with effectively.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament voted in April on a resolution calling for a compulsory quota mechanism to better share responsibilities between Member States. In 2014, 6 out of 28 Member States handled 77% of asylum applications across Europe on their own. Is this the solidarity and fair distribution of responsibilities referred to in Articles 78 and 80 of the Treaty? I don't think so!  The Council's attitude is shameful on this point, I believe that with these leaders Europe, the European Union would never have done so. Therefore, my invitation is, of course, to support the progress that Parliament has been calling for since April; The Commission's new proposals, which provide for larger numbers, immediately need a compulsory and permanent quota mechanism to meet the responsibilities that we as Europeans have and we also need to influence the long-term reasons: regional instability and the issue of inequalities.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all, the clear distinction must be made between refugees and illegal immigrants, because if we accept all people who come to the continent as people entitled to refugee protection, then we must accept that we must provide this protection to more than 100 million people. africa and the Middle East. Secondly, the question of the causes of this immigrant wave is extremely important, because while there is talk here about allocation and quotas and things like that, no one opens up the important question of the cause of what is happening. And the reason is the ongoing wars in Syria, in Iraq, in Libya, in all the other countries of the Middle East and in North Africa. These reasons must be eliminated, and until the dirty geopolitical games there are stopped, the flow of immigrants will not cease to come to the European continent.  The only thing that can and should be done is secular regimes, those who are against Islamic State, against Islam, to be helped, to be armed, to be funded and to be given the opportunity to eliminate the cause of the huge illegal migration. Otherwise, the allocation of allowances for me is unacceptable and will not work.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, in the face of a crisis such as that of refugees, we need concrete facts such as the vigorous response that in the Basque Country the local and regional already offers to channel the solidarity of citizens.  The Summit of Heads of State on 14 September should illuminate a consistent European policy based on humanity, solidarity and responsibility, and that means prioritizing the care and reception of refugees, organising them, providing secure visas and routes to reach Europe and better conditions in refugee camps.  Mafias that traffic in pain and fear must be pursued, and we need a policy of honest and sincere cooperation in the countries of origin and a "eurobody" that unifies the fragmented defence policy and makes it efficient in the face of a barbarism that has produced the greatest flow of migration since World War II.  A Europe without populism, with values in which we believe and to whose foundation, as Basques and Basques, we contribute from the beginning.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, today's lengthy and courageous proposal by President Juncker, which refers to the causes and responsibilities of the European Union, albeit descriptively, is the most formal admission of failure, both of the European Union's foreign and refugee policy, because, unfortunately, it is being carried out under the weight of thousands of dead, in the shadow of the inhuman living conditions for refugees and under the pressure now faced by the countries of Central Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, even at the last minute, let us tackle the tragic homicide issue fully with parallel and effective actions at all levels. Let us first of all acknowledge our responsibilities and ensure that there is never another refugee drowned or dead again, so that no other refugee is ever found again in miserable living conditions. With a respectable decent treatment of human beings, we must ensure that aid to refugees is the responsibility of the whole of the European Union. We need immediate guarantee of legal access and safe routes, establishment of a relocation mechanism, with a permanent and mandatory nature, abolition of the country's criterion of first entry and effective and effective initiatives for peace in war zones ..... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, if I was in danger, I would want to leave as well. These are very clear principles that we know. But the United Nations declarations understand this, and make sure that asylum is defined as based on a well-founded fear of persecution. The UN also makes a clear definition of those who are economic migrants, as well as those not fleeing from persecution. But the EU’s proposals are trying to abandon these principles. They are trying to create international law. They are trying to abandon the Dublin Regulations. Middle-class and wealthy MEPs, who have enough cash to avoid the economic and social problems of mass migration, come up with schemes such as this to salve their consciences, but they ignore the poor, the voiceless, the immobile, who live throughout Europe and who will have to live on the edge and suffer the consequences of these schemes. One cannot think of one without considering the other.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I fully agree with my fellow Member Kinga Gál and I ask and even demand that this priority debate and this plenary session not end in such a way that you, my dear European Commissioner, do not give Hungary firm answer as to whether or not to comply with mandatory EU standards. Look into the eyes of 10 million and 15 million Hungarians at least through monitors and look into the eyes of 500 million Europeans. Do we have to protect Europe's borders or not, can we protect it or not? Allow me to inform you that Mrs Merkel and the European Union have given these people an invitation. They understand that they have the right to go into Germany, and every single piece of legislation, every single police action, prevents them from do so. They are outraged, they refuse to go to reception centres, they refuse to give fingerprints, they refuse to abide by the law. So what do we do now?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to all of the colleagues for their reactions and overall support for the approach followed by the Commission. I really hope that our proposals can be adopted quickly as we now need fast decisions. I particularly look forward to Parliament’s involvement in the upcoming discussions on the permanent relocation mechanism and the establishment of the European Union list of safe countries, for which Parliament will be co-legislator. We will put forth all the effort necessary to implement the decisions already taken and make sure that Member States apply the common rules, and of course we will count on support from Parliament in these endeavours. This migration will last; that is a fact. The package adopted by the Commission today is only a step to better manage migration. We also have to work on integration of the refugees we welcome. This is essential for European cohesion. A successful integration policy is the most efficient tool against secondary movements. Cooperation with third countries and opening legal avenues to Europe is also essential. This goes hand-in-hand with the war we have declared on unscrupulous migrant smugglers. Member States have agreed on an EU resettlement scheme. We have never before reached 22 504 places in the European Union. We therefore have to build on this success and take even more initiatives in the future to open legal ways to come to Europe. Finally, protecting and defending our borders is crucial. We will launch a wider reflection to reinforce management of our borders and ambitious solutions.  Let me thank this House for the overall support. I took note of Members’ remarks, of their comments and I gladly notice that we share the ambition to work together as we have done in the past but also in the future, to increase understanding and finally find common solutions. I really look forward to the continuation of our very good cooperation throughout these months.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank you for this very rich debate and I can assure you that the Presidency will continue, as the Commissioner has said, this dialogue and collaboration with your Parliament, which has eminent political value, precisely at this difficult time.  The Presidency will spare no effort to move quickly. A lot of messages go in that direction. It will continue to work with all stakeholders on the basis of the Commission's proposals.  The next Council meeting, which will take place in a few days next Monday, will have a great responsibility in this regard. I also hope that a number of messages that have been formulated and expressed here in this Chamber will be taken into account at this meeting. There is a consensus among all of us: to succeed, we must remain united and clear about our priorities and the means at our disposal to achieve our goals. We must deal with the most urgent and, at the same time, quickly agree on new instruments adapted to the new situation. We need a comprehensive approach to this crisis.  I repeat what I said in my previous speech: we cannot procrastinate and we cannot procrastinate. We are not allowed to let time pass. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
