text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, September 10, 2015, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – Have we forgotten, as Juncker points out, that 60 million Europeans were on the run during the Second World War? Are we going to 'push back' the war refugees who are knocking on our borders today or wash up in rubber dinghies to non-European shores? And look the other way? We're supposed to take them in until the war is over. Because it is 'dignified and humane and historically fair' (Juncker).  The proposals put forward by the European Commission are concrete and effective. We fully support these proposals and expect the Interior Ministers not to break up on Monday without a formal agreement on a fair and mandatory dispersal plan for war refugees. And an agreement on a common list of safe countries.  We must not be naïve and also tackle the surveillance of our external borders much more efficiently. This crisis is therefore an opportunity. An effective European asylum policy depends on a joint registration at our external borders. Juncker announces new legislative proposals on an effective European border and coast guard. The time is right to work on this quickly. The time for rhetoric is indeed behind us.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I support the Commission President's proposals to establish a relocation mechanism in the event of a humanitarian emergency and a list of countries of origin to separate political migrants from economic migrants. I am particularly attached to the creation of a European coastguard corps, as Jean-Claude Juncker announced in his speech. As such, I have passed an amendment in the parliamentary committee establishing European supervision of the coastguard. If this project is adopted by the next plenary, it will unlock one million euros to coordinate the action of agencies like FRONTEX and the 300 public authorities that carry out coastguard functions. It is with concrete measures of this nature that we will be able to overcome this crisis. We've talked enough, now let's act!

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – In response to President Juncker’s State of the Union address I want to highlight the need for a radical shift in migration policies across EU countries. We are facing a large scale humanitarian crisis and it must be recognised that the attitudes and policies followed up until now have not worked. I condemn the current crisis and believe that every EU country needs to seriously think about increasing the number of refugees they have committed themselves to take. In addition, I would call upon countries to suspend the Dublin Regulations for those arriving from countries such as Syria, Eritrea and Sudan, where refugees are desperately fleeing war zones. These regulations are simply not practical in the present circumstances and create unnecessary burdens for displaced people genuinely seeking safety. Ireland is a country that understands the pains of these issues having experienced over a century and a half of migration. It is part of our history and part of our personality. Now we must come together to do more and welcome refugees from dangerous and war-torn countries. We as EU Member States have a shared responsibility to prevent human suffering so it is time we start to show a humane and proportionate response.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The European Parliament today discussed the situation of the many refugees heading to the European Union in a nightmarish situation. We seem to have tacitly accepted the appeal of all these people. But appeal is not a normal development. People from Syria, Iraq and elsewhere are being forced to flee their homes because of the fighting that has been going on there for years, with the co-responsibility of Western countries on both sides of the Atlantic. Member States of the Union participated in the US-led coalition that invaded Iraq in violation of the UN Charter in 2003 and, more recently, Union member states have also contributed in a variety of ways to undermining the Assad regime in Syria, providing the ground for the murderous rise of extreme Islamists. We need to address the cause of the problem. The European Union must actively assist Syrian society in particular, since it comes from the majority of refugees, in order to find a peaceful solution to its internal contradictions and, of course, to permanently eradicate the carcinoma of the "Islamic State". The West must rid itself of the dangerous illusion that it can impose its own model of governance everywhere and limit itself to seeking stability and seeking a peaceful settlement of disputes.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Solidarity, a common value, comes without an opt-out clause. Solidarity means addressing migration together, assisting each other to assist those escaping persecution and war. It is in times when we are facing our fears, when we are feeling overwhelmed that we must be more united in expressing our value of solidarity to protect the life of those escaping oppression and in fighting those who fearlessly make money off the misery of these people by exposing them to dangers and by bringing death to our lands and seas rather than life. The Council should no longer hide behind political rhetoric. Solidarity means ensuring that each Member State adheres to European standards established under the European common asylum system. Each Member State must take upon itself the responsibility to participate in asylum seekers distribution. While addressing a crisis, we should also strengthen our solidarity with third countries by assisting them towards a path to democratisation, strengthening their economies and job opportunities, and seeking social justice. This will address the root causes of migration. Humanitarian aid is not charity but a process of empowerment for TCNs to find peace, employment and justice in their own land. Our foreign policy needs to ensure that this aid is effective.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The migration crisis that we have been experiencing for many months and whose proportions are becoming exponential is not a refugee crisis. Many of these illegal migrants are not political refugees but illegal immigrants who have come to Europe because complicit national governments and the European Union have opened the doors for economic and political reasons. This migratory torrent is accompanied by the media sirens, the praise of the press and the professionals of indignation and good conscience. Yes, the reception of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants every month on our soil is a betrayal of the peoples of Europe who will be the first to suffer the disastrous consequences of this mass arrival of people. Who will fund the emergency facilities? What accommodations will be available? What jobs can we offer? The proposed introduction of quotas is the most egregious denial of the sovereignty of states and the integrity of their territory. If Europe's doors are not maintained, millions of other illegal migrants will follow the air call that has been created. The promoters of this demographic surge will therefore be responsible for the end of European history.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – Put immigration on the agenda and criticising the current European model is not a party political issue, as the left often argues, but a common European interest, and we need to find a solution to this pressing issue very quickly. But what does the European Commission propose? It would create quota migrants who could move freely within the EU internal market. In other words, they would presumably move again and again to the Member States where they wish to live; therefore, the whole mandatory quota system would fail every single day with the restart of each hijacked migrant. And the last few days and weeks have shown what migrants can do if they don't get what they want from Europe. The whole story will turn into endless table tennis between migrants and authorities and states on a daily scale of tens of thousands, blocking everything and everyone. Hungary clear position that political refugees should be protected. Our government is fulfilling all its international obligations. Through the European Agenda on Migration and the European Security Strategy, we must take decisive steps to improve migration management, strengthen cooperation and make Europe safer for its citizens in terms of organised crime and terrorism. National programmes approved by the Commission can provide significant financial support to Member States to address these challenges, but only if they are adequate.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU migration policy should be long-term, comprehensive and coherent. It should use the whole package of tools developed as part of the global approach to migration and mobility. It is necessary to implement the commitments and actions already made more efficiently. The number of refugees admitted cannot be limited, as the idea of automatic distribution of refugees is a bad solution, which means that a Member State actually loses control over the number of arrivals and the process of accepting them from a security point of view. Poland, as an EU border country, is dealing with an influx of refugees from across the eastern border and the mass issuance of visas and work permits to Ukrainian citizens. In the first half of this year only, my country spent more than half a million of them. Due to the conflict in Ukraine, there are more than 1.5 million internally displaced people. This group potentially increases migratory pressure at the EU's eastern border if the situation deteriorates. Any responsible solutions at European level must also take this into account. However, I believe that any action we will take in Europe on the refugee problem is doomed to fail. This problem must be solved at source, i.e. in the countries from which they are fleeing.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – It has been said in this debate in many ways that the Mediterranean is being the scene of a great tragedy. We're all aware. Let's do something then. I will repeat what I proposed here several months ago: it is urgent to set up a European search and rescue fund to rescue endangered ships at sea. We must not wait for those people who long to reach our shores to reach our borders. We can't keep letting them die at sea, almost always anonymously, sometimes in front of the cameras. Frontex, by definition, will not perform this task. That is why we need a new fund that allows what the Italian Military Navy already, through Operation Mare Nostrum, undertook alone. You have my most sincere recognition. Let us take his witness and show that Europe not only formulates its values, but is willing to be consistent and act under its dictate. If not, we will have to rethink what so much institution and union is for.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. The tragic consequence of an endless tragedy, the massacres, the migrants trying to break down the walls and injuring themselves on barbed wire, the clashes in Hungary as we debate here. Every time I talk in my country about the role of Europe, I have to point out the differences between the different institutions: Parliament, which has for some time sent out a very strong message that has not been heard before, the Commission, which over time has proved us right and has finally launched a courageous agenda, and the Council: the Council which still does not decide, which postpones, which is lost in sterile distinction. Act now, we repeat, and we see far beyond the quotas that are not sufficient, change Dublin and take note of a phenomenon that will certainly not stop because it is the result of geopolitical change that we cannot stop but that we absolutely must govern.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – There is a humanitarian crisis in Europe: people fleeing war fearing for their lives, cold and starving, including in Hungary. We need not only a long-term and workable solution, but also swift, humane action. All possible moral and material support must be given to the receivers, to the care organisations, without any political or other commitment. At the same time, action must be taken against all incitement and exclusion, which has already caused many human disasters in history. I would like to thank the Hungarian and European citizens for the selfless help they have provided in trouble, often alongside the organisations called for, and sometimes, as in my country, for them. In the current situation, it is unacceptable that some governments are powerless or hostile and do not want to participate in a common European solution.  We need a common European refugee policy and a comprehensive integration system. An automatic distribution system should be established between Member States which takes into account the needs of asylum seekers to a high extent. In the long term, a legal and safe way must be created so that those fleeing war can reach Europe. Now is the moment when Europe must put aside its egotism, its political differences and act unitedly in the interests of refugees, before the coming winter puts refugees who trust European values and rightly fear for their lives in an even worse situation.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. – The influx of migration is also caused by the passivity of the international community in terms of civil wars, despotism and injustice. We were busy on other matters, we wanted to intervene as little as possible until the problem finally crossed our borders. What is more, we can see that a new player is entering the hottest point, seeking a geopolitical revanch rather than anything else. Action is needed to help address the problem at its source, to help third countries that are close to even larger numbers of refugees. It is also necessary to strengthen the eu's external border by providing the necessary mandates and resources for relevant EU missions and institutions. Fight the now well-organised and rapidly adaptable illegal business of people smugglers. After all, it is those who really need asylum in the EU to ensure that they are the most vulnerable groups. Yes, this is indeed a European problem, and the solution must be a common European one. However, solidarity cannot be imposed. The positions of the Member States need to be brought closer together, ensuring the sustainability of the decisions and the effectiveness of implementation. Some countries need to work hard to adapt their integration programmes to new and drastically grown needs. Such countries should urgently seek and receive good practices on how to properly and fully integrate refugees and their families to live in peace and democracy, enabling them to work and earn, study and study, and to help them become full, creative members of society.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: in writing. – Europe is facing a crisis that is getting worse every day and that we need to respond urgently to. Increasing the reception capacities of refugees within the EU's borders without Europe's determination and consistency is not a solution, will only add new waves of refugees and will exacerbate humanitarian problems. The root cause must be addressed: economic underdevelopment and lack of opportunities. This is demonstrated by the contrast between countries in the vicinity of conflicts, such as Qatar, Oman or Kuwait, and those that have become the homeland of war and terrorist groups.  Some Member States, including Romania, have not faced such problems and must seek the financial and logistical support of the EU and countries with experience in the construction and management of refugee centres, in order to treat this joint humanitarian effort with the utmost seriousness and responsibility. I visited refugee camps and talked to people who are living this drama. They want to go home. I expect European leaders, very affected by the dramas of refugees, to put demagoguery aside and act firmly, as they have unfortunately not done so far, to channel political, diplomatic, military and financial resources to end the conflict and rebuild the affected areas.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. The proposals put forward by the European Commission to resolve the refugee crisis are concrete and courageous measures. In recent months, this Parliament has already advocated the need for both an emergency mechanism, with compulsory quotas for migrants to be accepted in the Member States, and a permanent mechanism which, through a reform of the Dublin Treaty and the creation of legal and safe channels for immigration, would put an end to the tragedies of the Mediterranean. Among other things, a broad interpretation of the family reunification system and – for specific cases – the promotion of private sponsorship mechanisms. If it is known that, as a result of the demographic changes taking place, the European economy needs migrants, well before economic reasons, it is humanity and our own history – Europe has been a continent of refugees for centuries – that require us to act consistently to prevent further loss of life and to implement common and lasting solutions to the refugee crisis. This request, adopted by the European Parliament, comes directly to us from the citizens of Europe. It is now up to the Council and the Member States to shoulder their responsibilities. We Europeans no longer want to be ashamed of ourselves as human beings.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – A humane and workable solution must be found quickly to the refugee crisis. If this is not achieved or is not done, the risk of european division will increase significantly. The resolution of this crisis will also have a significant impact on the future of the European Union. Recent weeks have shown that the European asylum system is not working as it should. In the current situation, war refugees everywhere in Europe have not been able to cope humanely. However, the refugee crisis is manageable and the European Union can cope with this humane settlement if all countries help. Some countries are making serious efforts, but many have not made a contribution so far. Such contrasts are also rapidly increasing tensions between EU Member States. Therefore, a humanly significant solution to the refugee crisis should be offered by all Member States.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "In view of the situation, no one can remain indifferent. Every day we receive information about further dramatic attempts to get migrants to Europe. These are harrowing images. The need to resolve this drama poses an extremely urgent challenge for the European Union. This is confirmed by frontex data from January and February of this year. During this time, the number of migrants in 2014 increased significantly compared to 2013: the Central Mediterranean route by 42%, the Eastern Mediterranean route by 107%, the Western Balkan route by 990%. The largest group to apply for asylum in the EU in Q1 was not Syrians, who made up 16%, but mainly residents of the Balkans: Kosovo, Albania and Serbia. Frontex predicts that this number could double next year, to around 2.5 million people. The solidarity we should show migrants must not consist in mutual reassuance or blame, which undermines the effectiveness of action by building internal conflicts. That is why it is so important to prepare a m.in strategy, including: increasing bilateral assistance and assistance programmes, with a particular focus on countries of transit and origin; stepping up efforts to combat networks of traffickers and smugglers; effective control and protection of the European Union's external borders or stepping up cooperation with the international community, in particular the UN, the African Union and the League of Arab States.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: in writing. – The current migration and refugee crisis will continue unless the root causes of the problem are addressed. EU crisis management structures should focus on the need to find sustainable solutions to the numerous conflicts in our neighbourhood. Putting an end to the civil war in Syria and fighting Islamist terrorism such as ISIS/Daesh should be at the top of the EU security and defence agenda. The proliferation of violent non-state actors in large parts of Africa and the Middle East has a direct link with the urgent migration crisis that Europe is facing. The EU must play a more prominent role in finding a political solution to the Syrian conflict and support actively the UN-led negotiations to restore peace and stability in Libya. The EU military operation EUNAVFOR Med must be integrated into a comprehensive strategy towards the migrants’ countries of origin and transit. We need to make better use of the comprehensive approach as a unique tool to coordinate our migration, development, diplomatic and security policies. In addition, we should continue and reinforce our support for Syria’s neighbouring countries, namely Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon, who have already taken in millions of migrants and refugees.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – The scale, complexity, and urgency of today’s humanitarian crises are unprecedented. There is no easy solution and we cannot help everyone but we must do everything in our power to help as many as possible. Europe must stand up for its values and live up to the expectations of many European citizens. Instead, we see a commendable action from our German colleagues and sheer panic in the voice of many other European leaders. The European Union is not just about grants, development funds and the single market. It is about values. This is our chance to show the world that the EU is committed to the principles of liberty, democracy and respect for human rights – the freedoms we all hold dear. While the UK Government struggles to show leadership, Scotland stands ready to offer sanctuary to refugees. The Syrian civil war, now entering its fifth year, is the main reason why we see a mass exodus of refugees, until their homeland is safe men, women and children will do anything to find safety. As our First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said our response will be judged by history and I also hope that the next generation will be proud of our response.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – Junker's speech was bold and courageous. In such a divided Europe, he acted very motivationally in terms of stylusing the refugee crisis, calling for greater solidarity, cohesion, humanity and respect for dignity. If the proposals he has put forward could become meat, it would certainly be a major step forward. How many figs there are and will be in his pockets will show the time. The permanent mechanism of migration, relocation and assimilation seems, in addition to the idea of amending asylum laws across Member States to enable immediate work and the earnings of migrants before they are granted asylum, a hard nut to realise. This is mainly due to complex bureaucratic processes. At the moment, the most important thing is to start with a common European approach without religious, nationalist, racial and other excuses that would prevent a common approach. A lot has been said in almost 80 minutes of the speech, and if at least 80 per cent of everything is achieved, it will be a great success for the EU, which is now writing the history of its future. Of course, we can also criticise it all, but now is the time for a positive approach. There are no numbers in front of us, but people who are waiting and deserve our attention and help. At this place, we must not forget our shared European history, which has been marked by various wars and refugees.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I do not recognize myself in this policy of European governments. In recent days, politicians have said they want to deprive refugees of certain rights or create special statutes for these migrants. I believe that these kinds of statements must be put to an end. It is out of the question to embark on this path which would undermine our moral and legal duty to welcome these refugees who arrive at our country to escape the horror. In such a situation, the role of politics is not to stoke fears or to maintain fantasies, but to act according to the principles and values that underpin our rule of law. Europe must take its share of responsibility. People who fear for their lives should be allowed to apply for asylum in their country of origin, so that they do not put their lives at risk by crossing the Mediterranean in extremely dangerous conditions. In any case, there will be no viable solution without solidarity and without humanity. I will continue to fight for these values to be taken into account and respected!

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. – The current situation in the European Union is characterised, among other things, by a misguided policy towards the influx of migrants, inertia, paralysis and self-surrender. The Union's immigration policy has collapsed. While the international community is unable to unite and take strength from it – the Islamic State and the other enemies of Europe can be very pleased with the "state of war" that has now emerged and is escalating. Europe's values, culture, identity and future are at stake. In particular, the Union should protect its own law-abiding citizens and indigenous national communities, not facilitate the invasion of economic squatters who violate borders and laws. It's true that we have to help the persecuted. However, the Christlike commandment of inclusion does not in any way apply to those who threaten our Christian-rooted continent. Hungary is facing many baseless accusations and untrue attacks in these times of crisis. Not only does it have to deal with the daily siege of tens of thousands of people arriving through the Balkans, but at the same time it must suffer backstret attacks from the European left-wing side and also fight its internal enemies who are trying to destabilise the country. We do not want syria and the world's dissatisfied people to migrate to Europe. In the long run, it won't help them, it will come at the expense of all of us. We want Germany to remain germany, Estonia to Estonia, Hungary and Europe to Europe. I am proud that the Hungary to protect not only its own people, but the whole of Europe.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. – I consider inadmissible the way in which hundreds of thousands of people, desperate is true, are, without any possibility of control, in the cities of Europe. I fully agree that they need massive humanitarian aid, and I believe that it is necessary, in this respect, to urgently create refugee camps capable of hosting such a human influx. But we cannot leave unanswered the fundamental question of the vulnerability of our maritime and land borders. The epidemiological and terrorist risks involved in this chaotic movement of hundreds of thousands of people through Europe must also be taken into account.  I would also like to draw attention to the EU's inability to anticipate this exodus. The discussion a few months ago about hosting tens of thousands of people is out of date. We need measures to address the causes of this critical situation. And the main cause is Islamic State, whose bloody expansion can only be stopped by an intervention by a large international coalition with European and Arab participation, aimed at restoring peace in Syria and Iraq, saving the population subject to jihadist atrocities, and allowing millions of refugees from neighbouring states to return to their countries of origin.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. – Merciful and righteous. For me, these biblical key concepts guide the way in which migrants and refugees should be treated. Merciful by working together in Europe to arrange the reception of refugees. Many citizens lead by example and help refugees with bed, bath and bread. Every European Member State must play a part in this reception.  Just by working for safe habitats in northern Iraq and northern Syria, by setting up and resting regional reception camps in the Middle East and North Africa properly, by agreeing to return to safe countries and fully committed to tackling people smugglers. And just by not being naïve: there would be ISIS fighters coming along in these migrant flows. Our security services must be doubly alert.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which The services estimate that it takes us three-quarters of an hour. If you help, we may be a little quicker.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Mr President, briefly, just thirty seconds to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the great work done in this important report which will undoubtedly help to boost trade globally, especially in developing countries. And, in the face of the migration challenge we are experiencing in Europe, and when there is unanimity that the solution must be at source, we certainly need more than ever instruments like this that drive economic development, especially in those countries that need it most.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, we have an oral amendment here which has been agreed among the shadow rapporteurs. It is basically an update in relation to what we heard this morning about Commission President Juncker’s new proposal. Members will find it in writing in their voting list, because it is a bit difficult to read out, but basically we say that a further relocation of 120 000 applicants from Italy, Greece and Hungary should be completed on the basis of the new Commission proposal. That is the essence of it. Members will find the wording that is specifically going to be voted on in their voting lists, so please read it as it is very complicated. (the oral amendment was not accepted)

name: Laura AGEA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council in delegation for relations with Palestine because I believe that after many years the European Parliament finally recognises the official link between the European Union and the Palestinian State.  This vote is the logical continuation of our Resolution of December 2014 and also helps to strengthen the legitimacy of a people to be able to dispose of themselves as a nation officially recognized, not only by the European Union, but also and above all by many nations on the international stage.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I supported without hesitation the proposal to change the name of the Delegation of the European Parliament for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by which it should long be its name, which was a Delegation for relations with Palestine. I welcome the conclusion that this proposal, the result of a months-long campaign and advocated by my political group colleague Martina Anderson, chair of the delegation, has been endorsed by the majority of the Eurochamber. Although symbolic, this is a success in the struggle of the Palestinian people and the movement of solidarity with their legitimate cause. Following the recognition in 2013 by the United Nations General Assembly of Palestine as an observer state, I welcome the European Parliament's position in this direction with actions such as this change of name which I hope and wish to take a step further towards recognizing the full rights of the Palestinian people and state.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Since the Palestinian state is not recognized by almost all the member countries of the European Union, the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine makes no sense. Making this change now violates the sovereignty of states. By this act, in fact, the Union gives itself the right to have an independent position on foreign policy in defiance of the treaties.  The position of the National Front is very clear: we are in favour of the official recognition of the Palestinian state and the fundamental rights of the Palestinian people, but, as a matter of principle, we do not accept that the Union is expressing a different opinion than that expressed by most of its Member States.  That is why I abstained on this proposal.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, which is consistent with my previous vote on recognition of Palestine. Rather than rehearse the same reasons, I refer to my reasoning in a previous Explanation of Vote.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following UN General Assembly Resolution 67/19 recognising Palestine as a non-member observer State and the European Parliament Resolution of 17 December 2014 on the recognition of the State of Palestine, it makes perfect sense that the designation of the European Parliament delegation working on matters relating to the Palestinian State reflects the recognition of palestine. With my vote, I would like to reaffirm the justice of this recognition, and to call again for this to be another moment that can encourage greater involvement of the European Union in the process of resolving the Israel-Palestine conflict. The recognition of the right to establish a Palestinian State is, for all those who advocate the need for the coexistence of the two States, a symbolic act of the greatest importance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to replace the name 'Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council' with 'Delegation for relations with Palestine'.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I abstained on this name change: the recognition of Palestine seems to me to be very unwelcome on the part of a European Union which is constantly aiming to eradicate the last sovereignty that its Member States still have.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of changing the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council in delegation for relations with Palestine in order to make Parliament's external action more coherent with that of the European External Action Service, but also to act on the Union's willingness to move towards a peace agreement on the basis of a two-state negotiation.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This text proposes to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. I abstained in the vote on this text because I believe that foreign policy must be the work of the Member States, even if this change does not affect the delegation or the territory concerned.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text being voted on is not critical, so I supported it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of changing the name of the parliamentary delegation of this house for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to that of delegation for relations with Palestine. Other Union institutions, such as the European External Action Service, already use the name of Palestine in their media. It is necessary to resume recognition of Palestine as a State, a path already initiated by Member States such as Sweden, France, the United Kingdom, Spain or Italy. In this process, it is appropriate for the European Parliament and the other institutions of the Union to take clear positions in favour of recognition. The socialists' position can be nothing more than to support this change in denomination.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical proposal with political significance. I did not support the unilateral proclamation of the Palestinian State without Israel's support and abstained on today's vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I don’t believe that the EU approaches the Israel/Palestine even-handedly, and am deeply concerned by the bias towards the Palestinian side of this tragic and contentious issue.  It is my belief that until the EU takes a more neutral approach, and, indeed, Hamas stops calling for the destruction of the Israeli State, there will not be a lasting peace.  Accordingly, I have no faith whatsoever in the EU approach, and thus voted against this proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 After the vote on the resolution on the recognition of the Palestinian State on 10 December 2014, the logical consequence was to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. I believe that the decision is not in line with the provisions and prerogatives of my group.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal because I believe that formal recognition should follow the facts and not anticipate them. At the moment, in my opinion, the situation is not ripe for such a change, but I still think it is a good thing that we are still talking about it because a solution must be found quickly and quickly.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I supported without hesitation the proposal to change the name of the Delegation of the European Parliament for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by which it should long be its name, which was a Delegation for relations with Palestine. I welcome the conclusion that this proposal, the result of a months-long campaign and advocated by my political group colleague Martina Anderson, chair of the delegation, has been endorsed by the majority of the Eurochamber. Although symbolic, this is a success in the struggle of the Palestinian people and the movement of solidarity with their legitimate cause. Following the recognition in 2013 by the United Nations General Assembly of Palestine as an observer state, I welcome the European Parliament's position in this direction with actions such as this change of name which I hope and wish to take a step further towards recognizing the full rights of the Palestinian people and state.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the change in the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to the Delegation for relations with Palestine, because this is not just a change in name but has strong political significance. This change reflects the UNGA Resolution 67/19 which upgraded the status of Palestine at the United Nations to that of Non-Member Observer State and thus the denomination Palestine shall be used on all occasions.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. Considering that, legally, the United Nations does not recognise the State of Palestine and that the European Council has not taken a decision on this subject, which falls within its jurisdiction, I voted against this report.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, it should come as no surprise that the Chair of this Parliament’s Delegation to the Palestinian Legislative Council is leading this latest political stunt. This disingenuous proposal is but another unilateral attempt to recognise Palestinian statehood contrary to international law and contrary to reality.  A two-state solution can only derive of bilateral negotiations between Israel and Palestinian representatives. This is enshrined in the Oslo Accords and several UN resolutions. No worthless name change can change that fact. Therefore, because we in Northern Ireland are used to Sinn Fein attempting to rewrite the history of the IRA’s terrorist past, it comes as no shock that they are also aiming to reshape reality in Europe on this issue. Don’t be fooled. Like in Northern Ireland, the end of terrorism must be a precursor to talks in the Middle East scenario. Hamas must stop their reign of terror if the situation is to move forward.  And this is the primary message that the European Parliament must send.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal to change the name because I believe that this should be discussed in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and not directly in plenary.  Another very good reason not to change the name right now is that such a change at the moment could give legitimacy to the terrorist organization (Hamas) that governs in the Gaza Strip at the moment. In this regard, the EU should not provide legitimacy to a terrorist organisation, but positively promote the peace process by promoting internal Palestinian reconciliation. Any step that may negatively affect the peace process must be avoided. The Middle East peace process is a high priority on the EU agenda and this must continue to be the case.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Changing the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to "Delegation for Relations with Palestine" is an initial step towards the recognition of the State of Palestine, which we fully agree with.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution because it calls for the timely resumption of credible peace efforts in the Middle East peace process, where unfortunately a stalemate persists; it calls on the Israelis and Palestinians to avoid actions that could trigger further escalation, including hate rhetoric and hate speech in public life, as well as unilateral measures that could undermine the outcome of the negotiations and threaten the viability of the two-state solution; a lasting solution to the conflict can only be achieved in a regional context with the involvement of all relevant regional actors and the support of the international community;  The resolution reiterates its firm support for the 1967 two-state solution, which provides for exchanges of agreed territories and Jerusalem as the capital of both states, as well as the coexistence, in the name of peace, security and mutual recognition, of a secure State of Israel and an independent State of Palestine. , democratic, territorially contiguous and capable of autonomous existence, on the basis of the right to self-determination and full respect for international law; lastly, it stresses that non-violent measures and respect for human rights are the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace;

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of changing the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to "Delegation for Relations with Palestine".

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the proposal to change the name of the Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to 'Delegation for relations with Palestine', as I am always in favour of politically and diplomatically correct solutions. That is the case when we talk about the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by Delegation for Relations with Palestine. We understand that the second version, "Relations with Palestine", does greater justice to the sense of what bilateral treaties have to be treated between equals and that podemos's declaration in favour of a Palestinian state has always been clear.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request for the Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to change its name so that the title will be aligned with that of other inter-parliamentary delegations. In this way, its work can be compared to the work of other councils.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the request of the Palestine delegation to change their name. This is a symbolically important statement in the move towards Palestinian statehood.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by Delegation for Relations with Palestine. We understand that the second version, "Relations with Palestine", does greater justice to the sense of what bilateral treaties have to be treated between equals and that podemos's declaration in favour of a Palestinian state has always been clear.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to the Delegation for Relations with Palestine, as I support the process and the effort to create a Palestinian state.  I experience the decision we have taken to change the name as part of this process and the continuation of earlier decisions taken in the European Parliament. It is known that I am convinced that the solution of two states, Israel and Palestine, which will have good social relations and relations based on lasting peace, is something I sincerely support.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Since the Palestinian state is not recognized by almost all the member countries of the European Union, the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine makes no sense. Making this change now violates the sovereignty of states. By this act, in fact, the Union gives itself the right to have an independent position on foreign policy in defiance of the treaties. The position of the National Front is very clear: we are in favour of the official recognition of the Palestinian state and the fundamental rights of the Palestinian people, but we do not accept that the Union is giving a different opinion than that expressed by most of its Member States. That is why I abstained on this proposal.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against the name change of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council. Since the United Nations did not recognize the State of Palestine and the European Council had never taken a position on the subject, there was no formal legal basis to support the proposed name change. The proposal has been adopted, which I regret.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: por escrito. ‒ EH Bildu has voted in favor of changing the name of Delegation for Relations with Palestine, from the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council (DPLC) into the Delegation for Relations with Palestine. EH Bildu believes that the name change will allow the delegation to go forward and fulfil the potential of its remit, working to improve relations with Palestine in relation to the protection and promotion of human rights, democratic values, social relations, economic partnership and the assessment of international agreements. The new name is much more representative of the work that the delegation does and will allow the delegation to fulfil its potential as a fully-fledged delegation for relations between the European Union and an external state – in this instance, the state of Palestine.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The United Nations does not officially recognize the State of Palestine, and the European Council has never taken any such decision. That is why I voted against this proposal. Indeed, the European Parliament cannot take a decision on this subject ahead of the UN and the Council.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report, which includes renaming the delegation with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. This can be an important step towards the recognition of Palestine.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the proposal to change the name of the "delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council" to "delegation for relations with Palestine". I understand the symbolic value of this change and I am in favour of the two-state solution. However, these two (future) states would have to recognize each other, which unfortunately is not possible at the moment. It is not by changing the name of the European Parliament's delegation that this problem can be solved.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I supported without hesitation the proposal to change the name of the Delegation of the European Parliament for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by which it should long be its name, which was a Delegation for relations with Palestine. I welcome the conclusion that this proposal, the result of a months-long campaign and advocated by my political group colleague Martina Anderson, chair of the delegation, has been endorsed by the majority of the Eurochamber. Although symbolic, this is a success in the struggle of the Palestinian people and the movement of solidarity with their legitimate cause. Following the recognition in 2013 by the United Nations General Assembly of Palestine as an observer state, I welcome the European Parliament's position in this direction with actions such as this change of name which I hope and wish to take a step further towards recognizing the full rights of the Palestinian people and state.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I did not understand at all why the People's Party group was only against the name change. As the peace process develops, there will also be two countries in the Middle East. It is therefore absolutely logical to change the name of the European Parliament delegation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal to change the name of the Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to 'Delegation for relations with Palestine, because steps must continue to create an independent Palestinian State.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this change of name as I believe the new name better reflects the role of the delegation.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. – The vote against this modification is justified by the fact that though the practical result is merely technical, it has political implications that we do not support. These implications are, in our view, negative for the Europe Union and its support implies responsibilities that the Union cannot afford at this stage. The juridical recognition of a state should be the accomplishment of a de facto situation that does not exist at the moment. This modification may hurt the negotiations within the Middle East peace process that many of our politicians stand for. The misuse of political narratives may have consequences that can hurt the role of the Union within its neighbourhood.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report proposes to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. I consider this to be in line with a future recognition of the Palestinian state and I am voting for it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Since the Palestinian state is not recognized by almost all the member countries of the European Union, the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine makes no sense. Making this change now violates the sovereignty of states. By this act, in fact, the Union gives itself the right to have an independent position on foreign policy in defiance of the treaties. The position of the National Front is very clear: we are in favour of the official recognition of the Palestinian state and the fundamental rights of the Palestinian people, but we do not accept that the Union is giving a different opinion than that expressed by most of its Member States. The Member therefore abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the amendment.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the change in the name to the Delegation for Relations with Palestine as it is important that the international community recognises the steps that the Palestinians are making towards statehood as part of a two state solution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to the Delegation for Relations with Palestine, which is in line with Article 4 of the Implementing Provisions governing the work of all European Parliament Delegations.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Decision on the internal organisation of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of the Decision of the European Parliament of 12 March 2014 on the number of interparliamentary delegations, delegations to joint parliamentary committees and delegations to parliamentary cooperation committees and multilateral parliamentary assemblies (2014/2632(RSO), which decided on the number of delegations and their regional groupings, With the aim of contributing, through a continuous interparliamentary dialogue, to the strengthening of parliamentary democracy, I have nothing to do with this proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text proposes to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to a delegation for relations with Palestine. I abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which changes the name of the "delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council" to a "delegation for relations with Palestine". I am not in favour of this measure because, in legal and formal terms, the United Nations does not recognize the State of Palestine. Nor does the European Council recognise this. Any attempt at unilateral recognition of Palestine is doomed to failure, the only solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict being the mutual recognition of two states.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for changing the name of the Delegation for Relations with Palestine.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because communication takes place not only with the Council, but more broadly.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and I say no.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The current conflict situation between the democratic state of Israel and the Palestinian Authority, as well as the internal disputes we are witnessing in the territories under the Palestinian Authority and the lack of full democracy and the rule of law are the main reason for the European Union's inability to recognise Palestine as a state at this time.  The Palestinian Authority's task is to achieve appropriate standards by isolating influences that deny democratic principles in this area. Successful peace talks between Israel and the Palestinian Authority are a precondition for the establishment of two states for two peoples. For this reason, I do not support the change of the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to the Delegation for Relations with Palestine, until the expected and necessary steps towards the establishment of peace and democratisation of society under the Palestinian Authority are taken.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This proposal aims to change the name of the delegation in charge of relations between the European Union and the Palestinian authorities. I am in favour of the creation of a Palestinian state, but it must be done in a good diplomatic agreement so that the region is not further destabilized than it is now. That is why I prefer to abstain on this vote.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I support this proposed change as another effort by the European Parliament to contribute to a solution to the "Palestinian issue".

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 It is not by changing the name of a delegation from the European Parliament that we will contribute to the creation of two states capable of living in peace alongside each other, which is one of the main objectives of the international community and of Europe. That is why I abstained.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal to rename this delegation because I consider it premature. Peace in the Middle East will not bring unilateral gestures towards either side of the conflict, but an agreement involving the State of Israel alongside the Palestinians.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council in delegation for relations with Palestine in the interests of legislative and political clarity.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of changing the name of the parliamentary delegation of this house for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to that of delegation for relations with Palestine. Other Union institutions, such as the European External Action Service, already use the name of Palestine in their media. It is necessary to resume recognition of Palestine as a State, a path already initiated by Member States such as Sweden, France, the United Kingdom, Spain or Italy. In this process, it is appropriate for the European Parliament and the other institutions of the Union to take clear positions in favour of recognition. The socialists' position can be nothing more than to support this change in denomination.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to change the name of the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council in delegation for relations with Palestine, in the continuity of the recognition of the State of Palestine by the European Parliament last December. Since the end of 2012, Palestine has been recognized as a non-member observer state with the United Nations. The European Union, for its part, has stated, through its High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, that it wants to play a decisive role in the Middle East peace process. It is essential that negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority evolve, so that the rights of Palestinians and Israelis are recognized. Just as it is unimaginable that one day a lasting settlement of the Middle East conflict will be achieved without the democratic and sovereign state of Palestine being recognized as is Israel's. Palestine must be recognised on the basis of the 1967 borders, with Jerusalem as the capital of two states, living side by side, in mutual recognition, and the European Parliament must fully seize its role as representative of the peoples of the Union by arguing for a two-state solution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by Delegation for Relations with Palestine. We understand that the second version, "Relations with Palestine", does greater justice to the sense of what bilateral treaties have to be treated between equals and that podemos's declaration in favour of a Palestinian state has always been clear.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I supported without hesitation the proposal to change the name of the Delegation of the European Parliament for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by which it should long be its name, which was a Delegation for relations with Palestine.  I welcome the conclusion that this proposal, the result of a months-long campaign and advocated by my political group colleague Martina Anderson, chair of the delegation, has been endorsed by the majority of the Eurochamber. Although symbolic, this is a success in the struggle of the Palestinian people and the movement of solidarity with their legitimate cause. Following the recognition in 2013 by the United Nations General Assembly of Palestine as an observer state, I welcome the European Parliament's position in this direction with actions such as this change of name which I hope and wish to take a step further towards recognizing the full rights of the Palestinian people and state.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal because I feel that it is a more appropriate name for this parliamentary delegation, and represents a step, albeit extremely small, towards peace between Israel and the State of Palestine.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒By reading previous agreements with the Palestinian delegation, some groups within Parliament saw fit to propose a change in the name of the Palestinian Legislative Affairs Council. I find such a move one-sided and hasty. The European People's Party's Committee on Foreign Affairs did not have enough time to discuss the possible consequences of this decision in the dynamic world of foreign relations and interaction between countries.  Given the fragility of the situation in the Middle East, I think it is better not to make premature decisions. I do not accept this initiative and hope that such initiatives will be adopted in the future with the prior consent of all committees relevant to monitoring the situation.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The change of the name of the Delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to "Delegation for relations with Palestine" is also in line with the positive work produced by the Delegation. This development also underlines the status of the State of Palestine and supports the two-state solution as well as the creation of an independent Palestinian state. At the same time, such actions, even in their symbolic nature, send a message of solidarity to the Palestinians that their struggle has not been forgotten and that a large portion of the international community will be on their side until the final vindication. For these reasons we voted in favour of changing the name, a proposal which had also been put forward on the initiative of our own political group.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to "Delegation for Relations with Palestine"

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal because it reflects the common practice, including that used by the European External Action Service, and the change in the status of the Palestinian territories at the United Nations. At the same time, I consider the change to be of a very technical and practical nature. In my view, it in no way constitutes or symbolises the EU's full legal recognition of Palestinian statehood, which, in my opinion, can only take place under the framework of a comprehensive Middle East settlement, subject to appropriate conditions.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the requests that the name of the Delegation be changed from Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to Delegation for Relations with Palestine.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against this proposal for several reasons. Of the 28 Member States of the European Union, only 9 currently recognise the State of Palestine. As the Middle East peace process is one of the Union's priorities, any shift that could adversely affect that process should be avoided.  A change in name could destabilize an already extremely difficult and complicated situation, and destabilize Israel in mediation attempts. Also, the same could unintentionally give legitimacy to the terrorist organisation Hamas, which holds the Gaza Strip. Therefore, I consider it crucial for the EU to continue promoting and advocating for the peace process and for reconciliation within Palestine.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The decision to rename the delegation for relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council was to be 'Delegation for relations with Palestine' was not supported.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by Delegation for Relations with Palestine. We understand that the second version, "Relations with Palestine", does greater justice to the sense of what bilateral treaties have to be treated between equals and that podemos's declaration in favour of a Palestinian state has always been clear.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal to change the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council by Delegation for Relations with Palestine. We understand that the second version, "Relations with Palestine", does greater justice to the sense of what bilateral treaties have to be treated between equals and that podemos's declaration in favour of a Palestinian state has always been clear.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of normalizing the name that the Delegation of relations with Palestine should receive and to have the name it deserves as a political reality.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of changing the name of the Delegation for Relations with the Palestinian Legislative Council to the Delegation for Relations with Palestine. My positive vote is not only in accordance with my belief of the viability of the two-state solution, but also related to the everyday functioning of the Delegation in the European Parliament. This Delegation, akin to the Delegation for Relations with Israel, is a forum of dialogue and exchange with representatives of Palestine which should ultimately foster a mediated and balanced approach to solving the Israeli/Palestinian dispute. I believe therefore that this can be best achieved if the two delegations hold equal formal recognition in their inter-institutional relations with the European Parliament.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'Since Palestine was granted observer status by the United Nations in 2013, the European Commission, and together with the EEAS, switched to the use of the name Palestine. It is only natural for the European Parliament to use the same name.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament (EP) adopted a resolution supporting, in principle, the recognition of the Palestinian State and the solution of the coexistence of two States, believing that both sides should move alongside the deepening of peace negotiations, which should progress". Following this decision, and taking into account its decision of 12 March 2014 on the number of interparliamentary delegations, delegations to joint parliamentary committees and delegations to parliamentary cooperation committees and parliamentary assemblies, the EP decided that the Delegation for Relations with the Legislative Council of Palestine should be referred to as "Delegation for Relations with Palestine".

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her All in all, I would like to speak on all the fisheries applications. Normally, it is a win-win situation: it sounds good, we are making a partnership agreement and at the same time providing development aid. I voted in favour of the amendments, but I always feel unwell overall and would therefore like to ask the relevant committee not to let up in the necessary follow-up. We must, of course, see whether, firstly, there are really no more fish being fished than is possible, and secondly, of course, we must also look just as carefully at whether the money we then pay for them is really being put into development projects as we imagine. Not that it gets stuck somewhere in administration or in other channels. With this reference, I was able to vote in favour of the amendments. I think and hope that the follow-up, the follow-up to these amendments, is also in good hands in the relevant committee.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. Guinea-Bissau, after thirty-five years of agreements, remains mired in poverty and its fisheries sector remains unwrapped. The European Union uses its economic supremacy to impose agreements that actually benefit industrial fishing.  These agreements, in order to be carried out on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or set of states shears the resources of third parties. In considering that this is not the case and for the reasons set out herein, I have not been able to consent to this agreement.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This three-year fisheries partnership agreement relates to the financial consideration paid by EU Member States for their vessels to be allowed to fish in guinea-Bissau waters. It concerns 28 tuna seiners/longliners, 12 tuna canners, as well as several shrimp trawlers and freezers. Of these vessels, 15 are French. Overall, this is a good agreement for French fishermen and for Bissau-Guineans who have significant difficulties in combating illegal fishing. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose these agreements, which have a whiff of exploitation about them. We should not be paying developing countries to plunder their natural resources. I therefore voted against the agreement.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation, which aims to conclude a Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Guinea-Bissau. The first fisheries agreement with Guinea-Bissau was concluded in 1980 and has since been granted fishing opportunities in its waters by EU Member States. A number of protocols for the application of the Agreement were subsequently signed and the last Protocol was in force until 15 June 2012. The new EU-Guinea-Bissau agreement provides for a eur 9.2 million loan. The annual financial contribution of EUR 6,2 million was eur 6,2 million. access to the resources of the Guinea-Bissau economic zone and eur 3 million to support the development of the fishing sector in that country. I welcome the conclusion of this protocol because it is very important for both Guinea-Bissau and the European fleet fishing in the waters of this country. However, it is important to carry out a more detailed assessment of the future prospects of this agreement. A better link should be established between sector support under the Fisheries Agreement and development cooperation instruments. I agree with the need to improve the quantity and reliability of information on catches and the conservation situation of marine resources.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this win-win agreement over a three-year period. This fisheries agreement is in a way a development agreement that should contribute to the political stability of the country. In exchange for 9,200,000 euros per year, Guinea-Bissau will allow access to its territorial waters of European Union fishing vessels, including twelve tuna seiners and surface longliners as well as three French tuna caneers. In addition, each EU trawler must take sailors from Guinea-Bissau, which will allow as many people in Guinea-Bissau to live and work in their country.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted for the partnership agreement with Guinea-Bissau because of the importance of its trade relations with the fishermen of the European Union, but also because fishing ensures the survival of thousands of guinea-Bissau residents. The agreement also welcomes the improvement in the health situation on the ground and the positive development of the country since the presidential election in May 2014.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation aims to allow european union fishing vessels to enter Guinea-Bissau waters for a period of 3 years with financial counterparties. This agreement is essential for the stability of the country since it aims to combat illegal fishing (especially Chinese) and to reassess stocks... However, the country is suspected of trafficking in fishing licenses organized by ministers and diplomats in Guinea-Bissau in return for a real plunder in favor of the West that promotes migration.  Considering, however, that this is a balanced and beneficial agreement for both parties, I have decided to vote for it while remaining vigilant about its implementation.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in the Ferreira report with regard to the fisheries partnership agreement with Guinea-Bissau, and the rapporteur himself admits that there will be very little success with regard to the objectives of cooperation with the Republic of Guinea-Bissau in this area, which is precisely why I am opposed to allocating EUR 10 million to guinea-bissau.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This renewal is made possible by the EU's decision to normalise its relations with Guinea-Bissáu, following democratic elections in 2014. I welcome this renewal which guarantees the sustainability of fishing activity in accordance with the principles of the new CFP, allowing the Galician cephalopod fleet access to this fishing ground, which means its return to European agreements after its expulsion from Mauritania in 2012. Up to 16 vessels will be able to operate in Guinean waters, thus easiing their situation. It will also ensure the activity of 20 Huelva seafood vessels, 14 freezer sequeros and 9 ported pipes in Bermeo, all affected by the suspension of the Mauritanian Agreement. France, Italy, Greece and Portugal also have fishing opportunities. The Protocol will provide a disbursement of EUR 9.2 million per year, of which EUR 3 will be intended to strengthen Guinea-Bissa's fisheries sector and administration. I thank the Commission for speeding up the procedure for approving this agreement, which is also a sign of support for the new democratic government and will lead to a significant injection of liquidity for the guinea-Bissau administration. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of parliament's report expressing its support for the Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol between the European Community and the Republic of Guinea-Bissau in the fisheries sector. This Protocol fixes the fishing opportunities and financial contribution of both parties to the agreement in force.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that this partnership agreement with Guinea-Bissau can bring many benefits to both sides, allowing harmonious and sustainable development of the whole region.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The text put to the vote of Parliament aims to give a positive recommendation for the fisheries partnership agreement with Guinea-Bissau. Until June 2012, fishermen in the Member States had access to the country's territorial waters under an agreement reached in 1980. Since its ratification, this agreement has been renewed several times through various protocols. The agreement negotiated by the Commission on behalf of the Member States is a continuation of this partnership. The agreement will have a positive impact on the development of Guinea-Bissau's economy, as well as for French fishermen who will have the right to exploit Guinea's marine resources within the limit of 12 surface seiner and longliner tuna and three tuna canners. This agreement is for three years. The agreement is beneficial to both parties, so I voted for this recommendation.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Guinea-Bissau is currently one of the poorest countries with one of the lowest PER GDPs per capita in the world. The state economy relies heavily on fisheries resources, so food dependence on fishing occupies a significant place. Since 2014, the European Union has resumed cooperation with Guinea-Bissau, at which point negotiations on the Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement have also been relaunched. With the suspension of negotiations with Mauritania, the Eu-Guinea-Bissau Fisheries Agreement has become of increased importance and can even be considered one of the most important fisheries agreements, allowing access to mixed fishing areas. I voted in favour of this recommendation, which will enable EU vessels to fish in Guinea-Bissau's exclusive economic zone, within the limits of the available surplus, with a view to developing local industry in this sector and developing the country's economy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement would cost the EU coffers almost EUR 10 million, 3 of which would be directly aimed at the development of their local fisheries. Given that access to fish stocks is not significant for our operators and given the very poor results, also accepted by the rapporteur, on the objectives of cooperation with that country, I voted against.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The coup d'état in Guinea Bissau in 2012 led to the suspension of negotiations on the fisheries agreement. Since the holding of elections in May 2014, the resumption of negotiations has led to the signing of a new protocol to the agreement in November 2014. This new protocol provides fishing opportunities for 28 seiner and longliner tuna and 12 canners. The financial consideration allows access to the waters and the sustainable development of artisanal fishing in Guinea-Bissau. Parliament wishes to be the recipient of the minutes of the joint committee meetings which allow the management of the use of the financial consideration for the development of the fishing sector.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial compensation provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Guinea-Bissau.
