EU-flagged vessels must fish in accordance with the objectives of the common fisheries policy, comply with international and local legislation, and last but not least, they must carry out this activity in accordance with the principle of sustainability. I therefore support the provision in this report that the European Commission must ensure compliance with all our values and objectives, while at the same time requiring the Joint Committee to take the necessary measures when and if necessary.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I support the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Cape Verde. Sustainable fishing is an important step for economic development.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the fisheries protocol signed between the EU and the Republic of Cape Verde, which allows 71 European vessels to fish in Cape Verde's territorial waters in exchange for a financial consideration of EUR 3,300,000.  Although the latest protocol provides for measures to strengthen monitoring of exploitation and sectoral support for development, I consider that the investments to support the development of Cape Verde's fishing activities are far from sufficient to justify such looting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The document concerns the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial contribution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have ascertained the importance of the partnership between the EU and the Republic of Cape Verde in fisheries and the need for the conclusion of a relevant protocol. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and confirm my vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The new Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde on the fortification of fishing opportunities will provide a framework for fishing activities and will in particular allow ship owners to continue to obtain fishing authorisations in the waters of the territory of the Republic of Cape Verde. Together with the Partnership Agreement, it will also contribute to better management and conservation of fish resources through financial support from programmes adopted at national level.  In addition, one of the objectives of the Agreement is to strengthen cooperation between the Republic of Cape Verde and the European Union in promoting a sustainable fishing policy and rational exploitation of fishing resources in the fishing zone of the Republic of Cape Verde. I support the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with the Republic of Cape Verde, just as I supported the Protocol supporting it. I believe that these two documents will greatly contribute to the protection of fishing resources, the protection of fishermen and the creation of a sustainable fishing policy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. In support of the recommendation, I obviously support the text it accompanies and I therefore vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the report containing the proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde on the identification of fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde. I agree with the view that this is a Benefit Agreement for both parties that provides access to and sustainable exploitation of fish resources.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. As part of promoting cooperation with third countries in the area of fisheries, I voted for the protocol renewing the application of the partnership agreement in this sector with Cape Verde. This agreement is strategic as it ensures fishing opportunities for European vessels and strengthens trade and political links between the EU and Cape Verde.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Fisheries Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde is intended to strengthen cooperation between the parties by laying the groundwork for the development of a sustainable and responsible fisheries policy in Cape Verde, both from an environmental and socio-economic point of view. In this context, it is important to stress the importance of the new monitoring mechanism envisaged by the Parties in order to ensure compliance with shark catch thresholds. It should also be noted that Parliament is concerned about ensuring monitoring of the implementation of the Protocol, in particular with regard to sectoral support, as well as the monitoring of all fishing activities in the region, including those carried out in the context of support programmes initiated by other development partners. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I welcome the signing of this Protocol, which will benefit 30 longline vessels, 28 freezer tuna setters and 13 tuna pipers from France, Portugal and Spain. In particular, it will benefit 22 Galician longline vessels, 16 freezer tuna setters with base port in the Basque Country and Galicia, and 7 tuna boats with port in the Basque Country. This is therefore good news for the Spanish and European fishing fleet, ensuring the sustainability of fishing activity in accordance with the principles of the new CFP.  This new protocol covers a period of 4 years and offers fishing opportunities to 71 EU vessels in the field of tunids for a reference catch of 5,000 tonnes/year in accordance with a financial contribution of around half a million euros per year, half aimed at promoting sustainable fishing, including strengthening their Cape Verde monitoring and control capabilities and supporting their local fishing communities. It is regrettable that the activity has been interrupted between 31 August and 1 January with particular damage to the Spanish longline fleet. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. Since it respects the sustainable fishing criteria. It takes into account development reports for the region.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. These agreements do not serve to support the development of third-country fisheries sectors, but to buy from governments to keep things as they are. In the not being able to develop their own fishing sector, these countries have surpluses that we fish for. Meanwhile, artisanal and inshore fishing in the EU is being progressively dismantled by European Union and our government policies. These agreements, in order to be on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or group of States disarms the resources of third parties. It is important to give an in-depth social debate about what these agreements really mean, both for the populations of third countries and for the European productive sectors. For the reasons set out here, I voted abstention.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 As highlighted by today's report, I am pleased that this new Fisheries Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde is being adopted in accordance with the sustainability measures provided for in the new Common Fisheries Policy, both from an environmental and socio-economic point of view. I am concerned in particular about the level of uncertainty of the impact of fisheries on shark populations, but I think the provisions of the Protocol for this subject to be studied in detail seem to me to be correct. In addition to the report, the amendment to the proposal for a report, which reinforces concern about shark populations, has had my support.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because not only will it bring about enhanced cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Cape Verde, but it will also give way to a responsible use of the resources in the fishing zone of this country. Furthermore, this agreement will make it possible – or at least easier – to meet the needs of Cape Verde more effectively: in particular, its fight against illegal, unreported and/or under-regulated fishing.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution hearing the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Cape Verde, as this agreement will offer the possibility for 71 EU vessels to fish in Cape Verde's waters.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because the new Protocol will provide a framework and conditions for the fishing activities of European fleets and ships and will enable European fishermen and boat owners to continue fishing on Cape Verde. The Protocol will also contribute to better management and conservation of fish sources, in particular through financial support.  Also, one of the goals of the new Protocol is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Cape Verde and their joint development, but also policies that will lead to rational exploitation of fish resources in the Fishing Zone of Cape Verde. This Protocol will also help to better protect sharks that will make the European Union involundate with its developed science in this field, in order to help its partners on Cape Verde in this regard.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as this new agreement ought to make it possible to meet more effectively the needs of Cape Verde in its fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing by stepping up monitoring and surveillance within its exclusive economic zone, by improving the management of fishery resources, by supporting dialogue with all stakeholders, as well as regional and international cooperation, by improving the health quality of fishery products and by fostering the development of non-industrial fishing.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report with a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Cape Verde. We need better projects, more transparent fisheries monitoring and a more effective fight against illegal fishing. We must also ensure the safety and security of local fishermen and much-needed education and training. The key here, however, is the control, which must be very thorough in order not to lead to excessive fishing.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national and economic interests. This agreement harms the interests of our country because it will reduce fishing in our country because catches from third countries acquired at a much lower cost will be promoted. Furthermore, this Agreement does not in fact combat reckless fishing of sharks in this area.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 As I said, fishing is one of the significant economic activities of the European Union and the Member States.  One of the countries near the EU territories that provides the conditions for fisheries cooperation is Cape Verde. The Partnership Agreement with Cape Verde on fisheries was concluded in 2007 and operated until the end of 2014. A provisional agreement is currently in force, which needs our approval. The agreement will regulate, inter alia, shark fishing quotas, ensuring a quantity that does not endanger ocean biodiversity, but also a consistent annual financial contribution to Cape Verde, amounting to half a million euros, which will enable the country to effectively fight illegal fishing and develop legal fishing.  For these reasons, I believe that it is necessary to adopt this agreement, which will support both sides and promote the Union's fisheries interests in a sustainable manner.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the new EU-Cape Verde fisheries partnership agreement and voted in favour of this report. By this vote I also called on the Commission to seek guarantees that fishery in this area is exploited in a sustainable and responsible way.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report identifying fishing opportunities and the financial contribution between the European Union and Cape Verde. I support the conclusion of a protocol that introduces, inter alia, a close monitoring mechanism based on the quarterly exchange of shark catch data to ensure sustainable resource exploitation.  I believe that this agreement was adopted in accordance with the sustainability measures of the new Common Fisheries Policy and the environmental and socio-economic aspect. While research has shown that the exploitation of some shark species, which make up the bulk of total catches, is within safe biological limits, I support the call for assurance that this fishing will take place sustainably and responsiblely. In view of the fisheries agreement signed between the European Commission and Cape Verde, I think it is appropriate to monitor all fishing activities in the region, including those that may not comply with European fisheries policy, in order to ensure that all actors are informed and that the European Union is informed of all activities before the next extension of the agreement.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. As this is about strengthening relations between the European Union and Cape Verde, I supported the recommendation in a coherent manner. The Recommendation proposes better management and conservation of fisheries resources through financial assistance from the European Union to create long-term country-specific plans. Because it is extremely important to plan for the sustainable depletion of marine resources, and because we need to strengthen relations between countries.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. Since it respects the sustainable fishing criteria. It takes into account development reports for the region.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Agreement advantageous to both parties, especially since Cape Verde is unable to combat illegal fishing. I am voting for the adoption of this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. Since it respects the sustainable fishing criteria. It takes into account development reports for the region.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Because of the new provisions on sharks, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. As well as providing for the draft Council Decision, Parliament needs to approve the signing of this Protocol in order, on the one hand, to grant fishing opportunities to European vessels and, on the other hand, to increase cooperation between the EU and Guinea-Bissau through the Partnership Agreement. To do so, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement provides for financial consideration paid for access to that country's resources but also to support the development of the fisheries sector. It provides for fishing opportunities for the EU fleet. The economy of this country depends heavily on agriculture. In this sense, productive diversification is one of the challenges facing the country. Artisanal fishing, including subsistence fishing, ensures the survival of many fishing families (figures vary according to estimates). However, we accompany the rapporteur on the need for an assessment and will consider more detailed this Agreement, its history and future prospects, in particular in terms of sectoral support.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between Cape Verde and the EU, as the report emphasises both very positively the environmental sustainability measures and does not neglect the socio-economic view. In my opinion, both parties can benefit greatly from each other.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report together with my colleagues from my group, the ECR. The fisheries agreement between the EU and the Cape Verde Islands greatly expands fishing opportunities. The agreement also provides financial support to the Cape Verde Islands and includes the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The agreement also guarantees the conservation and sustainable use of fisheries and partnerships between companies and organisations developing economic activities in the fisheries sector. As a result, the cape Verde-based fishery will benefit.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, to my mind there is something more than a little exploitative about these fisheries agreements: we effectively pay very poor countries to allow us to plunder and fish their natural resources. Madagascar, in particular, in the Indian Ocean has a unique ecology: it has flora and fauna which are so varied from geological origins. This situation needs very careful treatment and protection, and I do not think that this agreement is necessarily what the people of Madagascar need.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. These agreements do not serve to support the development of third-country fisheries sectors, but to buy from governments to keep things as they are. In the not being able to develop their own fishing sector, these countries have surpluses that we fish for. Meanwhile, artisanal and inshore fishing in the EU is being progressively dismantled by European Union and our government policies. These agreements, in order to be on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or set of states disarms the resources of third parties. It is important to give an in-depth social debate about what these agreements really mean, both for the populations of third countries and for the European productive sectors. For the reasons set out here, I voted abstention.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This four-year partnership agreement in the fishing sector with Madagascar on the possibility of fishing and the financial consideration allows fishing vessels from EU Member States to enter Malagasy waters. It concerns 40 tuna seiners, 54 surface longliners. Although shipowners will pay a larger share (40% versus 25% previously), this agreement is interesting for European shipowners, and in particular for the French and for the Malagasy, whom shipowners will have to encourage in hiring. So I voted for it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to conclude a Protocol to the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar. It lists the target species, the estimated value of the fish, the amounts to be invested and the total return on investment expected, the observer programme to be carried out alongside fishing activities, lists the vulnerable and protected species, defines guidelines which should encourage detailed scientific monitoring, including the possibility of conducting experimental fisheries. I support the proposals that methods and technologies should be defined in order to preserve vulnerable species.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this win-win agreement. It is in the interests of our Member States in general, and France in particular.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted for this new protocol in the fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar, which includes funding for a fisheries observation programme in Madagascar, because of the importance of this sector to the Malagasy economy but also to European fishermen.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to the fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar: fishing opportunities and financial consideration. It is to allow eu fishing vessels to access Malagasy waters in return for 6.1 million euros in financial aid. This agreement is a step in the right direction since shipowners pay a little more than in the previous agreement, i.e. 40% instead of 25%, and among European shipowners who fish in the Madagascar EEZ, it is the Spanish and the French who benefit the most. Finally, European shipowners fish more than 20 nautical miles from the coast so as not to interfere with small-scale Malagasy artisanal fishing, unlike Chinese or Japanese shipowners who do not always follow the rules. However, in the future, shipowners will have to be put to greater use. On the other hand, I believe that the Union should instead demand the hiring of more local fishermen, promote a better fight against illegal fishing and monitor the application of the criteria requested if we really want to improve the situation on the ground. I have therefore decided to vote for this agreement while remaining vigilant as a member of the EU-Madagascar friendship group.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While a good technical agreement is a good agreement, the uncertain coverage of controls on the activities of EU fleets, together with a complete absence of an assessment of the real economic benefits of an investment of over 6 million euros over 4 years in favor of Madagascar, led me to opt for a vote of abstention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Protocol is part of the EU's network of tuna fishing agreements in the Indian Ocean and mainly benefits vessels from France, Italy and Portugal and about 40 Spanish vessels, several of them from my Community. It covers a period of 4 years until the end of 2018, for reference catches of 15 750 tonnes/year in accordance with a total financial contribution of just over EUR 6 million, of which about half will go to support Madagascar's fisheries sector. The amount to be added to the disbursements of European shipowners, which can amount to 4 million. The agreement complies with the principles of the new CFP, ensuring the sustainability of fishing activity and improving fleet control standards. Among the improvements achieved is the 25% increase in the quota allocated to the European longline shark catch fleet, of which almost all of spain's 18 longline vessels are Galicians. It also allows to give stability to the European fleet in the Indian for a longer period of time, going from 2 to 4 years.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which Parliament expresses its support for the Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol between the European Community and the Republic of Madagascar in the fisheries sector. This Protocol fixes the fishing opportunities and financial contribution of both parties to the agreement in force.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this recommendation, which gives the possibility to fish for EU vessels in the Madagascar fishing zone, in line with management measures. This support meets the objectives of the national fishing policy, in particular the needs of Madagascar in the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that this partnership agreement with Madagascar can bring many benefits to both parties, allowing harmonious and sustainable development of the whole region.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The text put to the vote of Parliament aims to give a positive recommendation for the fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar. Given that European fishing vessels will benefit from access to Malagasy waters and that the French and Spaniards are the ones who fish the most in Madagascar's exclusive economic zone, I find this agreement advantageous for France. In addition, from a formal point of view, the partnership agreement is very well prepared: it specifies the target species, the expected value of the catch, the amounts to be invested and the profit forecasts. In addition, it proposes an observation program to monitor fishing activity and mentions vulnerable and protected species. So I voted to adopt this agreement.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 In return for the use of this fishing zone, the European Union will finance madagascar's fisheries sector for an amount of EUR 700 000 per year, with a further general counterpart of approximately EUR 866 250 in the first two years and EUR 787 500 in the last two years of the agreement. In total, the Agreement provides for a counterpart of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar during the four years of validity of this Partnership Agreement. Although, at a technical level, it is a good agreement, it should be noted that there is little coverage of controls on the activities of EU fleets and that there is a total lack of assessment of the real economic benefits of sector-specific investment (which is unfortunately absent from almost all non-EU fisheries agreements). Abstention vote.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. This sustainable fisheries agreement has been in effect provisionally since 1 January 2015. The protocol to this agreement allows 40 seiner tuna and 54 surface longliners from the European Union to have access to Malagasy waters. This new protocol has been improved to include VMS tracking and electronic capture data reporting. It contains clauses for reviewing and denouncing agreements in the event of non-compliance with commitments made in the fight against illegal, undeclared and unreglected fishing.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial compensation provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community. This is an agreement that offers the possibility of fishing to about one hundred fishing vessels, and which was reached only after numerous working meetings between the partners concerned, requiring a lot of information from the various analysis documents requested by the European Union. The text specifies not only the target species, the quantities of fish expected, the amounts to be invested and the generic profits that can be derived from the various operations, but reference has been made specifically to the observation programme that will accompany the activities, listing vulnerable and protected species and defining the guidelines underlying detailed scientific control, including the possibility of carrying out experimental fishing activities.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ It must be noted that the agreement is much  better than previous ones on how close EU-vessels are allowed to fish (further out than before), it takes account of the new, mostly good, EU policy on sustainable fishing and gives higher  financial compensation/payment as well as better help to local fishery communities. However, while there were some positive aspects to this report, nevertheless, local fishermen will still not get the brunt of the benefits of this agreement and some of the local fishermen groups have been very negative (others more positive though). It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Madagascar in the Indian Ocean has a unique ecology, flora and fauna.  Accordingly, I believe that it is essential that special protection should be given. This fairly standard agreement allows 94 vessels to plunder Madagascan waters, and quite frankly, is the exact opposite of what this delicate eco structure requires.   Hence, I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of this Protocol as it ensures to develop cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Madagascar which will help to promote sustainable fisheries policy. The Protocol also outlines the observation program aiming to protect species. Moreover, the agreement will be beneficial to the EU market as well as plans to provide quality fish products and develop a partnership framework between EU vessels and local fishing vessels.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of the Protocol to the Agreement is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Madagascar with a view to establishing a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Madagascar's fishing zone, in the interests of both parties. Not finding any particular objections and problems, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement because it allows fishing vessels in the European Union to access Madagascar's territorial waters. It should be noted that among the European shipowners who fish in the Madagascar EEZ are also French shipowners. As for European shipowners, they fish more than twenty nautical miles from the coast, which does not harm Madagascar's artisanal fishing.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community. Madagascar's economy is mainly based on agriculture, livestock farming and fisheries. Fisheries resources shall be used for local consumption and shall form the basis of international agreements under which this Fisheries Partnership Agreement forms part. The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar is based on the rules established on the basis of the management mandate of the Indian Ocean Tuna Management Committee and other internationally accepted rules.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of a fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar. The agreement includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels and the capture of 15 750 tonnes of fish in the waters of Madagascar's exclusive economic zone. In return for the use of this fishing zone, the EU will finance madagascar's fisheries sector to the amount of EUR 700 000 per year, with an additional general counterpart of around EUR 866 250 in the first two years and EUR 787 500 in the last two years of the agreement. In total, the Agreement provides for a counterpart of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar during the four years of validity of this Partnership Agreement.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that this is a good agreement for fisheries, including the target species, the quantities of fish expected, the amounts to be invested and the general profits hoped for. The key point of the agreement is the observation programme to accompany the activity, which mentions vulnerable and protected species and sets out general guidelines that should encourage detailed scientific monitoring. Finally, I believe it is necessary to define methods and technologies to protect vulnerable species, in particular sea turtles, cetaceans and seabirds. Madagascar is an island country and its economy is mainly based on agriculture, livestock farming and fishing, where fish resources are used for local consumption. The main objective of the Union is to increase the autonomy of the partner countries in the fisheries sector and to contribute to the fight against undeclared and regulated illegal fishing, and I agree.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar is the result of the interest of the EU, the Government of the Republic of Madagascar and the shipowners. I support the new fisheries protocol between the EU and Madagascar, provisionally implemented since 1 January, will last for four years and include opportunities for 94 vessels from Spain, France, Italy and Portugal. In return for the use of this fishing area, the European Union will finance the fishing sector of the Republic of Madagascar by approximately EUR 6 107 500 during the term of this Protocol. The Commission should verify the fairness of the protocol, including the sharing of benefits generated by European shipowners.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the renewal of the Partnership Agreement is an opportunity to strengthen trade cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar. In addition, the reaffirmation of a fisheries partnership provides for the establishment of management and monitoring bodies as necessary instruments to combat illegal fishing and ensure compliance with the relevant measures taken by the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (IOTC). I voted in favour of the agreement because I believe in the importance of responsible exploitation of fishery resources, in order to promote economic growth in the sector, ensuring the sustainability and transparency of fishing activities. Proper and controlled management of the supply chain would help to ensure certified quality food products for the European market. These requirements for good governance are consistent with the European objectives on development cooperation and the common fisheries policy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement as it augments cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Madagascar. The recommendations put forward in this Fisheries Partnership Agreement will assist both the EU and Madagascar in meeting the objectives of the development of a sustainable fisheries policy in the interest of both parties. The agreement puts forward a proposal for monitoring processes and developing future guidelines for possible experimental and sustainable fishing.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. These agreements do not serve to support the development of third-country fisheries sectors, but to buy from governments to keep things as they are. In the not being able to develop their own fishing sector, these countries have surpluses that we fish for.  Meanwhile, artisanal and inshore fishing in the EU is being progressively dismantled by European Union and our government policies. These agreements, in order to be on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or set of states disarms the resources of third parties. It is important to give an in-depth social debate about what these agreements really mean, both for the populations of third countries and for the European productive sectors. For the reasons set out here, I voted abstention.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The protocol and agreement is being established due to the new regulation governing the Common Fisheries Policy, which places emphasis on sustainable fisheries and good governance. The partnership arrangements under the agreement are intended to promote the responsible exploitation of Madagascar’s fishery resources, providing an opportunity to boost economic growth, improve the human rights situation and conditions for workers. The rapporteur regards the agreement as an opportunity for the EU to encourage Madagascar to abide by human rights, democratic principles, the rule of law and good governance. Hence I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the adoption of a Memorandum of Understanding offering European vessels the opportunity to fish in the fishing area of the Republic of Madagascar. The aim is to strengthen cooperation between the EU and Madagascar in order to create a partnership for a sustainable fisheries policy. The protocol provides for fishing opportunities in several areas, the financial contribution to come for the next two years and beyond. Finally, it meets the objectives of national fisheries policy, and in particular in the fight against illegal fishing. In favour of this win-win partnership benefiting both the European fishing sector and the development of a third country, I voted for this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This agreement with Madagascar will allow European fishermen to expand their fishing territory, while respecting the environment. It is also essential to take action to combat any form of illegal fishing. So I voted in favour of this protocol.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar includes the fishing opportunities for 94 vessels in the waters of the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Madagascar, in exchange for a counterpart of EUR 6,107,500 to be borne by the European Union. From a formal point of view, I believe that this is a good partnership agreement for the fisheries sector. This agreement, in fact, details the target species and the expected fish values, specifies the amounts to be invested and the expected generic profits, refers to the observation programme that will accompany the activity, mentions vulnerable and protected species and defines the general guidelines that should encourage scientific control.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of a Protocol amending the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Madagascar. It is also clear from the report on the new Protocol that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The proposed report seeks to accept a new fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar. Although the financial counterparties paid by shipowners are much greater than those defined in the previous agreement, it is an acceptable regulatory framework, notably guaranteeing a certain distance between the fishing areas of European vessels and the Malagasy coasts, thus allowing local fishing activities to develop. Convinced that this agreement will benefit both sides, I voted for this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national and economic interests. This agreement harms the interests of our country because it will reduce fishing in our country because catches from third countries acquired at a much lower cost will be promoted. Furthermore, this Agreement does not in fact combat reckless fishing of vulnerable species in this area.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The new fishing protocol between the EU and Madagascar, provisionally implemented since 1 January, lasts for four years and includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels (40 seine and 54 longliners of various sizes) from Spain, France, Italy and Portugal. The EU will finance madagascar's fishing sector by around €700,000 a year, in addition to a general consideration of around €866,250 in the first two years of the protocol and €787,500 in the last two years. In total, the agreement provides for the eu's €6 107 500 counterpart to Madagascar over the four years. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it benefits French and European companies in a balanced way.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought to promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national and economic interests. This agreement harms the interests of my country because it will cause fishing to be reduced in Greece, since catches from third countries acquired at much lower cost will be promoted. Furthermore, this Agreement does not in fact combat reckless fishing of vulnerable species in the area concerned. For these reasons, I am voting against it.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the implementation of the Fisheries partnership Agreements with Guinea Bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar, as they will provide fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the exclusive economic zones within the limits of the available surplus. They will grant support to the development of a good fisheries policy and grant EU vessels more fishing opportunities while respecting the environment. At the same time, they will help the development of a sustainable fisheries policy in those countries and promote the responsible exploitation of fishery resources. Those Protocols is of great importance from a financial perspective and for the country’s economy, in particular for the fisheries sector and the development of the local fisheries industry, and provides for enhanced scientific and administrative cooperation, while combating IUU fishing (Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated). Considering their importance for the partner countries and the EU fleets operating in these waters, I support their approval.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on a Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar: fishing opportunities and financial compensation, as I support the positions and proposals it contains in terms of a sustainable fisheries policy.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the Fisheries Partnership Agreements. They are of immense importance to the non-EU countries of Guinea-Bissau, Cape Verde and Madagascar, as the financial performance of the fisheries sector and hence their economic development is driven by the financial performance. The people living there are not themselves able to use their natural fish resources. For us, these agreements are equally important, as they allow the European fishing fleet to fish in the waters of the partner countries. This will strengthen cooperation between the EU and Madagascar.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this recommendation given the conclusion of the Protocol will help maintain fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the fishing zone of Madagascar and contribute to better management and conservation of fishery resources through financial support (sectoral support) for the implementation of programmes adopted at national level by the partner country, in particular as regards monitoring and combating illegal fishing. Under the Protocol, Madagascar is expected to continue to cooperate effectively with the EU particularly as regards the sustainable management of fishery resources and the fight against IUU fishing.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the fisheries partnership agreement between the EU and Madagascar as through these agreements a responsible fishing scheme can be achieved. This four year protocol grants fishing opportunities to EU vessels in the fishing waters of Madagascar in line with internationally accepted rules, develops the local fishing sector and encourages concrete measures to safeguard vulnerable species.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement allowing European vessels to fish in Malagasy waters. The agreement covers 40 tuna seiners and 54 longliners. The Republic of Madagascar will receive 1,566,250 euros per year for the first two years and 1,487,500 euros for the following two years.  These sums include support for the sector policy of 700,000 euros per year. This aid will enable the development of local fishing sectors. In this regard, rapporteur Ricardo Serrao Santos said that the recruitment of Malagasy sailors would increase and that processing activities on the island of Madagascar would be developed. The future will tell us whether these laudable goals will be achieved. Finally, I note that Madagascar having concluded fishing agreements with other countries, the presence of European fleets will also help to monitor the evolution of fish stocks in the region, and of course to combat illegal fishing.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report for both ecological and social reasons, including: The plan allows fishing for endangered species, as well as a significant number of species classified as threatened (albacore, tuna, Spanish mackerel, scratched needle, blue shark). Moreover, the plan does not contain any foresight on the preservation of seabirds, turtles and marine mammals, which often suffer horrific deaths. In addition, madagascar's population is one of the most impoverished in the world. Under the plan, European subsidized boats consume the fish on which they depend for their nutrition and survival. They give Madagascar's population an une equitable distribution, less money is provided (decreasing by more than 100,000 euros per year) while the EU benefits the most (reference tonnage increased by 750 tonnes). This is not a casual incident: Payments from the European Union to Madagascar have been gradually reduced since the 1980s. These contributions do not benefit the development of the country as the plan lacks measurable objectives on this.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Conclusion of the Protocol will help maintain fishing opportunities for vessels of the EU when in the fishing zone of Madagascar. Furthermore, the Protocol will contribute to better conservation and general management of fishery resources through sectoral, financial support for the implementation of programmes adopted at a national level by the partner country. Hence, I voted for this recommendation, and agree that this Protocol is a good agreement for the fisheries’ sector.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the recommendation of the Protocol concerned with the FPA between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community. As the protocol is an important part of a broader network of fisheries agreements with coastal states in the south-western part of the Indian Ocean and the partnership agreement provides for the employment of seamen from the Republic of Madagascar or ACP countries. Not to mention that the agreement sets out the broad lines for detailed scientific monitoring, including the possibility of carrying out experimental fishing campaigns.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. 'Fisheries agreements between the EU and developing countries are aimed at clearing the seas and oceans. European waters are vastly overfished. Even more fishing is devastating for biodiversity. Such policies harm not only animals, nature and the environment, but also the local population on earth. We just have to stop subsidized overfishing.  Trading another round of fisheries agreements is not going to remedy the EU's failing fisheries policy. Nor is it going to get the EU to get its faltering fishing fleet going. That is why I voted against the EU-Madagascar fisheries agreement.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report for both ecological and social reasons, including: The plan allows fishing for endangered species, as well as a significant number of species classified as threatened (albacore, tuna, Spanish mackerel, scratched needle, blue shark). Moreover, the plan does not contain any foresight on the preservation of seabirds, turtles and marine mammals, which often suffer horrific deaths. In addition, madagascar's population is one of the most impoverished in the world. Under the plan, European subsidized boats consume the fish on which they depend for their nutrition and survival. They give Madagascar's population an une equitable distribution, less money is provided (decreasing by more than EUR 100,000 per year) while the EU benefits the most (reference tonnage increased by 750 tonnes). This is not a casual incident: Payments from the European Union to Madagascar have been gradually reduced since the 1980s. These contributions do not benefit the development of the country as the plan lacks measurable objectives on this.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Madagascar, as this way gives consent for the conclusion of the Protocol and allows a number of European vessels to fish in the fishing zone of the Republic of Madagascar.  On the other hand, the European Union will finance the fishing sector of the Republic of Madagascar and thus achieve mutual benefit. It also identifies the possibility of detailed scientific monitoring, including experimental fishing campaigns. I believe, however, that such activities must primarily take into account the sustainable exploitation of marine or fishing resources, and pay particular attention to the conservation of biodiversity and the environment.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar on the possibility of fishing and the financial consideration aims to allow EU fishing vessels access to Malagasy waters. In practical terms, they are 40 tuna seiners, 54 surface longliners over a 4-year period. Although shipowners will pay a larger share (40% versus 25% previously), this agreement is interesting for Europeans, especially the French, who have a large share, and for the Malagasy, whom shipowners will have to encourage in hiring. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Memorandum of Understanding for Partnership in the Fisheries Sector with Madagascar, which is intended to regulate the fishing of European vessels in the waters of Madagascar and which sets a financial consideration. This Memorandum of Understanding is transparent, beneficial to both sides and is in line with better cooperation in the management of fisheries resources, which is why I welcome the positive vote of the European Parliament.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this relationship between the EU and Madagascar, which concludes a fisheries agreement between the two sides. This agreement will allow 94 fishing vessels access to Madagascar's territorial waters (including French fishing vessels). The financial consideration for Madagascar will be 6.1 million euros.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report as it sufficiently promotes the opportunities offered by European fisheries in these waters.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement, as it is good for the fisheries sector.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which provides for a counterpart of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar during the four years of validity of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. This agreement is in addition to the package of other fisheries agreements approved today, in accordance with the environmental and economic sustainability measures of the new common fisheries policy.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the Council's motion for a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community. The agreement allows fishing vessels from EU Member States to enter Malagasy waters. Shipowners will pay more than under the previous agreement, 40% instead of 25%. Madagascar is not benefiting from this agreement in terms of employment, but the situation will improve. Among the European shipowners who fish in Madagascar's exclusive economic zone, it is the Spanish and the French who take the lion's share.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. These agreements do not serve to support the development of third-country fisheries sectors, but to buy from governments to keep things as they are. In the not being able to develop their own fishing sector, these countries have surpluses that we fish for. Meanwhile, artisanal and inshore fishing in the EU is being progressively dismantled by European Union and our government policies. These agreements, in order to be on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or set of states disarms the resources of third parties. It is important to give an in-depth social debate about what these agreements really mean, both for the populations of third countries and for the European productive sectors. For the reasons set out here, I voted abstention.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. The common fisheries policy causes and cannot be supported by environmental disasters in the EU's seas and in the seas of third countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The economy of Madagascar, an island state in the Indian Ocean, is mainly based on agriculture, livestock farming and fisheries. Fish sources in Madagascar are the cornerstone of international treaties, and one of them is the Fisheries Partnership Agreement. The new draft Protocol was proposed on 19 June 2014, which aims to provide fishing opportunities for EU navigable facilities in Madagascar waters within permitted borders and enhance cooperation between the EU and Madagascar, creating a partnership that is the basis for the development of a sustainable fishing policy and exploitation of fish resources in madagascar's fishing zone. The total financial amount allocated to this Protocol is EUR 6.602 million for the period 2015-2018. I supported the report because it represents a quality agreement for the fishing sector. The protocol defines the target species, the expected value of the fish, the amounts of money invested and the expected return thereof. It also strengthens Madagascar's economic stability, reducing its need for international assistance while strengthening its fishing sector and local fishing industry.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation with Madagascar should take place, I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision concerning the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this partnership. As with previous issues, this agreement gives European fishing vessels access to Malagasy waters. The French (and The Spaniards) being the most present in this space, this is for us a positive development.  Another positive point is that European fishing will take place more than 20 nautical miles from the coast, which will not harm Madagascar's small-scale artisanal fishing.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ One of the biggest criticisms of the European Union fisheries partnership agreements is around the monitoring and evaluation of the benefits of specific investments in the sector. To counter this effect, fisheries partnership agreements should contain explicit and measurable targets and indicators to be evaluated at the end of them. Objectives such as increasing the autonomy of partner countries in the fisheries sector (e.g. increased numbers of local fishermen), a contribution to combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, and the implementation of monitoring programmes (e.g. VMS or AIS) are issues that should figure more prominently within the partnership agreements.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar: fishing opportunities and financial compensation. This agreement provides for the possibility for EU vessels to catch a quantity of fish of 15 750 tonnes against an economic contribution paid to the country, for a period of four years, the time of the agreement. I therefore consider it necessary to make an effort to monitor and assess the benefits of sector-specific investment.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported mr Santos' report because I believe that a strengthened policy of cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar is absolutely desirable. The possibility for Community countries to benefit from the fishing zone of the Republic of Madagascar, as well as the financing provided for in return, can only bring benefits to both parties.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In the European Parliament, we have given the go-ahead, as my support, to the new fisheries agreement with Madagascar. My support for the recommendation we make on this protocol, although we also hope that in the future the opinion of this House will be more accounted for when entering into such negotiations.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between Madagascar and the EU, as the report emphasises both very positively the environmental sustainability measures, such as the protection of endangered species, as well as the socio-economic view, as in the hiring of seafarers there, which in turn provides jobs for the region. In my opinion, both parties can benefit greatly from each other.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report approves a new fisheries agreement with Madagascar for 4 years to replace the 2013-2014 agreement. The protocol authorizes 94 European vessels in the waters of Madagascar's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) for catching 15,750 tonnes of fish per year. This unbalanced agreement provides for an increase in the EU's fishing capacity while reducing the financial counterparties for Madagascar compared to the previous agreement. I reject this logic of going fishing on the other side of the world without concern for local fisheries and without social and environmental guarantees. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar on the possibility of fishing and the financial consideration aims to allow EU fishing vessels access to Malagasy waters. In practical terms, they are 40 tuna seiners, 54 surface longliners over a 4-year period. Even if the shipowners will pay a larger share (40% and not 25% previously), this agreement is interesting for the Europeans, especially the French who have a large part, and for the Malagasy that the shipowners will have to favor when hiring. I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new tuna fishing protocol between the EU and Madagascar, provisionally applied since 1 January, lasts for four years and includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels (40 seine and 54 longliners of various sizes) from Spain, France, Italy and Portugal. The EU will finance madagascar's fishing sector by around €700,000 a year, in addition to a general consideration of around €866,250 in the first two years of the protocol and €787,500 in the last two years. In total, the agreement provides for the eu's €6 107 500 counterpart to Madagascar over the four years. I believe that this is a good protocol that will help madagascar's economy grow, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in support of the agreement. The Fishing Partnership Agreement between the EU and Madagascar is an important part of the growing EU fishing sector based out of the south-western portion of the Indian Ocean. The agreement will further our goals of sustainability for these vital resources, while still allowing development of the fishing sector to continue.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The development of fisheries, which is one of the key economic sectors of the island of Madagascar, is an essential instrument for its sustainable economic growth. The partnership under this agreement will promote the fight against stock waste, the creation of new opportunities for growth and employment in Madagascar's coastal regions, the transfer of autonomy and the decentralisation of decision-making in this sector. I welcome Parliament's approval of the Council for this agreement, which is an opportunity for the European Union to encourage Madagascar to make efforts to comply with the ACP-EU partnership agreement, in particular its Article 9 on human rights, democratic principles, the rule of law and the proper management of public affairs. This agreement will enable the hiring of local fishermen and promote fishing opportunities for catch processing in Madagascar. The agreement is an indispensable tool to enable Malagasy citizens and the people of neighbouring countries to benefit from the benefits of the gradual opening of markets and the tremendous added value of globalization in terms of development.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The conclusion of the Protocol will help maintain fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the fishing zone of Madagascar and contribute to better management and conservation of fishery resources through financial support (sectoral support) for the implementation of programmes adopted at national level by the partner country, in particular as regards monitoring and combating illegal fishing. Under the Protocol, Madagascar is expected to continue to cooperate effectively with the EU particularly as regards the sustainable management of fishery resources and the fight against IUU fishing. That is why I have voted in favour of the report on fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Fisheries Partnership Agreement offers fishing opportunities for 94 fishing vessels, with the aim of catching 15 750 tonnes of fish in the waters of the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Madagascar. In return for the use of the fishery, the European Union will finance Madagascar's fisheries sector by EUR 700 000 per year and will make a further general contribution of around EUR 866 250 in the first two years of the Agreement and EUR 787 500 in the second two years. The Agreement foresees a total contribution of EUR 6 107 500 to be made by the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar for the four-year period of the current Partnership Agreement. The rapporteur recommends the adoption of the proposal, but sees an opportunity for future further development of the forthcoming fisheries partnerships and proposes to do so. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose is to allow access to Malagasy waters to 40 tuna seiners, 32 longliners with a gauge greater than 100 GT and 22 surface longliners with a gauge of 100 GT of the European Union. The consideration represents more than 6 million euros in 4 years, which is up from the previous agreement. In addition, it is specified that shipowners will be encouraged to hire Malagasy sailors and land their catches in Madagascar for processing, and that boats will not fish within 20 nautical miles of the coast so as not to interfere with artisanal fishing.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar is based on the rules laid down under the management mandate of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission and other internationally accepted rules. I am voting in favour of this report, which includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels, 40 of which are siege and 54 longliners of various sizes. 15 750 tonnes of fish are expected to be caught in the waters of the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Madagascar.  I would also stress the European Union's counterpart for the use of this fishing area, by financing the fishing sector of the Republic of Madagascar by around EUR 700 000 per year and another general consideration of around EUR 866 250 in the first two years of the agreement and EUR 787 500 in the last two years of validity. In total, the agreement provides for the consideration of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar during the four years of this partnership agreement.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to the fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar. As with the recommendation on the partnership agreement with Cape Verde, it must allow eu fishing vessels to enter Malagasy waters in exchange for EUR 6.1 million in financial aid. This agreement is a step in the right direction since shipowners pay a little more than in the previous agreement, i.e. 40% instead of 25%, and among European shipowners who fish in the Madagascar EEZ, it is the Spanish and the French who benefit the most. Finally, European shipowners fish more than 20 nautical miles from the coast so as not to harm small-scale Malagasy artisanal fishing, unlike Chinese or Japanese shipowners, who do not always follow the rules. However, in the future, shipowners will have to be put to greater use. On the other hand, I believe that the EU should instead demand the hiring of more local fishermen, promote a better fight against illegal fishing and monitor the application of the criteria requested if we really want to improve the situation on the ground. I have therefore decided to vote for this agreement while remaining vigilant.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Generally speaking, this is a good partnership agreement for the fisheries sector. Sadly though, only planned monitoring through an observer programme only involves 10% of the European fleet. This is a low figure and it is important to make efforts to increase the coverage rate.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which approves the partnership between the European Union and Madagascar for the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the madagascar fishing area. It is about promoting sustainable fishing for the benefit of both parties. The agreement provides that EU vessels will be able to deploy 94 fishing vessels and catch 15,750 tonnes of fish in Madagascar's waters in exchange for more than 6 million euros in funding for Madagascar's fisheries. It provides for the recruitment of sailors from Madagascar on board the ships.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this recommendation regarding the partnership agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar that has arisen from the interest of both sides and also from vessel owners after several meetings between the parties. The partnership is intended to promote the responsible exploitation of Madagascar’s fishery resources, providing an opportunity to boost economic growth, improve the human rights situation and conditions for workers (and for women in particular) and eradicate illegal child labour in this area.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it presents in an objective way and supports the new Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Madagascar. It is very important for EU-flagged vessels that these new agreements with third countries are fair and provide access to important fish resources. The agreement, as also presented in the report, is fair and respects the objectives and principles of the new EU common fisheries policy. The agreement also requires EU-flagged vessels to be monitored to a certain extent and to employ a minimum number of fishermen from Madagascar or the region on board. By such provisions, together with the amounts to be paid by the EU to the Government of Madagascar, the agreement ensures both sustainable exploitation of fish resources in the region and a fair one.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I support the fisheries partnership agreement between the European Union and Madagascar. Sustainable fishing is an important step for economic development, which is still heavily based on the fisheries sector.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the fisheries agreement signed between the European Union and Madagascar, which provides for a fishing authorization for 94 European vessels in the waters of Madagascar's Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) for catching 15,750 tonnes of fish per year. I consider that this agreement does not offer satisfactory social and environmental guarantees in a country where civil society is facing a situation of great poverty and where fish reserves are populated by protected species. In addition, the agreement does not propose any explicit provision on the exclusion protection of marine mammals, seabirds or sea turtles.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The contract shall set out the species to be caught and the expected value of the fish, as well as the amounts to be invested and the estimated overall return. An observation programme is also provided, which must be accompanied by the activity, and lists vulnerable and protected species. The Agreement provides a general framework for the promotion of detailed research, including experimental fishing opportunities.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of this agreement, which will ensure responsible and sustainable fishing. It should be noted that the Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar is based on rules established on the basis of the management powers of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission and other international rules. This agreement will be of particular benefit to both parties. In line with the EU's ambition to support the development of national fisheries sectors in countries with which it cooperates, the agreement lays down vulnerable and protected species, defines guidelines that should encourage comprehensive scientific monitoring, including the possibility of experimental fishing, as well as the amounts to be invested and the total return on investment expected. It is important to ensure that the vast majority of the EU's financial contribution is allocated to support a sustainable national fisheries policy. In addition, the agreement establishes an observer programme to be carried out in close to fishing activities.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since I consider the fisheries partnership between the EU and the Republic of Madagascar to be important for the advantages enjoyed by both sides, I also consider it necessary to improve the rules of the sea protection of protected marine species (sea turtles, cetaceans, seabirds) in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Fishing has long been a source of profit for Madagascar, mainly tuna and prawns exported. Along the shores of Madagascar sail ships with European Union flags, of which there is a limited number for fishing. The Treaty seeks to conclude a Protocol setting out fishing opportunities and the financial contributions provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and Madagascar.   The partnership between Madagascar and the European Union has so far been successful, so its extension is beneficial for both sides. The main objective of the treaty is to achieve cooperation between the European Union and Madagascar by creating partnerships focusing on sustainable fisheries. This contract allows ships from Spain, Portugal, Italy and France to sail and fish on the shores of Madagascar and is part of a network of tuna hunting contracts.  It is very important to work on the development of sustainable fisheries and to provide financial assistance to Madagascar and therefore I support the extension of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between Madagascar and the European Union. Financial packages will also contribute to combating the ever-present illegal fishing. For all these reasons, I voted for this Treaty.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to the fisheries partnership agreement with Madagascar. As with the recommendation on the partnership agreement with Cape Verde, it must allow eu fishing vessels to enter Malagasy waters in exchange for EUR 6.1 million in financial aid. This agreement is a step in the right direction since shipowners pay a little more than in the previous agreement, i.e. 40% instead of 25%, and among European shipowners who fish in the Madagascar EEZ, it is the Spanish and the French who benefit the most. Finally, European shipowners fish more than 20 nautical miles from the coast so as not to harm small-scale Malagasy artisanal fishing, unlike Chinese or Japanese shipowners, who do not always follow the rules. However, in the future, shipowners will have to be put to greater use. On the other hand, I believe that the EU should instead demand the hiring of more local fishermen, promote a better fight against illegal fishing and monitor the application of the criteria requested if we really want to improve the situation on the ground. I have therefore decided to vote for this agreement while remaining vigilant.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol establishing fishing opportunities and the financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Madagascar. In particular, I support the provisions on the sustainable exploitation of fishing resources, as as many as 90% of plant and animal species are endemic, which is best evidenced by the exceptional value and level of biodiversity on this island, which we must treat responsibly.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar as well as my colleague Santos' report. One of the biggest criticisms of the European Union's fisheries agreements with other countries is a poor system of monitoring and evaluating the benefits of investments and a lack of measurable objectives.  The Agreement with Madagascar specifies the target species, the expected values of the fish caught, the amounts to be invested as well as the expected returns on investments, which makes it a good partnership agreement and refutes the aforementioned criticisms. The European Union will finance madagascar's fisheries sector with a budget of 6 107 500 euros over 4 years.  The primary objective of the Agreement is to provide fish fishing to EU vessels in the fishing zone of the Republic of Madagascar, in line with the measures adopted by the competent regional Fishing Management Organisation, i.e. the IOTC, and above all to improve cooperation between the European Union and Madagascar through the creation of a framework for the development of a sustainable fishing policy and the setting of measures for the exploitation of resources in madagascar's fishing zone for the benefit of both parties.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the approval of the protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and the financial consideration provided for by the fisheries partnership agreement between the Union and the Republic of Madagascar. This agreement respects the rules established under the management mandate of the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission to promote sustainable management and consumption of Madagascar's fishing resources.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels, 40 of which are siege and 54 longliners of various sizes. 15 750 tonnes of fish are expected to be caught in the waters of the Exclusive Economic Zone of the Republic of Madagascar. In return for the use of this fishing area, the European Union will finance the fishing sector of the Republic of Madagascar by around EUR 700,000 per year and another general consideration of around EUR 866 250 in the first two years of the agreement and EUR 787 500 in the last two years of validity.
