In total, the agreement provides for the consideration of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar during the four years of its validity.  Because I believe that it deserves a positive general assessment, while safeguarding the interests of the parties, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar, which sets out the fishing opportunities and the financial consideration provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Madagascar.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Some 20 fisheries partnership agreements have been concluded by the EU with countries in the South in recent years. They all have a common objective: financial and technical assistance to local fishermen in exchange for fishing rights for the European fleet. A concrete example is given this afternoon with the positive vote of the European Parliament on the fisheries agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community. For while the island of Madagascar is a huge territory, the fourth largest island in the world, its economy is poorly developed and diversified and relies above all on agriculture, livestock and fishing. European aid is therefore essential, amounting to more than 6 million euros for the four years of the partnership agreement' validity. In practice, it allows 94 vessels, including 40 seiners and 54 longliners, to fish up to 15,750 tonnes of fish in the waters of the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Madagascar. It is also important that this fisheries agreement contains a biodiversity component through monitoring of fishing activity and mention of vulnerable and protected species.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this Protocol is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and Madagascar with the establishment of a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fisheries resources in the Madagascar fishing area, in the interests of both parties. This is an opportunity to boost economic growth, improve the human rights situation and conditions of workers, especially women, and eradicate the illegal work of minors in this area.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This Protocol is part of the EU's network of tuna fishing agreements in the Indian Ocean and mainly benefits vessels from France, Italy and Portugal and about 40 Spanish vessels, several of them from my Community. It covers a period of 4 years until the end of 2018, for reference catches of 15,750 tones/year according to a total financial contribution of just over EUR 6 million, of which about half will go to support Madagascar's fisheries sector. The amount to be added to the disbursements of European shipowners, which can amount to 4 million. The agreement complies with the principles of the new CFP, ensuring the sustainability of fishing activity and improving fleet control standards.  Among the improvements achieved is the 25% increase in the quota allocated to the European longline shark catch fleet, of which of the 18 Spanish longline vessels almost all of them are Galicians. It also allows to give stability to the European fleet in the Indian for a longer period of time, going from 2 to 4 years.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. By adopting this report, the European Parliament approved the conclusion of the new EU-Madagascar Partnership Agreement. This agreement includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels from the Union (from Spain, France, Italy and Portugal): 40 seiners and 54 longliners of different sizes. It is planned to catch 15,750 tonnes of fish in the waters of the exclusive economic zone of the Republic of Madagascar. In total, the agreement provides for a 6.1 million euro consideration from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar over the four-year validity of the partnership agreement.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the Protocol of Agreement is to grant fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the fishing area of the Republic of Madagascar.  I believe that strengthening cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Madagascar, through the creation of a partnership framework, will allow the development of a sustainable fisheries policy, as well as the rational exploitation of fisheries resources, in the interests of both parties, as it specifies the target species, the expected value of the fish, the values to be invested and the expected overall return. The Protocol will also serve to develop the local fishing industry, in partnership with EU vessels and to provide the EU market with quality fish products The annual financial contribution is EUR 1 566 250 for each of the first two years of the Protocol and EUR 1 487 500 for each of the following two years. This support meets the objectives of national fisheries policy and, in particular, the needs of the Republic of Madagascar in the fight against illegal fishing. In that sense, and as in the other Agreements voted on today, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar, which provides for the fishing opportunities for 94 vessels and the catching of 15 750 tonnes of fish for four years. The agreement provides for a counterpart of EUR 6 107 500 from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar, to be expected to be ated over four years.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained as the agreement broadly appears to be acceptable, but is marred by the lack of a careful and objective assessment of the real economic benefits of the sector-specific investment.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report for both ecological and social reasons, including: The plan allows fishing for endangered species, as well as a significant number of species classified as threatened (albacore, tuna, Spanish mackerel, scratched needle, blue shark). Moreover, the plan does not contain any foresight on the preservation of seabirds, turtles and marine mammals, which often suffer horrific deaths. In addition, madagascar's population is one of the most impoverished in the world. Under the plan, European subsidized boats consume the fish on which they depend for their nutrition and survival. They give Madagascar's population an une equitable distribution, less money is provided (decreasing by more than EUR 100,000 per year) while the EU benefits the most (reference tonnage increased by 750 tonnes). This is not a casual incident: Payments from the European Union to Madagascar have been gradually reduced since the 1980s. These contributions do not benefit the development of the country as the plan lacks measurable objectives on this.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The fisheries agreements signed by the European Union with third countries, however much they are disguised as sustainability and mutually beneficial to both sides, remain the cover for further exposing the resources, in this case fisheries, of the countries with which they sign these agreements. These agreements do not serve to support the development of third-country fisheries sectors, but to buy from governments to keep things as they are. In the not being able to develop their own fishing sector, these countries have surpluses that we fish for. Meanwhile, artisanal and inshore fishing in the EU is being progressively dismantled by European Union and our government policies. These agreements, in order to be on an equal footing, must be based on justice, equity, sustainability and, in the case of agreements such as this one, to focus on the attainment of the food sovereignty of peoples, so that no State or set of states disarms the resources of third parties. It is important to give an in-depth social debate about what these agreements really mean, both for the populations of third countries and for the European productive sectors. For the reasons set out here, I voted abstention.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Madagascar because I believe that this is a great opportunity for cooperation, development and an instrument to strengthen bilateral relations between the EU and Madagascar. The agreement will last for four years and will have a budget of EUR 6 602 million. The overall objective is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and madagascar with a view to establishing a partnership framework for the development of a sustainable fisheries policy and the responsible exploitation of fishery resources in Madagascar's fishing zone, in the interests of both parties.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft recommendation, of which I was rapporteur, approves the conclusion of a Fisheries Protocol which opens up european union fishing opportunities in the Republic of Madagascar. This Partnership Protocol is based on the rules laid down by the relevant fisheries organisations and includes fishing opportunities for 94 vessels. More than 15,000 tonnes of fish are expected to be caught in the waters of madagascar's Exclusive Economic Zone. In return for the use of this area, the European Union will finance Madagascar and its fishing sector in particular by more than EUR 6 million over four years. This Protocol will have environmental concerns, including cessation of fishing in the event of excessive shark catch. Activities will be monitored both through an observer campaign and using remote tracking tools. Although not a perfect solution, given the poor coverage of the program, it will contribute to a better understanding of the fishery, populations of the target species and inventory of impacts on accessory species and habitats. I am convinced that the Fisheries Protocol with Madagascar can help to improve conditions in a country with enormous difficulties while benefiting European fleets.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The Conclusion of the Protocol will help maintain fishing opportunities for vessels of the EU when in the fishing zone of Madagascar. Furthermore, the Protocol will contribute to better conservation and general management of fishery resources through sectoral, financial support for the implementation of programmes adopted at a national level by the partner country. Hence, I voted for this recommendation, and agree that this Protocol is a good agreement for the fisheries’ sector.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution under the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar will offer the possibility for EU vessels to fish in the waters of the Republic of Madagascar, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because, among other things, this Protocol enhances relations between the European Union and Madagascar and their continued cooperation. This Protocol creates a framework for cooperation between the EU and Madagascar and develops a partnership.  The Protocol will enable the development of fisheries and fisheries policies. This Protocol will specifically assist Madagascar in the fight against illegal fisheries. The European Union will also help with its scientific achievements and knowledge in terms of better monitoring, developing local fisheries, and European citizens will have access to quality fish and marine products.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it is a good partnership agreement for the fisheries sector. However, I would have liked to see greater efforts made to increase the coverage rate of planned monitoring through an observer programme.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The fact is that the Madagascar area is away from the territory and territories of the European Union and it is therefore essential to clearly establish frameworks for cooperation and exploitation of surplus fishing potential. Among other things, due to the remoteness of the territory, it is essential to establish clear reliable reliable authorities to oversee the implementation of the decisions taken in this report as well as those taken in the Partnership Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and Madagascar, and primarily to establish a joint committee in order to properly oversee the work of any institutions that would function in the waters of Madagascar.  I support this report as it clearly underlines the importance of implementing Article 9 of the a partnership agreement on fisheries, which validly fulfils the above needs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol setting out the fishing opportunities and financial contribution provided for in the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between the Republic of Madagascar and the European Community on behalf of the European Union. It is very positive that the European Union concludes partnership agreements, but it also offers development assistance. I would like to point out that the committee responsible shall carry out all necessary controls, both in terms of the quantity of fish caught and as regards the financial contribution. Money must come from development projects and should not be lost on administrative costs.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought which promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national and economic interests. This agreement harms the interests of our country because it will reduce fishing in our country because catches from third countries acquired at a much lower cost will be promoted. Furthermore, this Agreement does not in fact combat reckless fishing of vulnerable species in this area.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Fisheries cooperation between the European Union and other States concerns not only maritime areas near the European continental area, but also certain areas close to island territorial units belonging to the Member States but located in other oceanic regions. One such example is cooperation with Madagascar, which concerns a maritime area in the Indian Ocean.  The Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar, concluded in 2007, expired at the end of 2014. A provisional protocol is currently in force, which needs the approval of the European Parliament. It shall comply with relevant international agreements, including the measures required by the Indian Ocean Tuna Resources Commission. The document also provides for a considerable annual Union financial contribution of around EUR 3 million for the first two years, which will help Madagascar, a fairly poor country, to combat illegal fishing and develop the fisheries sector in general. From this point of view, I believe that the current document must be adopted in order to cover the needs of both development parties in this area.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and approved the conclusion of the new partnership agreement between the EU and Madagascar. The agreement provides for total compensation of EUR 6.1 million from the European Union to the Republic of Madagascar over the four years that the partnership agreement will run.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ As shadow rapporteur, I supported this €6 6 602 million four-year agreement, which allows European Union vessels to fish in the waters of the Republic of Madagascar. I believe that this agreement will help strengthen bilateral relations and benefit both parties.  In particular, European Union countries such as France, Spain, Portugal and Italy will retain their tuna fishing licence in the area. Thus, this partnership agreement lists the exact target species and the expected value of the fish as well as the amount of funds invested and the expected return, which I consider to be extremely useful provisions because they encourage transparency. The benefit that Madagascar benefits from this agreement is primarily financial assistance, the consumption of which is determined for the purpose of developing fisheries. Some of the funds will be usable to combat illegal fishing, which is extremely important in the sustainable use of resources, and the contract also commits to improving local knowledge of fish stocks and developing a local fishing fleet, which is of great importance for a country whose economy is mainly based on agriculture, livestock farming and fisheries.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the recommendation because it proposes to strengthen relations for mutual benefit between the European Union and Madagasker. Whereas it further proposes better management and conservation of fisheries resources through financial assistance from the European Union to create long-term country-specific plans. At the same time, it is of the utmical importance to plan for the sustainable depletion of marine resources and to strengthen relations between the two countries.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report for both ecological and social reasons, including: The plan allows fishing for endangered species, as well as a significant number of species classified as threatened (albacore, tuna, Spanish mackerel, scratched needle, blue shark). Moreover, the plan does not contain any foresight on the preservation of seabirds, turtles and marine mammals, which often suffer horrific deaths. In addition, madagascar's population is one of the most impoverished in the world. Under the plan, European subsidized boats consume the fish on which they depend for their nutrition and survival. They give Madagascar's population an une equitable distribution, less money is provided (decreasing by more than EUR 100,000 per year) while the EU benefits the most (reference tonnage increased by 750 tonnes). This is not a casual incident: Payments from the European Union to Madagascar have been gradually reduced since the 1980s. These contributions do not benefit the development of the country as the plan lacks measurable objectives on this.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The shipowners pay a little more than under the previous agreement, i.e. 40% instead of 25%. Madagascar is not benefiting from this agreement in terms of employment but the situation will improve. Among the European shipowners who fish in the EEZ of Madagascar, it is the Spanish and the French who take the lion's share. European shipowners fish more than 20 nautical miles from the coast so as not to harm Madagascar's small-scale artisanal fishing. I vote for this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report for both ecological and social reasons, including: The plan allows fishing for endangered species, as well as a significant number of species classified as threatened (albacore, tuna, Spanish mackerel, scratched needle, blue shark). Moreover, the plan does not contain any foresight on the preservation of seabirds, turtles and marine mammals, which often suffer horrific deaths. In addition, madagascar's population is one of the most impoverished in the world. Under the plan, European subsidized boats consume the fish on which they depend for their nutrition and survival. They give Madagascar's population an une equitable distribution, less money is provided (decreasing by more than EUR 100,000 per year) while the EU benefits the most (reference tonnage increased by 750 tonnes). This is not a casual incident: Payments from the European Union to Madagascar have been gradually reduced since the 1980s. These contributions do not benefit the development of the country as the plan lacks measurable objectives on this.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive. Even though the restriction on fishing sharks could be improved, it is still an attempt by the COM and Madagascar to limit catches of sharks. Such a provision only exists in the Madagascar protocol (a provision in Cape Verde only has enhanced monitoring beyond a certain percentage of sharks in the total catch).

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an agreement whose main objective is to offer European Union vessels fishing opportunities in the fishing area of the Republic of Madagascar. Similarly, cooperation between the EU and Madagascar for better management of fisheries resources in the area is increased. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that Recommendation.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement provides for financial consideration paid for access to that country's resources but also to support the development of the fisheries sector. It provides for fishing opportunities for the EU fleet. The economy of this country depends heavily on agriculture. In this sense, productive diversification is one of the challenges facing the country. Artisanal fishing, including subsistence fishing, ensures the survival of many fishing families (figures vary according to estimates). However, we accompany the rapporteur on the need for an assessment and will consider more detailed this agreement, its history and future prospects, in particular in terms of sectoral support.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Fisheries Partnership Agreement between Madagascar and the EU, as the report emphasises both very positively the environmental sustainability measures, such as the protection of endangered species, as well as the socio-economic view, as in the hiring of seafarers there, which in turn provides jobs for the region. In my opinion, both parties can benefit greatly from each other.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The ECR Group and I voted in favour of the Fisheries Partnership Agreement with Madagascar (FPA), as it allows fishing opportunities for EU vessels in the waters of the Republic of Madagascar. France, Spain, Portugal and Italy will receive licences for tuna fishing under this agreement. The agreement also commits to increasing local knowledge on fish stocks, developing local fisheries policy and the fishing fleet. The agreement also includes a clause on human rights , in line with the Cotonou Agreement – and is seen by the Commission as a way of strengthening bilateral relations between the EU and Madagascar.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this agreement is to impose on poor countries the burden of facilitating imports, in order to open their markets to the production of rich countries and large multinational groups. Once again, the World Trade Organization is acting to strengthen inequalities in global trade: that is why I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This protocol amends the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organization and aims to facilitate trade. In other words, it is a matter of speeding up the customs clearance procedures of goods and assumes that they are less controlled. Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we believe that trade policy must remain within the purview of the sovereignty of States. We are very opposed to the lifting of customs barriers advocated in this text. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I support the agreement, but Britain should be signing it not the EU!  I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. There are still significant differences between the border procedures of developed and developing countries and the slowing down of trade due to poor infrastructure, inefficient customs management and excessive bureaucracy. The trade facilitation agreement and the trade liberalisation process aim to reduce trade costs in order to boost exports and economic activity. The new agreement should significantly reduce the cost and cost of trade of time, thereby helping businesses to develop and making use of new export opportunities for the least developed countries, and I therefore support its conclusion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this ultra-liberal recommendation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Trade Facilitation Agreement ("AFE") is of great importance to European trade, which accounts for 22% of the world's trade. I therefore voted in favour of this recommendation to amend the Marrakesh agreement to simplify and harmonize international trade procedures. This will facilitate the implementation of the EFA for developing countries through special and differentiated treatment, and will also enable technical assistance from developed countries in certain areas.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This recommendation is intended to endorse the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the WTO. This trade facilitation agreement continues the free-trade logic by speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods. The latter will be less controlled, especially in transit goods that will no longer be subject to control at all. In addition, it encourages the use of independent tribunals (as in TTIP) in the event of a conflict, paving the way for arbitration mechanisms that further put state sovereignty in the closet. Finally, while it provides differential treatment for developing countries, this agreement pushes these countries to free trade, which, on the face of experience, has had little track record. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The World Trade Organisation remains a body extremely far removed from the needs of our production system, very little has been done to protect our geographical indications and the origin marking of products, the changes made with this text have not made any improvements to protect our territories, which is why I did not support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting the adoption of the Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol Amending the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization. This will give approval to the Trade Facilitation Agreement, a historic milestone, as it is the first multilateral agreement reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995, and is a boost to the Doha Round negotiations to set the rules for international trade in the 21st century. The Agreement is part of the so-called "Bali package", which covers two other trade policy groups: proposals on trade in agricultural goods and a development chapter dedicated in particular to the least advanced countries. The Agreement, which aims to simplify customs procedures and reduce export costs, reducing unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and ensuring lower customs delays, will have an economic impact of around EUR 60 billion per year on world GDP. It also includes rules of transparency, devotes particular attention to SMEs and differential treatment to developing countries, for whom both transitional periods are envisaged and technical assistance to facilitate their implementation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, by which Parliament approves the Council decision amending the Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (Marrakesh Treaty). Parliament supports the conclusion of the agreement on the amendment of the Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Marrakech Convention aims to simplify customs clearance and thus trade in goods worldwide, with a view to serious cooperation between the customs authorities of each State Party. Significant economic benefits are expected from the Convention, in particular for developing countries and least developed countries. Trade facilitation measures can also bring significant facilitation to SMEs. The Agreement also has the capacity to recognise in an innovative way the different implementation capacities from one nation to another by calling on developing and least developed countries to determine when the specific provisions of the Agreement will be applied and by linking the implementation of some rules to assistance provided by developed nations. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support the report amending the Marrakesh Agreement. The agreement will contribute to both developed and developing countries. Of course, for the Agreement to become valid, it needs to be endorsed by two-thirds of WTO members, but I think the importance of this Agreement is great for developing countries.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement contains some basic provisions that will make it easier for goods to move across borders and to make trade flows smoother and more predictable.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report proposes to accept the Council's decision to facilitate trade through a gradual clearance of goods. Signatory states could benefit from a reduction in the cost of trade, ranging from 12.5% to 17.5%. Consumers would also benefit from lower prices due to increased competition. Finally, the text provides for the release of EUR 400 million over five years to finance the improvement of customs systems in developing and least developed countries.  We formally oppose any agreement to weaken tariffs. This process will strengthen unfair international competition between Member States and emerging countries. Indeed, these trade agreements will accelerate the relocation of our companies and aggravate the imbalances in our external accounts. On the other hand, cost reduction is likely to be offset by higher margins in supermarkets and will therefore not in fact result in lower consumer prices.  So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The last WTO Ministerial Conference, held in December 2013, made some changes to the agreement underlying this international body. It goes without saying that some of the changes are of some use, but my political position – which is clearly critical of the WTO – does not allow me to give a positive vote. Not only that: with the Treaty of Lisbon, the prerogatives of the Member States within the WTO have been considerably reduced and nothing has been improved in this respect with the protocol to vote today. The WTO remains, even with these changes, a body that is extremely far removed from the needs of our production system. Within the WTO, nothing or almost nothing has been proposed to protect our geographical indications and the origin marking of products. Although these changes (less bureaucracy, and streamlining procedures) are basically useful, my vote is still against. The multilateral negotiating round concluded at the end of 2013 could and should have produced more significant results.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The World Trade Organization (WTO) aims to regulate international trade. Through this organization, we have at our disposal a set of rules allowing the establishment of a global trade where fair competition between countries is normality.  In the globalized economy we now know, this instrument was particularly necessary. The Trade Facilitation Agreement is the first multilateral agreement concluded by the WTO since its inception. The aim of this agreement is to speed up the movement of goods and customs clearance around the world.  The agreement will benefit everyone and especially developing countries. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation.  The main aim of the agreement is to simplify and modernise customs procedures and regulations, both to facilitate the cross-border movement of goods and to make trade flows smoother and more predictable, and to create greater transparency and enhanced cooperation between customs authorities. Once it enters into force, we will have an increase in trade flows, more revenue from the collection of duties, a greater volume of trade and an increasingly efficient customs administration.  The removal of administrative obstacles should not only make trade easier, faster and cheaper, but should also help developing countries and their businesses to gain greater benefits from international trade, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which contained a number of upsetting provisions. The agreement concerned the extension of the scope of the competence of the World Trade Organisation to the issue of trade facilitation, mainly in favour of corporate and industrialised countries. It was for these reasons, amongst others that I tabled a negative vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I support the agreement, but Britain should be signing it not the EU! I therefore abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to amend the Protocol of Marrakesh Agreement establishing the WTO as required by the Treaties. I believe amending the Protocol of Marrakesh Agreement will significantly improve trade movement around the world especially for developing countries.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation aims to give a favourable opinion on a Council decision amending the Marrakesh Agreement, which created the World Trade Organisation in 1994. This protocol, which amends the agreement, includes references to the Trade Facilitation Agreement, concluded in 2013. It contains some forty measures designed to facilitate the movement of goods, touching on issues such as regulations, rules, procedures, electronic payments, customs formalities, documentation, transparency, and cooperation between customs authorities. I voted in favour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The Marrakesh agreement is one of the rare jewels in the Doha Developing Round Crown that the WTO Members have managed to deliver. It will be a vital tool towards modernising customs procedures, cutting red tape and capacity building, especially in the developing world. Agreed all the way back in December 2013, now is the time for the EU to ratify it.  Investment in trade is fundamental to boosting the growth and development of a country. By supporting trade, the EU has helped to lift millions of people out of poverty in the last decade and this should remain key to our development work. This agreement will continue to easier and cheaper for developing countries to take part in the global economy. This is why, I was pleased to vote in favour of both the Zalba reports today.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. The Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) is the first multilateral agreement concluded by the WTO since its inception and has as its main purpose the simplification and speeding up movement and customs clearance of goods worldwide. With this report, the European Parliament recognises the benefits that the implementation of the agreement will bring for developing countries through its contribution to a more welcoming environment for businesses, in particular SMEs; urges all WTO members to try to find a solution without further delay in the implementation of the Bali package in all its aspects, including the reduction of trade distortions represented by agricultural subsidies; fully supports the EU's initiative to allocate EUR 400 million in funding over five years to trade facilitation reforms and projects such as improving the customs systems of developing and least developed countries and, finally, calls for regular information on how to finance them to be provided to the European Parliament and the EU Member States.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement, by which the World Trade Organisation was established. I am convinced that the objective of simplifying and speeding up the movement and customs authorisation of goods around the world must be pursued to the full, and therefore of developing and extending cooperation between customs authorities so that the reduction of bureaucratic constraints does not result in less security due to loose controls. I am convinced that customs cooperation, once implemented, can bring significant benefits to traders around the world and also an acceleration to the global economy, as costs will fall as international trade grows. Finally, as trade facilitation will be particularly important for developing countries, the markets themselves will become more efficient.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Zalba Bidegain Report which approves the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) by the Council on behalf of the European Union and amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO). After a decade of negotiations concluded at the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference, this Agreement is the most important outcome of the Doha Development Round, the first Agreement since the creation of the WTO that makes the multilateral system capable of addressing the concerns of developing countries. I welcome the fact that this new Agreement will allow developing countries and least developed countries to categoin commitments and set a timetable for their implementation, linking the application of some disciplines to the provision of technical assistance and calls for joint action by donor countries and development aid providers (as well as developing countries and the least advanced countries that are part of the WTO) in order to support the latter in the implementation of some provisions of the agreement. I hope that the Agreement will be ratified quickly after the approval by 2/3 of the 160 WTO members who agreed to its conclusion in the Doha Declaration.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am fully in favour of concluding the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), as it will ensure significant benefits for operators around the world and foster global economic growth. In particular, it will help to reduce costs and increase trade for both the import and export markets, encouraging worldwide commercial investment. I support the way in which issues relating to the implementation of the Protocol in the least developed countries are to be addressed, in particular the adoption of special and differentiated treatment and technical and financial assistance, concrete support to bridge the disparities between the different capacities for implementing the provisions by WTO members. However, I believe it is crucial that capacity-building funding should be based on proper assessments of the real needs of each country, ensuring that the available assistance is allocated to nations that really need it. As a result, the implementation of the agreement, in particular by developing countries, will lead to harmonisation and simplification of trade-related procedures by promoting opportunities to spread the use of innovative technologies and electronic payment systems.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The objective of this agreement is to impose on poor countries the burden of facilitating imports, in order to open their markets to the production of rich countries and large multinational groups. Once again, the World Trade Organization is acting to reinforce inequalities in global trade: that is why I voted against

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ With this positive outcome the Parliament gave its consent to the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol Amending the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organisation. This new agreement is expected to significantly reduce the time and cost of trading, and thus help businesses in developing and least-developed countries to access new export opportunities. In the light of the above considerations, I voted in favour of this positive recommendation.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO), the European Union confirms its strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda. This is an important signal that the European Union will send to Nairobi next December, where the tenth WTO ministerial conference will take place. Indeed, the ratification of the trade facilitation agreement by the 160 WTO members will successfully close at least one of the chapters of the Bali package within the broader framework of the Doha Development Agenda, which has been deadlocked for too long. It is in bodies such as the WTO that we must reaffirm our will and ability to converge on common global rules so that we can arrive at fairer, freer and more open trade for all. For these reasons, I voted strongly in favour of the recommendation.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The european Parliament's motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation highlights the main changes and critical issues in world trade. In this context, it is important to stress that the agreement represents a great opportunity for all Member States with regard to the promotion of research and development, and the dissemination of innovative technologies in developing countries as well. In addition, this agreement is part of a broader strategy promoted by the Eu ropean Union to promote trade policies through funding to improve the customs systems of developing and least developed countries; In this context, some programmes for greater regional economic integration have become a crucial element in promoting trade between the Union and its main partners in North Africa and Eastern Europe. A further positive fact concerns the expected benefits that small and medium-sized enterprises will benefit from this agreement. I therefore vote in favour of this text, in order to promote agreements for a balanced promotion of trade with the Union's other trading partners.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Purpose of the Marrakech Agreement is to simplify customs clearance and thus trade in goods worldwide, with a view to serious cooperation between the customs authorities of each State Parties. The convention is expected to have economic benefits from the present, in particular for developing countries and least developed countries. Trade facilitation measures can also bring significant facilitation to SMEs. The Agreement is also capable of innovatively recogniseing the different implementation capacity from one nation to another by calling on developing and least developed countries to determine when the specific provisions of the Agreement will be applied and by linking the implementation of some rules to assistance provided by developed nations. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to amend the Marrakesh Agreement. As the comprehensive analysis has shown, the agreement in its new form will not only be beneficial to our economy, but will significantly improve our trading structures. Reducing trade costs is essential in competitive and politically challenging times like these. Furthermore, customs enforcement and compliance with rules and obligations are crucial for further improving trade.  The spread of illegal goods and content must be countered and hostile reactions of society must be avoided.  Especially for countries like my strong and strong trading system, it is vital. Non-ratification is therefore an obstacle to transparency, red tape removal, simplification of procedures and due diligence with regard to commitments.  But above all, we must jointly guarantee the free movement of goods and this would be hindered if the relevant act is not adopted.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, in theory to manage to their advantage. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement demonstrates that it can be innovative in recognizing the differences between the various countries in terms of application capacity, asking developing countries and the least developed countries to define when they will apply the specific provisions contained therein and by associating the application of some disciplines to the provision of technical assistance by developed countries. The provision of technical assistance by donor countries to developing and least developed countries through an assistance mechanism is an essential aspect of the Trade Facilitation Agreement.  The World Bank has set up a fund for middle-income countries and can shell out up to €30 million a year, of which a third comes from the EU. The EU has committed to disburse more than €400 million in the field of assistance over a five-year period. In addition, the World Bank and UNCUCED have also allocate funds for this purpose, alongside member states. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I am currently against any trade facilitation agreement.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The Trade Facilitation Agreement is an innovative agreement not only because it is the first multilateral agreement on new rules that has been concluded under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation since its establishment almost 20 years ago, but mainly because it allows developing and least developed countries to group commitments into categories and decide on the timeframe for their implementation, implementation in some areas linked to the provision of technical assistance , calls on donor countries, development aid providers and World Trade Organisation members from developing and least developed countries to take joint action to help these developing and least developed countries implement some of the provisions of the Agreement, not least including an expert group to assess the situation in the Member State after the end of the notified implementation periods. The agreement in question is clear evidence of an innovative approach to recognizing differences in the implementation capacity of individual countries.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the protocol. The WTO remains, even with these changes, a body that is extremely far removed from the needs of our production system and has always been far from our idea of standards for local and quality products.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, theoretically to manage for their benefit. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond. For the above reasons, my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Once implemented, the Agreement should increase trade flows, expand duty collection revenue as a result of higher trade volume and better detection of fraud, and improve the efficiency of customs administrations. Transparency and automation measures will help to deal with border corruption. The OECD has estimated that implementing all the measures foreseen in the TFA would reduce total trade costs by 13-15.5% in developing countries, the potential benefits by far outweighing the mostly limited costs. Along with making it easier, faster and cheaper to trade, removing administrative hurdles should also help developing countries and their businesses, including SMEs, to better integrate in regional and global value chains, and thus to reap greater benefits from international trade.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report containing a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. The European Union has always worked to manage its trade policies in a coherent manner and to make trade free, fair and open; I therefore believe that the World Trade Organisation is the most fertile ground for promoting this approach. I am convinced that the implementation of the agreement, especially in cooperation with developing countries, will have very positive consequences for world trade because it will lead to greater harmonisation and simplification of procedures.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – President, I supported this recommendation given the Trade Facilitation Agreement seeks to reduce bureaucracy and corruption by modernising and standardising aspects of customs. It will prove most effective when appropriate technical assistance is given to developing countries, and the EU must be ready to assist.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ The modification of the Marrakesh agreement will make markets more accessible to developing and least-developed countries by significantly reducing time and cost of trading. This is the reason why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report because the conclusions of the document explicitly mention that the agreement will have greater benefits for countries that are previously in a position to comply with treaty commitments and for those that are already exporters. In other words, its terms are obviously unfavourable to developing countries.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because it will breathe new life into the World Trade Organisation. This agreement, which was reached through a consensus of both developed and developing countries will facilitate the battle against corruption and the reduction of unnecessary bureaucracy and modernise aspects of customs.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the Protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the WTO. The TFA contains a set of measures designed to improve the cross-border movement of goods by improving transparency, streamlining customs procedures and eliminating red tape. It also contains innovative flexibilities for developing countries. Thus, the first section of the Agreement stresses the commitments for expediting the movement, release and clearance of goods. I truly believe that the TFA is essential for developing countries as it helps to increase investments which eventually boost countries’ economy and further development. And most importantly, the EU is committed to cover a significant share of the funding needs and technical assistance for counties most in need to implement the Agreement.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Purpose of the Marrakech Agreement is to simplify customs clearance and thus trade in goods worldwide, with a view to serious cooperation between the customs authorities of each State Parties. Significant economic benefits are expected from the Convention, in particular for developing countries and least developed countries. Trade facilitation measures can also bring about facilitation for SMEs. The Agreement is also capable of innovatively recogniseing the different implementation capacities from one nation to another by calling on developing and least developed countries to determine when the specific provisions of the Agreement will be applied and by linking the implementation of some rules to assistance provided by developed nations. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Today, the so-called Marrakesh Agreement was voted on. These were amendments to the contracts concerning the World Trade Organisation. This organisation (WTO) is a very good body, which, among other things, ensures that world trade is conducted in a fair manner. (It is a pity that a similar organization for the financial sector still does not exist.) I have always believed that the European single market is the best thing about the EU. If free trade within Europe is good for individual countries, then global free trade should also be good for the whole world. It was easy for me today to agree to this proposal. Incidentally, as i am my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Marrakech Agreement aims to simplify customs clearance and trade in goods worldwide. In view of this, serious cooperation between the customs authorities of each State Parties is necessary. In particular, a positive impact is expected from the amendment of the Convention for developing countries and least developed countries. Trade facilitation measures can also bring significant facilitation to SMEs. The agreement recognises in an innovative way the different implementation capacities from one nation to another. It calls on developing and least developed countries to determine when the specific provisions of the Agreement will be applied and links the implementation of some rules to assistance provided by developed nations. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report because the conclusions of the document explicitly mention that the agreement will have greater benefits for countries that are previously in a position to comply with treaty commitments and for those that are already exporters. In other words, its terms are obviously unfavourable to developing countries.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, as this way gives consent for the conclusion of the agreement. It is clear that there are still differences between developed and developing countries, to which ineffixed customs management, weak infrastructure and a high level of bureaucracy must be added.  I therefore consider that it is necessary to balance the difference in the implementation capabilities of the countries present between countries and to emphasise the importance of technical assistance and the elevation of the level of transparency.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pablo Zalba-Bildegain's report on the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement. This protocol will strengthen cooperation between customs authorities to improve the flow of goods around the world. The report supports the European financial support initiative to developing and least developed countries, including to improve their customs systems. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is a useful addition to improving the position of developing countries in the global economy with little financial effort.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the agreement, which has been reached by consensus with developed and developing countries, as it seeks to reduce bureaucracy and corruption by modernising and standardising aspects of customs. It will prove most effective when appropriate technical assistance is given to developing countries, and the EU must be ready to assist.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization. This is the continuation of the logic of free trade without borders or control, with the "facilitation" of customs procedures.  In the end, goods will be less controlled, and goods in transit will no longer be controlled at all. Goods audits and inspections will be less frequent. There is a risk of an independent judicial authority in the event of disagreement, which opens the door to an arbitration mechanism that will undermine the sovereignty of states. Moreover, the argument that further free trade would enable developing countries to emerge from poverty faster is not necessarily verified by experience.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The objective of this agreement is to impose on poor countries the burden of facilitating imports, in order to open their markets to the production of rich countries and large multinational groups. Once again, the World Trade Organization is acting to strengthen inequalities in global trade: that is why I voted against it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The positive thing is that the agreement removes bureaucratic obstacles, but the negative is that it calls for financial assistance. I therefore abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. Since its inception in 1995, the World Trade Organisation (WTO) has played an important role in creating a rules-based international trading system. The original purpose of the EU, as well as the GATT (later the WTO), was to remove customs barriers and promote trade between Member States. The main objective of the Agreement is to simplify and accelerate the clearance of goods in the world, and results in a strengthening of the global economy.  Reducing overall costs and increasing trade create a better investment climate worldwide. The agreement is particularly important for the development of countries and assistance to SMEs, as it allows entry into the regional and global markets. I supported The Zalba Representative's report, as the implementation of the Developing State Agreement gives them the opportunity for a friendly business environment, especially SMEs, and citizens will be given easier access to more different and cheaper products. Given that Croatia is also a country that is just developing its market and should strengthen its competitiveness, and the EU has committed to financial assistance to developing countries, especially in projects such as improving the customs system and trade reforms, I once again urge the Croatian Government to use the assistance provided to them.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 To some extent technical amendment, I voted in favour.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakes Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The trade facilitation agreement (TFA) which was concluded at the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013 is the first multilateral agreement since the WTO was established in 1995. The TFA stands as an innovative agreement not only for being the first multilateral agreement on new rules to have been negotiated under the auspices of the WTO since it was created almost 20 years ago. It sets a pioneering approach by: - Allowing developing and least developed countries to categorize commitments and determine the timing of their implementation.  - Linking implementation of some disciplines to the provision of technical assistance. - Calling for joint action by donor countries, development assistance providers and developing and least developed country WTO members to assist the latter in implementing some provisions of the agreement. - Incorporating an Expert Group to assess the situation in a Member once notified implementation periods have expired, and the use of the TFA Committee as a forum for the exchange of experiences and deliberation. The Agreement pursues a ‘positive integration’ through specific practices and –instead of refraining from using certain policies – contains approximately 40 provisions for expediting the movement, release and clearance of goods.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. The agreement provides for the simplification of customs regulatory procedures to facilitate the cross-border movement of goods. Trade must be cheaper and easier to obtain greater benefits from international trade.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report aims to keep the door open for tariff facilitation for developing countries. It also contains sensible proposals to improve the position of developing countries in the international economic fabric. This motion must therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report aims to save the WTO, which has been under strain since the 2001 Doha Summit. The United States of America and the European Union proposed to Bali in 2013 a customs liberalization that was most beneficial to them, negotiated by allowing countries like India to temporarily protect their local agriculture when they practice forced protectionism and bought the support of developing countries with great humanitarian aid. The EU is in a hurry to conclude the agreement ahead of the next WTO summit in Nairobi in December 2015. For developing countries, therefore, it is the continuation of the WTO's usual negotiating technique, the gun to the head. At a more complicated summit than ever, where the BRICS are preparing the counter-attack with an Asian development bank strengthening the weight of their currencies against the dollar and developing new economic and geopolitical paths. I'm voting against this deal.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization aims to facilitate trade. In other words, it is a matter of speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods and making them less controlled. However, we believe that the trade policy of States must remain within the purview of the sovereignty of the peoples, and this in order to enable them to trade in their own interests. To preserve the security and sovereignty of states, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objectives of the Trade Facilitation Agreement are to simplify customs procedures and ensure flowed and as predictable trade flows as possible. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the conclusion of the agreement and to bring the trade facilitation agreement before the Parliament.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. While the new Agreement is expected to significantly reduce the time and cost of trading, and thus help businesses in developing and least-developed countries to access new export opportunities. It is important that the modernisation efforts should bear fruit in all countries.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement on the Simplification of Trade Procedures was concluded at the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013. The agreement is not so much a legal commitment, but rather a focus on cooperation to implement best practices that governments can support and abet. It contains some 40 provisions to speed up the movement, release and clearance of goods; including those relating to the publication of legislation, regulations and procedures, the application of electronic payments, the reduction of formalities and documentation requirements or the uniform application of border control procedures.  In the report, the referring party shall state the expected benefits of the agreement, in particular for developing and least developed countries, and the Recommendation clearly states that the European Parliament should support the Council's draft decision.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), concluded in December 2013, is the first multilateral agreement concluded since the WTO was established in 1995. TFA is an innovative agreement. In addition to being the first multilateral agreement on the new standards ever negotiated since the creation of the WTO almost twenty years ago, it has defined a pioneering approach by allowing developing and less advanced countries to categoin commitments and set a timetable for their implementation, linking the application of some disciplines to the provision of technical assistance , calls for joint action by WTO member countries to support the implementation of some provisions of the agreement and to incorporate an expert group to assess a Member's situation as soon as the implementation periods expire.  I support the TFA for recognizing the differences between the various countries in terms of application capacity, asking developing countries and less advanced countries to define when they will apply the specific provisions contained therein and associating the application of some disciplines to the provision of technical assistance by developed countries.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This recommendation is intended to endorse the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the WTO. This trade facilitation agreement continues the free-trade logic by speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods. The latter will be less controlled, especially in transit goods that will no longer be subject to control at all. In addition, it encourages the use of independent tribunals in the event of conflict, paving the way for arbitration mechanisms and further undermining the sovereignty of states. Finally, while it provides differential treatment for developing countries, this agreement pushes these countries to free trade, which, on the face of experience, has had little track record. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The TFA has breathed welcome new life into the WTO and confirmed the multilateral arena remains the most effective place for global trade regulation. This Agreement, which has been reached by consensus with developed and developing countries, seeks to reduce bureaucracy and corruption by modernising and standardising aspects of customs. It will prove most effective when appropriate technical assistance is given to developing countries, and the EU must be ready to assist.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text approving the conclusion of the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organization. The aim is to contribute to the growth of developing countries by creating a more favourable environment for businesses, especially SMEs. The report also supports the EU's initiative setting a five-year funding target of EUR 400 million to support trade facilitation reforms and projects, such as improving customs systems in developing and least developed countries.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting positively on this draft resolution so that the EU can ratify the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) as soon as possible, concluded at the 9th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation, WTO, in December 2013. In supporting the resolution, we hope that ratification by the EU will be an incentive for the other WTO member countries to ratify the agreement as soon as possible. In fact, for the agreement reached on the TFA to enter into force, ratification of at least two thirds of the WTO states is required.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this recommendation for amending the Marrakesh agreement that will amongst others allow developing and least developed countries to categorize commitments and determine the timing of their implementation.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a useful addition to the report. It is a small financial burden that should improve the position of developing countries in the world economy.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Agreement updates the Marrakesh Treaty and recognises differences between countries in implementation capacities. Developing countries and least developed countries are invited to decide when they apply specific treaty provisions, and the implementation of some areas will also be linked to aid from developing countries.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of the agreement.  It is to be welcomed that the FIRST multilateral agreement on the new rules has finally been reached in the WTO. It should be noted that this is an innovative agreement that sets out an innovative approach. The new agreement should significantly reduce the time costs and costs of trade and ensure appropriate conditions for the development of enterprises. It will also benefit those countries that trade and implement their commitments quickly. It should be noted that the agreement aims at positive integration through specific practices and through certain policy instruments. In order to ensure the effective implementation of the provisions envisaged, greater transparency and closer cooperation between customs authorities should be encouraged.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of amending the Marrakesh Agreement which would allow easier access to the export market for companies in developing and less developed countries. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the privileges by which this Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement will contribute to facilitating trade and customs compliance, I support these amendments. I believe that they will greatly contribute to simplifying the procedure in trading between The World Trade Organisation Member States, through the abolition, simplification and clearer interpretation of many customs regulations that are different between countries.  I also believe that this achieves a better understanding, trade and exchange of goods, money and services is accelerated, opening up the possibility of the economy growing as well. One of the main objectives is to level standards and controls in terms of quality and control of goods in transport. It is of utmost importance that this Protocol on amending the Marrakesh Agreement will bring to developing countries by opening up new opportunities for them in trade and business.  The reduction of the total cost of trade should also result in a reduction in the final prices of products paid by the customer, which is also a positive contribution of this Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This recommendation is intended to approve the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the WTO. This trade facilitation agreement continues the free-trade logic by speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods. The latter will be less controlled, especially in transit goods that will no longer be subject to control at all. In addition, it encourages the use of independent tribunals in the event of conflict, paving the way for arbitration mechanisms and further undermining the sovereignty of states. Finally, while it provides differential treatment for developing countries, this agreement pushes these countries to free trade, which, on the face of experience, has had little track record. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Last year's TFA Agreement is the first multilateral agreement since the founding of the World Trade Organisation in 1995. The new agreement is expected to significantly reduce trading time and costs, thus ensuring developing and least developed countries have easier access to new export opportunities. For these reasons, I support the recommendation on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - The Trade Facilitation Agreement adopted at the WTO Ministerial Conference in Bali (7 December 2013) is the first comprehensive multilateral agreement concluded since the wto was established. A key aspect of this contract is technical assistance to developing countries and less developed countries by donor countries.  It is estimated that the Agreement will have a significant impact on global trade due to cost reductions caused by complicated customs procedures. The European Union will allocate a total of 400m euros in aid over a 5-year period. In addition to the Union, other organisations such as the World Bank, UNCTAD and the Member States of the Union will also provide assistance.  It is very important to achieve good coordination of these funds in order to avoid spending money or multi-funding for the same purpose. Consequently, I support the proposal of a fellow MP for Zalba Bidegain.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 A difficult multilateral agreement on trade facilitation was reached in Bali in December 2013, with major bureaucratic simplifications at the borders, which would have allowed economic savings for all acceding countries, and in particular for developing countries. For various reasons, mainly linked to the resistance of India, which has returned to the content of the agreement, this could not materialise during 2014 and the procedure should therefore be concluded in the autumn, before the WTO ministerial meeting at the end of the year, when two thirds of the Member States should have ratified the agreement. The European Union is therefore formalising an agreement which it considers to be a source of important economic benefits for all partners. I voted in favour of this assent so that the Commission can proceed with the action resulting from the negotiating mandate granted.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I expressed my support for the recommendation to endorse the conclusion of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization. This protocol approves the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement. This agreement aims to support the integration of developing countries into world trade by providing these countries with flexibility over the necessary assistance as their needs are met.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 After almost a decade of negotiations, the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) was finally concluded at the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013. It is an innovative agreement, not only because it is the first multilateral agreement to be concluded since the creation of the WTO in 1995, but also because it favours a pioneering approach to address the concerns of developing countries and the least developed countries that are part of the WTO.  For this reason, and also taking into account the beneficial effects that the TFA intends to achieve in terms of improving and modernising customs procedures, increasing and accelerating trade and enhancing transparency and cooperation between customs authorities, I voted in favour of concluding the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of granting the adoption of the Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol Amending the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization. This will give approval to the Trade Facilitation Agreement, a historic milestone, as it is the first multilateral agreement reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995, and is a boost to the Doha Round negotiations to set the rules for international trade in the 21st century. The Agreement is part of the so-called "Bali package", which covers two other trade policy groups: proposals on trade in agricultural goods and a development chapter dedicated in particular to the least advanced countries. The Agreement, which aims to simplify customs procedures and reduce export costs, reducing unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and ensuring lower customs delays, will have an economic impact of around EUR 60 billion per year on world GDP. It also includes rules of transparency, devotes particular attention to SMEs and differential treatment to developing countries, for whom both transitional periods are envisaged and technical assistance to facilitate their implementation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement is the first multilateral agreement since the creation of the WTO 20 years ago and is considered the most important outcome of the Doha Development Round as it is being seen as a breakthrough in the capacity of the multilateral trading system to address the concerns of developing countries. This agreement, once implemented, will bring significant trade benefits around the world and boost global economic growth by accelerating the cross-border movement of goods, ensuring the fluidity and predictability of trade flows. It will also require greater transparency and cooperation between customs authorities.  I would also like to stress as a very positive aspect the removal of administrative barriers which will contribute not only to cost reduction, but also to better integration of developing countries and their enterprises into regional and global value chains, enabling them to benefit from international trade.  I am clearly in favour of this proposal and I hope that this Agreement will be ratified quickly by 2/3 of the 160 WTO members so that it can enter into force.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement was adopted at the NINTH WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013. Its objective is to simplify and speed up the movement and clearance of goods around the world.  The entry into force of the agreement will benefit commercial operators and stimulate global economic growth.
