I supported this report, which points out that this agreement creates a more favourable environment for businesses, especially SMEs, and that it should also allow consumers to access a greater supply of low-priced products.  It is also central to supporting the EU initiative, which sets a funding target of EUR 400 million over five years to support trade facilitation reforms and projects, such as improving customs systems in developing and least developed countries.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation which will guarantee trade for WTO members. In addition, the European Union will set eur 400 million for the least developed countries to help them comply with customs rules and obligations, as enshrined in the agreement.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider the WTO to be a body extremely far removed from the needs of the Italian and European production system.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report because the conclusions of the document explicitly mention that the agreement will have greater benefits for countries that are previously in a position to comply with treaty commitments and for those that are already exporters. In other words, its terms are obviously unfavourable to developing countries.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this agreement is to impose on poor countries the burden of facilitating imports, in order to open their markets to the production of rich countries and large multinational groups. Once again, the World Trade Organization is acting to strengthen inequalities in global trade: that is why I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, as while I am in favour of free trade I do not believe the EU has competency in this area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because it will breathe new life into the World Trade Organisation. This agreement, which was reached through a consensus of both developed and developing countries will facilitate the battle against corruption and the reduction of unnecessary bureaucracy and modernise aspects of customs.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour as the Protocol allows developing and least developed countries to group commitments into categories and decide on the timeframe for their implementation – that is, greater freedom for poor countries and less threat of falling into a public debt spiral.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report because the Agreement can bring many global benefits. It enhances the cooperation of customs duties of more countries, and cooperation and exchange of experience is extremely important. Also, the Agreement can greatly help the exchange of goods worldwide, entrepreneurship, competition, small and medium-sized enterprises, especially in developing countries.  Simplifying and accelerating movement and customs clearance of goods around the world are important and beneficial, and therefore this Agreement can bring economic growth and economic progress to countries around the world.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. The report underlines the importance of the provisions adopted in the package of measures during the ninth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation in Bali. Through the so-called package of measures, the report encourages the smooth development of international trade. I support this report, essentially also for my country, which as a member of the EU, but also a developing country, can feel on its own example the importance of facilitating customs regulations and trade measures. The adoption of these measures improves the climate in trade relations between EU member states but also with non-EU countries and authorizes the European Union to cooperate more or partner with developing countries or underdeveloped countries.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal as I support the liberalisation of international trade. It is precisely the reduction of the administrative burden in international trade that is one of the measures by which the European Union can really and freely help the economy and employment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, theoretically to manage for their benefit. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Action must be taken to further liberalise international trade, as it brings significant benefits to all parties involved. The Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement is one of the good examples of this. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of this protocol. Indeed a swift implementation of the TFA is essential for developing countries. The agreement will make it easier and cheaper for developing countries to trade, with the biggest gains realised in south-south trade, thereby facilitating their integration into regional and global value chains. Returns on a relatively modest up-front investment will be considerable in terms of growth, jobs and development The EU is committed to cover a significant share of the funding needs and technical assistance for counties most in need to implement the Agreement.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported this protocol on amending the Marrakesh Agreement, which, according to studies conducted, needs to bring over 100 billion euros to the global economy. I believe that this multilateral agreement will be of great benefit to developing countries as well as to other Member States, as its implementation reduces trade costs in its entirety.  The Facilitation Agreement is the first multilateral agreement based on new rules adopted on the basis of negotiations under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation, which allows development for even least developed countries and classifys obligations and sets the timing of their implementation, while also urging donor countries to work together and provide development assistance to least developed countries to succeed in implementing the treaty provisions. I also find it extremely useful to form an expert group to assess the situation in countries after the expiry of implementation deadlines, as this will contribute to increasing transparency.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Since the agreement aims to simplify and speed up the movement and customs clearance of goods worldwide and to improve cooperation between customs authorities, I supported the recommendation. Trade breaks will be beneficial for the whole sector as they boost global economic growth. Trade facilitation is particularly important for developing countries, as they are expected to get the most increased general trade flows from more efficient trade procedures. Trade facilitation measures also help small businesses access new export opportunities, while giving them access to global trade routes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report because the conclusions of the document explicitly mention that the agreement will have greater benefits for countries that are previously in a position to comply with treaty commitments and for those that are already exporters. In other words, its terms are obviously unfavourable to developing countries.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This trade facilitation agreement aims to speed up customs clearance procedures for goods. The treatment of developing countries will be differentiated while their infrastructure and the quality of their customs improve.  The Bidegain report proposes to accept the Council's decision. While some provisions make sense, others are frankly wrong. We are therefore opposed to it for several reasons: - it is the continuation of the logic of free trade without borders or control with the "facilitation" of customs procedures. In the end, goods will be less controlled (more at all for goods in transit), checks and inspections of less frequent goods requested by the text; - there may be recourse to an independent judicial authority in the event of disagreement: this opens the way for an arbitration mechanism and will remove sovereignty from States; - there is confiscation by the EU of an attribute of the trade policy of Member States with non-EU countries and WTO members; - this report advocates further free trade that is supposed to enable developing countries to get out of poverty faster, a fact that is not necessarily verified by experience. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report because the conclusions of the document explicitly mention that the agreement will have greater benefits for countries that are previously in a position to comply with treaty commitments and for those that are already exporters. In other words, its terms are obviously unfavourable to developing countries.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. On the two WTO reports that have been voted on in this plenary session, I voted in favour of this report and against the next one. I voted for this one. The WTO framework has been a space that has traditionally defended exporting industrialized countries, harming poor and developing countries. The alternative to this multilateral space has been even more damaging to the proliferation of bilateral treaties. In any event, in this report the vote has been positive in introducing the most important elements of the Doha round and, consequently, finally prioritizing those issues of economic interest to developing countries.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an agreement concluded within the World Trade Organization which aims to simplify and speed up customs procedures for the movement of goods around the world. This simplification can help increase global economic growth. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that protocol.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We regret that issues relating to solidarity and mutual respect between peoples have not been addressed at the Bali Ministerial Conference, aimed at truly balanced and mutually beneficial trade relations, which do not destiture their resources (natural, cultural and labour), the least developed countries in favour of developed countries. In our view, a fair agreement should necessarily take into account the reduction of the discrepancy between "rich and poor countries", would have to guarantee and create decent jobs with rights, should safeguard natural resources and meet environmental protection objectives, as well as respect cultural diversity.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report aims to keep the door open for tariff facilitation for developing countries. It also contains sensible proposals to improve the position of developing countries in the international economic fabric. This motion must therefore be supported.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Protocol concerns the ratification of the Trade Facilitation Agreement agreed to by the EP's Committee on International Trade. Research and analysis carried out on the adoption of this agreement by the WTO shows that its implementation will bring more than EUR 100 billion to the world economy and a reduction in trade costs by 12.5-17.5%. The adoption of the agreement can bring significant benefits not only to developing countries, but also to EU Member States as well as to the Union itself, leading to a multilateral trading system. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO) following its 9th Bali Ministerial Conference held in December 2013, in which the 160 members concluded negotiations on the "Trade Facilitation Agreement" , which deals with the first multilateral agreement since its creation in 1995 to establish a model for "customs modernisation". It is regrettable that issues relating to solidarity and mutual respect between peoples, which are really balanced and mutually beneficial trade relations, which do not outof their resources (natural, cultural and labour) in favour of developed countries, have not been addressed at the Bali Ministerial Conference. A fair agreement must necessarily take into account the reduction of the discrepancy between "rich and poor countries", will have to secure and create decent jobs with rights, should safeguard natural resources and meet environmental protection objectives, as well as respect cultural diversity. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament legitimizes a deeply discriminatory agreement, as it imposes costly administrative processes on developing countries for the sole purpose of facilitating the penetration of imports into their domestic market, curbing their autonomous and sovereign development. That's why I voted against it.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This protocol amends the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organization and aims to facilitate trade. In other words, it is a matter of speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods and making them less controlled. Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that trade policy must remain within the purview of the sovereignty of States. We are very opposed to the lifting of customs barriers advocated in this text. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I support the agreement, but Britain should be signing it not the EU!  I therefore abstained.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. There are still significant differences between the border procedures of developed and developing countries and the slowing down of trade due to poor infrastructure, inefficient customs management and excessive bureaucracy. The trade facilitation agreement and the trade liberalisation process aim to reduce trade costs in order to boost exports and economic activity. The new agreement should significantly reduce the cost and cost of trade of time, thereby helping businesses to develop and making use of new export opportunities for the least developed countries, and I therefore support its conclusion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Opposed to this trade facilitation agreement, which is part of free-trade dogma, I of course voted against this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Trade Facilitation Agreement ("AFE") is of great importance to European trade, which accounts for 22% of the world's trade. I therefore voted in favour of this recommendation to amend the Marrakesh agreement to simplify and harmonize international trade procedures. This will facilitate the implementation of the EFA for developing countries through special and differentiated treatment, and will also enable technical assistance from developed countries in certain areas.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. As with the recommendation, the aim of this report is to approve the protocol amending the WTO agreement to facilitate trade and to accelerate free-trade logic by ending customs barriers on goods and lowering controls on goods. Considering that the EU should not interfere in the trade affairs of states, since trade policy must be the sole competence of states, I have decided to vote against it. Moreover, I cannot endorse this globalist and ultraliberal policy that is killing our economies, which the technocrats of Brussels and the federalists of all kinds refuse to acknowledge.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In my view, the World Trade Organisation should be a neutral instrument that can also provide opportunities and legal protection for our legitimate commercial interests. The Zalba Bidegain report, on the other hand, seems to confuse development policies with international trade and focuses excessively on the needs of developing countries, leaving our territories and our production system at the mercy of the crisis, all this simply risks increasing the processes of relocation of production from the EU to Asia, which is why I voted against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which highlights the importance of the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, a historic milestone, as it is the first multilateral agreement reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995, and is a boost to the Doha Round negotiations, to set the rules for international trade in the 21st century. The Agreement is part of the so-called "Bali package", which covers two other trade policy groups: proposals on trade in agricultural goods and a development chapter dedicated in particular to the least advanced countries. The Agreement, which aims to simplify customs procedures and reduce export costs, reducing unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and ensuring lower customs delays, will have an economic impact of around EUR 60 billion per year on world GDP. It also includes rules of transparency, devotes particular attention to SMEs and differential treatment to developing countries, for whom both transitional periods are envisaged and technical assistance to facilitate their implementation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report on the draft Council decision amending the Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (Marrakesh Treaty) to facilitate trade. Parliament fully supports the European Union's initiative to provide for eur 400 million in aid. In order to finance trade facilitation reforms and projects, for example, the development of customs systems in developing and least developed countries, for a period of five years. This support should be very well coordinated with other international donors providing funding, such as the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the WTO and the World Bank.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe that the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement contains some basic provisions that will make it easier for goods to move across borders and to make trade flows smoother and more predictable.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the Own-initiative Report of the Committee on International Trade on the changes to the basic agreement within the WTO can only be negative. The text focuses too much on the needs of developing countries, whereas in our opinion the WTO should be a neutral instrument that can also provide opportunities and legal protection for our legitimate trade interests. Confusing development policies with international trade is a serious mistake, as it simply risks further increasing processes of relocation of production processes from Europe to Asia. In short, the report welcomes reforms within the WTO which, in fact, do not seem to me to be so important. The amendments tabled by certain left-wing groups seem to take account almost exclusively of the interests of developing countries and only on a few occasions make an interesting contribution to the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which contained a number of perturbing provisions. The agreement concerned the extension of the scope of the competence of the World Trade Organisation to the issue of trade facilitation, mainly in favour of corporate and industrialised countries. It was for these reasons, amongst others that I tabled a negative vote.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ I support the agreement, but Britain should be signing it not the EU! I therefore abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe amending the Protocol of Marrakesh Agreement will significantly improve trade movement around the world especially for developing countries. It is expected to increase trade and give small businesses access to new markets and as a result offer consumers a wide range of cheaper products. The Report emphasises that the degree and the timing of implementation of the agreement will determine the benefits that will be derived therefrom and that full and faithful implementation that reflects the priorities and concerns of developing countries within the remit of the Doha Development Agenda will be of greatest benefit to all signatories.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed concerns because, although the text is balanced and talks about a formal ratification of an international agreement, in the report by my colleague Pablo Zalba Bidegain there were no strong references to customs problems, tax controls and the fight against corruption. I therefore abstained on the final text of the resolution accompanying the ratification of the Marrakesh Agreement.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol because it is part of the logic of free trade without borders or controls, but which involves the "facilitation" of customs procedures.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The agreement adopts a "positive integration" approach through specific practices rather than refraining from using certain policies. It contains approximately 40 provisions to speed up the movement of goods for free circulation and customs clearance, including provisions for the publication of laws, regulations and procedures, the use of electronic payments, the simplification of formalities and documentation requirements or uniformity in the application of border procedures.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. The Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), concluded by the 159 WTO members (including the EU and its Member States) at the 9th Ministerial Conference in December 2013, is the first multilateral agreement concluded by the WTO since its inception 20 years ago. The aim of the agreement is to simplify and speed up the movement and customs clearance of goods around the world and requires greater cooperation between customs authorities. The text of the agreement includes rules on issues such as transparency and information requirements by customs authorities, appeal and review procedures, tariff and tax regulations, documentation obligations and special and differentiated treatment for developing countries. The agreement will enter into force when it is ratified by two-thirds of wto members. The European Parliament's agreement is required on this agreement to ensure that the EU fulfils its WTO membership obligations and to contribute to the successful conclusion of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference to be held in Nairobi in December.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this protocol because I believe it can lead to an improvement in the capacity of the multilateral trading system to respond to the concerns of developing countries, as well as those of European companies exporting and in need of modernised and simplified customs procedures and regulations, together with greater transparency and stronger cooperation. I like the innovative approach of this agreement, which will allow developing and least developed countries to classify commitments and determine the timing of their implementation, as well as linking the implementation of certain disciplines to the provision of technical assistance, with help from donor countries. It should also be noted that there is less emphasis in the agreement on binding provisions and greater attention to cooperation aimed at achieving a range of good practices that governments can support and respect, which I believe is essential in the current multilateral regulatory framework.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 At the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference held in December 2013, the 160 WTO members concluded negotiations on the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which is an important milestone in that it is the first multilateral agreement since the creation of the WTO establishing a model for customs modernisation among the 161 WTO members by granting benefits to developing countries and creating a more business-friendly environment , in particular for SMEs. The implementation of this Agreement will lead to the harmonisation and simplification of trade-related procedures, in particular in developing countries, providing for special and differentiated treatment, according to which developing countries and least developed countries can decide under what circumstances the different provisions will be applied and which will require technical assistance. I support this report, which has long been in line with what the European Parliament and the EU have long advocated in promoting free, fair and open trade that is balanced and mutually beneficial to all, and the WTO is obviously the stage for excellence in pursuing and reaffirming these principles.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am fully in favour of concluding the Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA), as it will ensure significant benefits for operators around the world and foster global economic growth. In particular, it will help to reduce costs and increase trade for both the import and export markets, encouraging worldwide commercial investment. Furthermore, for the effective implementation of the Protocol, the coordination of customs authorities will be essential and on this point it will be a priority to promote dialogue between countries, in particular developing countries. In this regard, I strongly endorse the way in which the problems relating to the implementation of the Protocol are to be addressed in the least developed countries, in particular the adoption of special and differentiated treatment and technical and financial assistance, concrete support to bridge the disparities between the different capacities for implementing the provisions by WTO members.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament legitimizes a deeply discriminatory agreement, as it imposes costly administrative processes on developing countries for the sole purpose of facilitating the penetration of imports into their domestic market, curbing their autonomous and sovereign development. That's why I voted against it.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report is supporting the Parliament's recommendation for the Protocol Amending the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organisation, and also highlights the importance of the agreement, that is expected to significantly reduce the time and cost of trading, and thus help businesses in developing and least-developed countries to access new export opportunities. In the light of this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The ratification of the agreement on trade facilitation by the European Union is of great importance, not only because it is the first agreement concluded in the WTO since its inception in 1995, but above all because of the agreement's innovative 'tailor-made' approach to the least developed and developing countries. They will, in fact, enjoy special and differentiated treatment which will allow them to choose the timing and methods of implementing the obligations arising from the agreement. I am convinced that the success of the trade facilitation agreement will depend to a large extent on the flexibility shown towards these countries. This agreement will also have the great merit of seriously hindering the phenomenon of corruption, introducing electronic payment systems and encouraging the use of the network to disseminate information and documentation necessary for the conclusion of exchanges. The agreement on trade facilitation therefore has the great potential to act as a lever for the intensification of global trade, which will have a more transparent and therefore safer, faster and more reliable trading system.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the adoption of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization (WTO). Adopted in 2013 by the WTO, the protocol aims to speed up the movement and customs clearance of goods around the world through significantly increased cooperation between customs authorities. Considering that this protocol is of particular importance to developing countries as it is a vehicle for global economic growth and also considering that it should enable small businesses to access new export opportunities, while offering consumers a wide range of products, I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This trade facilitation agreement is in line with an intensification of free trade and a reduction in effective controls at the borders and by customs authorities on the ground. The aim here is to encourage early decisions in order to speed up trade in goods. Moreover, by allowing the lifting of inspection notifications if the circumstances that justified them have changed, we find ourselves in a dangerous situation contrary to the precautionary principle which is intended, at a minimum, to apply to international trade in goods. Finally, this trade facilitation agreement continues the logic of overtaking states in the area of dispute resolution by proposing to strengthen an independent arbitration mechanism to support appeals against the decisions of customs administrations. Rejecting this laxity at our borders and this denial of the authority of states, I voted against this report

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly welcome the trade facilitation agreement. In order to maintain a well-functioning, efficient and healthy economic environment that resists a more attractive European market, as well as a guarantee of preserving our cultural heritage, fewer administrative burdens are needed. This can be particularly difficult for small and medium-sized enterprises that do not have the necessary means and know-how to combat public administration bureaucracy.  The trade facilitation agreement will not only enable better market access and a wide variety of goods and businesses, but what is even more important is that we will see many new opportunities for innovative technologies, such as e-payment systems, etc.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, theoretically to manage for their benefit. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade facilitation is essentially the responsibility of national authorities, but there is no doubt that in many areas multilateral cooperation can increase profits and reduce costs. Two thirds of WTO members must therefore ratify the Trade Facilitation Agreement in order to enter into force. The benefits that will come from the implementation of this Agreement for developing countries, as it will help to create a more favourable environment for businesses, in particular for SMEs, are evident and provided that it is fully implemented, should reduce uncertainty about market entry conditions and trade costs by between 12.5% and 17.5%. I agree with the implementation of this Agreement, particularly in developing countries, as it will lead to harmonisation and simplification of trade-related procedures.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the protocol. The WTO remains, even with these changes, a body that is extremely far removed from the needs of our production system and has always been far from our idea of standards for local and quality products.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, theoretically to manage for their benefit. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond. For the above reasons, my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call to all members of the WTO to try to find a solution without delay for implementing the Bali Package in all its aspects, including the reduction of trade-distorting subsidies, so that the DDA can be concluded for the Tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. Implementation of the agreement, in particular by developing countries, will result in the standardisation and simplification of trade-related procedures. Moreover, the agreement can provide new opportunities to expand the use of innovative technologies and electronic systems, including electronic payment systems, national trade portals and one-stop shops.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report targets the Agreement on the Simplification of Trade Procedures, which is not only an innovative agreement because it is the first multilateral agreement on new rules negotiated under the auspices of the WTO since the creation of the WTO almost 20 years ago. Its approach is groundbreaking and allows developing and least developed countries to categorise their commitments and set out the timetable for their implementation. This will require increased transparency and greater cooperation between customs authorities. I welcome the line set out in the report, because the provisions on goods under the transit procedure are of particular importance for landlocked countries wishing to trade through ports in neighbouring countries.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the amendments to the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation and the related implementation of reforms to achieve trade facilitation. We need instruments such as these that contribute to global trade in developing countries and promote their economic development.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report given the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which has been reached by consensus with developed and developing countries, seeks to reduce bureaucracy and corruption by modernising and standardising aspects of customs. It will prove most effective when appropriate technical assistance is given to developing countries, and the EU must be ready to assist.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ As I supported the Protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, I also voted in favour of this report as I believe the trade facilitation agreement will make markets more accessible for developing and least-developed countries thus contributing to their development.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against this trade facilitation agreement because it aims to speed up "the movement of goods, further reducing customs controls". The agreement is to "provide" developing countries with the opportunity to categorize their commitments and determine their timetable for implementation.  It is really a question of adapting to the difficulties of these countries in complying with international agreements, when they do not have the necessary infrastructure and resources, especially in customs matters. The agreement therefore allows them to prioritize their actions until they can meet all of their obligations. This mechanism is once again based on the unproseed idea that ever-increasing free trade would allow these countries to develop. Through this type of agreement, it is understandable that Europeanists still ignore the social and environmental disasters caused by the increased globalization of trade. They are therefore pursuing their objective of gradually removing all customs controls, in order to promote the transit and movement of goods.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because the report ignores the Principle of Development Policy Coherence. DEVE's view makes it clear that, even if there could be positive effects for developing countries, the first beneficiaries would be developed countries and, particularly, their corporations.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report as I believe it contributes to and complements the vote of the agreement well. The trade facilitation agreement (TFA) has many benefits, which will especially be felt by developing countries. With the ratification of the TFA in the European Parliament before, I look forward to the positive effects of this new agreement.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the Protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement establishing the WTO. The TFA contains a set of measures designed to improve the cross-border movement of goods by improving transparency, streamlining customs procedures and eliminating red tape. It also contains innovative flexibilities for developing countries. Thus,  the Agreement stresses the commitments for expediting the movement, release and clearance of goods. I truly believe that the TFA is essential for developing countries as it helps to increase investments which eventually boost countries’ economy and further development. And most importantly, the EU is committed to cover a significant share of the funding needs and technical assistance for counties most in need to implement the Agreement.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Today, the so-called Marrakesh Agreement was voted on. These were amendments to the contracts concerning the World Trade Organisation. This organisation (WTO) is a very good body, which, among other things, ensures that world trade is conducted in a fair manner. (It is a pity that a similar organization for the financial sector still does not exist.) I have always believed that the European single market is the best thing about the EU. If free trade within Europe is good for individual countries, then global free trade should also be good for the whole world. It was easy for me today to agree to this proposal. Incidentally, as i am my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because the report ignores the Principle of Development Policy Coherence. DEVE's view makes it clear that, even if there could be positive effects for developing countries, the first beneficiaries would be developed countries and, particularly, their corporations.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a non-legislative resolution by the European Parliament on the council's draft decision on the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, as this will improve the business environment, especially for SMEs, and will benefit developing countries and less developed countries.  Furthermore, it will allow for increased competitiveness and efficiency of businesses and access to new markets. I also believe that it is necessary to raise the level of transparency, improve the cooperation of customs authorities and strengthen cooperation with professional organisations. Therefore, this way certainly contributes to fair, open and free trade.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization aims to facilitate trade. In other words, it is a matter of speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods and making them less controlled. However, we believe that the trade policy of States must remain within the purview of the sovereignty of the peoples, and this in order to enable them to trade in their own interests. To preserve the security and sovereignty of states, I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pablo Zalba-Bildegain's report on the protocol amending the Marrakesh agreement. With this text, the European Parliament gives its necessary approval for the European Union to ratify this protocol and thus be able to fulfil its commitments in the WTO. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which follows a December 2013 conference in which 160 WTO member countries negotiated an agreement to facilitate trade. The aim is to harmonize and simplify trade procedures in order to promote free trade.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is a useful addition to improving the position of developing countries in the global economy with little financial effort.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement, as it is good for the fisheries sector.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ European Union, should contribute to faire trade, solidarity and mutual respect, on the other hand, WTO should be part of a multilateral framework. However, Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) does not include issues like: climate change, reducing the gap between rich and poor countries, promoting fair trade. I acknowledge that the implementation of Trade Facilitation Reforms has broader development benefits, despite that I believe that the FTA should not be implemented since it does not take into account the negative impact which will occur. This is why I voted against this report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the non-legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization. This is the continuation of the logic of free trade without borders or control, with the "facilitation" of customs procedures. In the end, goods will be less controlled, and goods in transit more at all. Goods audits and inspections will be less frequent. There is a risk of an independent judicial authority in the event of disagreement, which opens the door to an arbitration mechanism that will undermine the sovereignty of states. Moreover, the argument that further free trade would enable developing countries to emerge from poverty faster is not necessarily verified by experience.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament legitimizes a deeply discriminatory agreement, as it imposes costly administrative processes on developing countries for the sole purpose of facilitating the penetration of imports into their domestic market, curbing their autonomous and sovereign development. That's why I voted against it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Trade Facilitation Agreement (TFA) is a very positive and innovative convention for a number of reasons. Part of the ninth WTO Ministerial Conference, this is the first multilateral agreement since the founding of the wto in 1995.  The Convention seeks to harmonize and simplify trade-related procedures which will create a more business-friendly environment. In addition, it will have a significant impact on developing countries as they will receive differential treatment by which they can decide when they implement the various provisions and for which they will need technical assistance.  In addition, the emphasis on greater transparency will contribute to combating border corruption and provide greater security, which in turn will be a strong incentive for increased trade. Thus, since the agreement is a source of benefit for both parties, I declare myself in favour of it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement was adopted at the 9th International Trade Facilitation Agreement. Ministerial Conference in December 2013 and it is the first multilateral treaty concluded by the WTO since its founding in 1995. The main objective of the Agreement is to simplify and accelerate the clearance of goods in the world, resulting in a strengthening of the global economy.  At the WTO conference in Bali in November 2014, a Protocol was adopted that would amend the Treaty establishing the WTO from Marrakech. The next phase was the adoption of the Amendment Protocol, scheduled for July 2014, but this was prevented by India due to food safety problems. In November of the same year, the WTO General Council nevertheless adopted the Protocol, opening the way for it to be accepted, and it will enter into force when ratified by two-thirds of WTO members. The consent of the European Union is necessary for the Council to ratify the Protocol. Since the amendments include facilitating trade and simplifying clearance procedures, and the Protocol is in line with the Economic Objectives of the Union, I supported zalba Bidegain's report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 To some extent, this amendment is technical, because the WTO should be there. I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ over the next five years, the European Union will release €400 million to support reforms and trade facilitation projects in developing countries. They will serve as a matter of priority to eliminate trade disparities between countries associated with the World Trade Organisation. Developing and less developed WTO member countries will be able to decide separately, as far as possible, in which of the three specified time horizons they will implement the planned technical measures to facilitate world trade. This will help not only developing countries, but also countries of the EU itself. The EP will have to be informed about the actual use of the allocated resources.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakes Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, because it is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this trade facilitation agreement. This decision is based on several reasons: first, because this is a logic of free trade, without borders or control, which further reduces the checks and inspections of goods. Secondly, because in this case there is a risk of recourse to an independent judicial authority, and therefore to arbitration mechanisms, which will undermine the sovereignty of the Member States. Finally, because trade policy remains a prerogative of the Member States, which the EU does not have to take over.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this Report which acknowledges the benefits that the implementation of this agreement will bring for developing countries given the contribution it will make to a more business-friendly environment, in particular for SMEs; emphasises, in particular, that the agreement ought to reduce uncertainty regarding market entry conditions and the costs of trade by between 12.5% and 17.5% (according to estimates – such as those by the OECD) if fully implemented, thus allowing consumers to access a larger and cheaper range of products and businesses to access new markets and improve their competitiveness by increasing efficiency and reducing unnecessary red tape and associated costs.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of amending the Protocol on the Marrakesh Agreement. This amendment underlines the importance of issues such as transparency, transit of goods, simplification of customs formalities and, above all, simpler procedures which will facilitate contacts between countries for exports and relations between companies and consumers. The EU must be strongly committed to promoting free trade that is of common interest.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Marrakesh Agreement, signed in December 2013 in Bali at the WTO Ministerial Conference, is relevant to trade facilitation (e.g. bureaucratic simplifications at borders). During 2014, this document struggled to materialise. It is for these reasons that I supported the report signed by Mr Zalba, who proposed a series of amendments to the agreement, aimed at its effective implementation.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The report prepared by Pablo Zalba gives the green light to the adoption of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which is one of the wto's most important reforms since its inception in 1995. My support for the text and congratulations to the rapporteur on this very important work, as the implementation of this agreement will enable international trade to be accelerated and covered by bringing clarity and efficiency to red tape. It will also make it possible to take advantage of technological advances such as electronic payment.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. Through the Zalba Bidegain report, the European Parliament was asked to vote on the Trade Facilitation Agreement, which came out of the Inter-Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in December 2013. If the agreement in question takes up provisions that remind us of the Washington Consensus (for example, the one aimed at eliminating the formalities deemed "excessive"), it is clear that some measures are innovative and advance, paradoxically, in the direction of fair trade. Thus, the text establishes a differentiated treatment for developing and least developed countries (LDCs): they will benefit from greater flexibility in the implementation of the measures implemented. They will also be able to count on technical assistance of 400 million euros over five years from the EU to improve their customs systems.  Considering that this development, although very modest and insufficient, is necessary to mitigate the original ultra-liberalism of the WTO, I voted in favour of the ratification of this agreement by the European Parliament, as indeed the majority of left-wing MEPs.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report aims to keep the door open for tariff facilitation for developing countries. It also contains sensible proposals to improve the position of developing countries in the international economic fabric. This motion must therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Parliament is taking a position here in favour of the WTO agreement review protocol. It makes a long litany of lies about the benefits of free trade and asks emerging countries not to do what the EU and the US are doing by protecting some of their markets. It "urges WTO members to find, as soon as possible, a solution for the implementation of the Bali decisions in all their aspects, including the reduction of trade-distorting subsidies, so that the Doha Development Agenda can be concluded at the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference" in December. As with the approval process, I am voting against this resolution.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization aims to facilitate trade. In other words, it is a matter of speeding up customs clearance procedures for goods and making them less controlled. However, we believe that the trade policy of States must remain within the purview of the sovereignty of the peoples, and this in order to enable them to trade in their own interests. To preserve the security and sovereignty of states, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade facilitation is essentially the responsibility of national authorities, but there is no doubt that in many areas multilateral cooperation can increase profits and reduce costs.  The implementation of this Agreement, in particular in developing countries, will lead to the harmonisation and simplification of trade-related procedures, this Agreement may provide new opportunities to disseminate the use of innovative technologies and electronic systems, including electronic payment systems, national trade portals and one-stop shops. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the agreement. This amendment to the Marrakesh agreement will lead to decreased waiting time in the clearance of goods through customs in all participating countries by bringing about greater cooperation between the various customs authorities throughout the world. This will benefit companies both large and small that deal with import, or export, in their daily activities.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1994 had to be amended, given the profound changes in the global landscape, the new economic and geopolitical realities. Thus, the conclusion of this protocol will allow the Trade Facilitation Agreement (EFA), adopted by the WTO General Council in November 2014, to be included in the WTO legal framework. The EFA is expected to reduce the total cost of trade by more than 14% for low-income countries and by more than 13% for upper-middle-income countries by simplifying the flow of goods across borders. The EFA will also help propel the "active integration" process through a series of provisions aimed at speeding up the movement, release and customs clearance of goods, the use of electronic payment, the easing of documentation formalities and obligations, the standardisation of border procedures, etc.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The trade facilitation agreement (TFA) was the principal outcome of the WTO 9MC, held in December 2013 in Bali. The TFA, part of the wider ‘Bali package’, covers issues including advanced rulings, transparency, goods in transit, specific issues responding to the concerns of SMES and simplifying customs formalities. It is the first multilateral agreement ever reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995. The EU has been a long-standing champion of the TFA, given the benefits it will bring to both developing and developed countries. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This trade facilitation agreement aims to speed up customs clearance procedures for goods. The report presented proposes to accept the Council's decision to differentiate the treatment of developing countries, as their infrastructure and the quality of their customs improve. It is therefore in line with free-trade reforms with the aim of removing borders and controls. In addition, it paves the way for an independent arbitration mechanism that will remove a little more sovereignty from states and allow the European Union to confiscate an attribute of Member States' trade policy with third countries. Finally, this report assumes that free trade will lift developing countries out of poverty, which is not necessarily verified by reality.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is dedicated to promoting free, fair and open trade that is balanced and mutually beneficial for all. The World Trade Organisation is the natural framework for pursuing and reaffirming these principles. I support the continuing great divergence between the border procedures of developed and developing countries and that fragile infrastructure with inefficient customs management and excessive bureaucracy hinder trade.  I argue that the rapid and comprehensive implementation of the agreement is in the interests of all members of the World Trade Organization, given the measurable benefits and, in particular, the expected reduction in trade costs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. As with the recommendation, the aim of this report is to approve the protocol amending the WTO agreement to facilitate trade and to accelerate free-trade logic by ending customs barriers on goods and lowering controls on goods.  Considering that the EU should not interfere in the trade affairs of states, let alone when it comes to endorsing this globalist logic, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The TFA has breathed welcome new life into the WTO and confirmed the multilateral arena remains the most effective place for global trade regulation. This Agreement, which has been reached by consensus with developed and developing countries, seeks to reduce bureaucracy and corruption by modernising and standardising aspects of customs. It will prove most effective when appropriate technical assistance is given to developing countries, and the EU must be ready to assist.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this non-legislative motion for a resolution, convinced that the EU must commit itself to promoting free, fair and open trade, which is balanced and has a common interest for all, and that the WTO is the natural framework for the continuation and reaffirmation of these principles. The TFA agreement covers issues such as transparency, transit of goods, issues relating to SMEs and the simplification of customs formalities. It is also the first multilateral agreement ever reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995. The agreement pursues 'positive integration' through specific practices and addresses disparities between the capacity of WTO members to implement the provisions, allowing each developing or less advanced Member State to decide for itself when to implement, in accordance with a staggered timetable, each of the technical measures envisaged. In addition, if fully implemented, the agreement will reduce commercial costs by between 12,5 % and 17,5 %, allowing consumers access to a wider and more cheap range of products.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will amend the Marrakesh agreement and should increase trade flows, expand duty collection revenue as a result of higher trade volume and better detection of fraud, and improve the efficiency of customs administrations.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is hoped that the new agreement will significantly reduce the cost of time and money in trade and will improve access to new export opportunities for companies in developing countries and least developed countries.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I assessed the importance of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement because it is above all necessary, as the rapporteur Doru-Claudian Frunzulică pointed out, to ensure transparency in relation to automatic entry and payment of duties, as a means of combating the high level of customs corruption present in developing and less developed countries. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Supporting the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation, I also support the Trade Facilitation Agreement. This Agreement will contribute to facilitating trade in goods globally and thus improving the global economic situation.  It will also have a positive impact on developing countries that will create new pathways in trade, increase their trade, leading to reduced unemployment and job creation, improved living conditions, healthcare, etc. Increasing world trade will have a positive impact on all aspects of life and work, both retailers and workers.  We need transparency in trade as we are faced with various forms of illegal sales of goods and various manipulations and frauds.  I believe that this Agreement can bring a lot of benefits to trade and trade relations, and therefore to the global economy and people's lives.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. As with the recommendation, the aim of this report is to approve the protocol amending the WTO agreement to facilitate trade and to accelerate free-trade logic by ending customs barriers on goods and lowering controls on goods. Considering that the EU should not interfere in the trade affairs of states, let alone when it comes to endorsing this globalist logic, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Last year's TFA Agreement is the first multilateral agreement since the founding of the World Trade Organisation in 1995. The new agreement is expected to significantly reduce trading time and costs, thus ensuring developing and least developed countries have easier access to new export opportunities.  For these reasons, I support this report, which contains a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I would welcome the results of the NINTH WTO Ministerial Conference in Bali on 7 December 2013, where the Trade Facilitation Agreement was adopted. The treaty is the first comprehensive multilateral agreement concluded since the founding of the WTO. I believe that TFA will enable the modernisation of tariffs between the 161 WTO members and will primarily bring the greatest benefits to developing countries and less developed countries, through creating a better business environment and reducing uncertainty about market entry conditions as well as trade costs. Unfortunately, there are still large differences in the border procedures of developed and developing countries. The fact is that poor infrastructure and too much bureaucracy, the customs of developing countries are slowing trade.  For this reason, I fully support this report as well as the Union initiative, which allocates €400 million in support to reforms that will facilitate trade and reduce the gap of customs systems between WTO member states.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I expressed my support for the report approving the conclusion of the protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organization and on the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement. This agreement is a positive sign that multilateralism at work in the WTO can work.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is committed to promoting free trade that is balanced and mutually beneficial for all. In this resolution, Parliament welcomes the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement at the 9th WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013. This agreement is an important milestone, not only because it is the first multilateral agreement to be concluded since the creation of the WTO in 1995, but also because it will contribute to the modernisation of customs procedures, making progress on the ability of the multilateral trading system to address the concerns of developing and least developed countries.  To this end, the agreement provides for special and differentiated treatment, under which developing and less advanced countries are allowed to define autonomously the timetable for the phased implementation of the technical measures envisaged, while also linking the application of some provisions to the provision of technical assistance. They also contain around 40 provisions aimed at accelerating the cross-border movement of goods, contributing to the increase in the volume of trade, better detection of fraud and the strengthening of the efficiency of customs authorities, and it is estimated that it can reduce trade costs by between 12.5% and 17.5%.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which highlights the importance of the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, a historic milestone, as it is the first multilateral agreement reached since the creation of the WTO in 1995, and is a boost to the Doha Round negotiations, to set the rules for international trade in the 21st century. The Agreement is part of the so-called "Bali package", which covers two other trade policy groups: proposals on trade in agricultural goods and a development chapter dedicated in particular to the least advanced countries. The Agreement, which aims to simplify customs procedures and reduce export costs, reducing unnecessary bureaucratic burdens and ensuring lower customs delays, will have an economic impact of around EUR 60 billion per year on world GDP. It also includes rules of transparency, devotes particular attention to SMEs and differential treatment to developing countries, for whom both transitional periods are envisaged and technical assistance to facilitate their implementation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In parallel with the Recommendation of the European Parliament for the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement and similar to other international agreements, this Own Initiative Report was drawn up, expressing Parliament's view on it, because it was impossible to integrate it into the formal procedure for approving the Conclusion of the Agreement. The EU's work in promoting free, fair, open, balanced and mutually beneficial trade for all parties is undeniable, with the WTO being the natural framework for pursuing and reaffirming these principles. This Agreement is therefore an important milestone, not only because it is the first multilateral agreement since the creation of the WTO in 1995, but also to establish a model for customs modernisation among the 161 members. Its implementation will lead to the harmonisation and simplification of trade-related procedures, particularly in developing countries, through special and differentiated treatment, also providing a more business-friendly climate, especially SMEs, in access to new markets and strengthening their competitiveness.  I voted in favour of considering overall positive the special and differential treatment provisions given to developing and least developed countries with a view to facilitating their trade.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the European Parliament to approve this agreement, which will enable the European Union to fulfil its commitments as a member of the WTO, thus contributing to the success of the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference. The WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement was adopted at the NINTH WTO Ministerial Conference in December 2013. Its objective is to simplify and speed up the movement and clearance of goods around the world. The entry into force of the agreement will benefit commercial operators and stimulate global economic growth.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because the report ignores the Principle of Development Policy Coherence. DEVE's view makes it clear that, even if there could be positive effects for developing countries, the first beneficiaries would be developed countries and, particularly, their corporations.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament legitimizes a deeply discriminatory agreement, as it imposes costly administrative processes on developing countries for the sole purpose of facilitating the penetration of imports into their domestic market, curbing their autonomous and sovereign development. That's why I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, while I am in favour of free trade I do not believe the EU has competency in this area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from Pablo Zalba Bidegain as I believe it contributes to and complements the vote of the agreement well. The trade facilitation agreement (TFA) has many benefits, which will especially be felt by developing countries. With the ratification of the TFA in the European Parliament before, I look forward to the positive effects of this new agreement.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of adopting this resolution when voting on the adoption of a motion for a resolution of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation. The objective of the present Protocol was to facilitate international trading conditions for developing countries within the framework of WTO trade rules.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this report because the WTO Trade Facilitation Agreement is useful and promotes movement, customs clearance and exchange of goods worldwide. To achieve this, it requires greater cooperation between customs duties of different countries, and better cooperation between states results in stronger economies.  Furthermore, this Agreement can achieve benefits for traders around the world and increase global economic growth. It also reduces costs and increases trade in both imports and exports, while creating a better investment climate worldwide. Trade facilitation is particularly important for developing countries, and I welcome measures to help SMEs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Implementing this report would reduce costs, in particular by liberalising customs regimes and facilitating trade between countries of varying economic performance. The report focuses in particular on developing countries and underdeveloped countries. The report also supports a package of measures adopted in Bali during the Ninth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation. By expressing a unified position on this issue, we are able to show that the European Union never get in the way of clearly stated guidelines for greater and better trade connectivity and that we are ready to help all those countries interested in trade breakthroughs.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The disbursement of EUR 400 million to help third countries, including the city of Marrakech, is an unprecedented waste of resources that the EU draws from European citizens, in theory to manage to their advantage. It is not possible for countries to receive millions of euros in financial aid from the EU and their citizens to flood the Member States looking for work and beyond.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the main supporters of free trade worldwide. This is manifested by the constant attitude to finance the development and facilitation of international trade.  In this respect, supporting the amendment of the Marrakesh Agreement, which underpins the World Trade Organisation, is a new contribution to strengthening fair trade relations at planetary level. The amendment aims primarily at changing the treatment of developing and underdeveloped countries by establishing differentiation from other countries in the implementation of WTO rules and providing technical assistance for the compatibility of customs systems. The changes involve reducing and transparent customs procedures, increasing security and lowering commercial costs for the benefit of consumers. The development of the private sector of free entrepreneurs, especially those involved in small and medium-sized enterprises, will also be supported.  Reforming the global trading system through these changes represents a new opportunity for developing and underdeveloped countries. The EU must stand in solidarity with these countries and with the idea of fair free trade. These measures are in the interest of European citizens, who deserve to benefit from products with the best value for money.  That is why I believe that the current document must be adopted, as it is an important step forward in this area.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of this protocol. Indeed a swift implementation of the TFA is essential for developing countries. The agreement will make it easier and cheaper for developing countries to trade, with the biggest gains realised in south-south trade, thereby facilitating their integration into regional and global value chains. Returns on a relatively modest up-front investment will be considerable in terms of growth, jobs and development The EU is committed to cover a significant share of the funding needs and technical assistance for counties most in need to implement the Agreement.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution outlining the clear and immediate economic benefits that the Marrakesh Agreement will bring to developing countries and which aims to eliminate the excessive and inefficient administration that presents these countries with major problems in multilateral trade.  With a view to implementing customs and administrative reform, some countries need support, so I consider that it is extremely useful to emphasise the concrete treatment that allows those states to decide when certain provisions will be applied and for which provisions technical assistance will be required.  In my view, developing countries and least developed countries should use as effectively as possible the €400 million allocated by the European Union initiative to support trade facilitation reforms to strengthen their economies and improve trade with other countries.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Easing trade is particularly important for developing countries, as they are expected to get the most increased general trade flows from more efficient trade procedures. Trade facilitation measures also help small businesses access new export opportunities, while giving them access to global trade routes. I supported the report.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because the report ignores the Principle of Development Policy Coherence. DEVE's view makes it clear that, even if there could be positive effects for developing countries, the first beneficiaries would be developed countries and, particularly, their corporations.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This trade facilitation agreement aims to speed up customs clearance procedures for goods. The treatment of developing countries will be differentiated while their infrastructure and the quality of their customs improve. The Bildegain report proposes to accept the Council's decision. While some provisions make sense, others are frankly wrong. We are therefore opposed to it for several reasons: - it is the continuation of the logic of free trade without borders or control with the "facilitation" of customs procedures. In the end, goods will be less controlled (more at all for goods in transit), checks and inspections of less frequent goods requested by the text; - there may be recourse to an independent judicial authority in the event of disagreement: this opens the way for an arbitration mechanism and will remove sovereignty from States;  - there is confiscation by the EU of an attribute of the trade policy of Member States with third countries;  - this report calls for further free trade that is supposed to enable developing countries to get out of poverty faster, a fact that is not necessarily verified by experience.  I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it because the report ignores the Principle of Development Policy Coherence. DEVE's view makes it clear that, even if there could be positive effects for developing countries, the first beneficiaries would be developed countries and, particularly, their corporations.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. On the two WTO reports that have been voted on in this plenary session, I voted against it. The WTO framework has been a space that has traditionally defended exporting industrialized countries, harming poor and developing countries. This report is not the Trade Facilitation Agreement itself, but it allows us to make our position on this issue clear. The TFA is one of the most damaging elements of the WTO for the weakest countries in the organization and continues to impose the interests of developed countries.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation for the EU to adopt a Protocol to the Marrakesh agreement, better known as the agreement that constituted the World Trade Organisation in 1995. This protocol is called the World Trade Facilitation Agreement and has the objectives of easing customs procedures, reducing border delays and cut costs for exporters, in particular small firms and producers in developing countries. The agreement in fact includes a technical assistance mechanism (for which the EU has pledged over EUR 400 million in 5 years) that would help developing countries to handle customs procedures: this mechanism could help both developed and developing countries to reduce export costs by as much as 10-15%.  The World Trade Facilitation agreement would take effect upon ratification by two thirds of all WTO members.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This agreement has been concluded by 159 WTO members with the aim of simplifying and accelerating customs procedures for the movement of goods worldwide. This simplification can help increase global economic growth. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that protocol.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We regret that issues relating to solidarity and mutual respect between peoples have not been addressed at the Bali Ministerial Conference, aimed at truly balanced and mutually beneficial trade relations, which do not destiture their resources (natural, cultural and labour), the least developed countries in favour of developed countries. In our view, a fair agreement should necessarily take into account the reduction of the discrepancy between "rich and poor countries", would have to guarantee and create decent jobs with rights, should safeguard natural resources and meet environmental protection objectives, as well as respect cultural diversity.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
