text: Writing. The report aims to keep the door open for tariff facilitation for developing countries. It also contains sensible proposals to improve the position of developing countries in the international economic fabric. This motion must therefore be supported.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of the WHO agreement on trade facilitation. The new agreement will bring clear and immediate economic benefits to developing countries. The text deals with shortcomings and burdensome administrative requirements, which are particularly problematic for developing countries. The ECR is a strong supporter of the multilateral trading system and believes that the agreement is of considerable benefit, not only for developing countries globally, but also for the EU and its Member States.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report deals with the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Protocol amending the Marrakesh Agreement establishing the World Trade Organisation (WTO) following its 9th Bali Ministerial Conference held in December 2013, in which the 160 members concluded negotiations on the "Trade Facilitation Agreement" , which deals with the first multilateral agreement since its creation in 1995 to establish a model for "customs modernisation". It is regrettable that issues relating to solidarity and mutual respect between peoples, which are really balanced and mutually beneficial trade relations, which do not outof their resources (natural, cultural and labour) in favour of developed countries, have not been addressed at the Bali Ministerial Conference. A fair agreement must necessarily take into account the reduction of the discrepancy between "rich and poor countries", will have to secure and create decent jobs with rights, should safeguard natural resources and meet environmental protection objectives, as well as respect cultural diversity. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to regularise and allow Austria, Belgium and Poland to join the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation. This Convention provides legal certainty in this area by laying down general rules on the obligations of the contracting parties and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand Shipping came into force in April 2005. It aims to harmonize contract rules and river transport standards in Europe. It is also impossible to ratify it without an authorisation from the European authorities.  Austria and Poland have expressed their willingness to join, while Belgium had already ratified the convention in August 2008. It is therefore, in the Belgian case, to grant them the authorisation retroactively in order to regularize their situation.   We consider that each Member State is free to ratify or not to ratify this convention. We therefore respect the will of the Belgians, Austrians and Poles.  So I voted for this draft decision.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not accept the principle that Austria, Belgium and Poland should require 'consent' of the European Parliament to do anything.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Budapest Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway entered into force in 2005.  Eleven Member States have already acceded to the Budapest Convention. This proposal empowers Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and for Austria to accede to it.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted for it. It is up to these Member States to choose whether or not to ratify this agreement on the contract for the transport of goods inland shipping.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of enabling Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention. This membership contributes to the improvement of the internal market in the field of transport.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the Council's draft decision aims to authorise Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify or join the Budapest Convention on the Domestic Goods Contract (CMNI).  The convention was adopted by a joint diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the Un Economic Commission for Europe. As each country remains free to join if it wishes to join this convention and not noticing any disadvantage for France, I have decided to vote in support.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Svoboda report does not pose any critical issues for our production system, but our opposition would prevent Belgium, Poland and Austria from joining the Budapest Convention regulating navigation on the Danube River, which is why I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway aims to promote inland navigation and harmonise its contracts and rules throughout Europe. Only those Member States which have navigation routes which fall within its scope are contracting parties thereof.  Although the Convention is an agreement which partially belongs to the exclusive competence of the European Union, it nevertheless provides for the possibility for the Union to become a Party, and Member States may not ratify or accede to it without the authorization of the Union (Article 2(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). Eleven of the Member States are already Parties to the Convention, while fifteen Member States have indicated that they do not have inland waterways covered by that Convention. Belgium, Austria and Poland have expressed an interest in becoming Parties to the Convention. Their participation will encourage the broad application of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses, and it is therefore appropriate to give approval to the decision to authorise Belgium and Poland to ratify, and Austria, to accede to the Budapest Convention.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on Parliament's report by which Parliament approves the Council's decision to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Agreement on the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway (CMNI). This Convention authorises the Ratification of the Budapest Convention between the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland and allows the Republic of Austria to accede to this draft.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Inland Waterway Contract was adopted by a diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine and the Danube Commission in cooperation with the UN Economic Commission for Europe. The Treaty entered into force on 1 April 2005, thereby facilitating the harmonisation of contracts and inland waterway standards in the field of transport, which contributes to the efficient functioning of the internal market. The Budapest Convention is an agreement which is partly exclusively within the competence of the EU. Consequently, Member States cannot confirm or accede to it without EU authorisation. Belgium ratified the Convention on 5 August 2008, following the entry into force of the Rome I Regulation (the law applicable to contractual obligations) on 24 July 2008. It is therefore necessary to grant retroactive authorisation in order to resolve the current unregulated legal situation. Austria has indicated that it intends to join the Convention and Poland intends to ratify it. The party of these Member States will promote the broad application of the Convention, providing benefits for citizens and businesses. Consequently, the draft decision authorifies Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and austria to join it.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this recommendation to ratify the Budapest Convention for Belgium and Poland, as well as austria's accession to the Convention.  So far, 11 countries are involved in the inland navigation process, while 15 countries do not have inland waterways covered by the Convention. As these Members have expressed a desire to ratify and join, I support this recommendation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this authorisation because I believe that the accession of Austria, Belgium and Poland to the Budapest Convention will bring great benefits to citizens and businesses, not just the countries in question.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand Shipping came into force in April 2005. It aims to harmonize contract rules and river transport standards in Europe. It is also impossible to ratify it without an authorisation from the European authorities. Austria and Poland have expressed their willingness to join, while Belgium had already ratified the convention in August 2008. It is therefore, in the Belgian case, to grant them the authorisation retroactively in order to regularize their situation.  We consider that each Member State is free to ratify or not to ratify this convention. We therefore respect the will of the Belgians, Austrians and Poles. That is why I voted for this draft decision.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft decision of the Council authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway (CMNI) and the Republic of Austria respectively to accede to it. Both the accession of Belgium and Poland and Austria's ratification of this Convention provide a much better regulated framework for the transport of goods by inland waterway. The participation of these countries in the Convention is for the benefit of citizens as well as businesses and will contribute to the implementation of this legal instrument alongside the other 11 Member States that are already parties to the Convention.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this measure, which is of no importance to our production system. The Budapest Convention deals, in essence, with regulating navigation on the Rhine and Danube rivers. The members of the Convention are the States concerned for transport or commercial reasons. The EU as such cannot join, but a formal consensus of the European institutions is needed to allow – in this case Belgium, Poland and Austria – to be part of it. For this reason, a 'no' vote would mean preventing these Member States from ratifying the Convention, and there is no reason to do so.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland, respectively, to ratify and the Republic of Austria to accede to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods for Inland Navigation (CMNI). The Convention makes a major contribution to the functioning of the internal market in the transport sector by harmonising contractual and inland waterway transport rules at European level. Eleven Member States are already contracting parties to the Convention, while fifteen Member States have indicated that they do not have inland waterways falling within the scope of the Convention. Austria and Poland have expressed their interest in being part of the Convention, and there is no doubt that their participation will promote the large-scale implementation of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses. Belgium, on the other hand, needs retroactive authorisation in order to regularise the current irregular situation, having ratified the Budapest Convention on 5 August 2008 without first waiting for authorisation from the European Union.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The principle that Austria, Belgium and Poland should require ‘consent’ of the European Parliament to do anything, is, in my opinion absurd. This is one of many examples highlighting Member States’ subservience to the EU institutions.  Hence, I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to authorise Belgium and Poland to ratify, and Austria to accede to, the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 With the report, Parliament gives its assent to the decision to authorise Austria, Belgium and Romania to become part of the Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway. Eleven Member States are already party to the Convention and the addition of these three should facilitate the full application of the legal instrument, to the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted for this project because it leaves it possible for Austria, Belgium and Poland to join or not to join the Budapest Convention on the Domestic Goods Contract (CMNI). In my opinion, this does not represent a disadvantage for France, so I voted for it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention constitutes an agreement that falls partly within the exclusive competence of the European Union. However, the Convention does not provide for the possibility for the Union to become a Contracting Party. The draft decision therefore authorises Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and Austria to accede to it.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision authorising Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the contract for the carriage of goods by inland waterway and Austria to join it. The Budapest Convention, which entered into force on 1 April 2005, contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the transport sector through the harmonisation of contractual and inland waterway rules at European level. The Budapest Convention is an agreement which falls partly within the exclusive competence of the European Union. However, it does not provide for the possibility for the European Union to become a part of it. Member States may not, however, ratify or join it without union authorisation. To date, eleven EU Member States are already contracting parties to the Budapest Convention, while fifteen Member States have announced that they do not have inland waterways falling within the scope of the Convention.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because it contributes to the functioning of the internal market through the harmonisation of contractual and inland waterway rules at European level. I am convinced that the participation of Austria, Belgium and Poland will promote the large-scale implementation of this legal instrument, for the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The entry of new countries as members of the Budapest Convention contributes to a better functioning of the internal transport market. The Convention provides for the harmonization of contractual and inland waterway transport rules at European level. Although the Convention does not provide for the accession of the European Union, Member States interested in navigation on the Rhine and Danube rivers are encouraged to join.  I strongly support the draft ratification by Belgium and Poland and the accession of Austria, as the participation of these countries will promote a broader implementation of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to regularise and allow Austria, Belgium and Poland to join the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation. This Convention provides legal certainty in this area by laying down general rules on the obligations of the contracting parties and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Resolution is meant to give the consent of Parliament to the Council decision authorising Belgium and Poland to ratify, and Austria to accede to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. As of today, eleven of the Member States are already parties, while fifteen have indicated that they do not have inland waterways covered by the convention. Austria and Poland have expressed an interest in becoming parties to the convention. Belgium ratified the convention on 5 August 2008. It is therefore necessary to give retroactive authorisation in order to rectify the current irregular situation. For these reasons I voted in favour this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to allow Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Domestic Goods Contract (CMNI), and Austria to join.  Signed in 2005, this convention of international law contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and standards of inland navigation in Europe.  Knowing that Austria and Poland have expressed a desire to become contracting parties to the Convention, and that Belgium ratified the convention on 5 August 2008, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – With my vote, I want to contribute to the aim of harmonising contractual standards and inland navigation standards in Europe and to the proper functioning of the internal market. Belgium had already ratified this in 2008 but was still in an illegal situation, which means that Europe now also has to grant authorisation to Belgium.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Entry into force on 1 April 2005, the Budapest Convention contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the transport sector through the harmonisation of contractual and inland waterway rules at European level. Although the Budapest Convention is an agreement that only partially falls within the exclusive competence of the European Union, the Member States cannot ratify or join it without the union's authorisation. Austria and Poland have expressed their interest in becoming parties to this Convention, while Belgium ratified it on 5 August 2008 and retroactive authorisation is therefore required. I voted in favour of authoring the ratification of the Convention for these Member States because I believe that their participation will promote the large-scale implementation of this legal instrument, for the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Inland Waterway Contract was adopted by a diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine and the Danube Commission in cooperation with the UN Economic Commission for Europe and entered into force on 1 April 2005, thereby facilitating the harmonisation of contracts and inland waterway standards in the field of transport, which contributes to the efficient functioning of the internal market. The Budapest Convention is an agreement which is partly exclusively within the competence of the EU. Consequently, Member States cannot confirm or accede to it without EU authorisation. Belgium ratified the Convention on 5 August 2008, following the entry into force of the Rome I Regulation (the law applicable to contractual obligations) on 24 July 2008. It is therefore necessary to grant retroactive authorisation in order to resolve the current irregular legal situation. Austria has also indicated that it intends to join the Convention and Poland intends to ratify it. The party of these Member States will promote the broad application of the Convention, providing benefits for citizens and businesses. Consequently, the draft decision authorifies Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and austria to join it.  In view of the above, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. A Member State's accession to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand must be authorised by the European Union. Even if it is again a supranational hold on the nations, the desire for membership comes from the States themselves. It is therefore natural to regularise this situation and to support the authorisation of the ratification of the Budapest Convention by Austria, Belgium and Poland. That is why I voted for this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Accession to the Budapest Convention (CMNI) is a good step forward in streamlining contractual and navigation standards.  The use of maritime transport routes has long created a problem especially for my country and we often struggle with the non-recognition of judgments and issues regarding the choice of law for individual countries. In order for everyone to be satisfied with the means of transport concerned, we need an integrated legal system of mutually recognised competences of the other.  This will stimulate economic growth, competitiveness and legal stability. And the common judicial space will not only provide greater legal certainty, it will also promote awareness and appreciation for the use of inland waterways in order to effectively and mutually benefit without destroying the latter.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We consider that the development of trade within the EU, but also with large players such as Russia and Switzerland, has only to offer to the economies of the Member States. Through trade, Member States can tighten their economic relations with Russia, a country that the EU perceives as an enemy.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and rules on inland navigation in Europe. It is an agreement partly covered by the exclusive competence of the European Union. However, the Convention does not provide for the possibility for the Union to become a party.  Eleven Member States are already parties to the Budapest Convention and fifteen Member States have indicated that their inland waterways are not covered by the Convention. Austria and Poland have expressed interest in becoming parties to the Convention and their participation will encourage a wider application of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses. Belgium ratified the Budapest Convention on 5 August 2008. I agree with your agreement to the Budapest Convention.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, because it does not have a problem for France.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this measure. The Budapest Convention regulates navigation on the Rhine and Danube rivers.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this mandate because I believe that the development of trade both within the EU and with big players, such as Russia and Switzerland, has only benefits to offer to the economies of the Member States. Through trade, Member States can tighten their economic relations with Russia, a country that the EU perceives as an enemy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Budapest Convention is thus an agreement falling partly under exclusive European Union competence. However, the convention does not provide for the possibility for the Union to become a party. Nevertheless, Member States cannot ratify or accede to it without an authorisation by the Union (Article 2(1) TFEU). In this case, the Union’s exclusive competence is limited to a single provision, and an authorisation given to individual Member States would not have a negative effect on the implementation of the Union’s external policy on judicial cooperation in civil and commercial matters. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Inland Waterway Contract was adopted by a diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine and the Danube Commission in cooperation with the UN Economic Commission for Europe and entered into force on 1 April 2005. It contributes to the internal market by harmonising contracts and inland waterway standards in the field of transport. Eleven Member States are already parties to the Budapest Convention, while 15 Member States have indicated that they do not have inland waterways covered by the Convention. Austria and Poland have indicated their intention to join the Convention. Their participation will promote the broad application of the Convention, providing benefits for citizens and businesses. Furthermore, Belgium has ratified the Convention. Consequently, it authorifies Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and austria to join it. For these reasons, I, in addition to the rapporteur's proposal, support Parliament's consent to the mandate.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the 'Recommendation on the draft Council decision authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Treaty on the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation (CMNI) and on the authorisation of the Republic of Austria to accede to this Convention', as I consider the political and technical proposals made therein to be the right step.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I have given my consent to the authorisation of Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and to Austria's authorisation to accede to it. Their participation will bring benefits for citizens and businesses.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving Austria, Belgium and Poland the authorisation to ratify, or to accede to, the Convention on the contract for the carriage of goods by inland waterways (CMNI) and thereby of facilitating their pursuit of a better harmonised policy on transport by inland navigation.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation Routes contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and rules for inland navigation throughout Europe. Its ratification by Belgium, Austria and Poland will encourage the broad application of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses. Parliament is right to recommend such ratification.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted for this report on the Budapest Convention. This agreement covers contracts for the transport of goods inland shipping, mainly on the Rhine, Danube and their tributaries. It is essentially about harmonising these contracts with the standards of inland navigation in Europe. The adopted report approves the draft Council decision authorizing the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland respectively to ratify the Budapest Convention, and the Republic of Austria to join.  This approval is made necessary because Member States cannot ratify or accede to the Convention without an EU authorisation. While this limit on their sovereignty may be regretted, it does not justify preventing States that wish to do so from accepting the Budapest Convention.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Pavel Svoboda Report, which aims to authorise ratification, namely that of the Budapest Convention, concerning the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. The Convention, for its part, aimed to lay down the rules for the delivery, payment, collection and shipment of materials in internal trade transport.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today, in the plenary session, it was a privilege to have given consent to the accession of the Kingdom of Belgium, the Republic of Poland and the Republic of Austria to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. While this only represents the standard procedure through which Member States want to become party to international agreements which fall under the competence of the EU, it was still a remarkable occasion to facilitate these three countries’ pursuit of a better harmonised policy on transport by inland navigation.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the draft on the authorisation for Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify the Convention. I believe that the Member States which have navigable inland waterways falling within the scope of the Budapest Convention should therefore be authorised to ratify or accede to the Convention. Since the expressed interest of Austria and Poland to become a part of the convention, their participation will foster the broad implementation of this legal instrument, with benefits for citizens and businesses. Even though Belgium ratified the convention on 5 August 2008, I do consider that we should give retroactive authorisation in order to rectify the current irregular situation.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Paved Svoboda Report, which aims to authorise ratification, namely that of the Budapest Convention, concerning the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. The Convention, for its part, aimed to lay down the rules for the delivery, payment, collection and shipment of materials in internal trade transport.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision granting the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland the ratification of the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods by Inland Waterways and the Republic of Austria to join that Convention, as this contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising inland navigation standards, and contracts for the welfare of businesses and citizens.  While the European Union cannot be a contracting party to the Convention as such, Member States cannot accede to it without EU authorisation, and so far 11 Member States have acceded to the Convention. Therefore, given the importance of the Convention for states with inland waterways, I strongly support the authorisation of the ratification process for Poland and Belgium and Austria's approach to it.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand Shipping came into force in April 2005. It aims to harmonize contract rules and river transport standards in Europe. It is also impossible to ratify it without an authorisation from the European authorities. Austria and Poland have expressed their willingness to join, while Belgium had already ratified the convention in August 2008. It is therefore, in the Belgian case, to grant them the authorisation retroactively in order to regularize their situation.  We consider that each Member State is free to ratify or not to ratify this convention. We therefore respect the will of the Belgians, Austrians and Poles. That is why I voted for this draft decision.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Svoboda report on Parliament's approval of a Council decision authorising Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Inland Shipping Freight Contract ("CMNI"). This decision will allow certain situations to be normalised from a legal point of view and to harmonize contracts and standards of inland navigation in Europe, for the benefit of both citizens and businesses, which is why I welcome the positive vote of the European Parliament.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sought the opinion of the European Parliament on the Council's decision to allow Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods in Internal Navigation (CMNI).

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report. Waterways should be better used for the transport of goods, and the Budapest Convention sets an acceptable framework for this.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have decided to give a positive opinion on this project. The Budapest Convention dating back to 2005 was adopted by the Diplomatic Conference organised jointly by the Central Commission for Navigation on the Rhine and the Danube Commission, in cooperation with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. It aims to harmonize contractual and inland waterway transport rules between European countries. Eleven Member States, including Belgium, have acceded to the Convention and both Austria and Poland have expressed their willingness to accede to it. Their participation will promote the broad implementation of this legal instrument, for the benefit of citizens and businesses.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the council's draft decision authorising Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand, and the Republic of Austria to join. The Budapest Convention aims to harmonize contracts and domestic navigation standards in Europe. Austria and Poland have expressed a desire to become contracting parties. Belgium ratified the convention on 5 August 2008. It is therefore also necessary to receive the union's authorisation, in order to remedy the irregularity of the current situation. As each country remains free to join this convention if it wishes and not noticing any inconvenience for France, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to regularise and allow Austria, Belgium and Poland to join the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation. This Convention provides legal certainty in this area by laying down general rules on the obligations of the contracting parties and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I see no reason to prevent states from concluding this agreement if it is their will.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Budapest Convention on the Treaty on the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways entered into force on 1 April 2015. It covers issues such as the rights and obligations of the Contracting Parties, transport documents, the liability of the fare and the time limits for the setting of claims. The Convention applies to contracts for the international transport of goods between States of which at least one is a party to the Convention and contributes to the internal market in the field of transport, harmonisation of contracts and internal navigation standards across Europe. The Convention is an agreement falling under the exclusive competence of the European Union. Nevertheless, it does not allow the Union to become a participant, but Member States cannot ratify or join the Convention without union approval. Eleven Member States are already members of the Convention and 15 have pointed to the fact that they do not have inland waterways covered by this Convention. Austria and Poland have shown interest in joining the Convention. Belgium ratified the Convention on 5 August 2008, after the Rome Regulation entered into force. I supported a report authorifying Belgium and Poland to ratify and Austria to join the Convention, as the implementation of this legal tool has broad significance for the development of transport rights, as well as for the development of small and medium-sized enterprises near inland waterways.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 There are countries in the European Union that have not yet been annexed to the Convention, although they are EU Member States. I voted in favour with the group.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council Decision authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland respectively to ratify the Budapest Convention on Inland Waterway Freight Transport Contracts (CMNI) and the Republic of Austria to accede to it because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this draft ratification. The ratification of this convention by these countries will allow for the harmonisation of domestic navigation contracts in Europe. On the plus side, this draft decision recognizes the freedom of each state to choose whether or not to join. This decision will have little or no impact on France, so we can vote for it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways was adopted by a diplomatic conference organised jointly by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, and entered into force on 1 April 2005. It contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and inland navigation standards across Europe. Article 29 of the Budapest Convention contains provisions on the choice of law by the parties to a contract of carriage falling under the convention. Those provisions affect the rules laid down in the Rome I Regulation (Regulation (EC) No 593/2008 on the law applicable to contractual obligations). The Budapest Convention is thus an agreement falling partly under exclusive European Union competence. However, the convention does not provide for the possibility for the Union to become a party. Nevertheless, Member States cannot ratify or accede to it without an authorisation by the Union (Article 2(1) TFEU).

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods for Inland Navigation entered into force on 1 April 2005. It is of fundamental importance for the functioning of the internal market in the transport sector, since it has the effect of harmonizing contractual and inland waterway rules at European level.  For these basic reasons, I have decided to support this document, which authorises Austria, Belgium and Poland to join the agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the Recommendation authorising Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify or accede to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways (CMNI) is supported by .u2012. Eleven Member States are already part of this important convention, as it contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and inland navigation rules throughout Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Budapest Convention on the Treaty on the Carriage of Goods in Inland Navigation is also of great interest and importance to Austria, as it clearly deals with and regulates important issues in this area, such as the regulation on freight documents, the non-culpable liability of the sender or the carrier's liability. As Austria clearly benefits from this Treaty in the field of Danube navigation, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention (2005) creates a legal regime for international river freight transport. Eleven EU Member States have already joined the Convention, while 15 EU Member States have said they have no inland waterways under the Convention. Austria, Poland and Belgium subsequently expressed a desire to become contracting parties to the convention. Their participation will promote wider implementation of this legal instrument, enabling the development of river transport within the EU for the benefit of citizens and the environment.  The report before us allows Belgium, Poland and Austria to join. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand Shipping came into force in April 2005. It aims to harmonize contract rules and river transport standards in Europe. It is also impossible to ratify it without an authorisation from the European authorities. Austria and Poland have expressed their willingness to join, while Belgium had already ratified the convention in August 2008. It is therefore, in the Belgian case, to grant them the authorisation retroactively in order to regularize their situation.  We consider that each Member State is free to ratify or not to ratify this convention. We therefore respect the will of the Belgians, Austrians and Poles. For these reasons, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention was adopted by the Diplomatic Conference jointly organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Reno and the Danube Commission, in collaboration with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE). The Budapest Convention, which entered into force on 1 April 2005, proved to be a great success and contributes to the smooth functioning of the internal market in the field of transport. It aims to harmonise contractual and inland waterway standards between European countries.  By being part of this convention the acceding countries will benefit from the benefits of this convention. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in support of authorisation. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways establishes common standards for the carriage of goods through domestic waterways. Austria, Belgium, and Poland have expressed interest in becoming parties to the agreement, which first requires authorisation by the EU. I supported these three Member States to join with the eleven others that are already part of the agreement.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report on authorisation for Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify, or to accede to, the Convention on the contract for the carriage of goods by inland waterways. I believe it will be an important contribution to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and inland navigation standards across Europe.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Inland Water contract entered into force on 1 April 2005. The Convention is an agreement which falls partly within the exclusive competence of the Union but does not allow the Union to join. Member States, on the other hand, cannot confirm or join it without EU authorisation. Eleven Member States are already parties to the Budapest Convention and a further 15 have indicated that they do not have inland waterways covered by the Convention. Austria and Poland intend to join the Convention belgium ratified the Convention on 5 August 2008, a few days after the entry into force on 24 July 2008 of the Rome i Regulation which stated that agreements falling wholly or partly exclusively within the competence of the Union may be ratified by the Member States only with EU authorisation. In order to resolve the current irregular legal situation, it is necessary to grant retroactive authorisation. Consequently, the draft decision authorifies Belgium to ratify the Budapest Convention and Austria and Poland to join it. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Waterway contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and rules on inland navigation in Europe. I would point out that the EU cannot be part of the Convention and that its Member States can only accede if properly authorised by the EU.  I would like to say that the EU's foreign policy on judicial cooperation in civil and commercial matters is not at all affected by the fact that its Member States accede to the Convention. In view of the foregoing and the expression of interest on the part of Austria and Poland in becoming parties to the Convention and the need for retroactive authorisation to correct belgium's ratification, I have nothing to support this Recommendation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the Council's draft decision aims to authorise Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify or join the Budapest Convention on the Domestic Goods Contract (CMNI). The convention was adopted by a joint diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. As each country remains free to join if it wishes to join this convention and not noticing any disadvantage for France, I have decided to vote in support.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text which allows Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and Austria to join it. It is a question of these countries joining the other Member States in this convention in order to standardise the conditions for transporting goods by water and to obtain an international standard for the development of this type of transport.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the proposal because I am convinced (particularly on the basis of my experience in my home town of Linz) that inland waterway transport plays a role in the modern economy that should not be underestimated. Their promotion is therefore already of great importance – this is all the more true in times of congestion on roads and motorways. Legal certainty plays an important role in making this means of transport attractive and is strengthened by this proposal to ratify the Budapest Convention.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement falls partly within the exclusive competence of the EU, so Austria, Belgium and Poland need the EU's consent to ratify it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the EU authorisation for Belgium, Poland and Austria to join the Budapest Convention as provided for in Article 2(1) TFEU, as I believe that an extension of this Convention to more and more Member States will benefit European citizens. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods by Inland Waterways, which entered into force on 1 April 2005, contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contractual and internal navigation standards across Europe. The Convention does not provide for the possibility of the European Union becoming a party.  However, Member States cannot ratify or join the Convention without authorisation by the European Union. Eleven Member States of the European Union with inland navigation routes covered by the Convention have already become its parties and benefit from the benefits offered by the Convention, and the EU recognises the importance of signing the Convention for its Member States.  Recognising the importance of creating instruments for harmonising contractual and internal navigation standards across Europe and the benefits they bring to signatory countries, I support granting the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland ratification of the Budapest Convention and the Republic of Austria joining the Convention.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report on the Council's draft decision aims to authorise or join Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify or join the Budapest Convention on the Domestic Goods Contract (CMNI). The convention was adopted by a joint diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the UN Economic Commission for Europe. As each country remains free to join if it wishes to join this convention and not noticing any disadvantage for France, I have decided to vote in support.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways (08223/15/ADD1), the Council's request for consent in accordance with Article 81 of the Regulation paragraph 2 and Article 218(6) of the second sub-paragraph (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (C8-0173/2015), Article 99(1) of the first and third sub-sections, Article 99(2) and Article 108(7) of the ECT). The Rules of Procedure, as well as the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0231/2015), agree with that recommendation on the draft Council decision granting the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland the ratification of the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods inland Waterways (CMNI), and the Republic of Austria joining that Convention, which will further encourage the transport and transport of goods along these routes.  I hope that the European Union will continue to encourage the development of inland waterways, as a constructive alternative to road and rail transport.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Budapest Convention was adopted by the Diplomatic Conference jointly organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the River and the Danube Commission, in cooperation with the UN Economic Commission for Europe. It entered into force on 1 April 2005 and aims to harmonise contractual and navigational standards on inland waterways in European countries. The Convention contains provisions on the choice by the parties of the right to a contract of carriage covered by the Convention. Poland has expressed interest in acceding to the Budapest Convention on several occasions. Poland is committed to adopting a Council decision as soon as possible, which will enable it to become bound by the Budapest Convention, which Poland has been seeking for several years. That is why I supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention came into force in 2005 but since then new Member States have wanted to join. I voted in favour of the report authorising Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods inLand Shipping.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Waterway, which entered into force on 1 April 2005, contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and rules on inland navigation in Europe. Partly covered by the exclusive competence of the EU, in so far as it allows the parties to choose the law applicable to the transport contract falling within the scope of the Convention, this agreement may not be ratified or be the subject of membership by the Member States, without them being authorised by the Union (Article 2(1) TFEU). Austria and Poland have expressed an interest in becoming parties to the Convention. On the other hand, Belgium ratified the Budapest Convention on 5 August 2008 and it was therefore necessary to carry out a retroactive authorisation in order to correct the current irregular situation. This draft decision authorises Belgium and Poland to ratify and Austria to accede to the Budapest Convention. I voted in favour of their approval.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support the recommendations on the draft Council decision authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods by Inland Waterways (CMNI) and the Republic of Austria to join that Convention.  The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods by Inland Waterways was accepted at a diplomatic conference of the Central Commission for navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in cooperation with the UN Economic Commission for Europe. It entered into force on 1 April 2005 and contributes to the internal market in the field of transport, by harmonising contracts and inland navigation standards across Europe.  I support the agreement of the Council decision authorising the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways and the Republic of Austria to join that Convention.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Entry into force on 1 April 2005, the Budapest Convention contributes to the functioning of the internal market in the transport sector through the harmonisation of contractual and inland waterway rules at European level. Austria and Poland have expressed their interest in becoming parties to the Convention. Their participation will promote the large-scale implementation of this legal instrument, for the benefit of citizens and businesses. Belgium ratified the Budapest Convention on 5 August 2008. Retroactive authorisation is therefore required in order to regularise the current irregular situation. The draft decision therefore authorises Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention and Austria to join it. I voted in favour of this report on assent.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterway aims to promote inland navigation and harmonise its contracts and rules throughout Europe. Only those Member States which have navigation routes which fall within its scope are contracting parties thereof.  Although the Convention is an agreement which partially belongs to the exclusive competence of the European Union, it nevertheless provides for the possibility for the Union to become a Party, and Member States may not ratify or accede to it without the authorization of the Union (Article 2(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). Eleven of the Member States are already Parties to the Convention, while fifteen Member States have indicated that they do not have inland waterways covered by that Convention. Belgium, Austria and Poland have expressed an interest in becoming Parties to the Convention. Their participation will encourage the broad application of this legal instrument for the benefit of citizens and businesses, and it is therefore appropriate to give approval to the decision to authorise Belgium and Poland to ratify, and Austria, to accede to the Budapest Convention.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft resolution which authorise Belgium and Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the contract for the transport of inland shipping markets, and the Republic of Austria to join it. The Budapest Convention came into force in 2005 and contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and domestic navigation standards in Europe.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a recommendation seeks to allow the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Navigation and the Republic of Austria to accede to that Convention, which is considered to be an important instrument for promoting navigation within Europe. The Budapest Convention shall apply to any contract for the carriage of goods in which the port of cargo or place of taking charge and the port of unloading or place of delivery of the goods are located in two different States, of which at least one is a State Party to the Convention.  If the contract provides for a choice of several landing ports or delivery locations, the port of landing or the place of delivery to which the goods were actually delivered will determine the choice. Member States which have inland waterways falling within the scope of the Budapest Convention should therefore be allowed to ratify or accede to this instrument. I agree, so I voted in a favourable way.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Syod's proposal. Svoboda, concerning the authorisation for Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify or access the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods for Inland Navigation (CMNI).

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Paved Svoboda Report, which aims to authorise ratification, namely that of the Budapest Convention, concerning the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. The Convention, for its part, aimed to lay down the rules for the delivery, payment, collection and shipment of materials in internal trade transport

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to regularise and allow Austria, Belgium and Poland to join the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Navigation. This Convention provides legal certainty in this area by laying down general rules on the obligations of the contracting parties and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this due to the fact I do not believe that a nation state should have to ask for permission from the EU for anything.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, in the plenary session, it was a privilege to have given consent to the accession of the Kingdom of Belgium, the Republic of Poland and the Republic of Austria to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. While this only represents the standard procedure through which Member States want to become party to international agreements (which fall – even partly – under the competence of the EU), it was still a remarkable occasion to facilitate these three countries' pursuit of a better harmonised policy on transport by inland navigation.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft Council decision granting the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland the ratification of the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods inland Waterways (CMNI) and the Republic of Austria joining that Convention, taking into account Article 99(1) of paragraph 1 and 3 of the sub-section, Article 99(2) and Article 108(7) of the ECT. rules of procedure, and taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs. Austria and Poland have expressed interest in being included as parties to the Convention. Their participation will have many benefits for citizens and businesses. Belgium ratified the Convention on 5 August 2008, following the entry into force of the Rome I Regulations of 24 July 2008. Therefore, in this case it is necessary to give retroactive authorisation on ratification.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support a recommendation that allows the already agreed contracts for the transport of goods by inland waterways to be ratified as soon as possible, as it is fundamental for as much support as possible to the project of developing the area around the Danube River. Some non-EU countries also have access to this project. The adoption of the Budapest Charter will accelerate economic development and improve trade in Europe's internal waterways and at the same time provide access to waterways for those countries whose membership can benefit all parties involved in the charter.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ as there is no reason to restrict Austria, Belgium and Poland's access to this Convention.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We consider that the development of trade within the EU, but also with large players such as Russia and Switzerland, has only to offer to the economies of the Member States. Through trade, Member States can tighten their economic relations with Russia, a country that the EU perceives as an enemy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Inland waterways are a strategic asset of the European Union, both economically and socially. They allow the interconnection of Member States using the natural courses of the main rivers or of man-made connecting channels over time. This is a less polluting mode of transport, but also more advantageous in terms of price.  For these reasons, this type of transport must be supported at European Union level. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Navigation, adopted in 2001, regulates the commercial exploitation of inland waterways, setting uniform standards and harmonising national rules already in place in the 11 EU Member States that are signatories to the Convention. The accession of Austria, Belgium and Poland to this Convention constitutes a real gain, because it ensures the completion of the common navigation area by facilitating commercial transport activity. The European Union has the power to approve the accession of new Member States to the Convention.  I therefore believe that it is necessary to support this formal approach in order to strengthen the network of the Union's inland waterways, which is an important advantage for ensuring the coherence of the European common market.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways was adopted by a diplomatic conference organised jointly by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, and entered into force on 1 April 2005. It contributes to the internal market in the field of transport by harmonising contracts and inland navigation standards across Europe.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the ratification of Belgium and Poland and Austria's accession to the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods by Inland Waterways, as this Convention has proved to be extremely useful in achieving its purpose, namely to align contractual and inland waterway navigation standards with regard to the internal market in the field of transport.  This experience has some Member States of the European Union, such as Croatia, the Czech Republic, France, Germany and Hungary, which have an interest in participating in this Convention and are already Contracting Parties and their carriers are subject to the obligations, responsibilities and rights that this Convention adopts.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The Budapest Convention is an agreement that falls partly within the exclusive competence of the European Union. However, the Convention does not provide for the possibility of the Union becoming a Contracting Party. However, member states cannot ratify or join it without the authorisation of the Union. Eleven Member States are Contracting Parties to the Budapest Convention and 15 Member States have stated that they do not have inland waterways covered by this Convention. Austria and Poland have expressed interest in becoming Parties to the Convention. As their participation will promote the broad implementation of this legal instrument, which will benefit citizens and businesses, I supported the report.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Paved Svoboda Report, which aims to authorise ratification, namely that of the Budapest Convention, concerning the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. The Convention, for its part, aimed to lay down the rules for the delivery, payment, collection and shipment of materials in internal trade transport.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Transport of Goods in Inland Shipping was adopted by a joint diplomatic conference organised by the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine and the Danube Commission in collaboration with the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe and came into force on 1 April 2005. It aims to harmonize contracts and standards for inland navigation in Europe. Member States cannot ratify or accede to it without an EU authorisation (Article 2, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). Austria and Poland have expressed a desire to become contracting parties. Belgium ratified the convention on 5 August 2008, following the entry into force of the Rome I Regulation which came into force on 24 July 2008. It is therefore necessary that Belgium should also be the recipient of the Eu's authorisation, retroactively, in order to remedy the irregularity of the current situation. As each country remains free to join if it wishes to join this convention and does not see any inconvenience for France, I vote for this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Paved Svoboda Report, which aims to authorise ratification, namely that of the Budapest Convention, concerning the Contract for the Carriage of Goods by Inland Waterways. The Convention, for its part, aimed to lay down the rules for the delivery, payment, collection and shipment of materials in internal trade transport.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report, which authorises Austria, Belgium and Poland to ratify a Convention which gives greater legal certainty to internal naval transport.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. That authorisation is intended to authorise Austria and Poland to accede to that convention and to authorise Belgium with retroactive effect, which has already acceded to the Convention in August 2008. I therefore think it is appropriate to vote in favour of that Recommendation in order to approve the draft Council Decision.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is to authorise the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Navigation, and the Republic of Austria to accede to that Convention and is considered an important instrument for promoting inland navigation throughout Europe. The Budapest Convention shall apply to any contract for the carriage of goods in which the port of cargo or place of taking charge and the port of unloading or place of delivery of the goods are located in two different States, of which at least one is a State Party to the Convention.  If the contract provides for a choice of several landing ports or delivery locations, the port of landing or the place of delivery to which the goods were actually delivered will determine the choice. Member States with inland waterways falling within the scope of the Budapest Convention should therefore be allowed to ratify or accede to this instrument. Agree.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Budapest Convention on the Treaty on the Carriage of Goods in Inland Navigation is also of great interest and importance to Austria, as it clearly deals with and regulates important issues in this area, such as the regulation on freight documents, the non-culpable liability of the sender or the carrier's liability. As Austria clearly benefits from this Treaty in the field of Danube navigation, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This Recommendation seeks to authorise the Kingdom of Belgium and the Republic of Poland to ratify the Budapest Convention on the Contract for the Carriage of Goods in Inland Waterway, and the Republic of Austria to accede to that Convention and is considered an important instrument for promoting inland navigation throughout Europe. The Budapest Convention shall apply to any contract for the carriage of goods in which the port of cargo or place of taking charge and the port of unloading or place of delivery of the goods are located in two different States, of which at least one is a State Party to the Convention. If the contract provides for a choice of several landing ports or delivery locations, the port of landing or the place of delivery to which the goods were actually delivered will determine the choice. Member States with inland waterways falling within the scope of the Budapest Convention should therefore be allowed to ratify or accede to this instrument. We voted for it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I did not vote in favour of Mrs Keller's report. Not because I'm against solidarity. Vice versa. It's necessary, it's necessary. It's an expression of our humanity. By personal means, I try to help refugees, especially Christian families who come to the Czech Republic and who will be taken care of. They are fleeing persecution of the Islamic State. And it's in line with our values to help these people. However, I did not vote in favour of the report because it goes beyond the common agreement of the Member States on a one-off measure in the form of the redistribution of 40 000 refugees, which took place at the Council meeting in June this year. I consider it essential that it is the representatives of the Member States responsible for security who agree to accept refugees for the implementation of asylum policy on the territory of their states. The role of the European Parliament is certainly not in making decisions for them.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I supported the Keller report with conviction: it is a report that identifies some key priorities, considers the identified figure of 40 thousand migrants to be insufficient and calls for it to be only a starting point and for the quota system to become permanent.  I believe that what we have heard this morning also from Juncker is absolutely not enough, and I think it is absolutely wrong to make an obsessive distinction between economic migrants and refugees. This distinction shows that the main policy is aimed at controlling migratory flows rather than protecting the right of asylum. I hope that the Union's policy on migration will soon be changed, that the policy of the right of asylum will be changed, that we will think of welcoming European citizenship and that the Dublin Regulation will be amended.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I did not support the quotas voted on in this report. I have long been convinced that this administrative measure will not work in practice. We should allow asylum seekers to apply in a European country where they want, where they want to operate, and that European country should decide on their asylum if they meet international legal conditions. To me, this measure seems wrong, goes against the interests of asylum seekers and, above all, will not work in practice. These people are going to go to countries where they want to work, where they have family. And I believe that, ultimately, such an administrative distribution of asylum seekers can lead to a rise in sentiment in Europe against the Schengen area. And tempers will rise for the reopening of borders between countries, which I consider to be the biggest problem. Therefore, in line with the Czech Government, I am in solidarity, but against the administrative distribution of applicants.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, this is not just an historic day here in the European Parliament, but also in the UK, as we mark the anniversary of our Queen as the longest—serving reigning monarch. Her first speech as a teenager was to show solidarity with child refugees who had left their homes to escape the dangers of the Second World War. Though the situation of those escaping from Syria, Libya and Iraq today is very different from that of those escaping then, they face the same ordeal of having to flee their homes, often without any parent. There are 3 000 unaccompanied children in the camps in Italy. What is being done to ensure that they are permanently relocated and given positive protection and support? That is why I voted for the Keller report: because it is clear that we need to address the refugee crisis as the European Union as a whole, and we need to do it now.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to be brief. I mean, I supported mrs Keller's report, even though I did not support mandatory quotas. I'll justify why. However, I believe that, as with James in the Bible, it says that 'faith without works is dead', I do not understand how we can talk about European solidarity if someone does not support this report. I believe that solidarity means that I really support aid to Italy and Greece. We may have different views on mandatory quotas, and I myself had a different view on this issue. Mandatory quotas are, I think, primarily a matter of agreement between Member States. But if someone has not supported this report, I do not think that they, along with others, can claim to support European solidarity, because their faith in European solidarity is dead.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Of course, I voted against this report, and of course this meeting ended without Hungary answer as to whether Hungary should comply with eu mandatory standards and otherwise protect the EU's external borders or not. It was just a cliché about taking in as many migrants as possible, under as many different headings as possible. This is easy to say in the European Parliament, of course, because your life will not change at all, no matter how many migrants come to your country. They'll have the same income, the same black Mercedes will come with the driver, take the company to the luxury hotel, you'll live in safe living quarters, not with unfortunate, stressed-out migrant people. Your child, if you are fed up with your child studying with migrants and enrolling them in private school, they will resort to private health. Nothing is expensive for you, of course.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, honourable Members, I did not support this report because I am firmly opposed to the mandatory nature of quotas and the allocation of quota principles, at least because it violates the sovereignty of each state to control its own borders and to assess which people it can put on its territory and which cannot. And secondly, because somehow the standard in half the Member States of the European Union is different. How will you get some people to stay in Hungary, others in Bulgaria, others in Greece and others in Germany and Sweden? How do you decide which ones to stay where, and isn't that discrimination against themselves? Thirdly, there is no clear definition of what a refugee is and what is an illegal immigrant. We all know it in theory, but it is not applied in practice, and until it is clarified, until it is clearly and simply said what the capacity is, there is no point in these quotas, because they should be considered not against 150 000 or 160 000, as currently offered, but should be estimated against about 100 million, as is the population of Africa and the Middle East. This is unreasonable and cannot end in any good way. This also applies to the Schengen Agreement, not to mention that the Dublin Agreements regulations have also failed. That's why I'm against quota distribution.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, I have just voted against measures which would have effectively thrown open the doors of Europe to migrants coming here regardless of who they are. It would have become an effective common asylum policy, taking away sovereignty from the nation states, allowing people to come here with no regard as to whether they are genuinely seeking asylum because they are in danger, or whether they have just turned up on the shores.  This is yet another example of a knee-jerk reaction to a major, significant problem. They refuse to deal with the real issues in this place and all they do is say: ‘oh well, it is difficult, let us just open it up’.  I suggest that all the people who so passionately here today have argued in favour of opening the doors to everyone follow the example that Sir Bob Geldof has put forward – maybe they could offer to house many of these refugees, regardless of any checks on them, in their own homes, and then once they have led by example the rest of us could take them more seriously.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I voted and support the principle of fair solidarity between Member States in tackling the refugee crisis. At the same time, I supported the consistent implementation of the return of those migrants whose lives are not threatened either by war or starvation. Yes, every person has the right to seek a better life. At present, however, the priority is to save the lives of those people who are at risk. I could not support increasing the number of resettled asylum seekers from forty to one hundred and sixty thousand. I am aware of the need to view the situation realistically, but this Parliament should wait for the agreement of the Member States and then take a position on it. I am also opposed to the temporary measure becoming a long-term mechanism, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I voted in favour of this extremely important decision and will explain why. The issue of refugees is a question of common values of the European Union and indeed of solidarity. I am ashamed to admit that colleagues from my country who were elected to other political groups voted against. As a new Member State of the European Union, we cannot be just consumers of funds from the total EU budget, Latvia, as a new Member State. Just imagine that between 2009 and 2013 my country, Latvia, received €34 million in all programmes for refugees, and will receive another 29 million by 2020. I am really ashamed that we want to take funds from the EU with one hand, and the other hand, the hand of solidarity, cannot be given to those people who are really in a terrible position. The European Union cannot exist when standing on the ground. It must evolve and, i repeat, that is why I voted in favour.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, I was pleased to support this report today, which proposes to relocate 40 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other Member States over the next two years. This is a badly needed emergency response. It is a temporary derogation from existing rules, and only asylum seekers in clear need of international protection will be eligible. I agree with what Vice-President Timmermans said here today: this is a defining moment in European history. And I, like him, am pleased to see the huge response from ordinary people who want to help in whatever way they can. I have received many emails from Irish people offering rooms in their homes, offering houses, offering help in different guises – and it makes me proud to be Irish and to be European when I see the welcoming committees right across the continent.
