Finally I commend the proposal from the Pope that every parish should take in an asylum-seeking family, because, in the case of those who do not wish to return, this will help to integrate them into the community.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mister President, once again today the European Union has taken a further step in crushing the nation-state and the ability of its people to vote for governments who make their own independent decisions on issues as important as immigration, migration and asylum. The proposals put before this House do not only deal with European Union issues, but they have the arrogance of saying that we, the European Union, can also change international law. We will extend the definition of asylum and refugee to include anyone who is poor from any country. In doing so, you have said to the world that we will open the door to everybody in Africa, the Middle East and Asia who is not a genuine refugee, but simply wants to come here and work. The people who will see their wages reduced, their jobs displaced, the poor, the homeless and the people who have no voice in Europe will be the ones who suffer because of the arrogance of people in this Chamber.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, has this Chamber lost its collective mind? Have we forgotten that for every one refugee in Europe, there are 25 to 30 in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey alone? Then we encourage these dangerous boat journeys, made often by those rich enough to pay traffickers and able bodied enough to travel in such ways, forgetting the plight of those who live in those countries? Can we not think before we act, remember that the humanitarian crisis does not end at Europe’s borders, and stop sleepwalking into causing the very deaths that we are supposed to be trying to prevent?  I do not mind doing my bit but there are six rich Gulf States which have taken zero Syrian refugees. We need to encourage them to do their part as well. We need to remember that the world does not end at Europe and get out of this insular ‘little European’ mindset.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Although this report contains aspects which we reject head-on such as the identification of migrants through their fingerprints as if they were criminals, we voted in favour of this report because we understand that it is going in the right direction in terms of asylum policies in overcoming Dublin regulation and proposing a policy based on solidarity between States but taking into account the will of the applicants Asylum. The main positive points include a broader definition of family reunification than we had up to this point and a system of location of applicants based on their preferences.  It also includes reference to a regular assessment of the use of funds received by Member States for their asylum policy and the need to take into account the specificities of LGTBi women and individuals.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it paves the way for considerable relocation of refugees and asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to the rest of Europe. Whilst this number is insufficient, the report acknowledges that it is only a start.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Despite the continuing influx of refugees, some Member States are still closing in on European coordination and a fair distribution of these people seeking protection within Europe. Greece, Italy and Hungary are overwhelmed with asylum requests. Other Member States do not want to take in refugees at all, refusing to show solidarity with their European neighbours. Such an attitude is unacceptable and a common European response in this situation is urgently needed.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to transfer 40 000 people from Italy and Greece to other EU countries over the next two years. asylum seekers. I support the proposed mandatory EU resettlement mechanism and the calls for the necessary funds for the reception and integration of refugees. Better cooperation with third countries, fines for trafficking in human beings and ensuring safe and legal access to the EU asylum system are key priorities for today's refugee crisis.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which recognises just about every right to so-called refugees, and none to our states if they dare not to be overwhelmed by the migratory tsunami.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have endorsed this report, which underlines the need for Member States to show solidarity with each other in responding to the challenges of migration. The rapporteur stresses that the proposal to relocate 40,000 refugees from Italy and Greece to other Member States is a first step, but it will obviously be insufficient given the number of migrants arriving every day in some EU countries. It therefore calls for a deepening of this intra-European solidarity. The resolution also stresses the need and urgency to offer dignified reception conditions to migrants and to take into account certain elements in the country of relocation (family, language, etc.). Highlighting the failure of the Dublin system, which has created unbearable imbalances between Member States, the rapporteur calls on the Commission to go further and present a legislative proposal on a permanent relocation mechanism based on codecision by the end of 2015.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the Council's proposed decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece aims to encourage Member States to come together to respond to the challenges of migration. It supports the Commission's proposal on the binding relocation measure, which includes a key to the distribution of refugees among Member States, on the basis of the principle of solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities. It also goes further by proposing to increase the number of refugees to be relocated (50,000 at least, compared to 40,000 for the Commission).  Even though I understand the difficulties of states such as Italy or Greece, I do not think that the solution is to take in illegal immigrants even as Europe is going through a social and economic crisis (unemployment, poverty, poor housing, etc.). On the contrary, it would be appropriate to be firmer in australia's image and to remove all "aspiring pumps" for immigration. Also, why not ask the petromonarchies that have a lot of money to take their share of refugees as well? I have of course voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. I consider this report to be a clear picture of the EU's inefficiency: compared to more than 180,000 migrants who arrived in Italy in 2014 and more than 200,000 in Greece, the aim of this text is to take on 40,000 of them. I think it is totally unacceptable for the EU to deal with the issue of mass immigration into our territories in these botched terms. For all the reasons listed above, I voted against the Keller report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliamentary legislative resolution establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The Commission recently presented a comprehensive European agenda for migration. The agenda notes that Member States' asylum systems are currently under particular pressure and that the capacity for reception and processing of applications, especially in border Member States, is already under maximum strain. The annex to the agenda includes a redistribution scheme based on criteria set out in the Agenda, such as: GDP, population, unemployment rate, number of asylum seekers and resettled refugees, in order to alleviate the pressure of the Mediterranean crisis on greece and Italy most affected.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Keller report because it does not deal with real problems and therefore does not provide a solution to the current crisis. Mandatory quotas do not help.  The biggest problem at the moment is that today a fraction of the refugee influx is willing to register, cooperate with the authorities and accept refugee status in poorer Member States. Most of them are going to the Member States that promise more social assistance, and they are doing everything they can to get there. It will continue to do so after allocating quotas: as soon as possible, it will make its way to states where it can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution until we can protect Europe's external borders and the number of people who enter the Union increases by thousands every day, while only a fraction of them are entitled to refugee status.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 As the emergency linked to the pressure of asylum seekers continues, as is also demonstrated by the agenda and the debate that is taking place during this plenary session, today we are approving the legislative resolution on the relocation of the first 40 000 asylum seekers. This measure is of particular interest to Italy and Greece and which could serve as a valid test for a permanent emergency transfer system which the Union must adopt as soon as possible. In the resolution that I support, Parliament agrees to a first transfer within two years of 24 000 asylum seekers from Italy and 16 000 from Greece. In supporting the plan, Parliament also calls for better management of transfers to applicants to be given the opportunity to list the Member States where they would like to be transferred, in order to facilitate their integration. Another important point to which the resolution emphasises is the particular attention paid to the situation of unaccompanied minors who now account for a significant number of arrivals.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, which are a fair and just resettlement mechanism to relieve pressure on these two EU member states. As the report itself says, this is not a permanent solution but only a temporary measure, and all together we must show a greater degree of solidarity in the spirit of the high democratic values of the European Union.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the time has come for Europe to show its unity and solidarity by coming to the aid of those Member States that have been hardest hit by the migration crisis and are bearing the greatest burden. Italy and Greece alone are facing an epochal challenge that affects the whole continent, it is right that the other members should also play their part, in a spirit of solidarity that should characterise the construction of Europe.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 No Member State can effectively tackle the refugee crisis by its own forces. The European Parliament, in a resolution of 29 April 2015, stressed that the EU must base its response to tragedies in the Mediterranean on solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities, in particular towards the Member States that receive the largest number of refugees such as Italy and Greece. Parliament has called for a binding quota for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States. The principle of solidarity is also at the heart of the European Commission's strategic response to the ongoing crisis in the Mediterranean. As a first step towards putting the principle of solidarity into practice, we need the binding redistribution of people in clear need of international protection from Italy and Greece to other Member States. Emergency relocation, however, is only a first step: the Dublin Regulation needs to be reviewed and an effective political solution must be coordinated at unitary level in order to resolve the greatest tragedy that the Mediterranean has been seeing since the end of the Second World War.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report is a demonstration that the European Union is trying to impose on all Member States its vision on how to deal with the massive influx of illegal immigrants. By making the distribution of migrants compulsory and by imposing quotas on states, the rapporteur goes further than the Commission in its motion for a resolution. The European institutions show once again that they are not acting in the interests of the Member States, but in the interests of illegal immigrants, re-qualified as 'refugees'. This text is obviously harmful for France, whose interests remain my priority. I therefore voted against this unacceptable proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Hundreds of immigrants are currently choosing to leave their place of origin to start a new life in Europe. One of the causes of the impressive influx is the humanitarian crisis in Syria, and the effects we can see in the considerable number of migrants arriving across Europe. Since the beginning of the year, around 500,000 people have reached the EU. The countries that have the most to do with this crisis are primarily Greece and Italy, which are a gateway to Europe for the wave of refugees, since the beginning of 2015 in Greece reaching 249,855 refugees and in Italy 119,500.   I voted against the amendment which provides for binding quotas because I believe that the ability of states to offer decent conditions to immigrants must be taken into account, but I voted in favour of the Provisional Measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece as a whole, as we must stand in solidarity with these two countries which can no longer manage the situation , as well as immigrants who want a new life. I stress, however, once again the need to concentrate all efforts in the countries of origin of immigrants in order to eliminate the causes that give rise to this phenomenon.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is one of the symbols of the European Union's inefficiency. The great success achieved here would be the taking care of only 40 thousand asylum seekers who arrived in Italy and Greece in 2014. In Italy, 180,000 people arrived illegally in 2014. And it is an even more ridiculous figure when compared to the data of the first half of 2015: 115 thousand irregular migrants arrived in Italy only by sea. Well over 200 thousand in Greece alone. What's more, we are voting now, September 2015, a net year late. I am voting against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The wars on Europe's borders and the rise of Daesh have led to a massive influx of migrants into Europe. Most arrive in Greece and Italy, which, according to the Dublin Regulation, must handle these asylum applications. These two countries are not able to cope alone with this situation. We must show solidarity and accept that a certain number of migrants are relocated to our countries through a binding quota mechanism.  In July, the Council decided to reject this mechanism by relocating only 32,000 refugees against the 40,000 envisaged in the Commission's proposal. Through this report, Parliament sends a strong message to the Council by deciding to accept this relocation mechanism in the event of a humanitarian emergency and by asking to be a member of the Council.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of a temporary and emergency system for the relocation of 40,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece, under intolerable pressure, to other EU countries, over a two-year period. However, this emergency relocation is only a first, provisional step towards the implementation of the principle of solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibility among all The Member States. I therefore call on the Commission to present a legislative proposal for a permanent relocation mechanism by the end of 2015. We must also look in the long term at the problem of the Dublin system, the Community regulation on political asylum, which is rendered ineffective by the non-equalisation of national asylum systems. Dublin says refugees must seek asylum in the country of first entry. And that's a problem, because there are only a limited number of countries that have an external border. Reforms are therefore urgently needed to overcome the shortcomings of the current Dublin system and to arrive at a new system of fair distribution for all Member States.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We need to remember that for each refugee within the EU, there are 25—fold in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey alone. We must not encourage the dangerous boat journeys, organised by criminal and terrorist people smugglers.  We should appreciate that this tragic humanitarian crisis does not end at Europe’s borders, and must take every step to make end the wicked ends of those who traffic people across the Mediterranean. As the grandson of a refugee, I fully accept my responsibility to act on this tragedy, but there are many States, including those in the Gulf, who are yet to fulfil their humanitarian obligations. They too, must play their part.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of the proposal is to establish provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, in order to enable them to deal in an effective manner with the current significant inflow of third country nationals in their territories. This is putting their asylum systems under strain. These provisional measures aim to the relocate applicants for international protection that appear to be in clear need of international protection from Italy and Greece to the other Member States. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that these provisional measures will help Italy and Greece to handle with immigration in their states and welcome the introduction of the concept of mandatory distribution mechanism.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report declares Parliament's support for the establishment of a permanent mechanism for the compulsory relocation of refugees; this should be activated automatically when there is a particularly intense flow of migrants, as is the case today. Italy and Greece have to take in thousands of refugees, while the Treaty itself refers to the principle of solidarity in this area. Central to this is the fact that the report states that reallocation measures are only a first, emergency step towards a system of fair distribution of reception responsibility among all Member States.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Ska Keller's report on the migration situation in Europe. Putting in place a new distribution key, fair for all Member States and just for refugees, seems to me to be quite appropriate and encouraging for European solidarity.  A new emergency relocation mechanism that takes into account both the interests of refugees and the reception capacities of Member States needs to be thoroughly considered. In the course of this reflection, it is essential to distinguish between asylum seekers and economic migrants.  All Member States must respect and implement the rules of the common European asylum system. Seeking asylum is a right and must remain so for all persons prosecuted because of their political views, origin or religion. In the face of economic immigration, however, it is a matter of being realistic and analysing the needs of our labour market, which is in any case a matter of state sovereignty.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. \u2012 As a European citizen and as an Italian, I can only welcome the Commission's proposal to relocate 24,000 refugees who have arrived in Italy and 16,000 who have arrived in Greece. The problem is that, since the Commission took this decision to date, the number of migrants fleeing war-fighting territories has soared, another 68,000 in Greece and 67,500 in Italy. The Islamic State in Syria and the war in Libya are certainly not waiting for the times of the European Union. We need more measures and not just temporary measures. These people must be divided into all the countries of the Union, with a criterion. The refugee camps are sometimes their own real lagers, children cannot live there permanently just because we do not agree on how to take them in. We have to hurry, we don't have time anymore. More refugees in each country, also asking them where they want to go. Sometimes they have relatives in a European country who try to reach or speak the language of it, and this would promote integration, developing a sense of belonging and loyalty to the adopted country. We hope that the European Commission will take this into account in the next package of measures that it is expected to present before the end of the year.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Every Member State has a moral duty to help the refugees arriving from conflict areas like Syria or other war zones. We should help those who ask for our help.  But I cannot support the mandatory introduction of quotas. If a refugee does not want to stay in one Member State, we should not attempt to force them to. Such a system would not work without the suspension of the Schengen Agreement and the freedom of movement that is fundamental to Europe today. It is normal that a refugee will continue to move towards their preferred objective, where they might already have family or work, and no quota will stop this desire.  Each member states must be able to decide itself how many refugees to accept in its territory and accept those who truly desire their help. Therefore, I voted against this report.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report because Mrs Keller supports the Commission's proposal for a binding relocation measure that includes a key to the distribution of refugees between Member States, on the basis of the principle of solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities. Once again, this represents an attempt to override national sovereignty over border control and asylum and immigration management.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal voted on today finally addresses the issue of immigration with a "European" approach. Although it is partial and limited in content and despite knowing the Council's differences on certain points, it is nevertheless an important and urgent measure and we as a Parliament must support it together with our constructive criticisms. With regard in particular to the delicate situation of unaccompanied minors, I think it is important that the clarification has been introduced that the new mechanism should not reduce protections in relation to what has already been imposed by the Court of Justice (so that protection obligations fall on the country where the child is in fact, even if different from the country of first arrival or in which he or she has applied for asylum). Other aspects remain perplexed, such as: the scope of the decision, which is numerically small and strictly limited according to the nationality of the refugees; the possibility of suspending the mechanism as a "sanction" against Italy or Greece (but, in fact, to the further detriment of the protection applicants); the absence of a period of duration of the procedure starting from the arrival of migrants, to protect them. In spite of this, this decision is in itself an important step forward and a very useful practical instrument. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. A challenge that can only be solved jointly at European level. Leaving each country alone is neither a solution for the EU Member States nor for the thousands of war refugees driven away from homes. This only leads to an unequal distribution between countries and to more sad marches along Europe's motorways. These developments are also being seen in Danish soil these days. On this challenge, the EUROPEAN Union must come up with an answer and a solution. The key lies first and foremost with the Member States. We therefore fully support a pan-European solution, as agreed between the EU Member States.  However, how such a solution will work in practice must be a question for the Member States that have to take part in it. Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. That is the way it is today and that will be the future. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 On the proposal for a Council decision establishing interim measures in the field of protection for Italy and Greece and having regard to the proposal of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we approve the Commission's proposal as amended and call on the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly in accordance with Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. In April 2015, more than 800 people lost their lives while trying to reach Europe. No Member State can tackle the challenges of immigration and the refugee crisis with its own strength. It is therefore necessary for Europe to step up its joint efforts to prevent further disasters and to deal effectively with the refugee crisis, fulfilling its duty to protect those who need it. The European Parliament, in a resolution of 29 April 2015, stressed that the EU must base its response to tragedies in the Mediterranean on solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibilities, in particular towards the Member States that receive the largest number of refugees. The European Parliament has called for a binding quota for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States. With this report, Parliament fully supports the Commission's proposal for a binding relocation measure.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of migration is very complex and would require wide-ranging responses. However, at the moment Italy and Greece (together with Hungary, to be honest), are forced to manage an emergency for which the EU has a moral duty to intervene. It is a pity that the legal duty, which was to be enshrined in the Dublin Regulation, has not been properly designed and therefore the peripheral countries are faced with the situation themselves (or, rather, without the obligation to intervene of others). Clearly, I am of the opinion that migratory pressures must be managed, and that the idea of cooperation must be a direct consequence of the Schengen Agreements providing for free movement between States. Finally, this concept has also arrived in the capitals that matter most.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a proposal that aims to respond quickly to the humanitarian emergency that affects more intensely and particularly - at the time - Italy and Greece. It is important to point out that the Commission was courageous. The mechanism, provided for in the treaties, has never been activated. Although it was not sufficient to do so, as I said, and the reality unfortunately has made this gap worse, the truth is that the Commission's proposal is a good basis for discussion for what is really needed: a permanent mechanism and compulsory quotas the Council, as it has always been able to be up to it. But, as a matter of urgency for a solution, Parliament has decided to give up its right to rule on the Council's proposal, all the more so since it is not a co-legislator. However, let us stress the attention paid by this Parliament to the characteristics of migrants, which is also the most effective measure to avoid secondary movements and stimulate integration.  Attention paid to the quota determination criteria should be highlighted. This report will not change anything immediately, but it certainly provides the background for the preparation of the next instruments!

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. ‒ The key objective of the proposal is to establish measures that will relocate 40 000 migrant arrivals deemed to be ‘in need of international protection’ from the shores of Italy and Greece and move them to other EU member states. The United Kingdom has an opt-out and is not required to accept any of the quota. The proposal calls for burden sharing and a common EU asylum policy, which UKIP are fundamentally opposed to.  It even allows migrants who have entered European countries illegally the opportunity to choose where they are to be relocated.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with Parliament's report on the proposal for a decision on temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The refugee crisis cannot be resolved by individual Member States, but requires an effective European response. The watchwords are solidarity and responsibilities that must acquire a different content from what has been up to now. I fully support Parliament's proposal on a binding quota for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States. Emergency relocation is only a first step, implemented with a temporary derogation from the Dublin Regulation. It is understood, however, that this system currently in force has created considerable and unsustainable imbalances between the various Member States and the need to be adapted without further delay to the new requirements.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the relocation of 40 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece. It  is time to put solidarity in place with concrete actions. It is not enough, but it is an important step forward. I am also glad that my proposals to take into account in the process also the qualifications and competences of applicants were included. Many refugees are qualified and that can be more efficiently integrated if the receiving country can take into account their specific skills. Special attention should be give to children.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Although this report contains aspects which we reject head-on such as the identification of migrants through their fingerprints as if they were criminals, we voted in favour of this report because we understand that it is going in the right direction in terms of asylum policies in overcoming Dublin regulation and proposing a policy based on solidarity between States but taking into account the will of the applicants Asylum. The main positive points include a broader definition of family reunification than we had up to this point and a system of location of applicants based on their preferences.  It also includes reference to a regular assessment of the use of funds received by Member States for their asylum policy and the need to take into account the specificities of LGTBi women and individuals.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the Keller report. The flood of refugees has never been more measured in Europe, so the EU must respond to this. Although there have been positive proposals in the report, and I agree with the theory of solidarity, I do not believe that the introduction of mandatory quotas is the right solution because it does not bring about a long-term solution. There is already a tendency for the majority of refugees not to remain in the host State designated by the quota system as soon as possible and will move on to Member States where they can expect greater social support. I think the stability of the trigger situation, cooperation with the source countries and adequate protection of the external borders are more important.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is the first step towards a fair European policy which can address the current systems deficiencies. Through its initiative to relocate migrants from Italy and Greece, during a time where both countries are being put under massive pressure, Europe will be finally putting in place the principle of solidarity. The next step, as called upon within this report, is a permanent binding quota mechanism which takes into consideration the reception capacities of each individual member state. As I have stated in the past, this however must happen hand-in-hand with a total revamp of the Dublin system.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to define interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, in order to better manage the exceptional influx of nationals from third countries. As a priority, the report envisages the reallocation of candidates for international protection from Greece and Italy to other Member States. Despite reservations about the binding nature of the reallocation quotas, creating a call for air in the countries of departure to Europe without solving the causes of the migratory influx, I voted in favour of this report in view of the emergency situation facing Europe and the current humanitarian crisis.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I abstained on the final vote of the resolution on interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. It is important to put in place temporary measures to support refugees. However, the introduction of the system proposed by the text risks encouraging migratory flows to Europe without solving the root causes of this phenomenon and clogging up our systems, which are already not functioning optimally. The permanent and binding nature of quotas is not a viable solution to a resolution of the crisis. Instead, let us rely on exceptional and voluntary measures. In addition, Jean-Claude Junker's intervention on 9 September 2015 rendered the text obsolete.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The report proposed by Mr Keller follows the European Commission's plans to manage the flow of illegal immigrants to Europe. The principle of the distribution of migrants by country, with migrant thresholds to be accepted, in the name of a vague and indefinite rule of solidarity between Member States, is not acceptable. The doors of Europe must be kept and the peoples of Europe do not have to suffer from lax border management, a laxity promoted and maintained by the European Union. This denial of sovereignty and irresponsibility in migration policy are serious attacks on the peoples of Europe. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is far from providing solutions to the serious problem of illegal immigration. While there is an admission of the criticality of the situation in Greece and Italy, the proposed measures and the so-called "holistic approach", combined with the "wishes" for a review into the future of the treaties, are a mockery and show the technocratic perception of the committees.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 In response to the crisis situation in the Mediterranean and migration flows, the Commission has presented a series of solidarity measures and a fair sharing of responsibility between Member States to help those on the front line. On 13 May 2015, the Commission presented a European agenda on migration that includes immediate measures to prevent human tragedies and to address emergencies, as well as a new strategic approach to managing migration flows in the medium to long term. The aim of the proposal is to implement in practice the obligation of solidarity provided for in Article 78(3) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, proposing an emergency relocation providing for the compulsory distribution of 40 000 people (then increased to 160,000) with a clear need for international protection from Italy and Greece to other Member States through a binding mechanism for the distribution of refugees between Member States. Given that Parliament is only consulted in this procedure that remains in the Council, I believe it is essential for the European Parliament to express itself by a large majority in order to affirm the principle of solidarity, of a fair distribution of responsibility among all the Member States and to call for the establishment of a permanent relocation mechanism based on clear and defined criteria. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. On April 18, 2015, in the biggest disaster in the Mediterranean Sea since World War II, more than 800 people died on their way to Europe. The deaths of so many people, 1,867 in the first six months of 2015 alone, and the scourge of many more who put their lives at risk in the Mediterranean have dramatically revealed that Europe must improve its common efforts to prevent further disasters and to respond effectively to the refugee crisis, fulfilling its duty to protect those in need. The European Parliament has called on the EU to base its response to the refugee crisis on solidarity and fair division of responsibility. The EP advocates, for example, the establishment of a binding quota for the allocation of asylum seekers among all EU countries, more contributions to refugee resettlement programmes, enhanced cooperation with third countries and stronger measures against human traffickers and criminal networks of traffickers.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it denies states their sovereignty over border control and asylum and immigration management.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it is far from providing solutions to the serious problem of illegal immigration. While there is an admission of the criticality of the situation in Greece and Italy, the proposed measures and the so-called "holistic approach", combined with the "wishes" for a review into the future of the treaties, are a mockery and show the technocratic perception of the committees.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support a credible and substantial EU-wide compulsory resettlement scheme, including a binding quota for distribution, accompanied by a compulsory scheme for the relocation of recognised refugees within the European Union. The provisional emergency measures foreseen in the report will set up a fair and equitable relocation mechanism, will relieve the significant asylum pressure from Italy and Greece, by relocating an important number of applicants in clear need of international protection who have arrived in the territory of Italy and Greece. However, this is only a first step towards the creation of a long-term solution to the migrant emergency. Any proposal for a permanent emergency relocation mechanism must be based on a more substantial contribution to solidarity and responsibility-sharing among Member States, including a significant increase in the number of available relocation places to adapt to rapidly changing migratory flows and trends. I really hope that Member States will show more solidarity between them and we will be capable of creating a truly European asylum system.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it reflects the urgency of action and reflects Parliament's determination to respond to the migration challenges facing Europe today. In the resolution, we strongly support the establishment of an emergency relocation mechanism that shows our solidarity with refugees, especially the most vulnerable, but also with Member States which are under severe migratory pressure. We insist that this temporary mechanism be subsequently replaced by a permanent mechanism that could provide a long-term solution to the migration challenge. This mechanism must be mandatory for Member States, but flexible enough to allow rapid adaptation given the fluctuating nature of migration. In this resolution, we finally recall that the Western Balkans route has become an important axis of migration to the Union, with a considerable increase in irregular crossings across Turkey's borders with Greece and Bulgaria.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not vote in favour of the report because, in my view, it does not address a problem that deserves urgent attention and therefore does not provide a solution to the current crisis. Mandatory quotas do not help.  The entire mandatory quota system can fail every day with the continued migration of each hijacked refugee. Unfortunately, the sad events of recent days have also shown what refugees can do if they do not get what they want from the Union. The whole story will be about the daily repatriation of refugees and authorities, and of course the Member States, on a daily basis, in the order of tens of thousands, in infinite back and forth, making life difficult for our citizens.  The EU's misguided immigration policy to date is to blame for this situation. This policy has led to a huge wave of migration in many Member States. My view is to pretend that something is happening, as if a solution to a problem has been found, while this so-called solution is to further complicate the problem. The story bears an eerily similar resemblance to the greek situation. It doesn't seem like the final outcome either. Let us remain realistic: when dealing with the migrant issue, we do not need the quota system envisaged by the EU, because it is a sham solution.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are experiencing increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, because I believe that the migration phenomenon that is affecting the whole EU must be effectively reorganised as soon as possible, in order to allow Member States such as Italy and Greece to face an emergency situation characterised by a sudden and unmanageable influx of EU citizens. third countries. These are mainly asylum seekers, that is, people fleeing their country because of war, poverty and violence.  However, the Mediterranean coasts are not ready and do not have sufficient reception facilities to help such a large number of migrants. I therefore believe it is essential to improve relocation by promoting family, social and cultural reunification, which is an expression of the principle of solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibility among all the Member States.  The shortcomings highlighted by the Dublin system have created great inconvenience in the distribution of migrants, so it is necessary to take note of the Member States so that, as soon as possible, they carry out the reform of the system, bearing in mind that each of them is basically a person asking for help.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the 'Report on the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece', as I cannot support some of the proposals made in it by Mrs Keller.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The resettlement of 40,000 refugees within the EU is an important first step in our refugee policy. It is important to apply this quota system to other refugees. It is up to the Member States to reach an agreement on this.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. This summer's events have shown that Member States need to work together to respond to the refugee crisis. The report I are voting in favour of today contains provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece, in order to enable them to deal effectively with the significant influx of third-country nationals on their territory, which puts their asylum systems under great pressure. These measures are a step in the right direction but we must not forget that they are only one part of the overall approach that the EU must develop on migration.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal to introduce interim measures to distribute "migrants", i.e. illegal immigrants, in all European countries. This project is in line with the lax policy advocated by the European Commission. It is a sign of encouragement to would-be immigrants, which will lead to new waves of departures and tragedies in the Mediterranean. These newcomers, most often motivated by economic reasons, will compete directly with the poorest Europeans in the area of access to work, health and housing. Finally, by doing so, the Commission and the European Parliament demonstrate how dangerous it was to give the European Union powers over immigration and asylum. This power, as we had planned, is used to open our borders even more, against the advice of the majority of the French and Europeans.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which concerns directly the refugee crisis in Europe, and in particular the relocation of asylum seekers arriving in Italy and Greece. While we consider that the number of refugees considered in this text (40000) is clearly insufficient given the magnitude of human displacement that is taking place, the text speaks of this number as a beginning. It also proposes an automatic relocation system, which takes into account the preferences of refugees. In this way the approved mechanism can serve as a test bench to develop an effective system that can be applied on a larger scale in the months and years to come.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along with my fellow S&D MEPs voted in favour of this report. I did so for a simple reason. I believe in showing solidarity with those facing a crisis. We must show more solidarity between us Europeans, and to the rest of the world. We must create a truly European asylum policy.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I welcomed the emergency allocation mechanism proposed by the Commission when it was presented last May. It was therefore without hesitation that I gave my support to F. Keller's report.  In its broad outlines, this report supports the Commission's proposal, while providing some very essential nuances. In addition to its obligatory nature, this mechanism must be able to adapt to changes in both refugee flows and migration routes. In order for this scheme to be effective, the preferences of Member States and those of applicants should also be matched as much as possible. This would not only avoid the secondary movements of applicants between states, but also promote the integration of people relocated to their countries not host.  Finally, to deal with the urgency of the situation, Parliament has agreed to be consulted only this time or in the framework of the next emergency mechanism proposed by the Commission on 9 September, but it is crucial that the codecision procedure applies when it comes to deciding on a permanent allocation mechanism.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the proposal to establish provisional measures in the area of the international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. I truly believe, it is urgent that we provide holistic support to Member States under pressure and ensure ownership and build trust with other Member States. Therefore, this proposal enables to increase solidarity and responsibility sharing between member states. It is essential to remember that the refugees have their preferences and we should ensure to consider it. Thus, this emergency measure is a first step but a more permanent measure is needed.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the increasingly large number of people entering the EU irregularly from Greece and Italy, a proposal has been set forward to relocate approximately 40% of the total number of applicants for international protection from Syria and Eritrea who arrived on these soils in 2014. Thus, this proposal aims to relocate 24 000 asylum seekers from Italy and 16 000 from Greece. In 2015, the movement of migrants across the EU did not slow down. In fact, it was the largest since the Second World War, and a proposal for a permanent relocation scheme has been put forward. It is important to share the burden that this crisis has provoked with Greece and Italy, both of which have to confront new emergencies on a daily basis, and to support a just relocation of refugees within the EU. Furthermore – and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Keller report because it does not deal with real problems and therefore does not provide a solution to the current migration crisis. Mandatory quotas do not help.  The biggest problem today is that a fraction of the influx of refugees is willing to register, cooperate with the authorities and accept refugee status in poorer Member States. Most of them are going to the Member States that promise more social assistance, and they are doing everything they can to get there. It will continue to do so after allocating quotas: as soon as possible, it will make its way to states where it can expect greater social assistance. And there is no point in talking about quotas and distribution until we can protect Europe's external borders. Until this is achieved, the number of people who enter the EU will increase by thousands every day, while only a small number would be eligible for refugee status.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues, I voted for this report calling for a unified EU response in sharing responsibility for the ongoing crisis. I support the emergency binding mechanism to relocate an initial total of 40 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other Member States. We need a pan-European approach which will ensure that families are kept together at all costs and give special protection to the most vulnerable, including unaccompanied minors.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The European Parliament supported the Commission's proposal to establish interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The rapporteur of the Green Group, supported by the European left, proposed to amend the proposal by arguing for the establishment of a permanent relocation mechanism with binding quotas.  I consider that an informed decision cannot be made emotionally. It applies to everyday life but even more so when it engages the responsibility of its country. However, by allowing refugees to challenge relocation decisions, by conditioning the final destination on a ranking of countries of preference established by the applicant himself, the elected representatives of the European Parliament send a message that will be very well understood by economic migrants, smugglers and traffickers. The introduction of the proposed system in the absence of a European immigration policy is a mistake. It will encourage migration flows to Europe without solving the root causes and clog up our reception systems.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report comes at a time when Europe is facing an unprecedented refugee crisis. It also comes at a time when my party is leading a debate in the United Kingdom Parliament on the issue.  The Tory government's attitude to the developing situation has been shameful and that shame is reflected in their voting pattern in this parliament today.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which concerns directly the refugee crisis in Europe, and in particular the relocation of asylum seekers arriving in Italy and Greece. While we consider that the number of refugees considered in this text (40000) is clearly insufficient given the magnitude of human displacement that is taking place, the text speaks of this number as a beginning. It also proposes an automatic relocation system, which takes into account the preferences of refugees. In this way the approved mechanism can serve as a test bench to develop an effective system that can be applied on a larger scale in the months and years to come.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, because it is clear that more solidarity is needed, namely the common response of the European Union to the current migrant crisis.  It is obvious that Italy and Greece need to be supported strongly, as they are the first to face migrants arriving in Europe, and that Europe must have a single foreign policy to address this problem in north Africa, the Middle East, Ukraine and other crisis areas.  As regards the relocation process, it should be approached with a high level of consistency and rationality in order to respect the human rights and democratic principles of the European Union.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ska Keller's report on the responses to the migrant crisis in Italy and Greece. While this text was late to the decisions already taken by Member States in July, it gave Parliament the opportunity to put forward its proposals on how to respond to the migration crisis that Europe is experiencing, the introduction of mandatory quotas and a fair distribution system for migrants This report was adopted by a large majority , which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I cannot agree with it because this report advocates a common European asylum policy, including a refugee quota.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. – I believe that the Member States of the European Union should help the EU countries affected by the migrant crisis, which alone cannot cope with the influx of thousands of migrants, but, given that the report also provides for the introduction of a permanent, mandatory mechanism for the redistribution of refugees throughout the EU, I abstained at the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg on the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The EU needs a plan based on solidarity and voluntary reception of refugees, but not mandatory, automatic quotas for migrants. Nor does the report mention how the EU's external border will be strengthened in order to stem the uncontrolled flow of refugees and avoid the migrant crisis in the future.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the report, as it calls for a unified EU response responsibility sharing in light of the ongoing migrant crisis. It also states that priority should be given to vulnerable applicants, and among those, special attention should be given to unaccompanied minors. We must act now to prevent further loss of life and find a common lasting solution to the refugee crisis.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. A challenge that can only be solved jointly at European level. Leaving each country alone is neither a solution for the EU Member States nor for the thousands of war refugees driven away from homes. This only leads to an unequal distribution between countries and to more sad marches along Europe's motorways. These developments are also being seen in Danish soil these days. On this challenge, the EUROPEAN Union must come up with an answer and a solution. The key lies first and foremost with the Member States. We therefore fully support a pan-European solution, as agreed between the EU Member States.  However, how such a solution will work in practice must be a question for the Member States that have to take part in it. Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. That is the way it is today and that will be the future. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The Keller report, referring to the Commission proposal of 27.5.2015, aims to improve the situation of refugees from Syria and Eritrea, who have an average recognition rate of more than 75% in the EU, and to relieve the first host countries of Greece and Italy. The central means of discharge will be a European-organised distribution of quotas among the EU Member States. The report is problematic for a number of reasons. Firstly, the concept of the quota is currently unenforceable due to a lack of technical requirements. Enforcement of existing rules of the admission procedure is hardly successful. The Schengen system does not allow for long-term control of internal borders. Secondly, the report calls for refugees not to be assigned to a country against their will. As a result of this rule, only a few countries with attractive social benefits are targeted. Thirdly, the very generous German policy is creating false incentives and, moreover, is in breach of European law. States that have not been involved or consulted at all should now support this policy by quota. Many are unwilling to do so. Fourthly, contrary to the idea of subsidiarity, the European grounds for recognition of asylum seekers should be standardised. These and other reasons make the report seem unrealistic. Nevertheless, I have chosen to vote in favour because there is undoubtedly a humanitarian problem that needs a European solution.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 As I am close to the opinion of the Czech Government on migration issues, I could not support the report on the proposal for a Council Decision establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece. Again, these were quotas for the reception of refugees, with which I cannot agree. Although I sympathise with the suffering of Syrian refugees in particular, I consider forced solidarity to be a misunderstanding of my own sense of solidarity, which must, after all, be voluntary. Moreover, the absolute minimum of current refugees wants to live in the Czech Republic, and I can't imagine how we would hold them in our country by force in the 21st century. Moreover, the Czech Republic has already given home to refugees from many eastern countries, especially those fleeing civil war-torn Ukraine. However, it now appears that all eu institutions have decided not to take this into account. The EU must realise that its only hope is to put an end to the conflicts that have become catalysts for today's events as quickly as possible. Not all refugees want to stay in Europe. They want to go home, but that's where they'd care about their lives today. Quotas and hateful statements by ambitious political newcomers or aging matadors are not the solution. The solution to the problem lies where the problem began, in North Africa and the Middle East.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Agenda on Migration presented on 13 May 2015, is already outdated. We must and we should take immediate measures to respond to the crisis that Greece and Italy are facing. Under the Article 78.3 (TFEU), all Member States should ensure a fair and balanced participation. The report emphasizes on the fact that Dublin regulation should be amended. It addresses the difficulties, which Greece and Italy are facing with the inflow of national of third countries. Calls for asylum-seekers’ consent to be relocated and be also based on their criteria (family ties, social relations, work). The current Common European Asylum System, do not allow Greece and Italy to address the unprecedented request of asylum seekers. We need to adopt new measures. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. The report unreservedly shares the view that all Member States must be united in order to meet the challenges of migration, which is a Challenge for Europe and not just for border states. Greece and Italy have been under intolerable pressure for months now. They need to receive adequate support. As an Italian and a Sicilian, I strongly support the principle expressed in this report of shared responsibility and a significant drive for solidarity between peoples.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the legislative resolution and against the Commission's proposal to introduce interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. The whole philosophy of these texts is to think that the relocation and distribution of migrants across the European Union is a solution to the problem. Nothing is less true. As the external borders of the Schengen area are no longer guarded, the entire Schengen system has collapsed. Member States cannot therefore be prohibited from re-maintaining internal borders. The whole Eu policy on asylum and immigration is a failure. It must therefore be called into question and the sovereignty of the Member States restored. Mrs Keller's report does exactly the opposite, advocating even more powers for the European Commission, notably through a common European asylum system. This is unacceptable.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Although this report contains aspects which we reject head-on such as the identification of migrants through their fingerprints as if they were criminals, we voted in favour of this report because we understand that it is going in the right direction in terms of asylum policies in overcoming Dublin regulation and proposing a policy based on solidarity between States but taking into account the will of the applicants Asylum. The main positive points include a broader definition of family reunification than we had up to this point and a system of location of applicants based on their preferences.  It also includes reference to a regular assessment of the use of funds received by Member States for their asylum policy and the need to take into account the specificities of LGTBi women and individuals.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report aims to "resettle" refugees from Syria and Eritrea in order to relieve the burden on the first host countries of Greece and Italy. The central means of discharge will be a European-organised distribution of quotas among the EU Member States. I agree with this report, as I recognise that Greece and Italy are among the countries that are heavily burdened in comparison. Other EU countries should show solidarity in this situation. Since refugees from Syria and Eritrea have largely suffered persecution, they are entitled to asylum or protection under the Geneva Convention on Refugees. I think it is right that we should grant this protection. Despite my agreement, the report is also problematic in part. Firstly, the concept of the quota is currently unenforceable due to a lack of technical requirements. Enforcement of existing rules of the admission procedure is hardly successful. The Schengen system does not allow for long-term control of internal borders. Secondly, the report calls for refugees not to be assigned to a country against their will. As a result of this rule, only a few countries with attractive social benefits are targeted. Thirdly, the very generous German policy provides false incentives for migration to Germany. Other states that have not been involved or consulted at all should now support this policy by quota. Many are unwilling to do so.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the mandatory quotas for the distribution of immigrants. I do not agree with the statute that 'Member States ... should agree on binding quotas" for the distribution of immigrants. I do not agree with the push for 'common European standards' for the reception of asylum seekers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. In April this year, more than 800 people died in the Mediterranean on their way to Europe and a better life. They survived war and persecution, but lost their lives at the gates of Europe.  As no Member State can effectively deal with the refugee crisis alone, Parliament stresses that its activities must be based on solidarity and proper allocation of responsibilities, especially with those Member States that take in the most refugees.  I supported MEP Keller's report, in the hope that an agreement would also be reached as soon as possible for new waves of refugees arriving in Europe, with a focus on Member States' solidarity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing interim measures in the field of international protection for Italy and Greece, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/9/2015. I would also point out that impoverished Greece cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. On Lesvos alone there are currently more than 10,000 refugees at a time when the island has only 80,000 inhabitants. In Kos the situation is explosive. In Samos, which I recently visited, but also in Chios the problems are acute. Immediate measures are therefore needed here and now: firstly, the abolition of the Dublin III Regulation which turns Greece into a warehouse of souls; measures against Turkey which supports the slave trade circuits, as revealed by Hurriyet on 29 May 2015;

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report which proposes an emergency relocation procedure for illegal immigrants in the various Member States. Not only is this procedure an attack on national sovereignty over border control, but it is also based on distorted data, since the number of refugees considered does not take into account the recent crisis. In the name of the sacrosanct principle of solidarity, the EU is once again flouting the sovereignty of Member States in matters of asylum and immigration.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The temporary measures for emergency relocation are only one part of the holistic approach to migration as outlined in the Commission’s communication of 13 May 2015 entitled, ‘A European Agenda on Migration’ and the forthcoming own-initiative report by the European Parliament. The European Parliament stresses that all dimensions of the holistic approach are important and should be advanced in parallel. At its meeting of 25 and 26 June, the European Council agreed, in particular, in the light of the current emergency situation and of the commitment to reinforce solidarity and responsibility, on the temporary and exceptional relocation over two years from Italy and Greece to other Member States of 40 000 persons in clear need of international protection. Member States should agree on binding quota for the distribution of such persons.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing temporary measures in the field of international production for the benefit of Italy and Greece. We must act quickly with common European rules, with the principles of solidarity and responsibility as indissoluble principles in order to deal effectively with the refugee crisis. The EU must strengthen its joint efforts to prevent further disasters and thus fulfil its duty of protection to those who need it, protecting one of Europe's main achievements, namely free movement within the Schengen area.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 For reasons of geographical contiguity, Greece and Italy are under unmanageable migratory pressure. The two countries therefore need solidarity and shared support from the other Eu ropean States. Against this background, the Keller report fully supports the European Commission's proposal to establish binding measures to relocate 40 000 refugees hosted by Greece and Italy, among all Member States. By agreeing with the approach and purpose of the proposal, I have decided to support it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. Although I consider that this is just a drop in the ocean and that it will not solve the entire humanitarian crisis, it must also be taken into account that this is a situation that needs urgent response that cannot wait for "ad eternam" in order to achieve a possible optimal solution.  This report significantly improves the Commission's initial proposal, in particular by ensuring that applicants have to give their consent to be relocated, and by ensuring that the preferences of asylum seekers regarding countries for relocation should be taken into account, using criteria such as family ties, social relations, or other previous work or academic relationships. We urgently need more measures to be able to deal with this human tragedy in its entires.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. Italy and Greece are in an emergency situation by the arrival at their shores of thousands of people in a desperate situation.  It is therefore right that from the EU measures are taken to support these countries as we have also agreed, as my support, in Parliament. And we need to take permanent measures, because we can not only go in critical cases, but have a stable device that allows us to deal with these situations.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. In the face of the refugee crisis, which is still testing our concept of solidarity, the European Parliament had to formally validate the proposal put forward by the European Commission last May to urgently relocate 40,000 asylum seekers in Greece and Italy, according to a fair distribution key.  The Keller report, which is put to the plenary vote, achieves the level of ambition necessary to face the situation, in a way that is both rational and supportive. Not only does it encourage the mechanism for the solidarity distribution of asylum seekers (so that countries at Europe's external borders are not subject to disproportionate pressure), but it also urges states to respect the preferences issued by migrants, particularly those affected by family reunification. More importantly, it encourages governments, desperately wary, to commit to the longer term.  A critic of the Dublin agreements, the text underlines the need for a genuine comprehensive asylum management strategy, which I would like to see take the form of a European, solidarity and effective asylum system. Because this is the only coherent response to the migration flows of which Europe is the recipient, I voted for this text.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The proposal advocates a common European asylum policy and a mandatory refugee quota. It also stresses that social and cultural ties can also lead to the integration of asylum seekers into the respective Member States. In the case of emergency relocations, the Commission would decide which Member State should take in the asylum seeker. It must therefore be rejected in its full feed!

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The aim of the Commission's proposal is to introduce interim measures for Italy and Greece to enable these countries to effectively manage the current influx of refugees into their territory, which puts their asylum regime under pressure. The provisional measures envisaged in the proposal concern first and foremost the relocation of international protection claimants from Italy (24,000) and Greece (16,000) to other Member States. The total number of applicants to be relocated from Italy (24,000) and Greece (16,000) is about 40% of the total number of applicants in these countries. These measures are necessary, but the bureaucratic management of refugee flows under the aegis of the European Commission does not solve any of the causes of these forced departures. And it is time, rather than acting endlessly on the effects, to address the causes by stopping stoking wars in Africa and the Middle East and destroying the economies of the countries of the South through free trade agreements.   I abstain so as not to prevent the care of these people.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on interim measures in favour of Italy and Greece in the field of international protection. The call for 40,000 asylum seekers to other EU countries over a two-year period is at stake.  The European Parliament has shown solidarity and responsibility in the face of a serious humanitarian problem which should encourage the taking of a position on a permanent relocation mechanism. Europe must be able to respond, it must be supportive, but it must also be lucid. The debate needs to be done, for effective mechanisms to be set up to effectively help those who should benefit from this aid.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in support of the resolution.
