This emergency legislation will relocate people from two of the countries whose facilities for incoming migrants are under considerable pressure. This is a small step towards greater solidarity among Member States and a necessary point of departure towards a binding, permanent distribution mechanism between every Member State.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the face of the migration crisis, only an ambitious European solution will ensure a solidarity and sustainable management of the phenomenon. States such as Greece and Italy alone cannot manage the entire flow. It is a collective responsibility. I am therefore pleased that the European Parliament has agreed to the establishment of a mechanism for the relocation of 40,000 migrants currently located in Greece and Italy. I regret, however, that the Member States have not been able to put in place a mandatory allocation mechanism. This mechanism will soon be consolidated by a new Commission proposal which aims to distribute 120,000 additional asylum seekers within Europe, not only in Greece and Italy but also in Hungary. These mechanisms now respond in part to the emergency but can only be the first step towards a permanent European mechanism.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ I do not support the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece concerning the introduction of emergency measures in respect of 40 000 people. I do not agree with binding quotas for Member States, although this is a temporary derogation from the Dublin Regulation limited in scope and duration. I am disappointed that the ordinary legislative procedure has not been respected in this case and that the European Parliament has only been consulted very formally on this issue.  I believe that it is preferable for member countries to voluntarily show solidarity and willingness to help their neighbors in need. At the same time, I expect the institutions and bodies responsible for coping with the current crisis situation to function better.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on provisional measures in the international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. It is essential to show more solidarity between ourselves and create a truly European asylum system

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to relieve the burden on Greece and Italy, which have been hardest hit by the refugee crisis, the Commission proposes to reassive 40 000 persons in clear need of international protection from Italy and Greece to the other Member States as an emergency measure by means of a temporary derogation from the Dublin Regulation. The rapporteur welcomes the proposal, pointing out that the Member States of the European Union must form a united front to address the challenges posed by migration, and that the solution must be based on solidarity and a fair sharing of responsibilities, especially with those Member States that receive the largest number of refugees. As the 40,000 numbers were based on last year's refugee population, and this year the number of refugees has soared, he proposes to increase the number to 50,000. It takes a position in favour of a mandatory quota for the distribution of asylum seekers between Member States and an improvement in the quality of resettlement. As a lesson from the Maltese pilot resettlement project, it underlines that, in order to ensure successful resettlement, it is worth taking into account, to the extent possible, the preferences of refugees for the country of destination and attaching critical importance to information and consent. It draws attention to the fact that the Commission announced in its Agenda on Migration that it would present a legislative proposal for a permanent resettlement scheme under the codecision procedure by the end of 2015, and recommends that Parliament take the initiative in this regard and present an own-initiative report if the Commission does not come forward with such a proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Europe faces new challenges, is sought after by those who desperately flee war, violence, hunger, ill-treatment.  The flow of refugees seeking hope for themselves and their own in Europe is one of the world's new phenomena. And for new realities, we urgently need to have new solutions. Europe must welcome as well as possible those who have struggled to reach a safe haven. I think it is important to provide the Member States, themselves "gateways" to these refugees in the EU, with support to welcome them in a dignified manner. A swift and effective policy on the registration of these people is important, avoiding future situations of irregular displacement within the European area. I support that no Member State can deal individually with this influx of refugees efficiently. The EU must base its action on the principles of solidarity and the equitable sharing of responsibilities.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the Council's proposed decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece aims to encourage Member States to come together to respond to the challenges of migration. It supports the Commission's proposal on the binding relocation measure, which includes a binding key to the distribution of refugees between Member States, on the basis of the principle of solidarity and shared responsibilities, but goes further by proposing to increase the number of refugees to be relocated (50,000 at least, compared to 40,000 for the Commission).  I have of course voted against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which calls for a unified EU response responsibility sharing in light of the ongoing migrant crisis.In addition, the report states that priority should be given to vulnerable applicants, and among those special attention should be given to unaccompanied minors.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. Faced with the arrival of tens of thousands of migrants by sea, Greece and Italy have called for emergency measures to relocate 40,000 people across the European Union. This text, which calls on Member States to agree on binding quotas for the distribution of these people, is clearly not applicable within the schengen area, which abolishes internal borders. In addition, the majority of EU Member States have an asylum system that is already saturated and unable to accommodate more in dignified conditions. Germany, which has announced it wants to accept 800,000 refugees, has taken less than a week to reintroduce controls at its borders, overwhelmed by the air call it has provoked.  So I voted against it.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. We share Europe, it is in a Europe that helps me want to live, that is what guided my vote in favour of interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.  The right to asylum is a fundamental right. We cannot forget that our shared history is marked by those who have fled persecution. It is high time that Member States put an end to the incantations and review their integration policy. We need courage and ambition: Angela Merkel has shown the direction; today, Jean-Claude Juncker reinforces this path.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's position on temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece. I have done this despite the fact that I do not consider some of the principles on which the proposed part of the solution to the immigration crisis is based to be the most appropriate. I also voted in favour because there is no hint of another solution on the table, and the expression of opposition to the Commission's proposal in the absence of another option leads to an escalation of the current crisis. A crisis that is not about an abstract problem, but about tens of thousands of specific people. I do not consider the system of mandatory quotas to be the best, although, unlike many politicians, I think it can be set up to work. Even refugees have to respect the rules. I would welcome the agreement of the Member States on how to deal fairly with the problem. Unfortunately, past months have shown that the governments of the Member States are not capable of this agreement. I therefore supported the EP's position, as did 498 of my colleagues, because, in a situation where states are not one hundred to agree on a voluntary assumption of co-responsibility, the mandatory mechanism is the only solution that is realistically on the table and, in this sense, the only possible one.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This proposal advocates a common European asylum policy and a refugee quota. It also emphasises that social and cultural ties can also lead to the reunification of asylum seekers. On the basis of these facts, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Council's decision to institute interim measures for Italy and Greece to help them effectively manage the current influx of refugees into their territory, putting their international protection regime under pressure. These two countries face particular challenges at a time of increased migration flows. That is why it is necessary to support them by first providing for a mechanism for relocating refugees to the other Member States of the Union. This report calls on Member States to take part in this solidarity effort and to commit to a common response, worthy of our European values, for the management of this crisis.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. ‒ There are three main reasons for my decision to abstain on the vote on ‘Establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece’. First of all, the European Commission and the Council has already moved on with the plan to relocate asylums seekers from Italy and Greece, therefore there is no actual purpose for this Report. Second, the focus of this Report is on relocation and distribution of the asylum seekers among the EU MS, instead of looking for ways to deal with root causes and strengthening the EU external borders. Third, I do not think that binding and obligatory quotas which are forced upon EU MS can encourage any solidarity as it ignores specific national conditions. Latvia has suffered from large uncontrolled immigration during the Soviet Occupation, for which the consequences are still visible today. It is my strong belief that MS should be encouraged to show greater solidarity through voluntary means not be a binding quota system.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Recent weeks have shown that the European asylum system is not working as it should. Europe has not been able to deal with war refugees humanely, but the refugee crisis is manageable and the European Union can cope with this humane settlement if all countries help.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the migratory flows that are affecting Europe and some states in particular, Firstly, Italy, considering it essential for Europe to respond in unison and to observe the principle of solidarity laid down in the Treaties, also considering that immigration cannot continue to be regarded as an emergency but is a phenomenon that will continue to affect Europe for the years to come, I have decided to vote in favour so that we can finally arrive at a common policy both in the short and long term.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. The aim of this proposal is to put in place interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, in order to enable them to adequately cope with the current significant influx of third-country nationals. The large number of people arriving in these countries puts immense effort on the security systems and systems responsible for providing asylum and assistance.  The provisional measures provided for in this proposal relate, in particular, to the transfer of applications for international protection (in persons where it is obvious that such protection is indeed necessary) from Italy and Greece to other Member States of the European Union. This report sends a clear message to the Council that more solidarity and responsibility is needed to adequately address the rapidly growing needs caused by the large number of asylum seekers arriving in Europe. The situation is alarming, it requires immediate and concrete action, so I supported this report.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report on the Council's proposed decision establishing interim measures in the area of international protection for Italy and Greece aims to encourage Member States to come together to respond to the challenges of migration. It supports the Commission's proposal on the binding relocation measure, which includes a binding key to the distribution of refugees between Member States, on the basis of the principle of solidarity and shared responsibilities, but goes further by proposing to increase the number of refugees to be relocated (50,000 at least, compared to 40,000 for the Commission).  I have of course voted against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Keller's report calling for solidarity between member states and solidarity with refugees. I believe that the current EU migration policy is not enough to solve the problem of illegal migration. We have several hotspots in the world.  First of all, we have a war in the east of Ukraine, then a situation with the Group Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in the Middle East, and then various natural and social disasters that have befallen a large part of Africa. The pressure on European leaders is immense, and countries that are on Europe's southern borders must not be left alone in helping those fleeing all crises with hope for a better future.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the implementation of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. No Member State can deal effectively with the refugee crisis on its own. In its Resolution of 28 April 2015, the European Parliament underlined that the EU must base its reaction to the tragedy in the Mediterranean on solidarity and responsibility sharing, in particular with those Member States receiving the largest number of refugees.  If Italy and Greece do not receive adequate support, further movements of refugees and migrants are likely to continue on a larger scale. This puts at risk one of the EU's key achievements, freedom of movement within the Schengen area.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the context of the current migration crisis, the Eu must react and adopt urgent measures in order to be able to best manage this crisis in the interests of European citizens and migrants. The interim measures cited in the report help to better manage the flow of migrants and to organise a provisional distribution of refugees among Member States. I voted in favour of this report, because it is now essential that the Union act quickly, efficiently and coherently. However, the measures should also take into account the specificities and needs of member states in order to preserve stability within the Union's borders.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The 962% increase, compared to the same period last year, of migrants crossing the borders of the European Union irregularly has increased the emergency situation in the countries of entry, particularly Italy and Greece. Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 604/2013 assigns responsibility for the examination of the application for protection to the first country of entry, which has therefore been exerting negative pressure on their migration and asylum systems. In order to relieve the pressure on Italy and Greece, this legislative resolution establishes provisional measures in the field of international protection for the temporary and exceptional relocation to other Member States of 110 000 persons in clear need of international protection. In view of the shared responsibility of the Member States in the reception of refugees and applicants for protection, and also taking into account the current emergency situation and the extraordinary demands required by it - as regards strengthening solidarity and responsibility - I voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Faced with those who claim that "Brussels" would not rise to the challenge of migration and asylum, the Commission responds with concrete proposals to establish real solidarity and shared responsibilities between Member States. By voting on Franziska Keller's report, the European Parliament strongly supports the Commission's initiative for a mandatory distribution of refugees within the Union. These first emergency relocation measures for 40,000 applicants from Italy and Greece will soon be supplemented by new measures for 120,000 applicants, with the aim of establishing a permanent and mandatory relocation scheme as soon as possible. MEPs advocate a flexible mechanism to adapt to migration flows and routes. They also propose to take into account, as far as possible, the preferences of applicants and Member States insofar as this would promote the integration of people relocated to their host countries, while avoiding secondary movements within the Union.  The ball is now in the court of the Member States, which must show political courage at such a decisive moment for the future of the European Union.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. While EU Member States are facing a drastic increase in asylum seekers, the phenomenon does not affect all countries in the same way. Indeed, the countries at the gates of Europe, especially Italy and Greece, are suffering the full brunt of this situation and are often the first helpless witnesses to the migration catastrophe affecting the old continent.  I voted in favour of this text to support the principle of European solidarity and to distribute the refugees awaiting the verdict of their asylum application in an emergency relocation measure. I believe that it is incumbent on all Member States to take responsibility and resolve this crisis collectively.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes temporary emergency measures to relocate an initial 40,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to other EU countries over a two-year period. I also supported the provisions for greater solidarity and the establishment of a fair and equitable relocation mechanism. I also had the opportunity to deplore the non-suspension of the regulation and the non-suppression of the reference to the first country of entry into the territory of the Union.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. This is the biggest catastrophe in the Mediterranean Sea since World War II and the tragedy of this migration crisis. The emergency solution found by the Commission to this terrible situation was to trigger the emergency response system provided for in accordance with Article 78 (3) TFEU. The proposal includes a temporary distribution scheme for persons in clear need of international protection, as well as the allocation of funds for the relocation of applicants, ensuring fair and balanced participation of all Member States. I support the proposal to establish interim measures on international protection for Italy and Greece so that they can deal effectively with the significant entry of migrants and refugees into their territories. I also support, like the rapporteur, the Commission's proposal for a binding relocation measure that includes an obligation to divide refugees between Member States, based on the principle of solidarity and sharing of responsibilities, as emergency relocation is only an immediate solution to address the enormous pressure these two countries have undergone and which are at risk of the EU's main achievements , as freedom of movement within the Schengen area.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration phenomena are increasingly frequent, in fact, more and more people are forced to leave their state in search of a new destination. Greece and Italy have always been the countries most affected by this incessant phenomenon. In order to deal with this emergency, it is necessary for The Member States to cooperate and draw up laws capable of managing migratory flows, in order to protect the host countries. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for the binding distribution of refugees between the various Member States, while respecting the principle of solidarity and the sharing of responsibilities.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to vote against as the number of migrants relocated is absolutely derisory compared to the total number of people landed in Italy and Greece during the reference period.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which concerns directly the refugee crisis in Europe, and in particular the relocation of asylum seekers arriving in Italy and Greece. While we consider that the number of refugees considered in this text (40000) is clearly insufficient given the magnitude of human displacement that is taking place, the text speaks of this number as a beginning. It also proposes an automatic relocation system, which takes into account the preferences of refugees. In this way the approved mechanism can serve as a test bench to develop an effective system that can be applied on a larger scale in the months and years to come.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge. A challenge that can only be solved jointly at European level. Leaving each country alone is neither a solution for the EU Member States nor for the thousands of war refugees driven away from homes. This only leads to an unequal distribution between countries and to more sad marches along Europe's motorways. These developments are also being seen in Danish soil these days. On this challenge, the EUROPEAN Union must come up with an answer and a solution. The key lies first and foremost with the Member States. We therefore fully support a pan-European solution, as agreed between the EU Member States. However, how such a solution will work in practice must be a question for the Member States that have to take part in it. Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. That is the way it is today and that will be the future. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report. The rejection of the proposed administrative mechanism to build on a permanent system of redistribution of refugees between EU Member States should not be interpreted as rejecting people-to-people solidarity and helping people who need it. I believe that all Member States and their citizens are ready for it. At the same time, and first and foremost, I appeal to the EU's maximum international diplomatic efforts to end the war in Syria and other conflicts in the EU's neighbourhood, in which hundreds of thousands have already died and which are driving people from their homes, including to EU countries.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Although this report contains aspects which we reject head-on such as the identification of migrants through their fingerprints as if they were criminals, we voted in favour of this report because we understand that it is going in the right direction in terms of asylum policies in overcoming Dublin regulation and proposing a policy based on solidarity between States but taking into account the will of the applicants Asylum. The main positive points include a broader definition of family reunification than we had up to this point and a system of location of applicants based on their preferences.  It also includes reference to a regular assessment of the use of funds received by Member States for their asylum policy and the need to take into account the specificities of LGTBi women and individuals.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Because I believe strongly in showing more solidarity between we Europeans, we must create a truly European asylum policy. This is why I voted in favour of this report today.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ we are facing the biggest refugee crisis since The Second World War, which is why Slovakia, as well as other EU Member States, must be more accountable and in solidarity. For this reason, we cannot declare at this time that we do not want refugees, but we must try to help them. On the other hand, I am opposed to quotas. For this reason, in the case of the resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, I voted against this resolution. The document contained a number of controversial proposals, such as a system of preferences for the country of relocation by migrants or a lack of consideration of preferences for Member States, including taking into account the cultural and social environment of that country, which must be considered a not insignificant part of the integration of relocated persons.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The introduction of temporary international protection measures in favour of Italy and Greece in the context of an emergency situation as a result of the sudden influx of third-country nationals has proved necessary. The temporary measures also include additional costs for the EU budget totalling €240 million over a two-year period. As Italy and Greece are the first countries where migrants enter the EU, there is a need to strengthen increased demands on funds, but also to help manage the asylum process. Given that Amendment 3 talks again about binding quotas, and the nominal vote approved it, I abstained in the final vote on the motion for a resolution. By final vote, the report has been approved and Italy and Greece will be obliged to report to the Council and the Commission every three months on the implementation and proper use of the funds received under the approved decision.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The current refugee crisis and the disaster in the Mediterranean Sea have illustrated that Europe must work together to prevent further disasters and respond effectively to the refugee crisis by fulfilling its duty to protect people in need. As a first and very important step towards the implementation of the principle of solidarity, the Commission has proposed an emergency relocation measure for the transfer of 40 000 persons in urgent need of international protection from Italy and Greece to other Member States. The Dublin system has caused an imbalance between Member States, both in the influx of refugees and migrants and in their final destination, which requires its overhaul. The Commission's proposed relocations constitute a derogation from the Dublin Regulation. I support the conclusion that the mechanism to be set up anew should be binding on all Member States and should cover a much larger number of people than the initial 40 000. I agree with all the major key points of the report, such as the binding key for the distribution of refugees among member states on the basis of the principle of solidarity and sharing of responsibility, the increase in the number of refugees to be relocated, the importance of not relocating asylum seekers without their consent, and the taking into account of their preferences (family and social ties, language skills...), which is why I also voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The Keller report, referring to the Commission proposal of 27.5.2015, aims to improve the situation of refugees from Syria and Eritrea, who have an average recognition rate of more than 75% in the EU, and to relieve the first host countries of Greece and Italy. The central means of discharge will be a European-organised distribution of quotas among the EU Member States. The report is problematic for a number of reasons. Firstly, the concept of the quota is currently unenforceable due to a lack of technical requirements. Enforcement of existing rules of the admission procedure is hardly successful. The Schengen system does not allow for long-term control of internal borders. Secondly, the report calls for refugees not to be assigned to a country against their will. As a result of this rule, only a few countries with attractive social benefits are targeted. Thirdly, the very generous German policy is creating false incentives and, moreover, is in breach of European law. States that have not been involved or consulted at all should now support this policy by quota. Many are unwilling to do so. Fourthly, contrary to the idea of subsidiarity, the European grounds for recognition of asylum seekers should be standardised. These and other reasons make the report seem unrealistic. Nevertheless, I have chosen to vote in favour because there is undoubtedly a humanitarian problem that needs a European solution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the current migration crisis has the effect of introducing temporary international protection measures for the benefit of Italy and Greece. These countries cannot cope alone with such a large number of refugees, which is why they are asking for EU assistance in such an emergency situation. It is essential that other countries show their solidarity in order to provide assistance to the most affected countries to cope with the surge of refugees. As this report also talks about the introduction of binding quotas for all EU Member States, I have decided to abstain in the vote. Quotas are not a long-term solution to the problem. Lessons must be learned from this crisis and prepared to cope with similar situations in the future. This will not be possible without more effective border protection, the strengthening of Frontex and a new common asylum policy.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 Together with almost 500 democratically elected representatives of European voters, I voted in favour of the proposed recommendation to the Council on the temporary redistribution of escapees from Italy and Greece. I've been waiting a long time for our government to accept refugees voluntarily. She didn't do it, led by a vision of votes in the election. Showing such a clear and spectacular reluctance to any sign of solidarity within the EU at a time of such a complex geopolitical situation, when Europe must stand together, is a great gamble. The government clearly preferred electoral preferences, responsibility, and simply showing humanity to refugees. They are refugees, people fleeing the war that we are talking about, not economic migrants. Just to clarify, the EP does not co-decision in this case, but only gives the Council its opinion, which is not binding on the Council, that is, the Member States.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA is in favour of a comprehensive approach to the asylum crisis: a strong border policy, a firm integration and activation policy, with a sound dispersion plan. Today, therefore, the N-VA voted against the Commission's unilateral and inadequate proposal and the accompanying EP resolution.  Indeed, more attention should be paid to strengthening our external borders (e.g. organising hotspots to organise the return of economic migrants; and push-backs to safe third countries, referring to the Dutch government's statements and Commission President Juncker's qualification of candidate countries as safe states). This text will also put a brake on the EU's commitment to a firm national integration, activation and participation policy.  Finally, the text contains an unfair distribution key for the distribution of asylum seekers, again asking Western Europe to make the greatest effort. The N-VA is for a fair and workable system of permanent mandatory dispersion. The temporary system that has been voted does not meet those conditions. In view of the State of the Union address, we continue to call for a comprehensive approach more than ever.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Statistics since the beginning of 2015 confirm a clear trend of increasing illegal entries into Italy. Also, In 2015, Greece faced a high increase in the number of illegal border crossings, corresponding to more than 50 percent of the total number of irregular border crossings in 2014.  Interim measures in the area of international protection should therefore be put in place for the benefit of Italy and Greece to help them take care of refugees. It is also important to regulate refugees, control their permanent resettlement in other Member States from those countries where refugees are constantly arriving, and write them down using fingerprints. In addition to all of the above, I support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it calls for a unified EU responseresponsibility to the ongoing migrant crisis. In addition, the report states that priority should be given to vulnerable applicants, and among those special attention should be given to unaccompanied minors.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support this report to ultimately take a decision to help our Member States deal more easily and easily with the problem of accepting migrants.  Hoping that the European Union will address the cause of the growing influx of migrants into its territory as soon as schengen borders will be preserved, I think it is vitally important to provide assistance to Greece and Italy in the meantime so that migrants who do not intend to stay in these countries are more easily deployed to other areas. As part of the European Union, Croatia is ready to accept a certain quota proposed by the institutions of the European Union, agreed in accordance with the interests of all countries, provided that this quota is in line with our country's current infrastructure and economic capabilities.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I fundamentally disagree that the current problems with migrants should be solved by mandatory quotas for redistribution in the Member States. Quotas only amplify the problem with migrants. For a real solution, it is necessary to seal the EU's southern and eastern external borders thoroughly and to set up central camps in North Africa and the Balkans, where all asylum applications from migrants will be individually assessed.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, which proposes to relocate 40,000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece. The test is not only the political wisdom of the European Union, but also europe's humanitarian and solidarity. On these values, Europe was built and based on them even today. I am in the fore of the principle of fair solidarity between Member States in resolving the refugee crisis, but I am in the process of consistently returning those migrants whose lives are not at risk by war. First and foremost, it is necessary to help those in urgent need of international assistance.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on temporary international protection measures in favour of Italy and Greece in order to confirm my opposition to the solution to the migration crisis through quotas to date. The migration crisis is a complex problem that does not have one simple solution. However, this solution or the solution of individual sub-existing but interconnected problems must be sought together, at Union level, and should be actively involved in this debate. Above all, it remains our task to contribute to the future debate on the shape of the EU's asylum and migration policy. A system must be found that minimises the emergence of crisis situations and resolves potential crises arising from causes beyond the reach of eu or Member State competences quickly, effectively and while maintaining humanitarian commitments that cannot be waived.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is far from providing solutions to the serious problem of illegal immigration. While there is an admission of the criticality of the situation in Greece and Italy, the proposed measures and the so-called "holistic approach", combined with the "wishes" for a review into the future of the treaties, are a mockery and show the technocratic perception of the committees.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I was unable to vote in favour of the Keller report because it does not deal with real problems and therefore does not provide a solution to the current crisis. Mandatory quotas do not help.  The biggest problem today is that a fraction of the refugee influx is now willing to register, cooperate with the authorities and accept, say, refugee status in poorer Member States. Most of them are going to the Member States that promise more social assistance, and they are doing everything they can to get there.  It will continue to do so after allocating quotas: as soon as possible, it will make its way to states where it can expect greater social assistance. In the meantime, there is no point in talking too much about quotas and distribution until we can protect Europe's external borders and the number of people who enter the Union increases by thousands every day, while only a fraction of them are entitled to refugee status.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, in particular because it is in support of solving an issue of extreme urgency and affecting tens of thousands of people. However, I consider it important to underline that I consider the use of existing EU legal and financial instruments to be a temporary legal basis and I consider it urgent to establish a legal basis for a comprehensive and lasting management of the refugee and migration wave by the EU institutions. The proposal contains only a reference to the importance of the Balkan refugee route, while, in the light of the real migration data, I would have considered it justified if the provisional measures had covered Hungary, which is facing difficulties such as Greece and Italy; I will seek to assert this aspect in the future as a Member.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The last few months have been marked by an exponential increase in migration from conflict zones in the Union's neighbourhood to the Member States.  Beyond the populist polemics that mark the public space in the member countries, the problem will continue to exist; therefore there is a need to adopt a solution at EU level. The states where immigrants first reach (mainly Italy and Greece) are under enormous pressure, which requires joint action by the other Member States. It is necessary to redistribute refugees, in accordance with a scheme negotiated and adopted jointly, according to the possibilities existing in each Member State of the Union. Refusal to take in refugees clearly constitutes a violation of the principles on which the European Union was founded and cannot be accepted.  What is, however, an essential condition is that each person's rights are respected and that redistribution should not be affected by discrimination according to arbitrary criteria. At the same time, it is the right of every refugee to agree to its redistribution to one Member State or another; that is why I believe that the focus should be on what refugees want and less on what some European politicians want.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I did not vote in favour of this report as it only proposes short-term measures rather than providing a comprehensive approach to this complex problem. I could not particularly support the Commission’s proposal to redistribute asylum seeker according to the mandatory quotas to the Member States, which would force the asylum seekers to stay involuntarily in given countries.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I cannot support a coercive system of realisation of migrants and asylum seekers, as I consider that a much more effective and sustainable approach to fighting the current crisis is to build trust through a voluntary system in which each Member State would be willing to offer financial and in-in-aid to those Member States that are on the front lines; so far, it's Italy and Greece. I consider it crucial to find solutions to the causes of mass migration, to put in place strong and decisive measures to punish people smugglers, to help overcome the war conflict and to rebuild peace, and to establish a system for returning migrants to their home country. I also support strengthening the role of FRONTEX and EASO. I cannot agree with certain proposals incorporated into the report, such as a proposal to establish a system where refugees would have to consent to the Member State to which they would be allocated. At the moment, I hold it a priority precisely to build infrastructure and to establish an efficient system that will be prepared for all future challenges of migratory flows, which will certainly appear at the external borders of the European Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece aims to establish temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece in order to enable them to deal effectively with the current influx of third-country nationals. Italy and Greece's asylum system is under pressure. The provisional measures provided for in this proposal relate in particular to the resettlement of applicants for international protection, which, at first sight, appears to need international protection, from Italy and Greece to other Member States. I supported the report.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which concerns directly the refugee crisis in Europe, and in particular the relocation of asylum seekers arriving in Italy and Greece. While we consider that the number of refugees considered in this text (40000) is clearly insufficient given the magnitude of human displacement that is taking place, the text speaks of this number as a beginning. It also proposes an automatic relocation system, which takes into account the preferences of refugees. In this way the approved mechanism can serve as a test bench to develop an effective system that can be applied on a larger scale in the months and years to come.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Keller report, referring to the Commission proposal of 27.5.2015, aims to improve the situation of refugees from Syria and Eritrea, who have an average recognition rate of more than 75% in the EU, and to relieve the first host countries of Greece and Italy. The central means of discharge will be a European-organised distribution of quotas among the EU Member States. The report is problematic for a number of reasons. Firstly, the concept of the quota is currently unenforceable due to a lack of technical requirements. Enforcement of existing rules of the admission procedure is hardly successful. The Schengen system does not allow for long-term control of internal borders. Secondly, the report calls for refugees not to be assigned to a country against their will. As a result of this rule, only a few countries with attractive social benefits are targeted. Thirdly, the very generous German policy is creating false incentives and, moreover, is in breach of European law. States that have not been involved or consulted at all should now support this policy by quota. Many are unwilling to do so. Fourthly, contrary to the idea of subsidiarity, the European grounds for recognition of asylum seekers should be standardised. These and other reasons make the report seem unrealistic. Nevertheless, I have chosen to vote in favour because there is undoubtedly a humanitarian problem that needs a European solution.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The rapporteur agrees that all Member States must stand together to respond to the 'challenges of migration'. The proposal for emergency relocation is, in this respect, a limited but important "advancement". Keller fully supports the Commission's proposal for a binding relocation measure that includes a binding key to the distribution of refugees among Member States, on the basis of the principle of solidarity and shared responsibilities. It also suggests "consolidating the principle of solidarity" by increasing the number of refugees to be relocated. The Commission has proposed to relocate 40,000 refugees based on the number of refugees who arrived in Europe in 2014, without taking into account that these figures have since increased considerably. Ms Keller therefore proposes the figure of 50,000 "at least". This figure will, of course, still have to be revised upwards. This is an obvious denial of national sovereignty in border control and asylum and immigration management. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which concerns directly the refugee crisis in Europe, and in particular the relocation of asylum seekers arriving in Italy and Greece. While we consider that the number of refugees considered in this text (40000) is clearly insufficient given the magnitude of human displacement that is taking place, the text speaks of this number as a beginning. It also proposes an automatic relocation system, which takes into account the preferences of refugees. In this way the approved mechanism can serve as a test bench to develop an effective system that can be applied on a larger scale in the months and years to come.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was positive to this Ska Keller’s report. It establishes an emergency mechanism for the relocation of 40 000 refugees with high recognition rates (Syrians, Eritrean, Iraqis) from Italy and Greece to other Member States is adopted. The Parliament insists on a binding distribution key for the relocation of refugees. In addition, it is in favour of significantly stronger solidarity measures and increases the number of refugees to be relocated to 110 000. A large majority of the EP also suggests that the preferences of refugees for a Member State, based on family, social and cultural ties, should be taken into account to the extent possible.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it allows an emergency mechanism to be activated so that 40,000 asylum seekers can be relocated from Member States that are under increased pressure at their borders due to the refugee crisis (Greece and Italy) to third EU countries.  The report also lays the groundwork for developing a permanent emergency redistribution system so that we can act with agility in the event of an emergency. The report we voted on should serve as a model for the new emergency redistribution system.  The Commission has incorporated our proposals to take into account the interest of refugees. I think that's the way it should be. In order to achieve a positive outcome for all, i.e. refugees and society as a whole, it is important that we focus on refugees, where their families are, their language skills and their qualifications to improve the possibilities for integration.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: in writing. ‒ VVD is of the opinion that refugees must accept the outcome of the allocation system and should not be able to object to being placed in another EU Member State. If a refugee can avoid being placed in another country than Germany, the whole system will not work anymore.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. We need to move quickly towards a European approach to the refugee issue. With mandatory redistribution of asylum seekers across all Member States. But also with the return of asylum seekers coming from safe countries, and a firm approach to people smugglers. Merciful and just. The Keller report makes a number of valuable suggestions to both the Council and the Commission for Juncker's plan for the redistribution of asylum seekers. The most important is to allow asylum seekers to indicate a Member State of first choice. For example, because they already speak the language or have family living there. Member States may also indicate a preference, for example for asylum seekers with certain professional qualifications. Moreover, it is an option for asylum seekers to make that choice: that preference does not create obligations for a Member State. Keller goes too far when she makes a comprehensive bureaucratic procedure, including interviews with liaison officers and the possibility for asylum seekers to object to the relocation decision. With this observation, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Commission has just made a new proposal to relocate 120,000 asylum seekers to Italy, Greece and Hungary. The European Parliament on Wednesday (September 9th) adopted its position on the Commission's first proposal on the relocation of 40,000 asylum seekers. While this proposal was largely undermined by the Council and the Member States in July and many States vehemently opposed their responsibilities, it was important for Parliament to call on Member States to fully commit to the reception of refugees.  This report stresses the need for a permanent and mandatory solidarity mechanism for the reception of asylum seekers. Above all, it asks to ensure that the preferences of asylum seekers in their choice of relocation are respected and that the consent of the applicants is ensured before they are relocated to another Member State.  It's time to stop procrastinating. Member States must finally live up to their responsibilities and the so-called values of the European Union. These men, women and children all have rights and these must be respected in the EU. I'm voting for.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has obvious responsibilities in destabilisation and war, in the policy of economic dominance and the collection of natural resources in the countries of origin of these refugees, notably in Syria and Libya.  The report in question fully launders these responsibilities and pursues the same security policy by promoting the action of the FRONTEX Agency. The solidarity of the various countries in the reception of refugees is certainly decisive and necessary. But we believe that a system of binding quotas will not meet either their aspirations or the possibilities of countries with different capacities.  We also disagree that the 'territory of the Member States' is a 'criterion for determining the key distribution of migrants'. What is fundamental is the creation of conditions in countries for the integration of migrants into economic and social rights. For humanitarian reasons and in compliance with the Geneva Convention, states must take measures to give proper reception to refugees in an expression of solidarity with the peoples who are victims of these aggressions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The proposal advocates a common European asylum policy and a mandatory refugee quota. It also stresses that social and cultural ties can also lead to the integration of asylum seekers into the respective Member States. In the case of emergency relocations, the Commission would decide which Member State should take in the asylum seeker. It must therefore be rejected in its full feed!

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The refugee crisis is a human tragedy, but at the same time it poses major challenges not only for border control and freedom of movement, but also for the ability of our societies to care for the weak and those in need.  I am largely satisfied with the proposals presented today by the President of the Commission.  In order to deal with the acute crisis, it is fair and right that responsibility for asylum seekers should be shared more evenly among the Member States. It is equally important that the Commission listed the so-being of the so-being of the Commission. safe countries from which europe cannot be sought as an asylum seeker in the future. The number of applicants in need of protection is growing rapidly. In future, other legal means must be used to work in Europe from the Balkan countries and Turkey. However, it should be remembered that there can be many causes of the right to manoeity. There are countries where there is no actual war, yet people may be in need of asylum because of their political opinion, religion or sexual orientation, for example. Internal border controls within the Schengen area are not the way to contain the crisis, although temporary and local reintroduction of border controls may be necessary to bring the authorities under acute control. On the other hand, efforts to step up returns, measures to halt human smuggling and diplomatic efforts to achieve peace will be stepped up, which I consider important.  An ageing Europe needs immigration. The success of the integration of asylum seekers is a great opportunity for Europe.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of provisional measures in favour of Italy and Greece in favour of Italy and Greece. The report has been in the works for a long time and has been amended in the last few metres with regard to the Commission's relocation mechanism proposed by the Commission. I reject the relocation of asylum seekers, war refugees and economic emigrants according to a quota and the ideas of bureaucrats. The EU's common asylum policy has mutated into an immigration policy. It is seriously violating the principle of subsidiarity. The actionism supported by the Commission and the majority of Parliament only shows the old principle that, in the crisis, the answer is always more EU. This does not take into account the fact that the crisis was only created by incorrect EU rules. The Dublin Agreement has failed and does not correspond in a healthy way with the Schengen Agreement. Relocation quotas cannot save freedom of movement in the EU. Germany, in particular, should refrain from sending foreigners to its European neighbours in the east who do not want them back.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted against the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. I believe that the joint and several action of the Member States is crucial in formulating a concrete and sustainable response to the refugee crisis. This response must contain concrete elements, some of urgency and others that constitute a medium- and long-term response. With regard to the Central and Eastern European states, I believe that the most appropriate measure for their involvement in the European refugee relocation system is that based on voluntary quotas assumed in the emergency resettlement process. Moreover, this is the official position of the group of countries of the Visegrad Group, but also of my country, Romania. European support is needed to strengthen the capacity of these Member States to participate in the future implementation of common European asylum and refugee policies.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report deals with the asylum crisis in Italy and Greece and the launch of a system for the relocation of persons in need of international protection and applying for it to other Member States. The proposal calls for the transfer of around 40% of all irregular migrants to Greece and Italy in 2014. I do not believe that a system of forced relocation is the right idea. A better solution would be to build trust and a sustainable system based on the voluntary principle of other Member States. Rather, such large migrations should be prevented by achieving stability in the region, cooperation with third countries, an effective return system and severe sanctions for trafficking in human beings. Checks on the situation in Greece and Italy should be carried out more frequently and a system should be put in place to anticipate the increase in migratory flows at the border. I therefore voted against the request for a relocation scheme.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The phenomenon of landings across the Mediterranean Sea is taking on enormous proportions and putting a strain on the reception and asylum systems of Member States that are on the front line and faced with an increasing number of landings. This report aims to put into practice the obligation of solidarity provided for in Article 80 of the TFEU by proposing an emergency relocation measure providing for the compulsory distribution of 40 000 people in clear need of international protection from Italy and Greece to other Member States through a binding distribution key for refugees between Member States. An important point in the report is that Parliament repeatedly reiterates that emergency relocation is only a first step, important though it may be, for the implementation of the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility among all Member States and that a permanent relocation mechanism based on clear and defined criteria to be activated automatically is required.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 I believe that even good intentions can have unintended negative consequences. Unfortunately, this is also the case with compulsory quotas. Not because we have an excuse and refuse to help people in need, but because solidarity and help cannot be forced. To date, quotas have mainly contributed to accusations and quarrels, to increasing tensions and radicalising attitudes. It's not right, and we really have more. We have shown this repeatedly in the past when we have successfully coped with several migratory waves. As Pope Francis has also said, we must help people fleeing war. Without further standing still and with unnecessary emotion, the Government must invite representatives of the public institutions, churches, charities and NGOs involved to jointly draw up a concrete plan for both immediate and long-term assistance.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has serious responsibilities in the destabilisations and wars, in the policy of economic dominance and the collection of natural resources in the countries of origin of these refugees and immigrants, for the political interference and military interventions in which it has participated actively and firmly, in particular in Syria and Libya. The report in question fully launders these responsibilities and pursues the same security policy by promoting the action of the FRONTEX Agency. The solidarity of the various countries in the reception of refugees is certainly crucial and necessary, but we believe that a system of binding quotas will not meet either their aspirations or the possibilities of countries with different capacities. Much less do we agree that the 'territory of the Member States' is a "criterion for determining the key distribution of migrants". What is fundamental is the creation of conditions in countries for the integration of migrants into economic and social rights. For humanitarian reasons and in compliance with the Geneva Convention, States should take measures to give proper welcome to refugees in an expression of solidarity with the peoples who are victims of these aggressions and the EU abandons its policy of militarisation, neocolonialism and exploitation of the peoples of Africa and the Middle East. For the reasons expressed, we abstained.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, cities are home to nearly 75% of EU citizens. Cities are where two-thirds of our GDP is produced, and where the greatest challenges of our daily life lie too: tackling barriers to employment, social exclusion, pollution and climate change. However, as drivers of economic activity and innovation, cities are also where the solutions to these challenges can be found. The EU has already done great work on urban and regional development, especially in my region of the West Midlands. Cities like Birmingham, Coventry, Stoke, Worcester and Wolverhampton all have areas where the EU has contributed to their growth. However, we also have to recognise that there is a lack of coordination on urban policies, both horizontally and vertically. That is why I supported Kerstin Westphal’s report and why I am urging the Commission to ensure that towns and cities are much more closely associated with the entire European policy—making cycle and that the urban agenda is fully geared towards the objectives of EU 2020.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I want to say that I was happy to support this report, which also discussed whether there is the competence or competence of the EU institutions to talk about urban mobility, the urban agenda. I think that the debate is very late, or that there is really no need to debate whether the urban agenda falls within the scope of the European Union. I'm sure you do. There is no doubt that the mobility trends of European citizens are bringing together cities. That the majority of the people of the European continent will live in cities, and that if the European Union were to resign from the urban agenda, to urban mobility, it would undoubtedly resign from one of the main moves to define another period for this. I therefore hope that even colleagues who, in my opinion, did not incomprehensiblely support this report, will change their decision-making and thinking on this matter in the future, because the urban agenda, urban mobility is a matter of Eu policy and I have been honoured to support this report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, European policies have a direct impact on the development of cities and national urban policies. Member States' objectives are linked to smart, green, sustainable and diversity economic growth. Obviously, in diversity and tolerance towards each other. With these ambitions, European urban planning policies need to be strengthened. Improving the urban dimension of these European Union policies would make European funds simplified and allocated at local level, so that decisions are taken by local communities. That is why I support the association of cities and functional urban areas with the whole cycle of European urban policies. Functional urban areas, cities, Member States, the Commission must cooperate to improve these urban policies in concrete terms and according to the desire of local communities, because the people there know best what they want. Let us be the citizens of today for the cities of tomorrow.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – I consider it appropriate that Parliament has discussed a report on the urban dimension of EU policy. The fact that 80% of the population lives in or around cities justifies it. For the record, it's not a positive change. The main regrettable reason for this is that in many countries the population retention power of the countryside has decreased, in no small part because of the large-scale agricultural rate. But we must take note of the fact and it is therefore right that urban dimensions are given special emphasis in regional and regional development policies. For which I abstained and did not accept it, it was a separate paragraph, which, in order to manage urban policy, creates a central back-end institution for the Commission and thus a central will will prevail here too. That's why I didn't support it, I abstained.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I was happy to support the report on urban policies. I believe that, in addition to the different association policies that link different cities, it is right that we also talk about this at European level, that this is what the European Commission and, of course, the European Parliament is dealing with. We have already heard key arguments. There are between 50% and up to 70% of people living in big cities. In addition to economic development, these large cities also bring urban problems, that is, the daily migration of people, and environmental pollution is linked to it, and quality answers need to be found to all these questions. The next thing I consider very important is the coexistence of rural cities, which means that urban policies in the field of public transport, as well as the opportunities offered by suburban settlements, are what good practices need to be promoted and exchanged. Exchange of good practices – for this, the best parquet is european parquet.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir. Bhí sé suimiúil freisin – agus sásúil – go raibh an chuid is mó de na Feisirí sa Pharlaimint ina fabhar.  Tá leath de dhaonra an domhain agus 75 % de dhaonra an Aontais ina gcónaí i mbailte móra agus i gcathracha. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid gach rud a dhéanamh chun ár gcathracha agus ár mbailte móra a chur chun cinn, go háirithe ó thaobh fhás an gheilleagair de.  Ba chóir go mbeadh oideachas agus spórt ar fáil do dhaoine óga; jabanna ar fáil do dhaoine fásta agus fothain ar fáil freisin do gach duine. Rud eile, ba chóir go mbeadh aer folláin ar fáil sna cathracha. Chun é sin a dhéanamh, caithfimid díriú ar thaisteal, go háirithe, níos mó rothar agus níos mó gluaisteán leictreach, agus ar thithe nach mbeidh astaíochtaí ag teacht astu mar atá faoi láthair.  D’fhéadfaimis a lán a dhéanamh. Tá an t-ábhar seo an-tábhachtach agus is féidir linn cabhrú leis.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. I also supported this extremely important and at the same time timely decision because, as several colleagues have already mentioned in connection with this report, more than 70% of the European Union's population lives in cities. The city, it is an absolutely unique culture, the city is its absolutely unique place of meeting on the one hand industrial zones, on the other hand the cultural heritage that has been observed in the European Union for decades and hundreds. And the vision of urban development, colleagues, must also be coordinated at European Union level. It is now not compulsory for the Member States or for the municipalities, but it still seems to me that this is extremely important. I believe that, in order to develop a viable common strategy, local authorities should also be involved. And here the gap that can be seen between the national level – government and municipality, municipal government – must be reduced, for example. I will repeat myself again, I voted in favour.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, EU urban policies are an attempt to bypass the nation state to put EU policies directly into city regions. I warn the people of the West Midlands – who are facing the prospect of a combined authority backed by the EU – that, if this happens, you should be ready for positive discrimination when it comes to council employees. Be ready for congestion charges on your roads. Be ready to pay to have your domestic waste removed. This is all part of the priorities imposed by the EU in order to put our money back into our cities. We must stand together as the people of the West Midlands to fight against this West Midlands combined-authority idea. It is counter—democratic, it is against what we believe in and it takes democracy further from the people. Please join me, and let us fight this combined-authority idea and stop it dead.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims, within the margins offered by treaties (such as through the principle of subsidiarity) to deepen the participation of sub-state entities in the decision-making of European policies; Therefore, the adopted text supports, inter alia, the creation of the European urban agenda, which examines the objectives of territorial cohesion taking into account the potential and threats of densely populated areas. At this point, however, I must remind you that it is essential to take priority to rural areas, where they are generally at high levels of unemployment, greater difficulties in accessing public services and progressive depopulation. However, I voted in favour of promoting through the many financial instruments (such as Integrated Territorial Investments, Community-Led Local Development, etc.) and necessary participatory investments, to promote a more rational model of sustainable development in the urban areas of the European Union that create synergies not only with each other but also with their rural environments.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In the face of the challenges of smart, inclusive and green growth facing metropolises, the report calls for strengthening the role of European authorities on one of the competences outside their authority: urban policy.  In this text, it is planned to guide this policy according to the objectives set out in Horizon 2020, to facilitate european financing of local projects and above all to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities. That is why Member States are being asked to speed up decentralisation.  As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is in no way within the EU's competence. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European authorities therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States.  If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy.  Therefore, I objected to that text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further EU action, and for more taxpayers' money to be spent.  I oppose increases to EU spending.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Given the fact that more than 70% of the European population are living in urban areas and cities are affected by European regulation, but the coordination of various proposals with each other is not always coherent and implementation of them for cities is not easy, it is more than clear that a sustainable EU urban development policy requires an indispensable and a more unified EU approach. Therefore, I fully support this report and voted in favour of it.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which, once is not customary, takes on the powers that the treaties do not confer on the EU.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Europe continues to face a variety of challenges related to the economy, climate, environment and society at large. The report points out that most of these challenges have a strong urban dimension. Indeed, they are manifested mainly in and around cities (e.g. poverty, social and spatial segregation, environmental degradation) or find their solution (effective resource management and carbon-neutral economy, economic development and innovation, social innovation and integration, etc.). The rapporteur notes that although the role of cities in economic, social and cultural development is recognised, the political response at European and national levels has been slow and fragmented, with many sectoral initiatives but little integrated. He points out that more and more people believe that it is important that cities participate sufficiently in the design and implementation of EU policies, and that they are better adapted to urban realities. This change in attitudes has resulted in calls for an urban programme of the Union from a wide range of stakeholders at local, national and European levels, which are relayed by this report which I approved.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the urban dimension of EU policies uses the fact that three out of four Europeans live in an urban area to propose new transfers of sovereignty. Indeed, he believes that the European institutions play a major role in the development of metropolises thanks in particular to existing funds such as the ERDF, which devotes 5% of its budget to it, but he carefully avoids recalling that these come from the contributions of the Member States. The report naturally proposes to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities, to encourage Member States to speed up the decentralisation of their administrations in order to better integrate urban authorities in the development of these policies, to facilitate European funding of local projects...  The EU is still trying to interfere a little more in the policies of states and impose on them a real political "diktat" of good practices to follow, which have still not been up to the challenge.  Moreover, this Europeanist and federalist project would be contrary to EU law since urban policy is not within its jurisdiction. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While I largely agree with the content of the Westphal report, I believe that the desire to improve the coordination of different policies and better integrate the objectives of urban development into a greater number of areas by means of a European Urban Agenda risks extending the role and competences of the Commission to an area where I believe that the principle of subsidiarity must remain untouched. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. There are positive wordings on civic empowerment, democratic legitimacy and green efforts, while emphasising further integration and harmonisation of urban policies, the consequence of which will be European governance. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. More than 72% of the EU's population lives in urban areas where 2/3 parts of GDP occur. Moreover, the impact of European policies themselves is enormous at the local level. In view of the importance of urban areas in Europe, the EU began to get involved in local affairs, mainly through regional and urban development policies. This report, by german socialist Kerstin Westphal, examines the challenges of EU urban policy and gives recommendations for a future common sustainable urban development policy. The lack of coherence and coordination between the various EU rules and programmes and between the local level and the other levels of government seems obvious. Improving this interaction suggests, inter alia, the figure of the EU's special urban representative to coordinate EU policy and initiatives and optimise decision-making work between different levels of administration, while adapting the URBAN programme to the objectives of the 2020 Strategy and the challenges of social inclusion, demographic change and sustainability.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this Parliament's report, which discusses the urban dimension of European Union policies. As in 2014, half of the world's population and 72% of the world's population were Europe's population lived in urban areas, and by 2050 almost 80% of the land population will live in urban areas, Parliament believes that cities and functional urban areas need to be more integrated into the entire EU policy-making cycle. The Commission is invited to adopt a more locally based integrated territorial approach in the preparation of new policy initiatives for urban areas in order to ensure consistency, as well as to enable cities and functional urban areas to achieve the europe 2020 objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proportion of the population of cities worldwide is growing dynamically. As explained in the report, opportunities and challenges are concentrated in cities at the same time. Opportunities, because cities are the engines of economic development, job creation and innovation. And challenges, since cities are responsible for the vast majority of greenhouse gas emissions and energy use, are characterised by transport difficulties due to overcrowding, high levels of pollution and social exclusion. Against this background, the rapporteur welcomes the Commission's steps towards the establishment of an EU urban agenda and considers that this agenda should be based on multi-level governance, adequate EU funding, partnership, better regulation and regular exchange of information, taking due account of the principle of subsidiarity. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I therefore voted in favour of Kerstin Westphal's report on the urban dimension of EU policies.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of urban areas naturally crosses the main challenges facing the European Union. I voted in favour of this resolution, which supports the Commission's initiative to draw up a European urban agenda. To this end, it will be useful, as the resolution calls for, for the Commission to present an analysis of the data relating to the programmes already planned and supported in this field by European funds disbursed through the regions in order to arrive at a concrete strategy with monitorable objectives and results.
