An urban strategy that can only be coordinated with some of the main European programmes, such as the Digital Agenda and the Connecting Europe Facilities plan, in a dimension that must not be limited to the size of urban macro-areas, but must enhance the specific vocations of small and medium-sized urban areas, also by virtue of technological developments and their impact on the socio-economic dimension.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this own—initiative report was to examine the urban policy challenges for EU policy makers and to propose ideas for the improvement of the coordination and the coherence of EU urban policy. The report proposed a bottom-up and partnership approach in urban policies, under a new model of multilevel governance that would enhance the participation of cities, towns and their representatives in the shaping of urban related policies and in management and governance of programmes supported by EU funding. Many of my groups GUE-NGL amendments were included in the final text in order to improve vital parts of it. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that EU policies should support functional cities and urban areas by enabling them to express and fully realise their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development that are essential for the progress of the whole European continent.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In the face of the challenges of smart, inclusive and green growth facing metropolises, the report calls for strengthening the role of European authorities on one of the competences outside their authority: urban policy. In this text, it is planned to guide this policy according to the objectives set out in Horizon 2020, to facilitate european financing of local projects and above all to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities. That is why Member States are being asked to speed up decentralisation. As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is in no way within the EU's competence. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European authorities therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States. If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Urban Agenda sets out a coherent framework for EU urban policies by adapting sectoral policies to urban development needs, responding to urban challenges and contributing, at the same time, to strengthening territorial cooperation.  Cities are true engines of economic development, ensuring growth and employment, acting as catalytic centres for creativity and innovation. At the same time, urban areas face many economic, social and environmental challenges, to which the European urban agenda can provide concrete solutions. The objectives of the agenda should focus on specific priorities that have the capacity to deliver measurable results in the development of smart cities and the low-carbon and socially inclusive economy. Better coordination of European policies in the field of urban development and ensuring the necessary coherence is achieved through simplification, efficiency and harmonisation measures and by facilitating the widest possible access to a harmonised knowledge base. Financing measures available through the Structural and Investment Funds and existing financial instruments are essential support for the development of urban areas. Given that almost 70% of European citizens live in urban areas, I believe that cities are and must remain the main beneficiary of investments through cohesion policy.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 On the pretext (and good intention) of improving the coordination of different policies and better integrating the objectives of urban development into more areas by means of a European Urban Agenda, the report proposes extending the Role and Competences (Interference?) of the Commission in an area where, on the contrary, the principle of subsidiarity must remain tainted. Abstention vote

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted today in favour of the report on the urban dimension of EU policies on the basis of the following considerations: - it is clear how essential it is to cross traditional administrative boundaries in the common search for a solution to economic, social, environmental and demographic challenges.  - it is well known how difficult it is to overcome one's national borders and voluntarily to face the challenges coming from its own national territories in Europe. - I join the chorus of those who share the need for the adoption of a clear model of multi-level governance, we can make each person involved, up to the individual citizen, share a share in solving today's main economic, social and environmental challenges. I therefore agree with the report and the call for greater synergies between EU-funded programmes (LIFE, Horizon 2020, ...) and national, public and private investment.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this own-initiative report was to examine the urban policy challenges for EU policy makers and to propose ideas for the improvement of the coordination and the coherence of EU urban policy. The report proposed a bottom-up and partnership approach in urban policies, under a new model of multilevel governance that would enhance the participation of cities, towns and their representatives in the shaping of urban related policies and in management and governance of programs supported by EU funding. Many of my groups GUE-NGL amendments were included in the final text in order to improve vital parts of it. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further EU action, and for more taxpayers’ money to be spent. I oppose increases to EU spending.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Europe is currently facing multiple challenges such as the economy, climate, environment and society. Most often these challenges manifest themselves around the cities or find their solutions in and through cities. I agree that that cities need to get involved in the preparation and implementation of EU policies and that these policies need to be better adapted to urban realities. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains interesting and acceptable aspects of the need to develop a truly integrated approach to territorial development at European level. It has the merit of addressing the four main challenges of the urban dimension (management and governance, smart growth, inclusive growth, green growth), but remains vague in relation to the regeneration and enhancement of urban historic centers, and the environmental impact of further urbanization. These are undoubtedly important aspects, which, together with the vagueness about the figure designed to coordinate European urban policy, have led me to abstain.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it supports the willingness of the European authorities to grant themselves new powers that limit the scope of action of sovereign states in urban policy, which, it must be recalled, is in no way within the competence of the Union.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, 72% of the population lives in cities, a percentage that, according to estimates made by the European Commission, is expected to reach 80% by 2050. This phenomenon of urbanisation, while presenting development potential, on the other, risks increasing the challenges facing it: poverty, social inclusion and sustainable environmental development models.  Although more than two thirds of the Union's policies are of direct or indirect interest to cities, they have not been able to respond fully to local needs, both because of the fragmentation of instruments and initiatives and because there has been a lack of real and effective involvement of cities and urban areas in their definition, planning and implementation. In order for these European investment policies and funds to really and effectively contribute to the development of territories, the urban dimension needs to be strengthened in multi-level governance in order to combine local needs with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The report voted on today in plenary goes in this direction and underlines the need for a European Urban Agenda to be drawn up shortly in order to identify the issues to be addressed as priorities in the Union's policies. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 EU policies should certainly support cities, towns and functional urban areas and encourage them to make the most of their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development. Quite rightly, Member States are encouraged to cooperate fully with cities and functional urban areas, seeking their mandatory participation in the development and planning of strategic policies, such as national reform programmes and operational programmes.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that Mr McDerman's report is a good one. Westphal comprehensively illustrates all the challenges facing Europe's urban environment on a daily basis as cities continue to expand. In fact, there are many problems in population centres related to pollution, poverty, traffic, and so on, in order to resolve which I believe the EU needs to implement more specific urban policies and that cities themselves must play a more active role in their implementation. I also fully support the creation of a European urban programme that can better analyse the territorial impact of cities and coordinate the different urban instruments and policies implemented in Europe; This can be done by identifying a figure to work out projects to solve urban problems, taking into account the specific needs of each reality. Indeed, I believe that this project can be a valuable aid to cities to improve the environment and the lives of citizens and to implement a uniform policy in the Union to resolve common difficult situations in many population centres.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Kerstin Westphal's report on the urban dimension of EU policies. Functional cities and urban areas are economic pillars and drivers of eu job creation (as innovation and new economic activities often originate in the city), thus making an added value for the EU in its relations with other regions of the world. I support the Commission's initiative to work towards a European Urban Agenda, and I consider it essential to set up it with the aim of seeking better coordination between urban solutions and EU challenges, a better link between sectoral policies and governance levels, better targeting of EU funding for relevant local urban challenges and a better assessment of the territorial impact of sectoral policies.  The Urban Agenda should promote the development of governance solutions that can best respond to the challenges and objectives of sustainable, economic and socially inclusive development of Europe's functional cities and urban areas.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed this own-initiative report on the urban dimension of EU policies, as the time has come to give cities greater importance for the central role they have acquired over time in the european governance landscape. A more active role is not only to improve their participation in the European decision-making process, within the mechanisms responsible for respecting subsidiarity and proportionality, but also, and above all, to the introduction of the urban dimension into european strategic instruments and funding, which will be the real driving force for a more participatory and multi-level policy. I hope that the announced European Urban Agenda will be drawn up with a pragmatic approach in order to offer concrete instruments to make European cities protagonists in the European system.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims, within the margins offered by treaties (such as through the principle of subsidiarity) to deepen the participation of sub-state entities in the decision-making of European policies; Therefore, the adopted text supports, inter alia, the creation of the European urban agenda, which examines the objectives of territorial cohesion taking into account the potential and threats of densely populated areas. At this point, however, I must remind you that it is essential to take priority to rural areas, where they are generally at high levels of unemployment, greater difficulties in accessing public services and progressive depopulation. However, I voted in favour of promoting through the many financial instruments (such as Integrated Territorial Investments, Community-Led Local Development, etc.) and necessary participatory investments, to promote a more rational model of sustainable development in the urban areas of the European Union that create synergies not only with each other but also with their rural environments.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The debate on the European urban agenda is at a turning point. The forthcoming Dutch Presidency has announced that it will be one of the cornerstones of its strategy. However, in the run-up to next spring's Amsterdam Conference, we must equip and be ready. In my opinion, there are, among others, at least two priorities that need to be affirmed. The quality levels and standards of urban areas must be guaranteed, whatever their size and nature, by addressing infrastructure and intangible needs asymmetrically. In addition, the model of vision and management of territories must be changed from one based on purely structural assessments to another that places strategic attention on relational characteristics, understood both in terms of cooperation between countries and economic and social flows. The urban agenda cannot, therefore, be an object in its own right, it risks not representing added value, unless it is put in synergy with two important European strategies: the Digital Agenda and the Connecting Europe Mechanism (CEF). Only in this way can we overcome the limits which, today, prevent small and medium-sized areas in particular from intercepting the economic and productive processes and changes taking place.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this own-initiative report is to examine the urban policy challenges for EU policymakers and to devise guidelines and boundaries for a future sustainable EU urban development policy. The report emphasises the fact that there is no single European model for a city, and focuses on the challenges of tomorrow’s cities and the growth from ‘cities’ to ‘megacities’, the issue of smart, green and inclusive growth, and management and governance solutions. I believe in the need for a more unified EU approach to this topic and so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the policies of the European Union must support cities and functional urban areas in order for them to express and exploit their full potential as engines of growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development. I believe that these cities and functional urban areas need to be more associated with the whole policy-making cycle at European level.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report aims to improve the participation of cities in the design and implementation of EU policies on urban issues and calls on the European Commission to better coordinate its work within it. Many of the challenges facing Europe related to the economy, climate, environment and society are evident in cities and their peripheries, or find their solution (effective resource management, low-carbon infrastructure). The rapporteur therefore proposes the creation of a European programme as a first for the establishment of a full-fledged European Union urban policy.  Considering that better coordination of policies and instruments with an urban dimension at EU level is needed in order to provide more effective support to cities, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the urban dimension of the Union's policies. This report highlights the lack of coordination, both between the different regulations and programmes, and in the coordination of work between the European and local levels. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to have a real urban policy.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: Written. – As an Antwerp native, I think it is important that my city should also be more closely involved in European policy-making. Better coordination between different policy initiatives and grant programmes is important. Cities are a suitable place for economic growth, jobs, social integration and sustainable development.  They need to work together more in harmony and support each other.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Kerstin Westphal's report on the urban dimension of EU policies, as the report contains several ideas worth considering. The proportion of the population of cities worldwide is growing dynamically. As explained in the report, opportunities and challenges are concentrated in cities at the same time. Opportunities, because cities are the engines of economic development, job creation and innovation. And challenges, since cities are responsible for the vast majority of greenhouse gas emissions and energy use, are characterised by transport difficulties due to overcrowding, high levels of pollution and social exclusion. Against this background, the rapporteur welcomes the Commission's steps to establish an EU urban agenda and considers that this agenda should be based on multi-level governance, adequate EU funding, partnership, better regulation and regular exchange of information, taking due account of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Kerstin Westphal's report on the urban dimension of EU policies. The proportion of the population of cities worldwide is growing dynamically. As explained in the report, opportunities and challenges are concentrated in cities at the same time. Opportunities, because cities are the engines of economic development, job creation and innovation. And challenges, since cities are responsible for the vast majority of greenhouse gas emissions and energy use, are characterised by transport difficulties due to overcrowding, high levels of pollution and social exclusion. Against this background, the rapporteur welcomes the Commission's steps towards the establishment of an EU urban agenda and considers that this agenda should be based on multi-level governance, adequate EU funding, partnership, better regulation and regular exchange of information, taking due account of the principle of subsidiarity.  The report's proposals contain several ideas worthy of consideration, which is why I supported the proposal in the plenary vote in Strasbourg.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the underlying desire of this Report to bring together stakeholders from across EU regions to discuss how EU initiatives can benefit urban communities and spaces.  It is part and parcel of the EU that, at times, the nature of our relationship means that those regions that are on the periphery of Europe, both in status, size and population, fail to witness the greatest benefits from proposals brought forward by this Parliament. In my view, it is therefore crucial that all relevant forums are put in place to ensure that those towns and cities in smaller regions such as my own constituency, Northern Ireland, have their place in influencing EU initiatives. I am already aware of the work being carried out by the European Unit of Belfast City Council in relation to the Eurocities Network, and I very much support any review that gives local urban populations a greater say in how European funding and other mechanisms can bring benefits to their everyday lives.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Urban policies are, of course, the responsibility of local municipalities and authorities or of a higher level, but are by no means the responsibility of the European Union. The intrusion of supranational institutions in this area is a further violation of the sovereignty of states and the principle of subsidiarity that is enshrined in european treaties. These urban policies are likely to follow the Commission's vague and ideological objectives and its 2020 agenda. I cannot support such interference and a drift towards an increase in the Union's budget so that it can fulfil missions outside its competences. So I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 More and more people live in cities – in Europe and around the world. This development is accelerated above all by population growth and by new technologies. The aim of this own-initiative report by colleague Christine Westphal is to take a closer look at the challenges facing EU policy and to draw up a draft of the guidelines and boundaries of a future sustainable urban development policy.  In short, your rapporteur is of the opinion that EU policy must urgently take measures for an efficient urban development policy in order to have an impact on the effects of Europe's urbanisation and the speed at which this urbanisation takes place. In your rapporteur's view, only through active and coordinated action by EU policy will cities be able to perform their functions and offer their inhabitants the living conditions they want in the future. However, account must also be taken of the fact that European cities are exceptionally different and a common universal policy by the EU would not have the desired effect in all Member States. For this reason, I voted against the proposal made. I believe that it violates the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The urban dimension of EU policies is nothing more than a crescendo of exasthism and the development of citizens' dependence on the state. The EU should support agrophilia and consider ways and methods that, combined with the development of local agricultural production and entrepreneurship, would finally bring growth to the abandoned European region.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 70% of the EU's population lives in cities, as a result many challenges of the EU's environmental and economic policies are linked to the urban dimension. The EU Treaties do not provide a legal basis for urban policy and, therefore, we have seen how intergovernmental - often informal - cooperation has developed, which is defining a shared vision of urban development. Member States have therefore drawn up documents such as the Leipzig Charter, the Toledo Declaration and the 2020 Territorial Agenda, all of which are non-binding agreements.  This has led, in recent years, to the need to devise an EU urban agenda to facilitate the development of a sustainable EU policy for urban development. The report, while addressing the four main challenges of urban management such as governance, smart growth, inclusive growth, green growth, remains vague in two fundamental aspects: the regeneration and enhancement of urban historic centres (ideally aimed at avoiding the construction of ghettos with the consequent social, economic and cultural exclusion of most citizens) and the environmental impact of further urbanisation. I abstained.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. In 2014, half of the world's population and 72% of the European population lived in urban areas, and by 2050, almost 80% of the world's population will live in urban areas that constitute a single polycentric structure built around large, medium and small cities and surrounding areas. On the other hand, around 70% of European policies and legislation are implemented at local and regional level and better political coordination between stakeholders and government levels is needed, as the sectoral approach to EU policy can lead to policies and legislation that do not favour functional urban areas. I agree with the idea of creating a European Urban Agenda that better articulates urban solutions and EU challenges, a better link between sectoral policies and governance levels, better orientation of EU funding to relevant local urban challenges and a better assessment of the territorial impact of sectoral policies.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it aims to eventually transfer the powers of urban policy from the states to the European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the attempt to improve the coordination of different policies and better integrate development objectives, but this is an area where interference must not be allowed and the principle of subsidiarity must remain tainted.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative on the urban dimension of EU policies. The urban dimension of EU policies is nothing more than a crescendo of exasthism and the development of citizens' dependence on the state. The EU should support the opposite trend, that towards the countryside, and consider ways and methods which, together with the development of local agricultural production and entrepreneurship, can finally bring development to the abandoned European region.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Today, more and more people are living in cities, in Europe and worldwide. This trend is being hastened most of all by population growth and new technology.  I support the call by the rapporteur on the Commission to develop a new multi-level governance model combining formal governmental structures with informal structures which take into account new digital communication possibilities and network activities. The new model should guarantee an exchange of information both horizontally and vertically and should improve citizen participation and democratic legitimacy.  Another objective of the report is to simplify EU law in the interest of efficient urban development policy, in order to facilitate implementation and reduce costs. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of Kerstin Westphal's report on the urban dimension of EU policies. The proportion of the population of cities worldwide is growing dynamically. As explained in the report, opportunities and challenges are concentrated in cities at the same time. Opportunities, because cities are the engines of economic development, job creation and innovation. And challenges, since cities are responsible for the vast majority of greenhouse gas emissions and energy use, are characterised by transport difficulties due to overcrowding, high levels of pollution and social exclusion. Against this background, the rapporteur welcomes the Commission's steps towards the establishment of an EU urban agenda and considers that this agenda should be based on multi-level governance, adequate EU funding, partnership, better regulation and regular exchange of information, taking due account of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. It can be deduced not only from the fact that about two thirds of European policies directly or indirectly affect cities, but also from the fact that at present around 72% of its population lives in urban areas: we cannot but consider the impact of our decisions on cities and their citizens. For this reason, it is necessary to rethink and re-update urban areas according to the main criteria that will be at the heart of the 2020 Strategy: sustainability, inclusion and investment in services, because cities are the first contact between Europe and the citizen, our business card and our opportunity to make our commitment concrete and tangible. I therefore believe that a Europe approach that coordinates the various areas of competence by strengthening the dimension and urban development and providing, while fully respecting the principle of subsidiarity, for greater involvement of cities is essential.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP Initiative report on the urban dimension of EU policies, given the great importance of urban areas for the EU, both socially and economically: 72% of the EU population in 2014 lived in urban areas and 2/3 of Europe's GDP comes from cities, which are incubators of new economic and innovation activities. I believe that the role of cities in the formulation of European policies must be strengthened, with a bottom-up decision-making process that give a voice to the territories, understand their specific characteristics and enhance their diversity. True multi-level governance, therefore, that recognises the diversity of European cities and their essential function of practical application of EU decisions and regulations. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the urban agenda in order to fully implement the principles of proportionality, subsidiarity and partnership and to create sustainable economic development that is conducive to the social inclusion of the weakest groups. In order to promote a greater integrated land-based approach and also to take advantage of macro-regional strategies, I believe that cities need to be more involved in the programming of the Structural Funds, and I therefore welcome the rapporteur's idea of establishing, within the Commission, a political entity responsible for the urban agenda.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the 'Report on the urban dimension of EU policies' today, as I consider the area of urban development to be very important, taking into account all its social, economic and environmental challenges and the increasing phenomenon of rural exodus, and i find the report's countervable approach to it to be of little benefit, as it misses the needs and living environments of urban communities and metropolitan areas in Europe.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In view of urbanisation in Europe, we need to seek and implement measures for an effective EU urban agenda in order to strengthen urban dimensions in EU policies. The different interests of cities need to be taken more into account and the challenges of urban policy must be addressed.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the Development Committee of the Regions, dedicated to analysing and proposing ideas for EU urban policies. Since 78% of the Union's population lives in urban areas, a coordinated approach is considered necessary for the policies that concern them directly. While we believe that we need to be careful with certain formulations on "multi-level governance" that could open the door to privatization of essential aspects of urban management, we believe that as a whole the text is a positive step.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, I voted in favour of this report as it acknowledges that although there is no explicit EU competence on urban development, there is a broad range of EU initiatives which have an impact on towns and cities directly. This is clearly demonstrated by a number of towns and cities across the North—West Region of England, where I represent.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted favourably on the report on the urban dimension of EU policies. In my opinion, it is extremely important to examine the urban policy challenges for EU policy makers and to devise guidelines and boundaries for a future sustainable EU urban development policy, as it is the purpose of this report. Moreover, Commission should take the EU Urban Agenda into account in its next programme of work, in order to propose the necessary measures for its implementation in order to help cities and better coordinate Cohesion funds allocation to them. Fundamentally, I believe that usefulness and success of the programme lie within the smooth implementation of the EU policies at the local level.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with ALDE and the majority of the European Parliament in favour of the report on the Urban dimension of EU policies. With as many as 75%-80% of Europeans are living in cities, it is imperative that we support the new model of multi-level governance, cross-sector and EU Commission coordination of urban related polices. We need to strongly support the environmental, transportation, educational and employment needs of urban areas in order to ensure they are attractive places to live and work and furthermore cater for the needs of different sectors and age groups in society across Member States.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because I believe EU policies can and should support and enable towns, cities and other urban areas to meet their full potential as motors of economic growth, employment and social inclusion. I support the creation of a European Urban Agenda and believe that we need to enhance the participation of cities, towns and their representatives in shaping urban-related policies in the management of programmes which receive EU funding.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important initiative report. The Scottish Cities Alliance is a collaboration between the Scottish government and Scotland’s seven cities, and many of the issues covered in this report are relevant to the Alliance’s work.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the Development Committee of the Regions, dedicated to analysing and proposing ideas for EU urban policies. Since 78% of the Union's population lives in urban areas, a coordinated approach is considered necessary for the policies that concern them directly. While we believe that we need to be careful with certain formulations on "multi-level governance" that could open the door to privatization of essential aspects of urban management, we believe that as a whole the text is a positive step.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that towns, cities and functional urban areas should be fully supported by EU policies and should be more closely associated with the European policymaking cycle. Also, subnational governments should be involved in the policy process and development strategies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the urban dimension of EU policies, as I believe that EU policies should support small and large cities and functional urban areas and enable them to exploit their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment and social development. I support the establishment of the European Urban Agenda as a harmonious framework for EU policies with an urban dimension, with a view to better linking local urban solutions and EU problems.  Due to the growing disproportion between administrative and territorial structures (urban and suburban areas and rural areas), new forms of flexible governance are needed to continue the integrated territorial development of functional areas. The European Urban Agenda should be based on a multi-level governance method that encourages greater local level involvement at all stages of the policy cycle, thereby improving policy coherence with continuous changes in functional urban areas.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. In the face of the challenges of smart, inclusive and green growth facing metropolises, the report calls for strengthening the role of European authorities on one of the competences outside their authority: urban policy. In this text, it is planned to guide this policy according to the objectives set out in Horizon 2020, to facilitate european financing of local projects and above all to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities. That is why Member States are being asked to speed up decentralisation. As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is in no way within the EU's competence. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European authorities therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States. If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy. So I voted against it.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the urban dimension of EU policies. At a time when two thirds of Europeans live in urban areas and more and more European policies are having an impact on cities, it was necessary for Parliament to set its guidelines. The adopted text goes in the right direction and stresses that the priority is to bring existing urban initiatives into line, without unnecessarily legislating or adding new administrative burdens. It also stresses the need for Europe to adopt a flexible approach that does not focus solely on large cities.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets the guidelines for a future European urban policy. It proposes, for example, to better involve cities in the development of urban policies or for one of the European Commissioners to refer on these issues.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report contains neither a justification nor constructive proposals on how the EU should respond to increasing urbanisation and what the legal basis is subsidiarity. I am voting against the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it suggests that EU policies should support and enable towns, cities and functional urban areas to express and attain their full potential as motors of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal. The "functional urban areas" of the Union are made up of a single polycentric structure built around large, medium and small cities and their neighbouring areas, thus going beyond traditional administrative boundaries to embrace different territories united by the same economic, social, environmental and demographic challenges. EU policies should support functional cities and urban areas by enabling them to express and fully realise their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the urban dimension of European policies. As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is in no way within the competence of the European Union. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European Union bodies therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States. If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims, within the margins offered by treaties (such as through the principle of subsidiarity) to deepen the participation of sub-state entities in the decision-making of European policies; Therefore, the adopted text supports, inter alia, the creation of the European urban agenda, which examines the objectives of territorial cohesion taking into account the potential and threats of densely populated areas. At this point, however, I must remind you that it is essential to take priority to rural areas, where they are generally at high levels of unemployment, greater difficulties in accessing public services and progressive depopulation. However, I voted in favour of promoting through the many financial instruments (such as Integrated Territorial Investments, Community-Led Local Development, etc.) and necessary participatory investments, to promote a more rational model of sustainable development in the urban areas of the European Union that create synergies not only with each other but also with their rural environments.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This initiative report analyses urban policy problems arising from EU policies. The document develops guidelines and limits for a future sustainable common policy.  The present and the future of Europe and the rest of the world are going to be purely urban. That is why, as highlighted in this report, it is crucial to improve the coordination of the policies and development objectives of cities within the EU. In this sense, the urban dimension needs to become a staple of all relevant EU policies.  In addition, Union legislation should be simplified in order to facilitate its implementation and reduce costs. As the report shows, it would also be interesting to consider a new model of governance in which cities can contribute their experiences and opinion to the legislative process of the European Union.  Urban population figures are strongly clear and will be more clear in the coming years. That is why I am voting in favour of a report which stresses how it is inescapable to design and establish a true sustainable and efficient urban model.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is not supposed to address the future of cities. This will be based on natural development and also on the requirements of the population. Urban development should therefore be left to decision-making at the lowest level.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ 72% of all urban populations currently live in the European Union, a trend that is on an upward trend. Almost all European policies have real impacts on cities. The new dimension of cities such as employment centres, socio-political life and the entity providing a wide range of services to residents and visitors requires strengthening the role of cities in European policy. Not all European proposals and regulations are equally applicable in cities. However, common problems prevail on issues such as transport infrastructure and mobility, the environment, energy efficiency, spatial planning and social policies. Solving common problems requires cooperation with cities, their coordination and the development of EU urban policy as part of European policies that takes into account the position and development of cities as centres of economic growth.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the report on the urban dimension of EU policies because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I am voting against this report from the European authorities. As the rapporteur himself reminds us, urban policy is not dependent on the EU! This notion of the 'urban dimension of EU policies' is therefore a way for Brussels to give itself ever more powers, to the detriment of the states. In the event that this dimension comes under the control of the EU, its budget should increase, and with it the contribution of European states and citizens.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report, which calls for greater involvement of towns and cities in the Structural and Investment Funds’ programmes; believes that the lessons drawn from this could feed into an important policy recommendation for the development of cohesion policy after 2020; in this context, calls on the Commission to test the implementation of the European Urban Agenda in selected thematic fields, reflecting the challenges of urban areas (‘urban pilot projects’), in particular by ensuring the cross-sectoral coordination of different EU policies, removing existing overlaps and applying the multi-level governance model and conducting territorial impact assessments; asks the Commission to report to Parliament on the progress and results in this respect on a regular basis

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the urban dimension of EU policies. Among the objectives of Europe 2020, cities play a key role in employment and cohesion policy. Cities are home to challenges but also economic opportunities and direct services to the citizen. The EU must act towards a sustainable urban development policy, given that more than two thirds of all European policies affect cities more or less directly.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report starts from an analysis of the current impact of EU policy on cities, highlighting the potential room for improvement of European urban policy. I particularly welcomed the proposal to appoint an EU Special Representative for Urban Affairs, with the functions of coordinating the various initiatives. By agreeing with the objectives and structure of the report, I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. More and more people, both in Europe and around the world, live in cities. And you have to take that into account when designing policies of all kinds. That is why I find the report on the urban dimension of EU policies that we have supported so timely, which makes it very clear from Parliament that the EU must take this reality into account and act and legislate appropriately. We need to be able to adopt an efficient and clear urban policy, to ensure adequate living conditions for its inhabitants and to ensure that cities become an engine of European economy and society.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In her rather low-content report, the rapporteur fails to explain why the EU should react to increasing urbanisation in the first place and in detail. This report must therefore be rejected.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In 1950, 50.5% of the European population lived in cities. In 2014, this figure was 72%, and could reach 78% by 2030. Increasing urbanization challenges our societies to organize common living spaces as best they can. The rapporteur clearly lists the issues: climate change, demographic changes or improvement of the education system. But Parliament is consulted here to promote the Commission's 'urban programme for the EU', which relies in particular on the competition of macro-regions and 'cheaper administrative action'. On the other hand, the report does not question rural desertification and its consequences in terms of access to services for citizens. It is mainly limited to a series of good words, such as on the integration of citizens into the European legislative process, in particular thanks to new technological tools, without explaining how. I do not want to participate in such a biased consultation, the sole purpose of which is to approve and serve the interests of the European Commission, which once again exceeds its powers. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In the face of the challenges of smart, inclusive and green growth facing metropolises, the report calls for strengthening the role of European authorities on one of the competences outside their authority: urban policy. In this text, it is planned to guide this policy according to the objectives set out in Horizon 2020, to facilitate european financing of local projects and above all to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities. That is why Member States are being asked to speed up decentralisation. As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is in no way within the EU's competence. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European authorities therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States. If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the urban dimension of EU policies. Knowing that 70% of European policies and legislation are implemented at local and regional level, it should also be forgotten that cities, or large urban areas, play an important key role as an economic pillar and driver in job creation. However, they are still faced with less positive factors such as an ageing population and demographic decline, pollution, traffic congestion or social exclusion. In this sense, European policies play a crucial role for sustainable economic and social development.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in support of the report. 72% of the population of the EU and 94.8% of Malta’s people live in urban areas. This report focuses on the challenges we face today and how the urban environment can either solve or exacerbate these issues. It suggests cities become more involved in the creation of EU policy and establishes that we must focus more closely on the effect of policy on urban environments.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The land use is of an exclusively political nature. Urbanization transforms the very structure of states and creates a new economic and political institutional framework. Cities attract. By 2025 about 75% of the world's population will live in urban areas and 95% of urban population growth will be the result of economically weak social groups. The city is not limited to being a mere territory. It is a political, social, economic and cultural entity that is constantly changing. It's a living body. It is a place of contrasts where tradition, modernity, wealth and poverty rub shoulders. As the Congolese Sony Labou Tansi writes: "Every city has its soul. Every city has its body, its skin, its intelligence, its stupidity, its monster side, its share of mystery..." and his genius. We must mobilize our energies and convictions to inspire new models of collective life and new ways of personal and individual development. This question, which seeks the harmonious balance between the inalienable right of the individual and his collective duty, is existential for humanity. It sets the definition of the relationship between the freedom of the individual and his duty to others.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which examines the challenges of the urban policy for EU policy makers and gives advice for a future sustainable EU urban development policy, which is essential to gear the EU Urban agenda towards the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy and in particular to the topics of social inclusion, demographic change and sustainability.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The rapporteur assumes that, as the population grows and new technologies are emerging, the number of people living in cities in Europe and around the world is gradually increasing.In 1950, 50.5% of the European population lived in urban areas. In 2014, this was 72% and could reach 78% by 2030. Globally, the proportion of urban populations is expected to double from 29% in the 1950s to 2030, and in 2050 80% of the world's population is expected to live in cities. The report aims to address the urban challenges of EU policy. According to the rapporteur, cities will only be able to fulfil their function in the future through an active and coordinated EU policy and to offer their residents living conditions that meet their needs, and urgent EU policy measures are therefore needed to effectively influence the consequences and speed of Urbanisation in Europe.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 For many years, the creation of an urban agenda of the European Union has been advocated with the purpose of ensuring better coordination of policies and the integration of urban development objectives into a wide range of policy areas. I would like to support the so-called "European Urban Agenda", in order to be efficient, should adopt a shared conceptual model, which is regularly updated and thematic centralisation in a limited number of challenges in the broader context of the Europe 2020 objectives of smart, inclusive and sustainable growth. I believe that Eu policies should support cities and their metropolitan areas, which are also known as functional urban areas, and allow them to demonstrate their key role as catalysts for economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report on the urban dimension of EU policies uses the fact that three out of four Europeans live in an urban area to propose new transfers of sovereignty. Indeed, it believes that the European institutions play a major role in the development of metropolises thanks in particular to existing funds such as the ERDF, which devotes 5% of its budget to it, carefully avoiding the fact that they come from contributions from Member States. The report naturally proposes to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities, to encourage Member States to speed up the decentralisation of their administrations in order to better integrate urban authorities in the development of these policies, to facilitate European funding of local projects, etc.  This Europeanist project would be contrary to EU law since urban policy is not within its competence. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it recognises that although there is no explicit EU competence on urban development, a broad range of EU initiatives impact directly/indirectly on towns, cities and functional urban areas; is therefore of the opinion that well-developed and established national and regional urban policies are a prerequisite for a European Urban Agenda.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted for this text which sets out guidelines for a future European urban policy. This report reminds us that many of the EU's policies have an impact on cities and that it is important to better involve them in the development of these policies. Among other measures, he proposes that a Commissioner be a reference on these issues. I am in favour of these proposals, which will improve the coherence of urban arrangements.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I supported the WESTPHAL report, which sets out the guidelines for a future European urban policy. Many EU policies have an impact on cities and it is important to improve their coherence and coordination, without unnecessarily legislating. We also demand greater involvement of cities throughout the policy-making process.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will examine the urban policy challenges for EU policy makers and to devise guidelines and boundaries for a future sustainable EU urban development policy.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that directing EU policies towards the urban dimension of EU policies is an option adapted to the reality of our day. Taking into account that in 2014 half of the world's population and 72% of Europe's population lived in urban areas, and since it is estimated that, before 2050, almost 80% of the world's population will live in urban areas, it is clear that we are considering a population deeply attached to participatory democracy, economic development and development, but which requires an adequate supply of jobs. In this respect, I believe that the inclusion of a common European urban agenda that promotes in particular the development of governance solutions capable of responding to the challenges and objectives of a sustainable and inclusive economic and social development of urban areas is beneficial to the EU, and I am thinking in particular of Romania, a country that is changing demographically and urbanly at a higher speed. I also welcome the report's proposal to take into account the local territorial specificities of each Member State with a view to urban dimension and economic growth, an approach that should be applied in as many European policies as possible.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Unfortunately, the rapporteur is unable to explain in the report what the content is. Furthermore, it is not possible to see from the report how the European Union should react in detail to the increasing urbanisation. That is because of this, I voted against this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Commission's launch of an urban programme for the European Union as part of the cohesion policy. This report calls for putting cities and the urban dimension at the heart of all relevant European policies. He points out that cities, which now host more than 70% of the population, face many challenges such as climate change and new demographic changes.  I spoke on this issue, recalling the need to act in the direction of reducing the gaps in wealth and development that continue to widen between regions, leaving aside rural areas and neighbourhoods in difficulty, even in the most developed regions.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. More and more people are concentrating on living in cities, which creates the need for a wider range of issues to be resolved. The own-initiative report aims to address the challenges of EU urban policy and to outline the limits of the EU's future sustainable urban development policy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU faces many challenges related to the rapid urbanisation processes under way. If we are to achieve the cities of the future in the best possible way, while developing multi-level governance and promoting a better quality of life for people, we urgently need to draw up an efficient European urban agenda. I therefore voted in favour in order to guarantee European citizens sustainable urban development.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I supported the report on the urban dimension of EU policies because I recognise the importance of the fact that 72% of Eu residents live in urban areas and the rate tends to increase in the future. This fact makes urban areas the main driver of our economy, so the European Union needs to create a sustainable policy adapted to the needs of these areas in order to stimulate and facilitate their progressive and positive development. I firmly stand by the view that the need for administrative relief is extremely important, and not only when we talk about urban areas, but when we talk about EU policy as a whole.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Many of the challenges facing Europe today relate to the economy, climate, environment and society and also manifest themselves around cities, e.g. poverty, social and spatial segregation, environmental degradation, or find their solutions in and through cities, e.g. resource efficiency and CO2 neutral economy, economic development and innovation, social innovation and integration.  This report proposes that cities should be more appropriately involved in the conception and implementation of European Union policies and that these policies should be better adapted to urban realities. The European Urban Agenda has hereby received support to create itself in the form of a thematic focus framework, to transform itself prospectively and in due course into a full member of the European Union's urban policy. That is why I support this report on the urban dimension of EU policies and voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report on the urban dimension of EU policies uses the fact that three out of four Europeans live in an urban area to propose new transfers of sovereignty. Indeed, it believes that the European institutions play a major role in the development of metropolises thanks in particular to existing funds such as the ERDF, which devotes 5% of its budget to it, carefully avoiding the fact that they come from contributions from Member States. The report naturally proposes to improve coordination between the EU and local authorities, to encourage Member States to speed up the decentralisation of their administrations in order to better integrate urban authorities in the development of these policies, to facilitate European funding of local projects, etc. This Europeanist project would be contrary to EU law since urban policy is not within its competence. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In 2014, half of the world's population and 72% of europe's population lived in urban areas, and by 2050 almost 80% of the Earth's population will live in urban areas. Functional urban areas in the EU form a single polyctric structure built around large, medium and small towns and surrounding areas, transcending traditional administrative boundaries to cover different areas linked by their economic, social, environmental and demographic challenges.  Therefore, I support the rapporteur's proposal, as large and small towns and functional urban areas, such as metropolitan areas, play an important role in participatory democracy, but also represent key economic pillars and drivers of employment in the EU, as innovation and new economic activities often originate in cities. EU policies should thus support small and large cities and functional urban areas and enable them to fully reach their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support Rapporteur Westphal's report on the Council's proposal for a decision on the urban dimension of EU policies, which aims to challenge urban challenges for EU policymakers and to develop guidelines and boundaries for future sustainable EU urban development policies. I support the view that cities play an important role in achieving the employment targets under the Europe 2020 strategy and must therefore be included in the overall EU policy-making process, which can be achieved by including city representatives in expert groups that should also consult civil society participants and social partners.  As large and small towns and functional urban areas, such as metropolitan areas, play an important role in participatory democracy, but also represent key economic pillars and drivers of employment in the EU, as innovation and new economic activities often originate in cities, I consider this report necessary.  For all this, I agree with the view that EU policy should support small and large cities and functional urban areas and enable them to fully reach their potential as drivers of economic growth, employment, social inclusion and sustainable development.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 During this millennium, for the first time in the history of mankind, the number of people living in urban centers exceeded the number of people living in agricultural or other territories. In order to be able to govern this constantly expanding phenomenon in the best possible way, the European Union must equip itself with appropriate analytical tools. This own-initiative report aims to examine the challenges facing EU policy with regard to urban areas and to define the guidelines and limits of a future sustainable UNION policy for urban development. The report also proposes the appointment of an EU Special Representative for Urban Issues in the Commission. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Better coordination of EU policies and instruments with the urban dimension, the introduction of territorial impact analyses for new legislation and the implementation of a multi-level governance model and partnership principles are elements that can facilitate the achievement of greater coherence of urban policies in the future. Raising awareness of policy decisions on urban issues and juxtamodting the problems and challenges faced by cities, as well as developing common solutions within the urban agenda, can contribute to improving the quality of life of residents not only of metropolises but also of small and medium-sized urban centres. Noting the reservations about the choice of objectives and priorities, as well as the ability of local authorities to finalize the agenda, I decided to support the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I realize, even as a citizen of the city of Pilsen – the fourth largest municipality in the Czech Republic – the importance of the urban dimension of EU policies. I support its further development. I'd just be careful about setting up new entities within it. Perhaps I do not have to add that support for the urban dimension cannot and does not yet conflict with rural development. As a regional councillor and long-standing MEMBER, I know how important it is today to contribute to maintaining quality of life in rural areas. The report on the urban dimension therefore has my support.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In 2014, 72% of the European population lived in urban areas and this figure is estimated to rise to 78% by 2030. Urban spaces are increasingly economically and socially strategic spaces. With this in mind, the European Parliament has adopted a report setting out the guidelines for a future European urban policy. I voted in favour of this text, which stresses the need for a coherent and coordinated urban policy within the Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report currently addresses the challenges that urban policy poses to Eu policy. While the EU competences defined by the Treaties limit, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the scope of action on regional and urban policy, the rapporteur stresses that a wide range of EU initiatives have a direct or indirect impact on urban development. In this context, an EU urban agenda should be drawn up to evaluate policy coordination and ensure the integration of urban development objectives horizontally into the legislator's broad framework of policy areas. The aim is to ensure the coherence of environmental, employment, transport and energy policies, the impact of which has repercussions on urban areas. In view of the pace of urbanization, which points to a forecast in 2050 of almost 80% of the world's population living in urban areas, and in view of the urgency of this coordinated action in order to provide the eu's inhabitants with progressively higher living conditions, I voted in favour of the own-initiative report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. I recognise the importance of a European Urban Agenda for sustainable, integrated and socially inclusive development. In 2014, the share of the population living in urban areas of the EU was 72 %, reaching 78 % by 2030, generating two thirds of GDP. It is therefore necessary to take into mind the involvement of urban areas in meeting the EU's employment targets and in meeting the cohesion policy objectives for 2020. I reinforce the rapporteur's idea when he says that the European Urban Agenda should be compatible with the Global Urban Agenda.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. More than 72% of the EU's population lives in urban areas where 2/3 of GDP is produced. Moreover, the impact of European policies themselves is enormous at the local level. In view of the importance of urban areas in Europe, the EU began to get involved in local affairs, mainly through regional and urban development policies.  This report, which I have supported, by the German socialist Westphal KERSTIN, examines the challenges of EU urban policy and gives recommendations for a future common sustainable urban development policy.  The lack of coherence and coordination between the various EU rules and programmes and between the local level and the other levels of government seems obvious. Improving this interaction suggests, among other measures, the figure of the EU's special urban representative to coordinate EU policy and initiatives and optimise decision-making work between different levels of administration, while adapting the URBAN programme to the objectives of the 2020 Strategy and the challenges of social inclusion, demographic change and sustainability

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. 2012 359 million people (72% of the total EU population) live in cities and their peripheries. Although the pace of urbanization has slowed in recent years, an estimated 80% of the EU's urban population by 2050. In view of these figures but also of the importance that cities play in economic, social, cultural and environmental development, the European Commission wanted to launch a debate on the urban dimension of European policies and on the main features of a possible future urban programme of the European Union. This debate focuses on the usefulness of setting up an urban programme for the EU. In response to this request, I voted today in favour of a report which calls on the Commission to present a communication outs setting out the characteristics of the future European urban programme. This communication must be carried out in close collaboration with various stakeholders, including social partners. Like Parliament, I call on the Commission to identify major urban challenges in collaboration with stakeholders, appoint a policy officer to define the strategic direction and appoint an EU special coordinator for urban policy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 72% of the European population lives in urban areas and this report warns of the urban dimension of European policies and the main features of a future EU urban agenda. It is proposed that cities be more involved in the design and implementation of European policies, and they should be adapted to urban realities, observing the principle of subsidiarity and the limits of the European regulatory framework. The creation of an urban agenda at EU level should contribute to improving the quality, efficiency and effectiveness of development policies in the cities and regions where they are included - sometimes rural areas with desertification and depopulation problems, and is also a vehicle for promoting global sustainability and development aid policies.  Taking on an ambitious nature, it should also integrate European societal challenges of CO2 reduction, adaptation to climate change and inclusion or demographic change.  The role of local, regional, national and European entities in the definition, development and implementation of the agenda is of paramount importance, focusing on strengthening coordination between the various sectoral policies. Only through active participation and coordinated political actions can cities provide their inhabitants with solid living conditions.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with my group, I voted in favour of appointing an EU Special Representative for Urban Affairs. He will have to coordinate the policies and proposals put forward horizontally, while, vertically, he will have to follow and optimise the work chosen and undertaken. Urban development is an issue of fundamental importance for Europe and for the well-being of its citizens. Urban areas are centres of economic activity, innovation and employment, so they must be carefully managed through targeted policies and well-defined infrastructure plans.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the report aims at acceptable objectives, namely to improve the coordination of different policies and better integrate the objectives of urban development, but to this end it suggests extending the Commission's competences in an area where, on the contrary, I believe that the principle of subsidiarity must continue to prevail.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the Development Committee of the Regions, dedicated to analysing and proposing ideas for EU urban policies. Since 78% of the Union's population lives in urban areas, a coordinated approach is considered necessary for the policies that concern them directly. While we believe that we need to be careful with certain formulations on "multi-level governance" that could open the door to privatization of essential aspects of urban management, we believe that as a whole the text is a positive step.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, which addresses the current and future challenges of urban policy that will have to be addressed. According to the current trend, the population living in cities will increase, so it is necessary to deal with the questions of what the cities in which people want to live should look in the future. Sustainable transport, housing policy and energy networks are important issues. I agree with the statement that the EU Urban Agenda should focus on the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and in particular on the themes of 'social inclusion, demographic change and sustainability'.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which aims, within the margins offered by treaties (such as through the principle of subsidiarity) to deepen the participation of sub-state entities in the decision-making of European policies; Therefore, the adopted text supports, inter alia, the creation of the European urban agenda, which examines the objectives of territorial cohesion taking into account the potential and threats of densely populated areas. At this point, however, I must remind you that it is essential to take priority to rural areas, where they are generally at high levels of unemployment, greater difficulties in accessing public services and progressive depopulation. However, I voted in favour of promoting through the many financial instruments (such as Integrated Territorial Investments, Community-Led Local Development, etc.) and necessary participatory investments, to promote a more rational model of sustainable development in the urban areas of the European Union that create synergies not only with each other but also with their rural environments.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not agree with giving more power to the EU Commission, which I believe this report calls for.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it acknowledges that although there is no explicit EU competence on urban development, there is a broad range of EU initiatives which impact towns and cities directly.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted against the resolution in line with the group's position. Although the resolution contains beneficial proposals, I am concerned about the overall future scope of EU urban policy, which could threaten the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. In 1950 only 50.5% of the population of Europe lived in urban areas. By 2014, this figure was 72%, and by 2030 it could reach 78% at European Union level. The global population is living in cities in an increasing percentage and there is a great need to develop substanite urban policies. I want to focus on the following issues: What space does the EU have to act in urban policy? How does EU policy currently affect cities that should have an impact in the future?  How can EU urban policy coordination and coherence be improved? It is important to point out that in the European Union almost half of Europeans live in cities under 100 000 inhabitants, and the Commission's predictions show that today's cities will grow into "megacations" by 2050. The expected increase in the population in cities poses challenges for the direction of economic development, administrative structure and decision-making in growing cities. I believe that the development of future major cities will depend on city partnerships, structural funds, smarter regulation and the development of new multi-level managed governance models. It is important to establish a multilevel model of providing vertical and horizontal information, which with the idea of "Smart City" (Smart Cities) will realize its full potential.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 European cities are centres of economic activity, innovation and employment. This is evidenced by statistics which clearly show that in 2014 half of the world's population and 72% of the European population lived in urban areas, and by 2050 this trend will continue to increase. Although the EU does not have explicit competence in the area of urban development, I believe that there is a sufficiently wide scope not only for the EU, which has a direct or indirect impact on cities and functional areas, but also for us MEPs. Since I come from košice in the east of Slovakia and I know the surrounding towns very well, I can declare very responsibly that these towns are also experiencing problems that are associated with relatively high unemployment, serious problems in transport, their growth, lack of amenities and public services, and the reduction of citizens' quality of life. I supported the report because I believe that this report is the right step, which brings new challenges and objectives not only for local and regional, but also for national and European policy. I expect the Commission and the Member States to better coordinate a number of eu rules, programmes and initiatives that are relevant to cities in order to address urban problems.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. More and more people in Europe and around the world are living in cities. In 1950, only half of Europeans lived in urban areas, and in 2014 this proportion was already 72%. This is why policy at local, regional, national and European level faces new challenges in order to meet the economic, social and cultural needs of an increasing number of people in cities. In European urban centres, which are the driving force behind the exchange of information, as they contribute as much as two thirds of GDP, barriers to growth and employment must be removed and linked more closely to the formulation of European policy.
