Cities only participate in policy-making to a small extent, but this can be improved by their early involvement in political processes, for example through consultations and exchanges of best practice and experience, and the introduction of a assessment of the territorial impact of policies on cities, which will improve the practical feasibility of the measures. A coordinated and integrated approach is needed, which also takes into account the creation of synergies between EFSI, EU programmes, public investment and private capital in order to achieve maximum leverage for the funds invested. This report draws up guidelines for a future sustainable urban development policy at European level, which is why I voted to support it.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, as most of the ongoing challenges facing Europe, in particular those related to the economy, climate, society and environment, poverty, social and spatial segregation, etc., manifest themselves in or around cities. That is, solutions to the same problems are most often found in cities or through them. Therefore, cities should be more adequately innovative in the concepts and implementation of European Union policies, just as European policies need to be better adapted to urban environments and their reality.  It is therefore important that there is a certain uniform and integrated policy of the European Union towards cities and urban environments, and it is also very important that cities and urban environments have better coordination of policies and instruments at the level of the European Union, which is justified by the possibility of setting up representatives to take care of urban affairs and issues.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it recognises that although there is no explicit EU competence on urban development, a broad range of EU initiatives impact directly/indirectly on towns, cities and functional urban areas. I believe that well-developed and established national and regional urban policies are a prerequisite for a European Urban Agenda.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The fact is that most jobs and activities take place in cities. Accordingly, more modern European Union policy is also needed to address any problems facing cities. I support the initiative concerning the urban dimension of European cities.  Such an agenda enables better coordination of elements relevant to the effective functioning of European and national centres. Taught by the experience of the Leipzig Charter and the Toledo Declaration, the initiative would accelerate political and international co-operation related to urban centre infrastructure. Cities are the centres, and by this fact they profile and attract a large number of individuals, thus being the main carriers of development and progress.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the report in writing ‒ as I agree that the Commission should also take into account the impact on cities when developing its policies, and I also agree with many other proposals to streamline existing as well as future EU legislation.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the urban dimension of EU policies. The Urban Agenda is the responsibility of the European Union and it is right that this should be discussed both in the European Commission and in the European Parliament. We must encourage debates on urban mobility, as in 2014 as many as half of the world's population and 72% of the European population lived in urban areas, and the number continues to increase year after year. In addition to economic development, cities also bring problems, and we need to find an answer to these problems: education, sport, a decent life for everyone, clean air, transport, emissions, etc.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I can support aspects of this report relating to more coherent policymaking, increased knowledge sharing and a stronger voice for local and regional authority actors.  However, I maintain concerns about key sections referring to the eventual scope and external dimension of any future EU Urban Agenda, and for this reason I was unable to support this report at the vote today.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns EU city policy. While it has various concerns about the problems of urbanisation, the whole philosophy of the policies it promotes is based on the neoliberal policies of the Europe 2020 strategy. Also, although the environmental and demographic challenges and problems that exist today are recorded, there is no mention of the need to promote a human-centred development social policy, to contribute to the creation of new quality jobs and to provide solutions to the major problems facing cities today, particularly due to the economic crisis and tough neoliberal memorial policies.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The urban dimension of EU policies is nothing more than a crescendo of exasthism and the development of citizens' dependence on the state. The EU should support agrophilia and consider ways and methods that, combined with the development of local agricultural production and entrepreneurship, would finally bring growth to the abandoned European region.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The document adopted by the European Parliament not only supports the Urban Agenda proposed by the Commission, but also goes a step further by proposing that it should evolve over time into the Union's urban policy. The document also calls on the European Commission to better coordinate EU policies and instruments with the urban dimension and to introduce territorial impact analyses for new legislation and to implement a multi-level governance model and partnership principle. If the European Commission takes into account the proposals made by the European Parliament, our cities can gain a completely different quality and additional support, which is why I decided to vote in favour of the document on the urban dimension of Union policy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Urban areas are the places where the majority of the population of the European Union lives and the main engines of the economies of the Member States. Their development has been based almost exclusively, until now, on the interest of local and national authorities, according to a limited interpretation of the principle of subsidiarity. The implementation of European policies, however, has a direct effect on cities, especially in the area of regional development.  In this context, the need for a European policy for urban centres has become apparent, so that cities are able to face the challenges of globalisation, technological progress and urban development. This can be the result of better coordination, both horizontally, between the various sectors and European initiatives, and vertically, with a view to optimising the various administrative levels.  In this respect, the proposal to appoint an EU special representative for urban areas is a commendable initiative, which can give the necessary impetus to the process of deepening collaboration. The development of this European policy can contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, in particular with regard to social inclusion, demographic change and sustainable development.  For these reasons, I believe that the adoption of this report is appropriate for the development of our cities.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the urban dimension of EU policies. It calls for the urban specificity to be taken into better account in all European policies. It advocates the inclusion of the urban dimension in all European policies by taking into account ‘the urban acquis’ and in each case carrying out impact studies on small, medium and large-sized cities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This report is in response to the Commission's launch of a public debate and to the adoption of a formal communication "Urban dimension of EU policies - a key feature of the Union urban agenda", which highlighted the challenges of this urban Europe potential and proposed a set of consultation questions, aimed at clarifying the need for an urban dimension of European Union policy, i.e. what its objectives should be and what is the most appropriate way of future functioning.  I fully support the parts of the report that call for more uniform and coordinated urban policy-making, increased exchange of knowledge and good practices, and strengthening the influence of regional and local authorities in this segment. So I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the urban dimension of EU policies states that many of the challenges that Europe still faces are related to the economy, the environment, the climate. However, they are mainly in the vicinity of cities. It's like poverty, social and spatial hardship. Solutions to this problem, such as resource efficiency and a CO2-neutral economy, need to be found; economic development and innovation; social innovation and integration. I supported the report because it suggests that cities should participate more appropriately in the design and implementation of EU policies, while at the same time adapting these policies better to urban realities.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the Development Committee of the Regions, dedicated to analysing and proposing ideas for EU urban policies. Since 78% of the Union's population lives in urban areas, a coordinated approach is considered necessary for the policies that concern them directly. While we believe that we need to be careful with certain formulations on "multi-level governance" that could open the door to privatization of essential aspects of urban management, we believe that as a whole the text is a positive step.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The figure is shocking that, in 2014, half of the world’s population and 72% of Europe were living in urban areas, and that in 2050 almost 80% of the world’s population will reside in urban areas. I support the initiative of the Commission to work on developing a European urban agenda, as cities are facing major challenges in economic and social development, climate change and the transport and demographic changes taking place. It is positive to be advanced on the facts and seek solutions containing dialogue between all parties concerned.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. As the rapporteur points out, urban policy is not within the EU's competence. However, this project lays the foundations for a European urban policy, including the implementation of a timetable. The European authorities therefore want to grant themselves new powers as usual, which would further limit the scope of action of the States. If this competence goes under the European flag, the European budget will have to be increased by increasing the already high contribution of the Member States. Contrary to what they claim in this text, there will be no synergy with existing programmes. This will only add to the current Brussels bureaucracy. I therefore vote against the adoption of this text.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Functional cities and urban areas are the essential economic pillars and job-creating engines of the European Union. Although the European Commission published a Communication on the Union's urban agenda in 1997, the role of European cities in EU policy-making is still under discussion. The EU does not have explicit powers in the area of urban development, but a wide range of legislative initiatives have a direct or indirect impact on cities and functional urban areas. With its resolution, the European Parliament calls for the swift adoption of an EU urban agenda that is in line with the EU's objectives and strategies, in particular the Europe 2020 strategy. This will certainly lead to better policy coordination and better integration of urban development objectives into as many policy areas as possible.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this own-initiative report by the Development Committee of the Regions, dedicated to analysing and proposing ideas for EU urban policies. Since 78% of the Union's population lives in urban areas, a coordinated approach is considered necessary for the policies that concern them directly. While we believe that we need to be careful with certain formulations on "multi-level governance" that could open the door to privatization of essential aspects of urban management, we believe that as a whole the text is a positive step.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was in favour of the report, which is the EP response to the EU urban agenda from July 2014 and focuses on an urban dimension of policies and possible EU instruments to strengthen this approach. It supports the development of an EU urban agenda and further action to be taken to link urban areas closer to European policy making and requests the Commission to propose appropriate institutional and procedural tools or to reinforce their application.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I support kerstin Westphal's report. The main economic, social and environmental challenges go beyond traditional administrative borders and, in view of the increasing imbalance between administrative and territorial structures (cooperation between cities and suburbs, cooperation between cities and villages, etc.), new forms of flexible governance are needed in order to further implement integrated territorial development of functional areas.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. It's important that cities are getting smarter, more connected, and more open. Europe needs cities that promote the use of information and communication technologies, drive action to reduce energy dependence and achieve more efficient energy consumption, as well as transport infrastructures that reduce traffic, improve air quality and make cities cleaner and safer. This report is trying to move forward in this regard, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 It is well known that the vast majority of the European population lives in cities and that this is a trend that will deepen in the medium/long term (80% of the population in 2050). The report has a positive approach to the "urban issue" as a driver of economic development and an area of socio-economic inclusion. It thus advocates the application of the principles of subsidiarity, better articulation between cities and urban management as a factor of participation and citizenship. We share the importance of the urban dimension of policies and follow the idea that many of the current social and political challenges can only be solved at the level of territories with policies directed at the city where the population is concentrated and an increasing part of economic activity. What we do not agree with is the attempt to tie the urban agenda to the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, with which we do not agree and which is in confrontation with the need to give social responses of proximity to the populations.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In her rather low-content report, the rapporteur fails to explain why the EU should react to increasing urbanisation in the first place and in detail. This report must therefore be rejected.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 More and more European citizens are living in cities and the strong development of urban centres has posed a number of challenges to which Europe must be able to respond. In order to create the European city of tomorrow, it is first and foremost necessary to ensure smart growth, to create favourable conditions for innovation and research, to develop an environment favourable to business and young people through state-of-the-art and efficient education. A central point is that of mobility: it is essential that the use of green and sustainable means of transport is increased and that cities reach and maintain high energy efficiency standards. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Urban management requires the coordination of many activities and the taking into account of many different infrastructure and social needs. It is therefore impossible to spend structural funds efficiently and implement cohesion policy in urban areas without creating an action programme that comprehensively identifies the needs of small and large agglomerations. It therefore seems obvious to support the idea of creating an 'urban agenda', which will be the backbone of the EU's urban policy. Cities are the flywheel of the economy, they make up the majority of European GDP, they are educational and scientific centres. This leading role of cities is also associated with many problems, such as high population density, communication difficulties, the large number of pollutants emitted into the atmosphere and large disparities in the living standards of the population. The urban dimension of EU policy should take these aspects into account and take into account local and regional specificities, which can best be understood by casting a decisive vote in formulating the objectives of local authorities. We should use all available financial tools, both existing ones such as Horizon 2020 and those that are just emerging, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, to make cities as friendly as possible, including for people with special needs – the elderly or people with disabilities. I support the idea of creating such a comprehensive plan, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report focuses on the development of the European urban context, emphasizing that the vast majority of the European population lives in cities and that this is a trend that will deepen in the medium/long term (80% of the population by 2050). The report takes a positive approach to the "urban issue", classifying cities as engines of economic development and an area of socio-economic inclusion. It thus advocates the application of the principles of subsidiarity, better articulation between cities and urban management as a factor of participation and citizenship. It establishes, however, the implementation of the European Urban Agenda which "must take the form of a shared and regularly updated conceptual framework, with a thematic focus on a limited number of challenges in the broader context of the Europe 2020 objectives", challenges that must meet certain criteria such as: being in line with the shared conceptual framework and not being able to be solved unilaterally by Member States. Because we are not in line with this strategy in which market values and liberalisation swell, we abstain.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. This report had the ambition to define the guidelines for a future sustainable EU policy for urban development by promoting an integrated approach to territorial development, in order to achieve a Functional European Urban Agenda to give functional cities and urban areas the tools they need to achieve the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth under the Europe 2020 strategy. The final report, however, while dealing in fact with the four main challenges of the urban dimension-management and governance, intelligent growth, inclusive growth, green growth- appears vague in two fundamental aspects: the regeneration and enhancement of urban historic centers (just think – for example – of the rejection of Town Center Management that would have made it possible to counterbalance the attractiveness of large suburban shopping centers) and the environmental impact of further urbanization. Furthermore, in the part relating to the coordination of European urban policy, the rapporteur refers to a kind of EU special coordinator for urban issues who should set up a one-stop shop on urban policies within the Commission, without, however, actually clarifying either how this figure is to be appointed or the concrete practical benefits it would bring. It is for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the explanations of vote. I would particularly like to thank the interpreters and the other services and I hope that everyone will get something to eat.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU's role in the Middle East peace process.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying that the Middle East faces multiple challenges today, and we have discussed some of them this morning. Syria, Yemen, Libya: the list is long. Still, whatever the competing pressures might be, I strongly believe that we cannot put aside the Middle East peace process. It is crucial for the Israelis and for the Palestinians, and it is also crucial for regional peace and security. It is crucial for the international community. Further deterioration on the ground is happening at the moment, whether in Gaza, Jerusalem or the West Bank, and this has a deeply negative impact on an already-troubled region. The fact that this is the oldest conflict does not make it any less relevant. On the contrary, in a regional situation which is becoming increasingly worrying, this is the piece of the puzzle that we have to look at if we want to start somewhere. We all know that the conditions for relaunching final-status negotiations are not in place at this moment. There is a deep lack of trust on both sides and wide gaps on what a final deal should look like. But, as we have seen on Iran, with bold thinking, with a creative approach, patient diplomacy and an openness to compromise, and with a lot of teamwork from the international community, even the most difficult issues can be settled. Putting in place the conditions for a resumption of serious talks based on mutual steps is our first priority. Negative developments on the ground in this very same month only underline the importance of this work. We must not, and we cannot, lose what we have all worked so hard to build since Oslo: the development of institutions of a future Palestinian State through the Palestinian Authority. This includes essential services for ordinary Palestinians and vital cooperation, first of all in the security sector, between Israel and Palestine. But today we have a complete lack of process and prospects and, I would say not least, the presence of Daesh in the region. We will not live forever in the post-Oslo mode: we cannot take that for granted. If Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas fail to work together now, the future will be dangerous for both Israel and the Palestinians. And for the region it will be even more dangerous than it is now. A fundamental change in the political, security and economic situation in Gaza, including the end of the closure, is an essential starting point. The parties must urgently make progress towards a lasting ceasefire, based on their agreements in Cairo last year, and reach an agreement which both ends the Gaza closure and addresses Israel’s legitimate security concerns. Moving towards real reconciliation – national reconciliation – was on the agenda one year ago. It seems not to be on the agenda anymore. I believe, however, that we cannot afford to put aside a national reconciliation process in the Palestinian camp, including Palestinian Authority control in Gaza, starting with the control of border crossings. What we are doing is pushing both the Israelis and the Palestinians to show leadership and to refrain from any action which would lead further away from the two-state solution. We have revitalised the Quartet in recent months, in line with our commitment to building a new regional and international framework for peace. We have appointed an EU Special Representative to work full-time again on EU efforts to re-open a political perspective for Israel and Palestine. You know him, you have met him, and he is constantly working on this in Jerusalem with all our international partners and with the parties. We work closely, and he personally works closely, with the Quartet colleagues to press both sides, on the one hand, to take courage in setting out improvements on the ground – concrete legal steps that can change people’s lives – and, on the other hand, to try to rebuild trust, of which there may be less today than at any time in the past. We can aim for measures which empower the Palestinians, strengthen security cooperation and address Israel’s concerns. These are practical, concrete steps which, if implemented on the ground, would move the situation towards, instead of away from, the two-state solution. Of course, such steps cannot be a substitute for resolving the final-status issues. We know that very well, but I believe this is the best way to get there in what is a very tough political climate both on the Israeli side and on the Palestinian side. It can be a way forward and a way out of the stalemate. However, we are also rethinking the way in which the Quartet has been working, or not working, so far. You know that two out of four of the Quartet envoys – the EU and the UN envoys – are new ones. We have started to work very well together, and also with the other two colleagues. The Arab countries can play a leading role in strengthening and giving incentives to the process. The Arab peace initiative demonstrates the potential, which is even stronger now than when it was launched, for a wider regional settlement to end the conflicts: the Israeli-Palestinian one and the Arab-Israeli one. This is why the Quartet envoys went together to Cairo and Oman and will visit Riyadh in the coming days. The key Arab countries, and the Foreign Ministers that I met just yesterday, have made very clear to me that they are ready to play their role in this regional and international framework to try to restart the engine of the process. That is why UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has already sent invitations to the Foreign Ministers of the Quartet to meet on the fringe of the General Assembly in New York at the end of the month, and, in the context of the initiative that we have taken as the European Union, has also extended an invitation to the Foreign Ministers of Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia, and to the Secretary-General of the Arab League. We are working to prepare the ground for a genuine regional framework that can help the parties to take some steps. Again, I know I am not defining the final-status solution, but I believe that, from the situation we face today of complete despair to the dream of hope and a final solution to the conflict, we have to build the bridges that will enable us to get there. We have to create the conditions on the ground, and the political conditions. We are moving forward to build this credible international and regional framework to support the parties and to regain and rebuild confidence between themselves and in the international community, for we know that this is needed as well. The two parties need to find the courage and the space to start trusting one another but, most of all, they need a regional and international framework in which they can find trust. This too has to be rebuilt. But ultimately it is not going to be the regional or the international framework that resolves the crisis. Only the parties themselves can take the fundamental decisions. They can either advance together in the future, or they can allow the two-state solution to move beyond reach, with all the negative consequences that would bring for both sides and for all of us, including us Europeans. Leadership is needed, and the European Union is ready. All the major stakeholders agree that we face the same challenges in the region. We face regional threats, including the rise of extremism, terrorism and the failing states. Peace in the holy places would send such a powerful message to the world; you would really have to be blind not to see it. In the current regional environment we cannot afford to stand still. If we do not move forward, we will see violence coming back again – we are already seeing it from time to time – and we will see the two-state solution become less and less viable, if not impossible. I believe the international community, the Palestinians and the Israelis cannot afford that, because we do not know what is going to come next if we close the window for peace that Oslo opened. The time has come to provide real long-term security and hope for the Israelis and the Palestinians – knowing full well that these words sound empty to both at this moment. The time has come for both sides to make the necessary compromises and, most of all, to show leadership. This is what is needed. The time has come for us to put all our efforts into supporting this process and helping it to start again. These days call for the whole European Union to play its part, and I am glad that, as I understand it, I will be able to count on the full and united backing of this Parliament for the European Union effort to ensure that this conflict –the oldest one in the region – does not become a forgotten one at a time when we all need, more than ever in the decades ahead, to solve it strategically.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Madam Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her Colleagues! Since Mrs Mogherini and the European Union have gained new authority through the successful negotiations on Iran, this can also be a formidable foundation for the other two crises in the region, the war in Iraq and Syria and the Middle East conflict. And that is interwoven! I believe that the settlement of the conflicts in Syria, in Iraq, can only be achieved if we now get together with the Russians, the Americans, the United Nations, partly also under the leadership of the European Union, the Saudis and the Turks and the Iranians, in order to put an end to this proxy war. This, too, has to do with the fact that this will only succeed if the Quartet – with a strong role for the European Union in it – goes ahead with the Arab League or the Member States of the Arab Peace Initiative and makes another attempt to achieve the two-state solution. The goal must be: a viable state of Palestine and a secure Jewish state of Israel. And I believe that it is part of the fact that both sides have something to achieve bilaterally here. This includes an end to the settlement policy and an end to Hamas' violence.  Violence and settlement and all this do not fit in, and certain things must be developed on both sides in order to build trust, but at the same time the Arab states, like the members of the Quartet, must also ensure the necessary level of mediation and subsequent security for the country to move forward. We also need the appropriate support that we must provide to a viable state of Israel, for a functioning administration, for the fight against corruption, in order to have an economically viable state that can play its role. I therefore believe, Mrs Mogherini, that we should give you good wishes for your trip to New York to launch this initiative there. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Brok, there are two blue cards for you. I would like to ask you whether you would like to reply, but I would like to inform my fellow Members that after this request I will not be able to accept more than one blue card per speaker, because this will also be to the detriment of the speeches on request.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – The joint resolution mentions the large amounts of investment by the EU in Gaza, but the infrastructure this paid for was severely damaged during the 2014 conflict. For example, the north Gaza waste water treatment plant was damaged, meaning that 95% of water in Gaza is now unsafe to drink. I would like to ask Mr Brok whether he agrees, as suggested by the joint resolution, that we urgently need a list of EU-funded projects that were destroyed, with an indication of the cost of that destruction?

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Brok, I can only agree with what you have said. My question is this: what is your opinion on the fact that France and The United Kingdom have decided to bomb Islamic State positions at the moment, while Germany is trying a different line, including negotiating with Mr Assad. In your opinion, would it not be better if at least these three large countries in the European Union were to join forces and act together?

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to two questions about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank the If I may answer the last question. If I have understood the French and the British correctly, they want to bomb ISIS, not Assad. There is, I believe, a slight difference in assessment. There is a division of labour here. Germany has supplied weapons to the Peshmerga to fight ISIS – effective weapons – and is also training the Peshmerga to fight ISIS, for example. I believe that we need to have a common approach to fight ISIS. As I said in my speech, the most important thing will be that we win over the Turks, the Saudis and the Iranians to end the proxy war there and involve them in a common strategy here, because ISIS has now become a threat to everyone. This is perhaps a good task for the European Union to bring about. This will not succeed without getting those involved in the proxy war away from it. And we will have a struggle for influence under the alibi of a religious dispute. We must also deal with this together with these countries. When it is clear that a Gaza solution was to be resolved, we need to talk about whether what Israel has done was proportionate. But Israel has been shelled from Gaza. That has been noted, and we must also see that. We have to see that some of the building objects – cement – in Gaza have not been used for the construction of houses, but for the construction of tunnels. This, too, must be included in a balanced assessment. To draw up a list now that Israel should then pay compensation to the European Union in order to rebuild it does not seem to me to be a solution with which we can make progress here, but would only be a revival of Hamas, which has so far also prevented its political authority from Ramallah from having the regime there and being able to control the country. The Palestinian Authority must be responsible for all of Palestine, including Gaza. That seems to me to be the sensible starting point for getting to the table.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group, Mr President, this debate comes at the right time so that the European Parliament can support the European Union in playing as active and effective a role as possible in the Middle East peace process. It is today at a more serious impasse than ever before and poses a direct threat to the security of our European Union. Hence the need to reaffirm our commitment to a peace process in the area and, in particular, to the peace process between Israel and Palestine, based on the recognised border principles of 1967 and the fact that the two states, Israel and Palestine, must coexist in security and peace.  Madam High Representative, you have demonstrated, in the past year, your entire commitment, I would even say the enthusiasm, to help relaunch the peace process and to enhance the role of our Union in this direction. We support you, and the resolution we are adopting tomorrow comes to confirm, once more, if necessary, this. Any lasting solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can only be achieved in a regional context, with the involvement of important regional actors that you mentioned - Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia - and through close cooperation between us and the United States of America and also institutionally, through cooperation with the Arab League and relaunching its project, the Arab League Peanut Plan. In this context, my group and I are giving you our full support and I would like to remind you in this Chamber that we Europeans have recently received an extremely positive message from Israel. The Vice-President of the Knesset, opposition MP Hilik Bar, presented his document on a peace project, which is impressive in its courage, vision and strength to tell even truths that are inconvenient to the Israeli audience. He reminds us all of the words of the peace hero, Yitzhak Rabin, "You can only make peace with your enemy". This fundamental truth is still true today, including for Prime Minister Netanyahu.  Because the European Parliament has managed this year to help support the Commission's efforts, tomorrow we will adopt a resolution which, which, which will be recorded by all the groups in this Chamber. It is impressive, but it is also the strongest mandate we can give you, Madam President, to help bring our Union peace to the Near East. Thank you and wish you success. (The speaker has agreed to answer a question put in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Regulation).

name: Bas BELDER
text: "Blue card" question – Mr Boştinaru, you are giving up high on the peace plan of the Knesset member Hilik Bar. I share your esteem for Hilik Bar, because I know him personally. My question is: have you also put to him the present joint resolution on the Middle East peace process? After all, his name is mentioned. I strongly doubt that Mr Hilik Bar can agree with this resolution!

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Belder, I had the privilege to negotiate yesterday, in four long hours of tense but incredibly fruitful discussions and negotiations, with all the representatives of the groups in this House, and I can only confirm that by the end of that unprecedented negotiation session, all the political groups had agreed to co-sign this resolution. That being so, it is useless to challenge the support which was expressed by the political groups because they were the ones to decide, through their own political decision-making systems, to co-sign the resolution and to adopt it tomorrow. This will be an amazing demonstration of support for the work of the European Union. Parliament itself can never negotiate, but it can help to provide a strong mandate for the real negotiators, and the brokers of the negotiations, and such a strong message will – I am convinced – be properly heard too by Jerusalem and by Ramallah.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the prospects for the MENA region look grim if one were to think of Libya, Syria and Iraq. There is, though, a growing will from regional players to renew the efforts for the Middle East peace process between Israel and Palestine. As Egypt battles terrorist attacks in the Sinai, Saudi Arabia worries about growing Iranian influence after the nuclear deal and Jordan faces every day increasing pressure from the scale of its refugee crisis, as well as those from Palestine – also now from Syria – we can be more optimistic that there is a real common interest now to pursue a deal.  Therefore I welcome the High Representative’s call to the UN Quartet to relaunch the peace process and I do believe that the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative should be used as a blueprint to start from, with the commitment to the two-peoples two-nations approach.  With power shifting in the Palestinian Authority and Hamas reportedly facing pressure now in Gaza from ISIS, there is also reason to believe that those players at the centre of the debate are keen to see progress, for various different reasons as I have outlined. All too often the negotiations are undermined by focusing on the details too early, which is why contentious topics such as the status of Jerusalem, East Jerusalem, which settlements can stay or go, and the right of return for the Palestinians must now be left to the end, following simpler confidence-building initiatives now at the beginning. For instance, in my view, cooperation on the eradication of the ISIS menace, which is a common enemy to all the parties, must be the number one priority.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – The conflict between Israel and Palestine, the oldest in the region, as you yourself said Mrs Mogherini, often gives me the feeling of an eye for an eye and i would actually like to go back to Gandhi, who long ago said: 'an eye for an eye makes the world go blind'. However, we cannot be here in this hemisphere. We must not be blind to what has happened there and what is still happening there every day: settlements of high walls and barbed wires, children who cannot go to school, rockets from Gaza and bombs from Israel. I've been there and I've seen it. And actually I have to tell you: it is a scandal that this is still going on in 2015. I have rarely seen a conflict that stirs so many people, that makes so many people choose in a camp. Here in our groups too. That is why I would like to congratulate and thank the coordinator. We negotiated for four hours yesterday and I am very pleased that we have reached an agreement today. Mrs Mogherini, we spoke in Luxembourg this weekend and debated for a very long time. You have been working for about a year today or yesterday and I think you have done an excellent job. It is, as Mr Brok said, that you have actually shown, with your agreement with Iran, that you are a lady with courage, with strength. You've gained a lot of trust. But of course we are now placing a heavy burden on your shoulders and we hope that you will do everything possible to resolve this conflict. I would like to refer to this morning's debate, where President Juncker has put a very strong emphasis on tackling the asylum and migration crisis. I can't help but hear it here many times: Aylan, the little boy who died. I would like to say: Aylan has a lot of boyfriends and lots of parents who also want to live in peace. Let us now do everything we can here, use common sense, get everyone behind it. Mrs Mogherini, you already have our support to go to New York and ensure that these two parties come to a solution. A lot of good luck.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, yesterday we had a four-hour negotiation meeting to hopefully secure a joint resolution on the Middle East peace process. The GUE/NGL Group and my party, Sinn Fein, would prefer a stronger worded motion demanding the end of the occupation of Palestine and the release of political prisoners, particularly the PLC members who have been detained. I think, however, we all agree that the EU should be a dominant political player in the Middle East peace process by advancing meaningful initiatives for a comprehensive solution. High Representative, we believe that Palestine should be placed under international protection and the EU should ensure the full implementation of the recommendations contained in the UN Independent Commission of Inquiry report into last year’s assault on Gaza, including its recommendation to support actively the work of the ICC. The EU should also ensure that no EU funds are allocated to Israeli organisations involved in occupation activities, as a lever to apply pressure on the Israeli Government to re-engage in a meaningful peace process and to work for a two-state solution.  Of concern last week was the information imparted to a joint Palestine and Israel delegation meeting that Israel is not prioritising a peace process. We were informed that it is virtually off Israel’s foreign policy agenda. This is not acceptable, High Representative, and I believe it must be challenged. We wish you all the best.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, Mr Vice-President, colleagues, we are here again to talk about the Israel-Palestine conflict, and I am willing to bet a substantial part of my income from this House that it is not going to be the last time we discuss the issue. I will try to refrain from grandstanding and pretending that we, or anyone in this House, could know the exact solution to the conflict. What we know, however, is that the conflict needs to be resolved because a one-state solution – towards which there are some indications that Israel is moving – is a non-solution. My Israeli friends also know that. The reason why we base our position on the two-state solution is not ideological: it is a practical response to thinking about how the alternative would look. I would like to remind everybody of a brilliant piece by none other than Tony Judd, way back in 2003 in the New York Review of Books, which made waves in Israel as well. Back then he argued that, if the two-state solution was dead, the one-state solution might be coming and the bad news was that it was going to be much more costly for both the Palestinians and the Israelis. It is not a solution that anyone should aspire to, and we are not supporting anything which allows the last hope for a two-state solution simply to evaporate because of inaction. That is why we have been working very closely with the S&D Group and the rapporteur, and, luckily, after four hours of negotiations we were able to put together a text, which is not ideal from our point of view but which, at least, may provide strong support from this Chamber and offer a strong mandate for what to do next. The negotiations should resume and should involve both sides and all the parties. At the same time, we should not forget that international law needs to be observed, even by Israel, and if that is not a principled stance on the part of the EU we will not be able to influence the situation. Either we base ourselves on international law and international principles or we will have no impact on our immediate environment. The five-million political community simply cannot afford that, so thank you very much for your efforts, Madam High Representative, Mr Vice-President, and the best of luck to you.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, what I have learned in my first year elected to this place is that the problem with the EU’s role in the Middle East is that – to put it bluntly – political opinion often seems to favour one side of the argument. Across many of the different EU institutions, it remains fairly uncritical of Palestine and always puts the onus on Israel. It seems to me that it is carrots for Palestinians and a stick for Israel. Chairing the negotiation of a deal with a state that calls for the destruction of its neighbour, with massive grants of financial aid to Gaza, whilst rockets are still being fired into Israel, is hardly the best approach towards lasting peace. Central to your involvement, Commissioner, is support for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), with the EU as its largest multilateral donor. But, interestingly, my country, the UK, is not far off matching the total EU contribution. There remains a valid question about UNRWA’s efficiency and what exactly the EU is funding, as well as concerns over UNRWA’s governance. There always appears to be some budget crisis. Commissioner, I would like to ask what assessments and audit checks the Commission carries out on UNRWA. In the past, UNRWA has regrettably been a byword for corruption and waste. Finally, there is a question as to what the role of the EU is in the continuing discussions with the Quartet, UN Security Council and various bilateral negotiations. Is there not a danger of confusion with so many actors? Is it the case that the EU wishes to be involved so that it can appear as a player, rather than bringing something constructive to the table? There needs to be fresh thinking outside the constraints of a two-state solution. In any case, there needs to be a more even-handed approach to Israel. Until such a time, I fear that the stalemate and tragedy on both sides will continue. If Hamas were to renounce its call for the destruction of Israel, it would be the first step on this long, rocky road.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I still have blue card requests from Members who have to speak during the debate. If I also give the speakers the blue card, we will end the debate in two hours' time, it seems impossible to me, there is a timetable to be respected, and all the speakers from the following debates must be respected.  I therefore no longer accept blue cards from Members who are already registered to speak and I will be obliged, at the end of the speeches on behalf of the groups, to ensure strict compliance with the allotted time, because there are so many speakers in this debate, and there are many of them in the forthcoming debates. Out of respect for all our colleagues, I shall be obliged to cut off those who will be overtime.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the impoverishment, war and bloodshed of the peoples in the Middle East, the continued occupation and slaughter of the Palestinian people by Israel, the uprooting of people in waves to drown in the wet grave in which you have transformed the Mediterranean, these are all crimes bearing the stamp of the imperialist interventions of the European Union and its allies. , the United States and NATO. Crimes committed with all kinds of pretences, as today with the jihadists which is your repulsive creation. Today's Juncker declarations, the threats he has launched against third countries, with the tool of awarding the title 'safe country', are a sign of the intensity of the European Union's aggression and the sharpening of imperialist competition for control of energy resources and their transport routes. These competitions pose great risks to the peoples and Greece is involved in them. But the people have the power to spoil these plans. It is enough to properly target the capitalist system, monopolies and their associations, so that they can get their hands on the wealth they can produce and reap it themselves.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, we have been seeing the security situation in the Middle East steadily deteriorating for years now and I would say that the current situation is even worse, since we also have a near-total destabilization of the region which has consequences for other regions. We see it in Africa but we also see it in Europe in all areas, whether it is the migration of exiles or terrorists.  Madam High Representative, I believe that our history, our influence, our ability to speak with all countries and our moral as well as military power oblige us. They oblige us and they also allow us to act by uniting all those who are likely to participate in the restoration of dialogue and the restoration of trust. Now more than ever, I believe that the rise of terrorism and the destabilization of the region require rapid progress. There are fewer and fewer window of fire for reconciliation and peace action or for stabilization of the region. The basis of the solutions is known, and they are recalled in the resolution we will see tomorrow. The problem is the will to act and trust.  Madam High Representative, I believe that what is new in this resolution is the unanimity obtained in order to give you support that will effectively allow you to act and to have a leading role in motivating and perhaps forcing certain parties to come back to the table. I believe that the main problem is indeed , as I have already said - that of trust. Having spoken with the heads of state and the ministers of both countries, it is clear that the solutions are recognized, but there is a lack of confidence.  So everyone understood today that we have to act. Madam High Representative, you have our full support beyond our differences and differences; we wanted to mark it. It's up to you to show us that we were right.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, in this debate let us show the responsibility not simply to rehearse old arguments or entrench past divisions. Let us address what we can do now to bring people together for the future, and that should start with welcoming the new and active role being pursued by the High Representative/Vice President. We welcome the confidence which Ms Mogherini has established with the different parties, including the greater engagement to which she has committed herself again today with the Arab partners. When she came to the Committee on Foreign Affairs in July, Mrs Mogherini said Mr Netanyahu had told her that he had recommitted Israel to a two-state solution, and she added that she now expected him to show it. We should join her in that expectation on all Israelis and on all Palestinians.  To our Palestinian friends, we were proud to pass the resolution in favour of a move towards recognition of your state, but we always said that this was not a substitute for direct talks. We hope the successful vote today to name our own delegation, specifically one with Palestine, will be a further such encouragement. We note the efforts last week in Qatar of your chief negotiator to seek Hamas’ participation in a meeting of the Palestinian National Council. We encourage reconciliation, and should consider any further action the EU take can take to help achieve it. In today’s resolution, we will vote for full implementation of the recommendations made in the report of the UN independent commission of inquiry, which identified war crimes of the 2014 Gaza conflict, including to support actively the work of the International Criminal Court. It is right to do so.  Mr President, there will always be those who say nothing will change in the Middle East, but today’s resolution is for peace, for justice and for statehood. There must be no third intifada.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – More than ever, we are faced with a complex situation in a very broad region where different conflicts affect and exacerbate each other. And you are right, Mrs Mogherini, in that regional context, the oldest conflict is the piece of the puzzle you have to start with. And I therefore welcome your intention to play an active role on behalf of the European Union: to build a regional framework, to build trust to allow those parties to cross the bridge. We wholeheartedly support a two-state solution, in which Israel and Palestine coexist. The recognition of a Palestinian state is necessary, and it only makes sense through negotiations with Israel, with support from the international community. I would like to wish you, Mrs Mogherini, the courage and strength of your new active role in the conciliation to find a consensus in line with the balanced and nuanced attitude chosen in the past. I think it is important that you have the full support of this parliament, and you already have our support.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, the Vice—President has said today that this is a region of multiple challenges, and that is a central part of the puzzle. I could not agree more.  Madam Vice-President, there is something more important that you have said recently: the goal is two states for two peoples, and I think that exactly this wording is quite vital. I do not want to repeat what will be in the resolution – I believe that this is a resolution of support and peace – but what should the EU focus on? The EU should focus on reconciliation between the Palestinians: that is one goal. Second, rapprochement with Israel. The third goal is clearly Gaza: improving conditions there. We should aim at getting the two parties at the negotiating table without any conditions. Having said that, I think our goal should be for the Palestinians to administrate Gaza and, obviously, for the Israelis to cease any other acts regarding the settlements. In such a case, I think that we could agree: we could become a global player, but as a global player we could contribute to a resolution of the crisis. As naive as it may be seen today, I believe that it is achievable.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the Middle East is becoming increasingly dangerous. Unfortunately, the Union with its foreign policy is destabilising the region, as it supports the imperialist interventions that feed the terrorist forces, blood the people and create waves of refugees. At the heart of the drama lies the Palestinian problem. Resolving the Palestinian conflict will play a key role in the prevalence of peace throughout the Middle East region. We therefore expect the Union to support the struggle of the Palestinian people to create an independent, viable, sovereign Palestinian state, on the 1967 border, and with East Jerusalem as its capital. We expect it to respect international and European law and put pressure on Israel to end settlement and apartheid policies. We believe, Mrs Mogherini, that the Union must respect its own declarations and suspend the Association Agreement until Israel ceases to violate Article 2 on the need to respect human rights. We also call on you to intervene to end the arms trade between Member States and Israel, with which weapons are bombed in Gaza and entire families are being torn out. We want you to insist on guaranteeing the right of refugees to return and denounce the continuing violations of human rights. Refugees, especially children who are now refugees for the second time, must be protected and the release of all Palestinian prisoners must be demanded. First of all, however, we demand that the Union define its foreign policy objectives, that it ceases to be a tail of imperialist wars and that the United States ceases to serve the interests of the United States. The Union must serve only the interests of peace in the region.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! Mrs Mogherini, thank you for the statement and thank you for your commitment and thank you for mentioning that this conflict is not only the oldest, but that it is also very important to resolve, not least if Europe is to gain some credibility in the region. Our double standards are therefore very, very clear and are mentioned from many quarters. We insist only that international rules must be respected when it comes to others, but not when it comes to Israel. It is important to say that these are not two equal parties, no, one party is occupying the other! If you can't tell the difference between occupiers and occupiers, then there's something wrong in your head. Of course, I do not only miss the fact that we are told quite clearly that the occupation must be abolished, but also that we are given clarity as to what means we actually have to make things work. We have for many years folded our hands and wished it would go well, we want to build trust, we want people to believe in each other and so on and so on and nothing happens! Yes, more and more settlements are coming! In fact, something we can do is already there, and we should be aware of that. We originally have in our green proposal a number of things that can be done, which are remedies, not punishment, not BDS, not boycotts. In other words, to a very different extent than today, we must take our own laws seriously and comply with them and have a proper policy of separation between Israel and the occupied territories, so that attention is paid not only to products from there, but also to all companies involved in the occupation, including to universities, to banks, to everything possible. If we say that they will have nothing to do with the European Union because they are illegal under its own laws, I am pretty sure that something will happen.  Finally, if this is not taken seriously, I hope that we will then have another workable strategy that will spark the process, rather than just pious wishes and words.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, I wish I could look to the future with a little more optimism for the Middle East peace process, but unfortunately I would be lying to myself a little bit. This is because the situation today tells us that the control of power in Israel, as much as in Palestine, is firmly in the hands of the most dangerous party of all: the party taken!  This is true in Israel, where the new Netanyahu government appears crushed by its own electoral rhetoric, which is increasingly isolated and partly hostage to the nationalist and ultra-Orthodox parties that support it. And so every effort seems more catalyzed towards maintaining the status quo. To obstruct reconciliation between the Palestinian factions, between Hamas and Fatah, so as not to have an interlocutor; I would also like to say a few things about the difficult agreement on nuclear power in Iran to prevent its potential effects from actually materialising, that substantial change in circumstances which would perhaps actually help us to have a serious relaunch of the negotiations, with the cooperation of the Gulf countries and Turkey as well.  The Palestinians also have their serious responsibilities, first and then, a ruling class that is now light years away from the people it represents; Abbas' resignation may be an act of desperation or a tactical move, time will tell, but they certainly sow uncertainty in the short term. We are therefore at the mercy of this eternal postponement, while Gaza remains an immense and desolate open-air prison and illegal colonisations are proceeding.  Our role cannot be solely with infrastructure financiers and projects that are often destroyed, it is good to involve the Arab countries. , we will have neither a two-state solution nor an authority in the context and, unfortunately, we will som even more the germ of extremism and Daesh.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, the Middle East is on fire. It has descended into an indescribable chaos: the destruction of men, the destruction of memory, the destruction of differences in favour of the Islamic totalitarianism that is spreading in the Middle East and which is infiltrating all over Europe. The Middle East is bleeding and its blood is now flowing to Europe.  But who destroyed the nation-states of Iraq, Libya and Syria? Who destroyed the Arab governments that had subjected the religious to politics, maintained peaceful cohabitation between ethno-religious communities, allowed women access to autonomy and dignity? Who has awakened Islam's jihadism everywhere? Who created this monstrous Islamic State that turns children into slaughterers and destroys our multi-millennium legacies? Who supported Islamic fundamentalism in Afghanistan in the late 1980s? Who supported him in Yugoslavia in 1990? Who, in 1999, bombed Serbia, all of a time, a bulwark against Islamic expansion in Europe? Who today is arming the neo-Nazi militias and battalions of Chechen jihadists who massacre Russian-speaking villagers in eastern Ukraine? Who supports Islamic communitarianism and the construction of mosques throughout Europe? Who wants to force the nations of Central and Eastern Europe to turn away from their civilization by accepting Muslim immigration? That? As you all know, it is Euro-Atlanticism by the tyranny of emotion neutralising the reason of the peoples, by the bombs of NATO and by the migratory submersion. Many of you here will be complicit, in the face of history, in the slow destruction of our civilization, European and Christian civilization.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, a young Syrian said, in an interview, 'stop the wars and we will stop leaving our country'. But how do we stop the wars caused by the United States when, as the European Union, we ourselves are involved in them, wars that create refugees and immigrants who do not, of course, go to the United States but come to Europe, wars on which we presumably support the wrong side? In Syria, for example, we still want to topple Assad who is fighting against ISIS at a time when the dissidents have almost been militarily annihilated. We tolerate Turkey secretly sending weapons to ISIS. We tolerate Turkey illegally bringing thousands of migrants to Greece, including criminal jihadists. We tolerate Saudi Arabia bombing Yemen and finally, we tolerate Turkey which, instead of fighting against ISIS, is bombing kurdish fighters, the only ground force that has achieved military successes against the jihadists. If we do not change our policy, what answer can we give the young Syrian?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, the Union now has the institutional means and your personal commitment to play a more important and above all decisive role. There are three things I would like to highlight. First, we must be united and firm. We must be united because the Member States have a responsibility to respect your work and that of our Special Representative and to avoid unilateral actions weakening European action. We must be firm on the settlements that are illegal under international law and on the continuation of this policy, which is anything but favourable to the resumption of peace negotiations. Secondly, the Union's role is to identify and bring together moderate, interested and determined partners by and for peace in the Middle East. These actors must be found among Palestinians and Israelis as well as among other countries in the region. Intra-Palestinian reconciliation and the sincere efforts of Arab neighbours are needed. We will have to make the most of the European neighbourhood policy in this area, and I am thinking in particular of the role of the younger generations.  Thirdly, the UNION's strategy in the Middle East must be multidimensional, regional and realistic. It must be multidimensional and regional because there are challenges other than the strictly Israeli-Palestinian conflict: migration flows, civil war in Yemen, Syria and Iraq, not to mention the Islamic State. It must be realistic because the problems of the region which also threaten European security and stability will not simply fade away with the outcome of Israeli-Palestinian peace. So yes to audacity and patience. You have our support, because the European Union, thanks to you, will be determined to finally find a long-term perspective for this region.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear, even at this still pessimistic stage, the analysis of the data of reality reminds us that the two-state solution has no alternative. Some time ago, Shimon Peres said that it is not true that there is no light at the end of the tunnel in the Middle East, far from it! He said the light is there, the problem is there's no tunnel.  His was a bitter consideration that comes to mind every repetition of the difficulties between Israel and Palestine and the fact that the conflict, with less or greater intensity, has never stopped. And it is this perception of the intangibility of conflict, of fatality independent of the efforts of the world, that leads someone to look for alternative solutions, to think that, before we even go through it, we have to find the good tunnel.  But the truth is that there is no alternative solution, because of viable paths to peace, there is only one. The tunnel is there, but we must convince the Israelis and Palestinians to take it. In fact, what the conditions for peace between Israelis and Palestinians will be, it has been known for years, perhaps decades, that all the different peace negotiations have been structured on these formulae, from Madrid to Oslo, from Camp David to Taba, from the Roadmap in Geneva.  The impetus for the peace process, that of the two States, are the clear indications of the European Parliament's resolution. I understand the difficulties that you yourself, Madam High Representative, have described, but it is up to the European Union to take stronger and more effective action to achieve this objective. Moreover, we must be aware that, if we want to put out the fires in the Middle East, this is the first decisive step to take.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – The Member States of the European Union are today engaged in a real race to do good business with the Islamic Republic of Iran, which, as a state ideology, endorses and pursues the destruction of the Jewish State of Israel.  Speaking of the EU's role in the peace process in the region, Iran is mobilising and training Palestinian terrorist organisations for israel's intended destruction. High Representative, what role the EU actually plays towards Tehran and its Palestinian cronies. Explain that to me now! After all, you don't want to drag the last piece of land in the region into the current hurricane of unrestrained violence?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Dear High Representative, you have convinced us today that you really want to get into the realm of those who can move things. It must have come so far that we were faced with the catastrophe, the refugee catastrophe, that we understood that there was a causal link between wars, interventions, illusions on which the West's policy in the Middle East was based, and the consequences we face today. But I think the point is to realise what you testified to us by saying,"We are going to fight for peace." Peace is the most essential thing. The first thing you will face, however, will convince the great players to come, among them the European Union, that Europe can add value to the peace process, both in the Middle East, between Palestinians and Israelis, both in the entire Middle East and, I would say more broadly.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, this is indeed the oldest conflict in the Middle East and has had irreversible consequences, and so I would like to talk about a report that came out a week ago, a REPORT from the United Nations, so that we no longer have an irreversible consequence.  The United Nations study released in early September warned that the Gaza Strip could become uninhabitable in less than five years as a result of the three wars that followed. The water, the agriculture, the houses, the hospitals, the schools, it was all destroyed. The same study showed that socio-economic conditions in the territory are at their lowest level since 1967. The same study shows that the situation is unsustainable after 8 years of economic blockade. The same study notes that in the first four months of 2015, Israel again withawe withed customs revenues, which would represent 75% of the incoming money in the Gaza Strip.  In no conflict history is made in black and white. But it is true that this is not just any conflict and that there is an oppressive state that has been treated preferentially. Also this week there was another report showing that arms sales from European countries to the State of Israel continue to increase. In one of the countries this increase represented 1/3 of the invoicing, 1/3 of profit and represents, moreover, expenses of EUR 660 million. Madam High Representative, can we ever talk about peace processes in this Parliament without putting an end to the arms business? I confess i support, and support your effort. But we have to end the arms business process because there is no peace process that rhymes with the arms business.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Middle East is on fire, but we are talking about the only peace process that is still going on, even if that peace process is as good as dead. It will also be a two-state solution very soon if we do not act very quickly. This is very evident when visiting Israel and Palestine, as I last did in July this year, in the midst of the worst heat, 50 degrees celsius in the Jordan Valley, where the settlers get to buy the water for about 7 shekels and the Bedoans for 37.  We will discuss the role of the EUROPEAN Union here in the peace process. I believe that we can do this by being very clear about the settlers and their products. To make a clear distinction between what is Israel and what are the settlers. We have international law fully with us in it, and we can make a difference. We visited the village of Sosia, which is also under threat of demolition. There, a car has been pushed into the water well so that the Palestinians will never again be able to get clean water and then be forced to buy water via Israel in that case as well.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, I will also take some of the time that my colleague did not take, as my group agrees on this point. The destruction of the Near and Middle East is due first of all to the destruction of Iraq and this unnecessary war in Iraq, the sectarian management that was then made of Iraq, the subsequent destruction of Libya, the interventionism - also French, it must be said - and the destruction of Syria. All these acts were committed because of the right of interference that the West and the Union give themselves to manifest imperialism, supposedly in the name of human rights and democracy but, unfortunately, in reality, in the service of foreign interests contrary to our European interests. It must also be seen as the will of the United States to create profitable chaos to prevent the creation of a Eurasian and Eurocontinental Union.  In the face of this, I would like to stress, in relation to the criticisms that are being made against Israel, that this country is a pole of stability and democracy and that if we do want to make it a pole of war as well, let us move forward with this idea of the two states. We will then see what the result will also be for Israel, which at present, as I stress, is the only pole of stability and democracy. In these circumstances, it is scandalous, irresponsible and dignified, for my part, of the crime of high treason to prevent States from controlling the flow of migrants in which the Islamic State, which boasts of it, has itself claimed the infiltration of its fighters, who will tomorrow be a factor of instability in the Near and Middle East that will reach our continent. It is irresponsible that regimes such as Egypt or Syria are being destabilizationd and, ultimately, methods, it must be said, of sorcerer's apprentices also coming , let us be said - from the Commission. To top it all off, we support you, Parliament and the Commission, support Turkey at a time when Turkey has just attacked the Iraqi Kurds who are fighting the Islamic State. On the other hand, you are and we have largely remained deaf to the cries of agony of the Christian minorities of the East. Where were our tears in the face of the thousands of women and men sold as slaves, raped and beheaded? Our morality boils down to demanding that the abandoned, forgotten and defenceless European peoples welcome all the misery of the imperial wars we have supported. Of course, what then is the point of crying in an orchestrated way in a photo to make the people of Europe believe that we have heart? Where is our heart when the widespread suffering of other peoples is there and we stick to an image? The Union has betrayed, the Union will be judged by the people and by history.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, the problem at the moment, in my view, is that Israel's relations with the Palestinian Authority are more affected than in the past by external factors. The substantial disappearance of so-called Arab nationalism and Arab socialism, expressed by various regimes in the past, has strengthened the wing of extreme Islamists in the Palestinian Movement and in Arab countries. This means that the leadership of the Palestinian Movement is having difficulty making the necessary compromises with Israel because it does not want to be accused of treason. For its part, Israel, which is the only truly democratic country in the region and must therefore always be the privileged partner of the European Union, feels threatened by the development of Islamist forces, by instability in Egypt, by the substantial disintegration of Syria and Iraq for the benefit of the so-called Islamic State and by Iran's policy. The motion for a resolution is moving in the right direction, but we must broaden our action, just as the President of the European Commission, Mr President of the Commission, said this morning. Juncker, in order to create positive momentum in the wider region so that Israelis and Palestinians can come together. We therefore need more Europe in this case, in the sense of a truly common foreign policy, if we want to have a positive impact on the wider region so that the two parties can reach the historic compromise that we have been describing, unfortunately without seeing any result, for decades.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, I of course agree with the High Representative that there can be no successful Middle East peace process unless the international community – including ourselves – promotes responsible action on both sides.  However, I am afraid the actions we continue to witness from the Israeli Government are not conducive to peace. The settlement building continues, despite being a blatant breach of international law. The European Union response – your own response – is right and correct in the form of words, but failing in terms of any action. By our inaction, I think we give tacit support to an illegal occupation. The EU-Israel Association Agreement has, under Article 2, provisions for a formal human rights dialogue. We need to begin that dialogue immediately. If Israel refuses to halt the settlement building, we should move to suspend the Association Agreement. Trade preferences are carrots and sticks. If we are afraid to use the stick when facing such disregard for international law, then our claims to have values in our foreign policy become empty words.  What is interesting, though, is that while the institutions drag their heels our citizens are demanding the opportunity to take action. They are demanding to have mandatory labelling on products so that they can choose to boycott products coming from the occupied territories. So I welcome the news that the Commission will soon publish its proposal for labelling guidelines, but these must be mandatory guidelines showing that these are goods from illegally occupied territories. Mandatory labelling is essential, both for giving consumers accurate information on what they buy and to take seriously our obligations for a fair – as well as free – trade policy.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I think that the European Union on that point should not be perceived as biased. Unfortunately, some steps put us into a biased position, such as the labelling of products or today’s vote on the name change of the delegation. If we agree with the ‘two states, two peoples’ principle, we should actively engage in bringing both sides to the negotiating table with no preconditions, because they are very risky and we should send some signals to the Palestinian side.  We should condemn the recent rockets fired by Hamas or other military groups. We should say to the Palestinian side that they are a unified voice. It is a vital condition for reaching a solution.
