We should tell them that they must take greater responsibility and assume their governmental functions in the Gaza Strip, including security and civil administration, and we should urge them to hold democratic general elections. We should also take broader regional security challenges into account. Otherwise, we will get nowhere.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: – Mr President, Madam High Representative, once again we come to this House to adopt a resolution on the situation in the Middle East. Resolutions which are becoming less and less important, because of the lack of political weight and capacity for action that the Union has in foreign affairs; resolutions that too usually end up on wet paper. However, the resolution we are discussing today is a little closer to reality on the ground.  Unlike in past resolutions, this House no longer forgets the irrefutable existence of a population dominated by an occupying force, contrary to international law, or the lack of political will of the parties in the region to accept the existence of the opposite. But it does seem that we forget – although Mrs Matias mentioned this – the unquestionable fact that, if the blockade of Gaza is not lifted, Gaza will cease to be habitable in five years. And I do not say this: it is said by a recent report by the United Nations.  We must force a status quo as soon as possible to freeze the conflict and lift the blockade.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, we are used to overacting, aggressiveness or double standard with human rights with certain countries, but we turn a blind eye to others, for example with Israel. More than twenty-six United Nations resolutions failed to comply, crimes marked by international law, genocide, war, humanity, aggression... Two hundred children imprisoned, more than 400 administrative detainees in indefinite detention without trial, legalization of torture or a state of apartheid.  Of course we can do things from the European Union! We are Israel's greatest partner. We can condition the partnership agreement on compliance with Article 2: respect for human rights, ban on arms exports and arms imports between Israel and the European Union, suspend cooperation within the framework of the European Defence Agency or comply with a ban on selling illegal settlement products. All to come to peace, to a just peace with the borders of '67.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: – Mr President, in order to solve this conflict, first of all, it does not make sense to just replicate the conflict here in Europe and give advice only on the basis of party affiliation to one side, but in order to solve the conflict it also does not help to put half efforts into solving the conflict. So I am very much in favour of putting full effort into the solution of this conflict by a pathway where we remove the hurdles from these peace negotiations, by lifting the blockades as one very important step, also by strengthening the back of the Palestinian Authority, reaching unity for the fundament of the Palestinian State and making the responsibilities clear to both sides with regard to violent groups, which are undermining the peace process. I think that the European Union could give a very big effort to this and put this peace process into a position to solve it, and I think that it is urgent. As has been said by some colleagues, these are partners; these are partners we can talk to. The Palestinian Authority as well as the Israeli Government, but also Egypt and Jordan: partners we have to negotiate intensively with now, because there are other actors in the region which are not at all working for stability in the Middle East, and that has to be tackled altogether. So we have to use the moment to solve the big task and the big challenge of this conflict which is underlying and which, of course, is a hurdle to a further solution of conflicts which are urging us to quick action at the moment to solve also the situation of those people living in these regions.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Mr President, this debate is intended to include an exchange of views on how the EU can contribute to a renewed peace process in the Middle East. Let me address those blaming Israel for the non-existent negotiation talks, those who also pave the way for an EU boycott of Israeli products and those who name Israel an apartheid state. By doing this, you are not contributing to a constructive EU role in the current situation. A trustful relationship is based upon mutual confidence and trust. A one-sided EU position will not facilitate peace dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians. Today’s joint resolution has a fairly balanced approach. Despite this, I fear that the preconceptions we have seen over the years have already damaged the credibility of the EU. Israelis have noted the spread of anti-Israeli sentiments and anti-Semites in Europe. This needs to be confronted. Let us be clear: the only liberal democracy in the Middle East will never be a bigger problem than the evil dictatorships and terrorist groups in the surrounding region.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, for most of the time the dominant factor in the Middle East has been – and to a certain extent still is – the Arab-Israeli conflict. The two-state, two-peoples solution has been, and still is, the only conceivable – and therefore acceptable – way to try and solve it. However, in the wake of the Arab Spring, a new conflict has appeared, this time intra—Arab, between the Shias and the Sunnis. The recent advances of ISIS in Syria, where the civil war goes on unabated, and Iraq – as well as in Libya, where things were further complicated by the political division of the country – suggest an ample de—structuring process with dangerous and unpredictable consequences: the accompanying instability in a much larger area of the Middle East. Its reverberations within the Muslim communities in Europe and the current migrant tsunami are consequences we already have to face.  Under the circumstances, it will only be a question of time before this new conflict becomes dominant, pushing the old Arab-Israeli conflict into a secondary position, thus forcing us to revisit our traditional policies and alliances in an attempt to adapt ourselves to the new landscape in the area. Of course, that will not mean abandoning the efforts to solve that old conflict, only that the target and the reference framework we would be forced to operate in will be broader and different in nature.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, High Representative, thank you very much for your statement, but I must ask you a question. Why are we talking here almost exclusively about Israel and the Palestinian people, but the name of this has the role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process? I am now advocate for the European Union to play an active role in the next peace process in that area, namely in the north-west of Syria in the canton of Gozarto or Rodzava. There is democratic self-government that fully respects human rights and democratic principles, which need to be supported by the European Union, but not only by words, but also by concrete actions. With regard to the conflict in Israel, I would encourage you to be able to get partners at the highest level to sit at the table together again. This is absolutely necessary, because we are hearing that the Palestinian leadership wants to invalidate the Osla Agreement and clearly accuse Israel of failing to secure peace. If this is fulfilled, it will be a huge step backwards for the whole area. The chances of peace will be thwarted by the Palestinians, and we must ensure that this does not happen.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, this Israeli-Palestinian conflict , as everyone knows here, has now existed for 67 years. However, the regional context has probably never been so degraded since the beginning of this conflict. Wherever we look, towards the borders of Israel and Palestine, towards Syria where the Islamic State works today, towards Jordan with its hundreds of thousands of refugees, towards Lebanon more destabilized than ever, or towards Egypt, which is also experiencing difficult times, we see, perhaps it is the paradox of these situations, that this is probably the time to take an initiative. That is why I support what you are doing on behalf of the European Union. I really ask you to think about a new negotiating framework that is more effective than the quartet. We need to rethink the regional and international framework for the action that we Europeans can promote. Indeed, this is paradoxical, but it is probably the right time for the European Union to take the initiative again.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: – Mr President, it has been many years since I have read Simon Peres's book The new Near East, and there is talk that combining Israeli technology and capital with Arab resources could lead to this area being turned into one of the most dynamic in the world. Instead, $50 billion or more is spent each year on weapons, water disappears, and one of the worst environmental disasters in the world is created. I think it is very important that the peace process continues, because it would also help to stop the refugee crisis and help improve the situation of all the peoples in the region. Once, Jean-Paul Sartre, who is having a double anniversary this year, said a path to a deal would be possible because the left would certainly agree. But where to find a functional, actionable and hopeful left in the Muslim world? Perhaps this is a task for European diplomacy, as well as for the resources of the two opposing sides to come together. I think there's still a chance.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, the EU acting as the EU is actually in a much stronger position than many of our Member States to intervene within this crisis. We have cleaner hands than most and a clear set of values upon which we are founded and exist to promote, so it is those values enshrined in international law that we need to be consistent in upholding. I will not repeat comments made by other colleagues, I will focus specifically on labelling of settlement produce because I think this is a small but psychologically significant lever that is entirely at our control and which I think does have a disproportionate effect within Israel. Let us be clear. Israel has a right to exist and has a right to expect security within its own borders. It does not have a right to illegally occupy Palestinian land or allow settlers to illegally occupy Palestinian land and exploit it for their profit. Ms Mogherini, I was very pleased to hear you announce just last Saturday that the EU will be pressing on with labelling of illegal produce. Could you give us some more details of that, and a timescale whereby our citizens and our consumers can expect to see illegally-produced produce properly marked as such?

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, I think there is no dispute that the Role of the European Union in the Middle East peace process should be the role of a neutral and fair mediator. The aim of this process is to be the existence of two states. And I am glad that the Israeli Prime Minister has recently re-signed up to this solution. As far as the Palestinian Authority is concerned, it must also be insisted that the future Palestinian State unconditionally recognises the existence of the state of Israel. This future Palestinian state must also be administered by an administration that is truly capable of managing its entire territory, including its borders. administration capable of ensuring security and development on its territory. The achievement of the two-state objective can only be achieved through negotiation. Terrorism is not such an instrument. That is why the European Union must also ensure that its financial support does not end with terrorists. That would be more than counterproductive. After all, we must also acknowledge that Israel is an important and natural partner in the current situation of the Middle East precisely because it is a democracy.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, we are concerned about the Middle East and this morning's discussion on migration policies has reminded us how close this region is to Europe. She also reminded us that the European Union has an important role to play in conflict management. Thus, the inability for more than 40 years to carry out the peace process in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has led to a blatant injustice towards the Palestinians but also to insecurity or fragile security for Israelis.  According to the United Nations, and several of my colleagues have said today, in the Gaza Strip, life would not be possible in five years because of the many wars and blockades that have been waged. The policies of successive Israeli governments towards the West Bank, the settlements and also the checkpoints are policies of humiliation towards the Palestinian peoples. Therefore, of course, as a Europe, we must react to these situations and react constructively naturally. What tools do we have today? We have, in the context of these resolutions, a number of proposals, including proposals on labelling, which are not a boycott, but are simply aimed at enforcing regulations and law, including by the Israeli government.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, honourable Mrs Mogherini, honourable Members, it is increasingly clear that this conflict can no longer be dealt with on its own. Despite its long history, and despite its difficulties, it is increasingly clear that this conflict is becoming an integral part of the much larger clash that is taking place in the Middle East, namely the conflict between sunni Islam terrorist organizations united and headed by the Islamic State organization, which co-operates with all other terrorist organizations, such as Hamas in Palestine, and fights on several fronts. Without resolving this problem without resolving this conflict, there is no solution for the other.  The only way to put the issue clearly on the table is to tell the truth about what is Islamic State, who is funding it, who is organising it and who has an interest in it, and these truths must be told, because otherwise there is no way to seek and find a peaceful solution for the whole of Europe.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Madam President, a year after the last massacre in the Gaza Strip we are still discussing the role of the European Union in peace negotiations. But there are virtually no negotiations. The two-state solution seems difficult and the European Union's policy helps to make it impossible. How can there be negotiations when Israel has actually proved that it does not want any solution? For anyone who does not understand it, I say the following: Israel has handed over 40% of the territory provided for the Palestinian state to settlers, Israel carries out human purges every three years in Gaza, Israel does not accept the two-state solution, as Mr Netanyahu has publicly stated. All this is happening at a time when the United Nations Commission of Inquiry is talking about Israel's war crimes and the unprecedented material leveling of the Gaza Strip, blaming Israel's dominant military and political elite. Meanwhile, we count 5 million Palestinian refugees in squalid camps, we measure 750 kilometres of 12-metre-high Wall and we see apartheid conditions in Gaza. Are we still wondering about our role? But it is provided for and enforced by the international legal order that we claim to respect. Our role is one and the same: to immediately oblige the State of Israel to respect international treaties and the decisions of international organisations, to force it to tear down the Wall, to stop the blockade of Gaza, to stop settlements and to release illegal prisoners. Mrs Mogherini, the more we agree with our stance on Israel's impunity, the more our resolutions will be a waste of time, as Mr Netanyahu himself contemptuously described them.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her High Representative Mrs Mogherini! The Israeli-Palestinian peace process has been sidelined by the IS and Syria crisis. This is also due to the fact that there is really no question of a peace process at the moment. At the moment there are no official negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians.  To this end, as you said, we need confidence-building measures for and between the negotiating partners. I am very grateful to you for your strong commitment to the resumption of peace talks, and you have been doing so since the beginning of your mandate and deserve our full support for this. Not only this House, but also the whole of Europe, must speak with one voice. Only in this way can we throw all our weight behind the objective of a two-state solution. A major obstacle to this is Israel's settlement policy. The constant construction and construction of settlements on Palestinian territory makes a peace settlement more difficult every day. I wish you successful negotiations and I would like to return to your opening words that we have already seen in Iran diplomacy that it is possible to tackle the most complicated and difficult issues. But a lot of strength and a lot of success! Thank you very much, you have our support.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Thank you very much. We are debating the role of the European Union and its engagement in the Middle East. The tangible effects of this policy are evident in the ever-increasing wave of refugees and refugees coming from this region of the world. It must be made clear that, in this policy, the European Union has not only failed, but has failed. It was necessary to be more active and interact with the United States, for example, because the lack of effective external activity is reflected in hiccups.  If the European Commission's response to the wave of refugees is to launch a legal channel for their flow to Europe so that all asylum seekers can work in Europe from day one, as the President of the Commission said today in the European Parliament, how do we put this into line with another message he has communicated today that twenty-three million of its citizens are currently out of work in the European Union? This is irreconcilable, and that is why the Union needs more commitment to refugees, but there, on the ground, in cooperation with neighbouring countries. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – Do you agree with me that, in terms of migration and the refugee crisis in Europe, one of the biggest problems is that for every refugee in Europe, there are 25 to 30 refugees currently in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan? Furthermore, do you accept that there is an issue with economic migration in the UK because, in the last year up to June 2015, only 4% of those coming into the UK were refugees and 96% were economic migrants?

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much. As I said in my speech, I would like to stress once again that some of these people are refugees, and some of those arriving in this group are refugees, and there will certainly be terrorists among them. That is why this is such an important problem both for the United Kingdom you have spoken about and for the other Member States, including Polish one from which I myself come.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, your great commitment to peace in the Middle East, as you know, is constantly deteriorating. If the objective of the two States is not to disappear, this trend must be reversed quickly. This means, however, identifying priorities for diplomatic action. You have rightly spoken of trust and leadership. Neither takes root where pain is sovereign.  So, you really have to start there. That is why it is essential to stop and overcome the conflict, starting with the blockade of the Gaza Strip, where humanitarian problems, particularly those affecting children, are truly dramatic and unacceptable and, at the same time, I believe that it is important to give the United Nations Agency dealing with refugees the material conditions for working. Only in this way can conditions be created which will enable the Community, starting with the European Union, to make an effective contribution to the search for new negotiations.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her My short speech is a sigh of shock. In 1968, one year after the Six-Day War, I visited Israel as part of a study trip. I saw a vibrant country! I saw historic cities that we have known since childhood: Jerusalem, Bethlehem, Tel Aviv, Akkron, Hebron, Nazareth and the Sea of Galilee. I saw boys in Jerusalem and in the West Bank with awake faces and wise eyes. I thought that promised a future. And today, we are further away than ever from that hope.  I get the impression that politicians on both sides are torpedoing the balance because they benefit from the status quo. When Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated, Israel and Palestine lost a hope for reconciliation and peace. Israel and Palestine need a new Yitzhak Rabin! What can the EU do? Perhaps, to take up a word from Madame Mogherini, she can build bridges for a new Yitzhak Rabin. That would be my dream for this wonderful region and its brave people.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, the Middle East peace process began with the signing of the Oslo Agreement over 21 years ago. Since then many have lost faith that peace between Palestinians and Israelis is possible. Aggressive expansion of Jewish settlements in occupied Palestinian territory has radically altered the geographical map. Experts warn that territory for a viable peace based on a two-state solution is vanishing before our eyes. Once upon a time, Europe was riven with war; it took two World Wars and the loss of millions of lives before we understood the futility of war and began our own peace process. The suffering of Palestinians does not need to continue. We do not need another generation of young Palestinians with lifelong hatred in their hearts. We are running out of time, but not out of options. Let us use all our tools, diplomatic and economic, to create incentives so that this time peace has a real chance. It is for everyone’s good, including our own. Mrs Mogherini, good luck. You have our full support and endorsement.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Madam High Representative, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the Thank you, Mrs Mogherini, as the new EU foreign policy representative, you are the face of a new role for Europe in world politics. Europe has a special responsibility towards Israel. Europe stands alongside Israel, the only constitutional state in the Greater Region, in the peace process. Unlike my colleagues, I know that Benjamin Netanyahu has once again offered peace talks to the Palestinian transitional government for Israel. And with a clear commitment to the two-state solution – two states for two peoples. I find the discussions in this House, in which Israel is described as an aggressor or occupying power, all the less helpful. Measures such as the labelling requirement for products from Israeli settlements in the EU's internal market are a continuation of Israel's isolation.  And I warn against political naivety towards Iran. Only today, Iran's leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei predicted in online media that Israel would not survive the next 25 years. He rejected further deep cooperation with the West. If we do not rejoice too soon, we remain a reliable partner of Israel, we will create peace. So no labelling requirement!  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for that speech. I agreed with very much of it. Do you agree with me that attempts to label Israeli products and, in some cases, for European countries and European towns to boycott Israeli products, are totally counterproductive and totally missing the point that Israel is actually the real democracy in the area and has made a remarkable achievement to maintain that status in the light of the circumstances it faces? Would you agree with that?

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that Israel has a great task in this region. I know that the Gaza Strip has been handed over to the Palestinians. If there were greenhouses there, there were water systems, which were smashed by the new inhabitants who are there. As far as labelling is concerned, I once worked for a clothing store. There we sewed into the goods for Kuwaiti's new labels. It said: "This product is not from Israel, nor do the materials come from Israel. What are we? What do we sell ourselves for? I do not think Israel deserves it.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Madam President, we have a choice in the Middle East, and the choice as I see it is that we can continue to observe the situation as it deteriorates day by day, or we can act – and I am glad, Madam High Commissioner, that you are choosing the latter. With every year that has passed, the state of the region has got worse. That applies to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the aftermath of the war in Iraq, and the blood-letting in Syria. Even now, when we are confronted with the results of our inaction – thousands and thousands of refugees from the area – we seem to be paralysed. So it must be obvious to all of us: not engaging ourselves will not end the crisis. But what can we do? I totally agree with you: we must bring together the main actors – those on the front lines and those pulling the strings from afar – and discuss how to terminate the conflict. I know this is easier said than done, but not even trying will not bring any results. The European Union has the power; now is the time to act.

name: Kati PIRI
text: We are still committed to the two-state solution, but it seems to be further away than ever at the moment, in fact, slowly creating facts on the ground that no longer allow a two-state solution. That is why urgent action is now absolutely necessary. The EU will have to start removing a financial incentive that provides settlement building in occupied territories. I therefore welcome the announcement that you will be making a proposal on the labelling of products from illegal settlements.  I also ask the High Representative to urge the Israeli authorities to lift the blockade of Gaza. The situation for people there is getting more dire by the day. I welcome the fact that you want to play a more active role in getting the Israelis and Palestinians back to the negotiating table. As far as I am concerned, all the roots and sticks are available to you.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Colleagues, the situation in the Middle East has fundamentally changed. Syria does not exist as a state. Iraq does not exist as a state. Palestine does not exist as a state. Libya is a dysfunctional state. The whole region requires a new geopolitical order. The European Union has the ambition to be a leader in the organisation of a peace process between Israel and the Palestinians. However, this is only possible if the European Union becomes a leader in the new geopolitical order of the entire Middle East area. Today, the Palestinian-Israeli problem is not a central problem in the Middle East, it is part of this overall geopolitical solution, and that is a chance for the European Union, both for Israel and for Palestine. If Israel and Palestine become allies in the new geopolitical order, then the possibility of a rapid peace process in the Middle East is an option, and it is our Commissioner Mogherini who can focus on that.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to be able to address the High Representative Federica Mogherini again in this House on an issue on which she has shown great commitment and determination from the outset. Almost a year ago, we were here to discuss the recognition of the State of Palestine by Member States of the European Union. An important moment, but as she said herself then "not enough".  A year later, the Palestinian leadership is weak, Israel has a new government, the right-wing government ever, although I must welcome the courageous plan proposed by Erik Bahr and the fortunate experience of the Joint Arab List and we have the situation in Gaza, which is increasingly disastrous both for those who live there and for the security prospects of Israel and the region.  You are now here to receive an impetus to continue the difficult work of mediation and political and diplomatic pressure that is needed. The Union can play a fundamental role, Parliament fully supports it in making all the necessary efforts in conjunction with Ferdinando Gentilini, following the indications that emerged from the Council conclusions of 20 July, through a multilateral process involving all regional actors. Peace, security and stability are our objectives and we can achieve them with actions on our part that intelligently hold together principles and the defence of human rights and construction (the speaker is interrupted).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Indeed, it is time for the European Union to play a greater and more meaningful role in promoting the Middle East peace process. I think it is important for the European Parliament to give strong support to the active commitment shown by High Representative Mogherini in facilitating the peace process. At the same time, credibility and impartiality are essential conditions for effective EU action on foreign policy. For good reason, the proposal for a decision places great emphasis on the European tasks ahead of us in improving the security, humanity and political situation of the Palestinian population. I think it is important that the EU's efforts carry a similar weight in preventing terrorist acts from Gaza and other Palestinian territories, reducing Hamas' influence and setting up a capable Palestinian administration to ensure this in the wake of early elections. The current Israeli government and its policies can be loved or not loved – I do not like the current one, for example – but the exercise of Israel's sovereignty and the legitimate security interests of its citizens must be a lasting element of a credible and effective EU Middle East policy.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank to all my colleagues who have worked on this timely resolution on a complex situation. The peace process is taken to mean political negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. But the process of making peace – real, vibrant and viable peace – depends on real people and real communities. I would therefore like to highlight the work of civil society organisations, artists, academics and activists who are striving to build coexistence and dialogue between communities; organisations who seek to build tolerance, understanding and openness. These include the Israeli-Palestinian Bereaved Families Forum, made up of parents who have lost a loved one in the war and work together for peace, EcoPeace/Friends of the Earth Middle East, who connect Israelis and Palestinians in a fight for the environment, and Breaking the Silence, who are Israeli veterans who explain the wrongs of the occupations to Israeli society. The EU must take into account this grassroots work and these organisations. But the real question is how can EU institutions conduct a dialogue on the preservation of the two-state solution? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ana GOMES
text: – It is imperative to re-establish the peace process between Israel and Palestine. In order to do so, the European Union must make a real work of doing so, overcoming the resistance of some Member States in order to achieve the existence of two States for peaceful coexistence between the two peoples. As long as Israel blocks the return to negotiations, illegal occupation, humiliation and violence will continue and could lead to a new war. If Israel continues to prevent a viable State of Palestine, it is condemning itself to self-destruction. The two-state alternative is a single state, an idea that every day seduces more young Palestinians and Israeli-Arabs, and then, of the two, either we will have an undemocratic State of Israel or a state in which jews will be in the minority. If it wants democracy and peace, Israel must behave as a responsible actor and build trust with the Palestinian leadership by reopening the negotiations. Europe cannot afford to remain unwell. We're counting on you, Mrs Mogherini, count on us.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, as we well know, the deterioration on the ground in the Middle East is total.  We are getting further and further from the solution we are looking for, the only possible solution: two states in the region. And so it is imperative that the European Union and the international community deal with this task, doing two things: first, increasing the price that Israel pays for maintaining the status quo, a status quo that is accompanied by an occupation lasting more than fifty years, illegal settlements, a wall that is a disgrace to all, the blockade of Gaza , check-points, arbitrary detentions, major human rights violations. To do this, we have two great tools: the Association Agreement or our trade relations – etiquette is an example – and, at the same time, an empowerment of the Palestinian side, such as the recognition of the State of Palestine, which has to be accompanied and conditioned by the use of non-violence.  In the Middle East or we push history or history is going to pass over us.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Mutual trust and respect is essential in the peace process in general. I, however, support a two-state solution for two peoples. As regards the proposed resolution, However, I must say that it is unbalanced, and if it remains unchanged, I will not be able to support it. Each coin has two sides and at least two pages are present in each process. Therefore, there can be not only one side to blame for everything, as this resolution seeks to portray. For me, as a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, it is also important how European money is spent. Unfortunately, NGOs are often present in this complex event, which also receive funding from the European budget, where there is a suspicion that they are doing things that are seriously damaging to the Middle East peace process, such as promoting anti-Semitism and calling for the destruction of Israel as a state.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I still believe it is very important that, once again, we declare our support for a two-state solution with an independent democratic Palestinian state living side-by-side with Israel and its other neighbours. At the same time, the security of Israel has to be guaranteed because Israel also represents a pillar of stability and democracy in the Middle East. I welcome the efforts of the UN Security Council, notably the initiative taken by France to resume peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians through a resolution setting a framework and a timetable for this process, and support the call for a comprehensive European Union peace initiative to be presented at an international peace conference. Our priority should be to ensure full respect for the rights of the people living in this area, whose personal safety and living conditions have been threatened for decades by conflicts in the Middle East, some of which remain ongoing.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, restoring peace in the Middle East is crucial both for the peoples of the region and for the European Union itself, because that is the only way to stop the huge flow of refugees flooding the Aegean islands and the rest of Europe. At the same time, the European Union must take steps to stop Ankara from facilitating the slave trade that is moving thousands of refugees from Syria to Greece. Mrs Mogherini, I would like to take this opportunity to inform you and the House that the Greek-born Spyros Huckabee, an officer of the Burundian Police, has been imprisoned since 27 June for refusing to murder demonstrators. His life is in danger and I ask for your immediate intervention for his release. According to a letter given to me by his lawyers, he was tortured for 10 days, and the conditions in the prison in which he is being held in Burundi are miserable. We are also aware of the continuing human rights violations in Burundi, which has been repeatedly condemned by European Parliament resolutions. Please for your intervention.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mrs Mogherini, I have a simple question: is the European Union ready for a new global initiative, let's call it Oslo II, because Oslo I has certainly given great hope? Are we ready to embark on one major diplomatic offensive, as you have already done on other occasions, on which I would of course like to congratulate you, and try to really open up one big new regional story for the Middle East? Do we have a partner in that? Do the countries with which we are otherwise partners in some big business want to be together with us and use their influence to make one new big step forward in the Middle East? And the question is, is there still a realistic possibility of creating two states, Israel and Palestine, which in my deep belief is the only correct solution, but the question is is it really still possible? I hope to get your answer.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, when a government segregates a part of the population, deprives it of its basic rights, blocks communications between its communities, prevents its access to many places, arbitrarily detains its members and strips it of its lands, is implementing a policy that has a well-known name: apartheid. This is what the State of Israel applies against the Palestinian population, with a very clear intention: to prevent the solution of the two States, which this Parliament has supported, from becoming a reality. The European Union is a key player in the area and has the capacity to be blunt in avoiding this policy. It can sanction and can also curb your investments. And it would do so in a legitimate way, because Israel violates international resolutions and continues to establish its colonies in the occupied territories. If we really bet on a two-state solution as the sole guarantor of peace and human rights, we must be courageous and show a unique and strong European voice, which unequivocally condemns Israeli apartheid policy. Mrs Mogherini, we are giving you our trust, but we also ask you for firmness. Thank you.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Union's indecision is producing a dangerous power vacuum in the Middle East, a well-known German newspaper predicted two and a half years ago. And today will reap the fruits of this disastrous foreign policy. The highlight is the sad record of some 4 million refugees from the Syrian conflict.  European foreign policy, unfortunately, has proved incapable of responding decisively to crises. And I do not blame Mrs Mogherini at all today. It is not to blame for these mistakes of the past. We made the mistake of setting standards for other states according to our European standards, interfering in domestic affairs, which ultimately led to the destabilisation of entire regions. We have created situations, or co-created, in which far more people are now suffering and dying than under previous regimes. Today, we must recognise how important the Middle East and the Middle East are for our own security and stability. Ladies and gentlemen, Europe will certainly not be taken seriously with such a foreign policy, we must make a different foreign policy here. I am really appealing to Mrs Mogherini here, otherwise what we are will remain a ridiculous number for our partners internationally.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, I have a couple of straightforward questions for Ms Mogherini, and I would appreciate straightforward answers. Firstly, to our knowledge as the European Union, who financially supports Islamic State? Secondly, in particular, who buys oil from Islamic State? Thirdly, what kind of concrete efforts has the European Union made so far to identify those states or companies who obviously commit crimes under international law, and what kind of efforts has the European Union made in order to bring them to justice? These are the questions which have to be answered in order not to see more shocking pictures of Syrian children dying in the sea.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, first of all let me say to the last two speakers that maybe they came into the Hemicycle at the wrong time, because we are discussing the peace process between Israel and Palestine. We were discussing the Syrian and migration issues this morning. Let me – even if it is not my role – maybe apologise to members of the public who are probably following this debate more closely than some of the Members of this Hemicycle. (Applause) Let me thank you all for the support that you are expressing for the European Union’s stand and action when it comes to the Middle East Peace Process. Let me thank you sincerely for that. I think that a united position of this Parliament is going to contribute in a way that, as some of you know very well, is important; some others might not imagine, but it is going to count a lot. Let me also say, as sincerely as I always try to be, that some of your expectations might need to be carefully looked at. I do not want to downsize any of the expectations, but the work is going to be long and very difficult. It is true that we have an opportunity, as the European Union, because on this issue we are more united than we believe. Even though we are facing multiple crises all around us, I have been discussing and working on this very same issue with the Foreign Ministers of all the 28 Member States for the last four meetings of the Foreign Affairs Council, and we have unanimous conclusions and different stands, different political views, different histories of the countries that are members of the European Union, but we have a united policy on the European Union’s role when it comes to the Middle East Peace Process. So I will put all my energy and determination, as I have been doing since the beginning of my mandate, into trying to, as I said, restart the engine of this process and avoid the vacuum that we have been facing now for more than one year.  However – and I would count on your support in doing this, and on our unity – results will be difficult and will take time, that is if we manage to get results. Maybe the first steps will be very limited results, or sometimes we will have negative results and then sometimes positive results. Difficult deals and agreements take time and patience. This is just because I have heard a lot of good luck messages. I take this with enthusiasm, as you know, but we have to be realistic about the fact that the starting point today is a very difficult one for us to be realistic on regarding the situation in front of us. I think Antonio Panzeri described it, taking the words of a former President in the best possible way. I see our role as trying to help the parties to find the tunnel at the end of which there is light, and at the same time keeping the light at the end of the tunnel alive, because this is not to be taken for granted. We have these two challenges, these two works, in my view, to do: helping the parties to come together and find the right way, because there is no alternative, no substitute for direct talks – we have to be very clear about that – and keeping the perspective of peace and of the two states, the perspective towards which we are working. Because yes, there are doubts in the international communities, in the parties themselves, that this perspective of the two-state solution and of the peace process is still there. Our work has to be focused on this. And new initiatives: given this framework, the picture is not rosy; it is not encouraging at all. I think our role is to build conditions to get to initiatives. We can always have big international conferences. What is difficult is to prepare the big initiatives and to make sure that these initiatives then have results. Conferences after conferences after conferences do not solve the problem. The real point is now trying to rebuild a modicum of trust and trying to put an agenda on the table that can allow the parties to take some steps forward instead of some steps back, which is exactly what is happening today: reverse the process. I am sorry, I did not want to give you a cold shower, but we are talking about something extremely ambitious and extremely difficult, even if we take these minimum goals in front of us, and obviously something that I referred to in my opening remarks: building this regional and international framework. I am really convinced that if we have one way of playing our role to the full, as Europeans in the Middle East Peace Process, it is in partnership with our partners in the region, starting from our Arab friends. Because here we have two different conflicts and crises: one is between the Palestinians and the Israelis, but the other one is between the Israelis and the Arab world at large, and you cannot imagine – or some of you imagine and know very well – that from the Far East to Latin America this is an issue that, if it is not solved, contributes to creating radicalisation and also hate. So we have a global responsibility that we can play with our global partners. Indeed, we do have an opportunity: the Iranian deal that we will discuss, hopefully, in a couple of hours gives us a little bit of credibility in the sense that it is something that shows that multilateralism and diplomacy can work and lead to results, and our unity also gives us a chance. It is also our consistency that gives us a chance to play a role. One of you mentioned something that it is very important to me, and I thank those who raised it, because I did not mention it at the beginning and I take the chance to do so now: our work with international organisations, and in particular with UNRWA. We faced a major crisis over the summer. UNRWA was clearly desperately saying that the danger of not re—opening the schools for Palestinian kids was very real, and it is thanks to the European Union’s additional financial support that we managed to avoid the situation whereby Palestinian children in the camps were not able to go to school at the beginning of the school year. We avoided this, and in this way made a very important contribution. This is also an important role that the European Union plays. I well remember saying to the Hemicycle the very first time we had a debate on the Middle East Peace Process that we have to be not only a payer but also a player. Continuing to be a payer is also relevant in the conditions we are facing. So this is something that we have to maintain. Some of you asked about the labelling. I can share with you what I shared with the ministers at the weekend. I recently asked the services of the Commission, in particular DG TRADE, to complete and finalise the work on the European guidelines. It is not a matter of taking new decisions – decisions were taken long ago – but a matter of implementing them in a European way. So there is no decision needed: it is an implementation thing that for me has to do primarily with transparency for our consumers. It is not a boycott. I know very well that there are different positions in this room about that. My institutional and political starting point is that this is a decision that we owe to our citizens and our consumers, because they have the right – and the legal right, according to our European rules – to know the origin of the products they buy or that they decide not to buy. It is a matter of transparency for me. Also because I believe – and we discussed this the last time we were here in this room discussing the peace process – that our role is to try to facilitate and to build bridges. This means, as one of you mentioned, not taking one side, even if we see the limits of both sides. Some of us see more the limits of one or the other or both. I think there is no one in this room who does not see any limit of any of the two parts. Still, our role – if you want to play a role – in re-starting the process and bringing it to some positive result is to build bridges, to build confidence, to engage and not to punish. This is my stand. This is something that we do in full respect and, as always, that is the basis for the European Union’s action in international and foreign policy, in full respect of, and compliance with, international law. That is why my reaction to every step forward that is taken on the settlement is always immediate, because this is something that we do not and could not recognise in international law. This is illegal – but boycotting is another story. I hope I was clear: it is a matter of transparency that we owe to our consumers. Let me finish by saying that in trying to have a role in bringing the parties together, the sense of unity that can come from this Parliament is essential, because again, if we are not able among us Europeans to find a unified vision of the Middle East Peace Process, how can we ask the parties in the conflict itself to find a common vision and how can we aspire to facilitate the mediation? Showing that we can find common ground – and I know that each of you has a particular point of view – gives us strength like nothing else. I would like to thank you for your support and for your expectations, even if I would ask you to keep them under control, especially regarding the timing. I would also encourage you to go forward in finding common ground, because this is also the basis for us to ask the parties to find common ground themselves.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Six motions for resolutions were sent to me to conclude the debate. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 10 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – The situation in the Middle East concerns Europe as a whole. The de-escalation of the conflict between Israel and Palestine and the resumption of credible peace efforts must occur as a matter of urgency. As such, I salute the two-state solution with regards to the 1967 borders and Jerusalem as the capital of both states. I would like to further welcome the recent steps taken by Israel to ease restrictions on Gaza. However, I condemn the rocket fire by militant groups into Israeli territory. It is vital for the EU to work with the Israeli, Palestinian, Egyptian and Jordanian authorities to prevent the re-arming of terrorists in the Gaza Strip. Achieving peace in the Middle East is a key priority for EU foreign policy and crucial for regional stability and security.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Belarus.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs – Madam President, first of all, thank you for having this issue on the agenda of today’s plenary. I very much appreciate your long-standing interest and our cooperation on this important neighbouring country. Let me start immediately with the latest and most relevant development, which we also discussed with the Foreign Ministers in our informal meeting a few days ago. The release of all political prisoners just two weeks ago represented a long-sought step that was also welcomed by this Parliament. Since the December 2010 post-election crackdown, we had consistently called for their release. Restrictive measures were imposed and our cooperation with the national authorities was put on the back burner by comparison with the other Eastern Partnership countries. It is important to ensure that all former political prisoners can exercise their full civil and political rights and, of course, that no new politically-motivated imprisonments take place. In response to the release of political prisoners and in the context of the October presidential elections – the conduct of which will be extremely important – we need to send a clear signal to Belarus. We wish to move towards a further improvement in our relations, based on mutually-encouraging steps. I started discussions on the prospects in this regard with the Foreign Ministers in our informal meeting in Luxembourg last Friday. Of course we realise that the situation has not changed in a systemic way. Belarus remains the only country in Europe to still apply the death penalty. Civil and political rights, such as freedom of association and assembly and freedom of expression and media, remain restricted. In addition, the country’s economic and financial situation is extremely difficult. Still, in this context and taking a step back, one can see that the European Union’s consistent policy of critical engagement over recent years has yielded some positive results and contributed to an improvement in EU-Belarus relations. After the very difficult period of 2011-2013, EU-Belarus relations have been improving since the start of 2014 and have intensified in 2015 in the form of a number of positive developments: pro-active participation by Belarus in the Eastern Partnership, the recent resumption of the human rights dialogue and the country’s constructive stance in the context of the crisis in Ukraine. As a result, several high-level visits to Belarus took place in the first six months of this year to build on these openings. It is also encouraging that Belarus has agreed to the deployment of a fully-fledged OSCE electoral observation mission and that this mission has so far been able to set up and operate without restrictions. Four hundred short-term observers are expected to be deployed. In January, in recognition of the opportunity to announce the European Union policy of critical engagement vis-a-vis Belarus, the Member States agreed a list of measures that could be implemented if the conditions were right. A number of these measures have already been activated, including the signing of an early-warning mechanism in the area of energy supply, the launch of negotiations on a mobility partnership, and promoting approximation by Belarus to the Bologna education principles. I am convinced that, in addition to reacting proportionately to new events in the country and, obviously, remaining true to our values of democracy and human rights, we should implement a longer-term strategy focused on building links between the European Union and Belarus and on supporting the reforms the people of Belarus need and want so much. In this respect I looked with great interest at the European Parliament delegation visit to Minsk last June – the first such visit since 2002, as far as I know – and noted that the Members of this Parliament came back with a mixed and yet rather positive message tending in the same direction: the call for keeping communication channels open, resuming dialogue and working closely together. For the first time since the end of 2010 it is possible to imagine more constructive relations between the European Union and Belarus, and I am convinced that it is worth seizing on this moment and embarking on a more positive agenda with one of the European Union’s immediate neighbours and a key country in the partnership. I am ready and willing to listen to the discussions today and to work with you along these lines.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Belarus is free of political prisoners, I do not know for how long, but that is a fact. Anyone who ignores this fact disregards the emotions of their families. I warn against this. But anyone who overestimates this fact too, committing another mistake – above all, a lack of context analysis. We should not be under any illusions or excessive expectations, because we will make a mistake of political naivety. On the other hand, it is a fact that, in the current situation of stability challenges in the region, it is our common interest to seek a way of normalising relations between the European Union and Belarus. Realism, combined with the lack of compromises on the fundamental, fundamental elements of European values, is also the most important thing for possible openings and new proposals for economic cooperation. The most important time will undoubtedly come immediately after the elections in Belarus. They, observed by an increased number of observers, as well as the period after them, will be the basis for possible next steps from the list of twenty-nine actions prepared, inter alia, by the High Representative. It is important that europe's possible financial involvement is linked to privatization processes – including business developments, macroeconomic reforms. The entry of education into the Bologna system or the improvement of phytosanitary control in the field of food research should be appreciated. But this is just the beginning of the proposed action. The resolution, which at the beginning of this session had to go through a vote allowing it to be successfully finaled, was already much more modest in the next phase, and in principle it was formed in harmony. I would now like to thank the entire Delegation of the European Parliament for belarus for their work during the first mission in Minsk, as well as to other people who work in other bodies and support my activity – Sandra Kalniete, Mrs Heidi Hautali, and Mr Jaromír Štětin. Thank you very much, because all these efforts are better and more efficient also thanks to their cooperation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, during the summer, members of the Delegation for Relations with Belarus made a historic visit to our eastern neighbour. The last official visit occurred more than 12 years ago. One can hope that it has indeed been viewed as a signal on the part of the European Parliament and the European Union as a whole that we are finally ready to pursue closer and stronger ties with the Republic of Belarus. Likewise, the recent pardons of opposition figures in Belarus a few weeks ago can also be viewed as a signal, this time on the part of our neighbours, that they, too, are ready and willing to overcome existing difficulties and advance further on the path of better mutual understanding and cooperation. We acknowledge the fact that these pardons were granted, not only two months following the delegation’s visit, but also two months before the upcoming general election in the Republic of Belarus. In this context, such a step could provide grounds for a more common position with regard to the level of democratic development in the Republic of Belarus, thereby lessening the degree of any misunderstanding in the wake of the elections. As Vice-Chair of the Delegation for Relations with Belarus I am very happy about this step, because it clearly shows the willingness of the Belarusian leadership to both reconcile its differences with the European Union and to gradually move towards closer cooperation. Finally, this step is also very important to me as an inhabitant of a neighbouring country and EU Member State, Latvia. While the economic and inter-societal aspects of the Latvian-Belarusian relationships are already strongly developed and are gradually advanced further and further, this release could provide a powerful stimulus for a closer political dialogue as well. During the last year, especially following the close engagement of the Republic of Belarus and the conclusion and implementation of the Minsk protocols, EU-Belarus relations have finally started to warm up. In recent decades, most, if not all, of these warm-ups, regretfully, have never been long term. Just as a long winter is always followed by a spring, one can hope that soon afterwards it might progress to summer. Unlike with nature, however, we as humans have all the necessary instruments to achieve a lasting long-term partnership with our Belarusian neighbours. Of course, while part of the responsibility for the shape our relations took almost 20 years ago lies with the Belarusian leadership, it was never a good idea to isolate Minsk, thus only alienating them further. So once again, please allow me to repeat myself: let these recent pardons mark the road towards a long-lasting partnership between the European Union and the Republic of Belarus for decades to come.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The first common interest of the European Union should be the independence and security of our countries, and this requires, above all in the East, at the eastern borders of the Union, the consolidating of the independence of the countries that have emerged east of us and the perpetuation of the geopolitical changes that followed the break-up of the Soviet Union. And this makes the issue of consolidating independence and the identity of the new Belarusian state a paramount issue. The Belarusian authorities should be judged on specifics, on independence in foreign policy, on the rise of political freedom, on the freedom of non-governmental organisations, on the development of religious life, in short after desowiesing. And as far as elections are concerned, this upcoming presidential election, I appeal – let us observe not only the course of the electoral act itself, but the whole election, that is, the election campaign. The Belarusian authorities should also know that freedom of expression of opposition party candidates will be essential for our assessment. But, of course, in perspective, we need to see this next election that will follow the presidential election, which is a more distant general election. Here, the main criterion for assessing the situation in Belarus should simply be the appearance of the opposition in parliament. And that's what we're waiting for.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the decision by Belarus to free the six political prisoners is good news. However, nothing new appears to be happening in Belarus. We have witnessed time and again the imprisonment of political activists and civil society representatives in Belarus. Then, when the political climate is bad enough, Belarus steps up and frees some prisoners in order to get a reward from the European Union. So on the one hand they release a few political prisoners, and on the other they arrest new ones. We need to see other measures taken that improve the state of democracy and civil liberties in Belarus. With the presidential elections approaching, there remain many areas that need to be improved. Belarusian opposition activists and civil society must be guaranteed freedom of speech and freedom of political rights. In order for the elections to be considered free and fair, the OSCE recommendation should be adopted and implemented. There must also be freedom of the media. The EU must find ways to enhance contact between the civil societies of the EU and Belarus, and we need to support civil society organisations. The facilitation of visa-free travel is very important. The launch of the visa facilitation talks in 2014 was a good start, but we need to take it further now. And last but not least, the abolition of the death penalty. We will continue to address this issue until its final abolition in Belarus. It is the only country in Europe that still has the death penalty as a punishment. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – I note that the six political prisoners freed have not had their full civil rights restored. So, for example, if they wished to stand as opposition candidates of the current authority in Belarus, they would not be permitted to do so. In your view, is lifting that condition a prerequisite for free and fair presidential elections in Belarus?

name: Urmas PAET
text: blue-card answer. –  If it really happens and all these people’s civil and citizens’ rights are restored, then it is a step in the right direction. But there are lots of other issues, and we cannot yet be satisfied with Belarus. I mentioned some of them; there are more. The level of human rights, the rule of law and democracy are not where they should be.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, there is no doubt that the release of six political prisoners is a positive gesture, as colleagues from different groups have already said. It is probably the case that the so-called critical, constructive approach of the Commission and the External Action Service has been good, but now we have to say that we must make steady progress on certain concrete cooperation initiatives in order to see whether Belarus is really ready for democracy. Above all, the forthcoming elections will be a test because, as we all remember, after the 2010 elections, the regime very brutally crushed the opposition. It's happening at the moment, too. We must not turn a blind eye to the fact that the opposition is still being disturbed. When we visited Minsk in June with the delegation led by Mr Zdrojewski, we heard how the Vice-President of the Electoral Commission openly despised members of the opposition and declared that they were inegoable from joining the electoral committees. I would also like to refer to areas of cooperation that I consider essential when the Commission and the External Action Service are planning programmes. The independence of the judiciary is a key issue which I believe should be promoted through concrete cooperation. We have largely focused on supporting the opposition and civil society, but we could also examine whether the authorities would be prepared for residents, people, citizens to be more involved in local decision-making. This is an area referred to by the EU delegation as a promising initiative that could be focused on. Finally, Mr President, Belarus and Azerbaijan are both members of the Euronest Assembly, but if we compare the situation, then there is a terrible repression going on in Azerbaijan, which is much worse than ... (The President interrupted the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8)).

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. I know that you are very keen about ensuring that democracy is complete. My question is a ‘what if’: what if you find the democracy is complete – full and fair elections – everything is as you wish, but then the democratically elected government still wishes to maintain, as part of its mandate, the death penalty? What would the position be then with the democratic government, with the people having voted on the issue? What would you do then, or would you recommend?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for very much for this question. My answer to your clear question is clear: I think we have to consider the abolition of the death penalty as a priority and we should not compromise on that, and I hope that your party’s group will come to the same conclusion.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I cannot give the Congresswoman another blue card opportunity, because we are past the timeframe. I would like to make useful use of the available framework. My fellow Members, please understand that I can only accept a blue card comment from a Member.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which I was in Minsk in July of this year, and I get the impression here that it would certainly not hurt some Colleagues if they did it once. I met there with various representatives from politics and business. What we perceive on the ground above all is a great deal of uncertainty. The uncertainty is not only already given by the geographical location of this country, but the uncertainty goes in different directions. One is towards the large neighbour to the east, which is one of the largest economic partners and, as we know, is not always easy to assess. On the other hand, great uncertainty also with the neighbour in the West, which, controlled by others, has partly put itself in a situation that is worrying and is already doing more harm to itself than anyone else with the sanctions. The situation on the ground is therefore not easy for the political leaders in Minsk. I can tell you one thing: during my visit, it turned out that the doors in Belarus were wide open. In any case, as the High Representative has already said today, I welcome our rapprochement with Belarus and the opening of dialogue with this very important country at such an important key point on this continent. Other countries should follow suit.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: blue-card answer. – This year I visited Minsk twice, and that is why I welcome with particular feeling the release of political prisoners in Belarus, as well as Belarus’s involvement in attempts to stop Russia’s hybrid war against Ukraine. These steps, along with a fair campaign and fair elections, should lead to an upgrade of the dialogue between the EU and Belarus. If the OSCE observers give a positive assessment of the Presidential elections, the EU should review its sanctions. I am not so naive as to believe that President Lukashenko has been taking these steps out of a sudden change of heart. It is entirely possible that it is just a cold, political calculation. It is a fact that Belarus continues to depend economically on Russia’s subsidies, President Lukashenko is willing to enhance military cooperation with Russia, possibly for the sake of avoiding any unpleasant hybrid surprises for Belarus. But we should also listen to those pro-European actors in Belarusian society who encourage the European institutions to give positive feedback to the recent developments in Belarus and who say that the EU should interact more with Belarusian society at large through education, technical cooperation exchanges and so on, rather than just hoping that Lukashenko will fall. At the same time, the EU should continue its policy of critical engagement, and we all have to make it clear to the Belarusian authorities that the normalisation of relations with Europe depends on the advancement of democracy in Belarus. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. Madam, you had a very interesting start to the speech, in which you stressed the need for the European Union to get closer to Belarus, which I believe, in order to perhaps in the long run also promote a rapprochement with Russia. At the end of your speech, I discerned a reluctance: you said that perhaps in Belarus, it was better to encourage, as I understand it, elements closer to the European Union than to Russia. Is there not a contradiction? I did not get it right. Personally, I prefer the first part of your speech, which was about the rapprochement with Belarus to favour the one with Russia.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: "blue card" answer. Mr. Lebreton, I have the impression that my intervention has been mishandled by interpretation. Yes, I am in support of a rapprochement, but only if the OSCE mission certifies that the presidential election was conducted according to the standards of that organization.  I am in for dialogue and engagement with Belarus but on the basis of our principles in the Union.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, I was an observer in the presidential elections, but also in the mass protests in December 2010, when thousands of people protested in Minsk against the faking of the presidential election. The most prominent opposition leaders have been arrested and convicted. Indeed, six known political prisoners have recently been released, but arrests of graffiti authors are immediately frequent in Minsk, so it is premature to talk about the irreversible loosening of the dictatorship. There will be presidential elections in Belarus on October 11th, but it is already almost reliably known who will be their winner. Opportunity connoisseurs believe that President Lukashnchenko is likely to demand that the result of the elections be recognised and that the West lift his sanctions. Indeed, how realistic is the prospect of Europe's longest-serving dictator becoming a little bit of a partner of the European Union in the turbulent area of the eastern neighbourhood. The European and Belarusian oppositions remain fragmented and paralysed. The country has become a sideshow to the Russian crisis. Nevertheless, I support a return to dialogue because the alternative is unclear.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, having already passed the 20-year mark in office, Lukashenko will no doubt do whatever it takes next month in the elections to win his sixth mandate as President. Lukashenko has been a key ally in Putin’s expansionist plans for Russia and has led Belarus to becoming one of the founding members of the Eurasian Union. The crisis in Ukraine has confirmed the true level of Putin’s ambitions, and those ambitions were confirmed not just to EU Member States but also to Belarus and Kazakhstan. The EU should, of course, be open to a new political direction for Belarus, and we must leave the door ajar diplomatically. We should not, however, lull ourselves into the false pretence that Lukashenko is a democrat or interested in anything other than achieving his own political survival. As the report suggests, the fighting in Ukraine is now at its lowest level, and we must thank the Minsk agreement – in part brokered by him – as a way of beginning the process of ensuring lasting peace in Ukraine. But Ukraine needs more military and financial support in order to stabilise and ensure that the peace is permanent. Furthermore, whilst I welcome the release of political prisoners, such gestures do little to alleviate the chronic civil and human rights abuses in Belarus. I remember that 10 years ago I called Belarus the Cuba of Europe, and I am afraid it still remains that today.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, it is now 21 years since Alexander Lukashenko came to power, having been so-called freely and democratically elected. We in Europe seem to be rather tired of trying to find a solution to how to help the people of Belarus more effectively. Over this period of time we have tested many things, starting from sanctions, travel restrictions and asset freezing and ending with re-engagement or critical dialogue, which seems to be the case at the moment. I must say very openly that I do not believe in Lukashenko starting to behave in a way which is different from that which we have already observed. Playing politics of promises and lies is not our style and we should not take part in such games. Yes, today we welcome the release of six political prisoners, but those freed have not been rehabilitated, contrary to our demands. Yes, there will be so-called elections in Belarus very soon, but the country’s electoral code has never been reformed, contrary to our expectations. So we are going to see one more re-election of Mr Lukashenko, with no votes counted at the polling stations and no independent observers allowed to prove it. Yes, Belarus has been hosting negotiations trying to end the war against Ukraine, but at same time, Belarus voted against the UN resolution on 27 March 2014. Let us wait for the coming elections before we make any major decisions about Belarus.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on 11 October a presidential election will be held in Belarus. In 1995 and 1996, the country chose by referendum the path of union with Russia. The European Union has since put in place a sanctions regime that is constantly aggravated after each election to make Belarus pay for its pro-Russian choice. The lifting of sanctions against 26 Belarusian officials and the release of opposition activists by the Minsk authorities are, admittedly belated but positive, steps in the direction of unblocking diplomatic relations between the Eu States and that country. This is to be emphasized and we must move forward.  It would be, I fear, a grave mistake, shared by your services Commissioner, to hope to take advantage of this situation to put Belarus in a pro-Western policy seeking to further divide Europe. It is a comprehensive dialogue between the European Union, its states and the eurasian Union states that must be put in place.  Finally, it is worth noting the extremely positive role of President Lukashenko in all matters relating to the Minsk agreements.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Madam President, we all know how politics before elections can control us with the excitement, the excitement of an Olympian. We do things we wouldn't do any other time. We're tethering with energy, ideas and promises. And that is what just happened to Belarusian President Lukashenko a few weeks before the presidential election on October 11. He abruptly released most political prisoners, including prominent ones. While we consider his gesture to be a step in the right direction, we have no doubt that it is a pre-election tingling to persuade the international community to gradually turn into a democrat. The state continues to intimidate human rights defenders. The state affects journalists working for foreign media without accreditation. Released political prisoners are not fully rehabilitated and their release is not unconditional in all cases. Our resolution calls for presidential elections to be conducted in accordance with international standards, including full access by opposition presidential candidates to state media.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Madam President, I think we have a well-balanced resolution on the table. On the one hand, we should also positively reflect on the fact that the government of Belarus released six political prisoners this August. Indeed, it is good news that the former presidential candidate Statkevich and others have been set free. However, I am afraid that it has more to do with the upcoming October elections than with any substantial changes in the government’s approach to human rights and political freedom. So far there have been only limited modifications of legal codes, which are used by the regime to oppress media freedom as well as the activities of civil society and political opposition. We have to express more support for NGOs which are calling for concrete action and legislative changes on the side of the Belarusian Government.
