At the same time, and in closer cooperation especially, any financial assistance should be granted only after serious political efforts are made.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, while we can only regret seeing the European Union take its position of systematic hostility to the Russian Federation, we must welcome the improvement in our relations with Belarus. It was time, especially after Minsk's efforts to secure a lasting ceasefire in Ukraine. So, please, do not make the same mistake as with Ukraine. Yes, let us get closer to Belarus but do not try to distance it from its Russian neighbour. Belarus can and must fulfil the role that was Ukraine before the crisis: a bridge, a link between the Russian Federation and the European nations.  Indeed, at a time when Europe is facing the immense challenge of pouring millions of so-called refugees into our soil, it is essential that the whole of our continent finally stop tearing each other apart. The reality of this outburst goes beyond the fiction imagined by Jean Raspail in his prophetic book The Camp of saints. So let's cease to divide us or the whole old continent will descend into chaos.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: A journalist dared, some time ago, to ask Alexandr Lukashenko if, in his opinion, he had too much power. Lukashenko, who changed the Constitution more than a decade ago to run whenever he wished for the presidency of Belarus, replied that he did indeed have a lot of power, but that it is necessary to save the country from anarchy and banditry. He went on to explain that the main force of the regime he leads is stability. That is precisely the problem: the stability that Lukashenko is talking about has an enormous price: freedom of expression, freedom of the press, freedom of association. Anyone who dares to oppose it is treated with violence and repression. I recall that of the nine challengers in the 2010 presidential election, seven ended up in prison. They were accused of organizing a mass disturbance - that is the precise expression used. They were, in fact, protesting, along with tens of thousands of other people, against the results of the presidential vote, as the OSCE had already stated that the vote in question was far from meeting minimum international standards. Five years later, we see, Lukashenko wants to be re-elected in order to continue to ensure the stability that was earlier. The means remain the same. Nikolaevich, the former presidential candidate of the country, a well-known opposition figure, was arrested just yesterday when he was returning to Belarus after four years of exile. The elections that are coming, unfortunately, have a taste of déjà vu, as I think those in the neighbouring country will be, because Putin has also announced his interest in staying in the country's presidency, also for stability.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: –  Madam President, the latest release of political prisoners by the authorities in Belarus represents a crucial step for relations between the EU and this country. Today the Belarusian people still suffer important violations to their human rights and fundamental freedoms. Civic and political rights are often the target of repression. Freedom of expression and freedom of the media are sadly challenged. The opposition remains secluded, at the very margins of the political process. In a few weeks Belarus will hold presidential elections, which represent a unique opportunity to show the way – a new path. These elections, if free and fair, may indeed bring the EU and Belarus closer. But, most importantly, these elections will be a test for democracy in Belarus, a test for the authorities to show their genuine and unconditional commitment to the rights, needs and demands of the people of Belarus. This opportunity must not be missed.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Belarus is one of the last islands of authoritarianism in Europe. It is very, indeed, very unlikely that this situation will change in the short term. President Lukashenko's position in the country is very strong, decisive, it can almost be said to be omnipot of omnipottive. However, we should also be open to gestures of goodwill that will encourage Belarus to open up more broadly. The events of recent months, that is, the release of some political prisoners, are one of the main indicators of gradual change. The signals that have been coming from this country in recent weeks need to be read with the utmost care. However, we should definitely notice them and welcome them as a step in the right direction. Therefore, these first gestures should not go unanswered by the European Union. We should look and realistically assess the possibilities of removing some of the restrictive measures that have been applied to Belarus in recent years. And this should be done before the presidential elections in October this year in Belarus. Ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to mention that I am also rapporteur for the European Neighbourhood Policy. I would like the gradual relaxation of the regime in Belarus to translate into its full participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy. Belarus is undeniably a European country, it is indeed time to see Belarus with European, democratic values.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Jens NILSSON
text: question ("blue card"). "It's natural that we talk about the choice that is to come and that we are critical and question whether it will be fair. It's good that we're talking about the prisoners who are released. In the long term, however, we must have a strategy, and I think that support for civil society should be included in that strategy. The question is whether, as rapporteur for the neighbourhood programme, you also think that one of the EU's greatest tasks with regard to Belarus should be to strengthen civil society.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: blue-card answer. – Definitely, yes, we should strengthen civil society in Belarus. But we should be fully aware of the complexity and sensitivity of the situation, and we should strengthen the real civil society, not Lukashenko’s regime. I am emphasising this because it is not so easy, and we should really have a strategy based on a deep analysis of the real situation in the country.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear High Representative, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear! Nikolai Statkiewicz, Nikolai Dziadok, Igor Oliniewicz, Yuri Rubkov, Yevgeny Waśkowicz, Artiom Prokopienko – these are the names of political prisoners who served sentences in Belarusian prisons under various pretexts. Nikolai Statkiewicz, the opposition presidential candidate, has spent five of the six years he was sentenced to. To this group should be added Alesia Michalewicza, who two days ago, returning after a dozen years in exile, was arrested and fortunately released on the same day. It is undoubtedly a breakthrough that political prisoners have been released, but we also know that they have not been rehabilitated. They are freed, but they are not free. They are under constant police monitoring, have limited civil rights.   Some in this Chamber remember what happened after the previous elections in Belarus, when many opposition activists were arrested or re-arrested shortly after what would seem to be a normalisation of relations with the European Union. No one wants a replay of this story and the next game of appearances. Although we have clear signs of warming (because both the release of political prisoners and, until recently, the first official visit by the European Parliament delegation to Belarus in many years with the official agenda of meetings with both the Senate government and representatives of civil society and the opposition are evidence of warming), this will not automatically trigger a re-normalisation of relations between the Union and Belarus. Further steps are needed – achievable. This needs to be built on the bridges referred to by the High Representative. After all, potential cooperation between the European Union and Belarus would be mutually beneficial, and the conditions placed by the European Union do not require money, but a political decision, greater openness in the crucial area of respect for human and citizen rights for the European Union.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Madam President, let me update on how the situation in Belarus is being relaxed. On Monday, opposition candidate from last year's presidential election, Aleś Mihaljevich, was arrested in Belarus. He spent four years outside his homeland, the Czech Republic granted him asylum. He was coming back because of a more liberal approach, with other candidates being fired. Mr Mihaljevich was released after a few hours, but his trial is still not over. The news that is coming to us so far informs a worrying development in the run-up to the next election. Opposition parties can participate in controlling the counting of votes in less than half a percent of districts. Media coverage of the election also seems to us to be worrying. For example, the list of all presidential candidates in the media was published only twelve times, and on one hundred and eighteen websites there was no information on groups collecting signatures for presidential candidates other than Alexander Lukashenko. And the broadcast, which was the content of President Lukashenko's activities, takes up an average of seventy-five percent of the airtime.  Given this information, it is to be feared that the elections will be held as they have been in the past. And as a member of a country that in the past, twenty-five years ago, still experienced a similar fear, non-freedom, I intercede for the European Union to be very fundamentally active in transforming Belarus into a democratic country.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to comment in this debate, because Belarus is a very close country for us, which borders the EU. In October this year there will be presidential elections again in Belarus. And a president with dictatorial tendencies probably didn't surprise anyone when he announced that he would run for office again. Belarus's president would thus have spent almost a quarter of a century in office. I don't think he's going to make up for Fidel Castro. It would be a smile if there was nothing behind all this but repression and restrictions on political opponents, journalists and civil society. The very preparation for the presidential election raises concerns about undemocratic practices and shows that the elections will be manipulated again. There is growing pressure on candidates in elections and people collecting signatures for their candidacy. As my previous spokesman has already said, a few days ago, former presidential candidate Aleś Mihaljevich, who was granted asylum in my country, the Czech Republic, was arrested in 2011. Yet there are also positive signs that give us hope. Belarus is a country that is slowly opening up to Europe under the influence of the Ukrainian crisis and other factors. We have also seen some positive progress in the field of education, for example. Belarus recently signed up to the Bologna process. This will help universities and especially students and as a result of the development of the whole society. I am proud to come from a country that, thanks to President Havel, has always been very committed to helping Belarus. I believe that this country will gradually become a country belonging to the family of countries of the European Union. That is why we need to support the resolution that we are about to approve.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam Vice-President, Respected High Representative Mogherini, thank you for your statement. I think that we have all prepared a quality resolution on the situation in Belarus today, where we are all aware that a few weeks before the new presidential elections, the result is practically known in advance, because we see that the process of democratization and transition is more than slow in this European country, which from a series of presentations of our colleagues represents a kind of anachronism. Nevertheless, after the visit of the delegation in charge of Belarus led by our colleague Zdrojewski, after more than thirteen years we can record some progress by the European Parliament, a shift in the dialogue on the issue of human rights protection, and of course we positively view the release of political prisoners as a signal for the better. However, this should not be a one-off move, but we expect it to continue and that this process of gradual evolution of the situation and regime in Belarus has its better and European standard. I also believe that the Commission needs to think about the possibility of sectoral cooperation, in particular one that is not strict sensu related to meeting political criteria, that we influence young people, that we influence the media scene and of course help the Belarusian opposition in this regard. I would recall a meeting of the Euronest Assembly a few months ago in Yereen, in which representatives of the Belarusian opposition participated and I saw this as one positive step. As head of the Delegation to Ukraine, I believe that this kind of role of Belarus as a certain international mediator is important, but it would also be good if the situation in Ukraine was presented objectively, not that it is influenced by Russian propaganda and that in some way the situation in Ukraine helps democratization in Belarus. The existence of the death penalty, the execution of the death penalty is reprehensible and therefore I hope that our human rights dialogue will also lead to the acceptance of global and European standards on the protection of human rights and of course the abolition of the death penalty.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, In my short speech, I want to join my Czech colleagues, The High Commissioner, who reported on the case of Aleś Mihaljevich, who was a candidate in the elections in Belarus and who was granted asylum in the Czech Republic in 2011. I remember very much this case, it was our government that granted political asylum to this candidate for President of Belarus at the time. At the time, he testified how he had been imprisoned in Belarus, how he had been tortured, how he had indeed been subjected to inhuman treatment, and after now believing that there was political warming in Belarus, he had returned to that country. As my colleagues in the Czech Republic have already told you, he was immediately detained at the border and questioned and is further charged. I therefore ask you very much to perceive this case of this human rights campaigner and, in the event of any negotiations, to mention his name. He deserves our support.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome the progress achieved by Belarus in the areas of higher education, vocational training, the digital market, the energy sector and food safety, among others, that will most certainly lead to increased cooperation between Belarus and Europe. I also have to praise the role Belarus played in facilitating negotiations between Russia and Ukraine. However, I remain concerned by the continued prejudice against human rights and fundamental freedoms, the serious shortcomings observed during previous elections by independent international observers in Belarus, and the lack of an effective rule of law. I believe the Commission should support, through financial and political means, the efforts and democratic aspirations of Belarusian civil society, independent media and non-governmental organisations in Belarus, while leading the country towards more respect for democratic principles, human rights and the rule of law. To define the situation in a few words, I could say: stability within a complex authoritarian regime.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, there is no doubt that positive changes are being seen in Belarus. However, on the other hand, these positive shifts should not give us too much hope that there will actually be more radical changes, because objectively it is very difficult to believe that Lukashnchenko will change a lot. However, I am convinced that any opening in Belarus due to the overall context of the Eastern Partnership and all that we know is happening in the east of our continent should be welcomed. And of course, belarusians should be encouraged to think about their future within the European Union. This process will be long, as with the Countries of the Western Balkans, perhaps even longer. But, on the other hand, the alternative is just an embrace of Russia or maybe something else, a fourth. So I am convinced that the policy you want to implement in Belarus is a step-by-step policy and I hope that this policy will give a good result in the near future.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not deny that the human rights situation in Belarus gives me the deepest concern. Despite the release of the political prisoners so far detained, former candidates even in part in the previous presidential elections, the situation remains quite worrying and dramatic. On the one hand, for the freedom of expression of the independent media, which are always in great difficulty, especially because of the abuses in Article 2 of the Administrative Code – if I remember correctly – on the other hand, not least because intimidation continues and we will probably see yet another farce electoral process.  This must not, however, lead us to try to make the same mistakes again as we did in the past with Ukraine; we should develop a strong approach, yes, of cooperation and conditionality towards Ukraine in order to ensure that the situation improves over time, we actually get concrete and factual progress, but without putting the Belarusians back on the wall against the wall in the face of an hamlet choice between us and Russia, we have seen what this has led to in the Ukrainian crisis and I sincerely think that we should learn from our past mistakes.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, I will be very brief, because for me this session was mainly a good chance to listen, to take note and to make sure that Parliament’s thoughts about the way forward for our relationship with Belarus are fully incorporated and included at this stage of reflection. So I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for their contributions, especially those encouraging more cooperation between the European Union and Belarus at all levels. I think this is the first time since the end of 2010 that we have had the opportunity to engage on a more positive agenda in this regard. I agree with the president of the delegation who said that the approach to Belarus should be holistic and not limited to our policy on sanctions. Indeed, several of the 29 steps could be activated, including in the economic field. Finally, as indicated, we are considering, together with the 28 Member States, the way ahead in response to the release of the prisoners. Our response will need to be proportionate and adequate, taking account of timing and sequencing. You all pointed out the pros and cons, the question of timing, and the difficult challenges still ahead of us. At the same time, we agree that there is a window of opportunity now that should not be missed. So the question is how to do it in the smartest, most positive and most productive way. Obviously I believe any EU response has to be, and will be, accompanied by steps to increase cooperation. I am sure that we will be able to continue our work together in this direction, looking very closely at what happens in the coming weeks, especially in view of the upcoming elections.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123 of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote is scheduled for tomorrow, Thursday, at 12.00 p.m.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the nuclear agreement with Iran.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vicepresidente della Commissione. – Grazie Presidente, mi piacciono queste giornate, dalla mattina alla sera in Parlamento, mi mancavano dall'Italia! Mr President, let me first of all say that I am very glad we are finally taking one of the most important points. I was surprised, I was looking back at my presence in the Parliament – you know I am coming often – but this is the first time we discuss Iran. I am glad to do so after we reached the agreement and also after a visit of a delegation from our Parliament to Tehran.  Let me start by saying that it was an honour for me to represent the European Union in the negotiations and in the signing of the deal we reached on 14 July in Vienna with Iran. As many have said the moment was really an historic one. We should all be proud of what we have achieved, also because we have achieved that together, showing unity, unity of purpose, unity of method and we did this while we were negotiating at the signing and also in the follow up, this first months of the follow-up, of the agreement. The deal has put an end to years of negotiations aimed at securing a comprehensive long lasting solution to the Iranian nuclear issue and it has also put an end to decades of tensions and distrust.  What we achieved in Vienna is a victory of diplomacy, of multilateralism and, I think in this respect, is also a victory of the European Union. And it is a good deal the one that we reached. First of all we would have not accepted a deal that was not good. It is a strong, durable and verifiable deal because we know very well trust is important but agreements of this nature are not and cannot be built on trust, they are built on things that are verifiable, and written in all details in the agreement. It took so much time, it took so much energy also because we wanted the agreement itself, the text and the annexes themselves to be as detailed as possible in order not to leave space for interpretation or disputes in the implementation phase and in the follow-up.  I said it is not based on trust but it is an agreement that while it starts to be implemented can open the way to build trust and this is the bet we are doing, that implementing the deal will also help building trust, trust within the region and within the international community, I would come to that at the end, but also trust as I said and confidence in something very rare and something very precious, which is again the fact that diplomacy, multilateralism, negotiations can lead to results. In fact we prevented probably, most probably, we prevented a crisis or a major conflict through our action.  So that is why I was so proud that the European Union was able to facilitate and to lead to a positive result in this negotiation. Indeed it was also important, it is also important because it is hard, very hard, to think not only in the recent years, but especially now with the security situation we have all around the European Union and in the globe. Difficult to imagine any other moment in history when all the world powers be them Europeans, US, Russia, China, acted in such close cooperation in addressing a common challenge, recognizing a common interest of the international community and being able to act together. The European Union, as you know, played a crucial role. First of all as a facilitator of the talks but also, and let me praise our staff, our excellent people for that, as a pen holder of the agreement and of all the technical annexes to that. Sometimes we refer to the European bureaucrats, well it is thanks to our people, experienced, very knowledgeable about even tiny technical details of nuclear programmes, if we were able, as Europeans, as European Union, to indeed write concretely all the details of the annexes. I was proud of my team, I was proud of our European team. (Applause) Yes you can clap because they deserve that, they deserve that and indeed thank you because I am very happy and it is nice when my personal role is recognised but I always say this was a team work, not only with our partners in the international community, this was also a team work of our staff, and really our people did an excellent job, staying in the same sometimes closed rooms for months, months literally, working on papers, days and nights. So thank you for thanking them with me, they really deserve it. Now we come to the critical phase. We will keep, I will keep personally, a crucial role for the phase of the implementation as I would stay as a coordinator of the Joint Commission overseeing the implementation of the GCBOA. Implementing the agreement effectively is critical. The UN Security Council endorsed the agreement as you know on 20 July through resolution 2231 and this very same day, in the Foreign Affairs Council, we had a unanimous endorsement by the Foreign Affairs Ministers. We started as the European Union preparations for our own legal measures necessary for lifting the sanctions and we look forward to a positive conclusion of the parliamentary reviews. As Iran will start implementing its nuclear commitments after the reviews will be finished, EU, UN and US economic and financial sanctions will be lifted upon verification of the IAA, and let me also say that our cooperation with the IAA was excellent and also was a way of strengthening, which is something, sometimes we say, but it is difficult then to do, to empower an important agency to do their work, and cooperation in that respect was really excellent. Very importantly going back to sanctions, sanctions lifting will be subject to snap back in case of violation of the agreements. So far I have to say we have very encouraging signs. Iran has complied with the road map agreed with the IAA and has submitted the requested information regarding the outstanding issues we had. Now we need to keep in mind that the current process remains very sensitive. We will keep focusing on the implementation of the agreement and this is something not only that I underline, but this is the main reason for my visit in Tehran, just 14 days after the deal was signed. I stressed in the Tehran meeting with the President Rouhani, with Foreign Minister Zarif, we were missing each other after having spent so much time together in Vienna all of us, but also with the president of the parliament that I know has kept a very positive and constructive memory of her visit there. I stress that the successful and speedy implementation of the deal is key. The deal is signed but it enters into the real elements, into the real force, once we start and especially once Iran starts implementing it. Implementation phase will be key because it is the key to open the doors towards a renewed engagement between the European Union, its institutions, and its Member States and Iran. That is very clear to me that the majority of the work of re-engaging, restarting bilateral relations will be with the European Union. Out of all the partners sitting around the table we are clearly the ones that for history, for geography, for economy, for interest in the common region we share which is the Middle East, have a clear agenda of interest of exploring ways of working with Iran, as difficult as it can be also on the way ahead. During my visit, we also identified with the Iranian authorities areas of common interest, on which a possible cooperation can start in the months to come in parallel with implementation. Trade, energy, environment, technology, aviation safety but also terrorism and regional issues, and obviously human rights, we agreed the following steps. First we will start an informal political dialogue, starting from senior official level to further explore areas of potential cooperation and elaborate possible details. Second, we will look into the possibility of a European Union presence in Tehran once the agreement has come into effect. This process requires all European Union institutions to work in a coherent way. For these reasons I have created a common joint Iran task force bringing together services from the Commission and DS (???) that will serve, that has started already to work, to serve as the interface one to ensure the necessary level of coordination in the European Union site. But as we discussed also this morning and also with the President of the Commission, the agreement opens some new opportunities for a different, more cooperative regional framework, and I believe this is really what is going to be more relevant for us. It can open the way to a new way of addressing the crisis in Syria, first of all in Syria. And let me also say that I will discuss also this possible developments tomorrow with Zafandemistura (???) in Brussels, but also in Yemen and in Iraq and in Lebanon, and so on. Maybe this could be a way of allowing us to bring different parties together with a different perspective. The perspective that managed to bring a result to the negotiations on the nuclear programme of Iran, which is the win-win approach. Different parties around the table brought together by either a common interest or a common threat they have to face together and many of you referred to the need to face together joining forces the threat of Daesh in a more coherent way. Well, I believe that if we managed to start implementation of the deal, to start developing new relations based not from today to tomorrow, it will take time, but based on some degree of mutual interests and mutual trust, we could also find more effective ways of facing the challenges we have in the region. This will not happen overnight. That is clear, but let me say that's the issue of building a more cooperative framework in the region, in the Middle East, is the interest of all. A more cooperative Middle East would mean first of all an increased dialogue between Sunni and Shia forces and this would be the real nightmare for Daesh - uniting forces on the ground, uniting forces of differences, and obviously facing their messages of sectarianism and hate that can only grow, flourish on divisions. At the same time let me stress and finish with that because I believe it is important in itself for us Europeans, the deal with Iran it is important for all these different political reasons I am stressing but it is first of all important because it is a milestone for regional and global non-proliferation. It is first of all a non-proliferation agreement. It is first of all a security agreement. We have been focusing very much on the political meaning of it but the concrete outcome, first outcome of the agreement, is a security and a non-proliferation one. It can strengthen and it strengthens the non-proliferation treaty and could create momentum towards a full ratification of the nuclear test ban treaty. The deal reached in Vienna can also promote disarmament globally and it can foster progress towards the Middle East weapons of mass destruction free zone that as you know, has always been very much supported by all of us in the European Union institutions and Member States from the very beginning. It is obviously a very ambitious goal, but the non-proliferation and disarmament agenda when it comes to the nuclear weapons is an agenda on which I know I find in this Parliament a partner on which I can count and as much as you can count on my personal commitment to that. So to sum up, because we are late, as usual, let me say that I was proud of representing the European Union there because I believe that that was really the way of serving our face our best face of international engagement, which is that of serving peace and stability and let me say that thanks to the efforts of many, of many, we served the EU interests and the interests of the global community at the same time and we showed, I believe, the European Union at its best. (Applause)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, High Representative, I would like to start by welcoming the agreement of 14 July on the Iranian nuclear issue and personally congratulate you on your commitment to facilitating this agreement.  After more than a decade of negotiations, the agreement reached by the partners and Iran finally offers hope of providing a lasting solution to this issue and replacing confrontation and mistrust with cooperation for good. But to do that, we cannot rest on our laurels. The agreement aims to cut off Iran's access routes to the fissile material needed for nuclear weapons and provides for a system of inspection and transparency needed to verify the implementation of the agreement. The key, as you pointed out, is implementation.  The lifting of economic and financial sanctions against Iran will only be possible if the International Atomic Energy Agency sees the implementation of the commitments made in the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan. I would add that implementation is also a challenge for our European diplomacy, for the diplomacy you lead, given the recognised role of the European Union in this agreement and I am glad that you have pointed this out and highlighted this during our meeting today. At the same time, I think we need to start looking beyond this agreement and see how we can move forward on other contentious issues that still mark our relationship with Iran. First of all, within the country itself, I recall that President Rohani has also made a number of promises on the human rights situation in that country and perhaps it would be worth recalling. Finally, we must look at this agreement from the broader perspective of our goal of seeking peace and stability in the Middle East. I would like to express here the hope that the Iran nuclear agreement will also have an impact, first and foremost, on the Iranian crisis, but also on Yemen tomorrow, and that we will have real cooperation as a result of this historic agreement.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, no one wants self-congratulation when the challenges we face are so serious, but the Iranian nuclear deal was a notable European achievement – personally for the High Representative, for her predecessor and for their team.  In the last week, some would think that the only importance was the reaction inside the US Congress, but today’s debate demonstrates European support for a European deal. We should not be deflected in developing our own European strategy to follow up its implementation. Europe expects Iran to keep its promises, but we have to show we will be a reliable partner in keeping our own promises in return.  We have heard from the High Representative about the setting-up of the interinstitutional task force and I would like to ask her about the Parliament’s role in that task force in helping bring forward a new era of cooperation ranging from energy to education to the environment, as she outlines. We endorsed the proposal for the opening of an EU delegation in Tehran. But Europe is not, and will not, be uncritical. Europe’s response can and must strengthen reformists within Iran. We will criticise the death penalty, but when 80% of the executions are drug-related – and the Iranians told us themselves that their policies in combating drugs are failing – surely EU cooperation in the fight against drugs can have some real influence.  Similarly, we have a difficult but essential job to engage Iran in the fight against ISIS and in resolving the conflicts within the region, thus dealing with the causes of today’s migrant crisis, not just its symptoms. But today America is talking to the Russians and the Russians are talking to the Iranians. We need to talk about how we can engage Iran in the cause of peace. Finally, recognising the important statement of the Saudi foreign minister expressing satisfaction with the assurances about the deal, the wariness the Israelis have expressed to me is this: that this is a deal for 15 years, but, they ask, what about 15 years and one day? We can find an answer. In Europe’s cooperation with Iran we can seek development, which means there will be no going back. We did a nuclear deal. We now have to make sure it is a deal for development, a deal for modernity, a deal for peace.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: question posed by raising the blue card. - I have a question for a colleague. I agree with what he said, but I wonder whether he considers it a problem in the agreement that Iran is given a period of 24 days to prepare before its nuclear facilities are inspected by a UN inspection or an international atomic energy agency. Isn't there a danger that Iran will have room to hide or that it is violating the agreement? I beg your opinion, colleague.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer. – I was part of the European delegation with Christian and the other colleagues that went to Tehran, and we were very careful not to second-guess the very detailed negotiations that Ms Mogherini and her team undertook in Vienna. I do not intend to do so today. Are there risks in any agreement? Of course there are risks, but the risks of a covert nuclear programme in Iran, where people were talking about bombing it as the way of stopping it, were far greater. To have this nuclear agreement is something that we should be celebrating, and I believe you and I probably ultimately agree about that.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, despite warnings from critics, it is right to welcome the P5+1 diplomatic breakthrough in concluding a nuclear deal with Iran, and I extend my congratulations to High Representative Mogherini. The alternatives – military, in particular – were unrealistic and had the potential to cause further fall-out in an already destabilised region. We should not allow a new-found cooperation with Iran, however, to blind us from past experience. The regime in Iran is no stranger to being economical with the truth, and it will be the enforcement and verification measures of the deal that will judge it to have been a success or failure. Ensuring that Iran complies with the terms agreed and being prepared to swiftly reimpose EU economic sanctions are absolutely crucial. The deal should also not deter the EU and its Member States from criticising Iran where necessary. Its continued human rights abuses and sponsorship of terrorism have not been tamed by the so-called moderate President Rouhani. Under his leadership, the number of executions, including of political dissenters and minorities, has soared, with the average now standing at around two per day. We in my Group rightly and readily condemn the barbarity of ISIS, but the Iranian regime – ISIS’ mortal enemy – is only marginally better. Furthermore, we cannot ignore Iran’s funding of groups such as Hamas and Hezbollah and its continued stoking of sectarian power plays in Lebanon, Syria and Bahrain. The migrant crisis has illustrated to us that Europe cannot exist in isolation in a globalised world. It is difficult to shield ourselves in Europe from the events and problems of the Middle East, but we must not let this deal allow Iran to cause us further mischief. The UK – my country – has just reopened its embassy in Tehran, so it is probably now time for a small EU delegation there too.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in these challenging times, which expose our divisions and lack of position on the global stage, we must underline that when the EU leads, and when we are united, we see results. My compliments go to you, High Representative, your predecessors Javier Solana and Catherine Ashton, and your teams. I enjoyed seeing pictures of the almost all-female crew, but mostly the results that were reached behind closed doors. They must have inspired many women in Iran, too, who need room for participation in society and politics. Certainly the ambitious, smart, Iranian young generation inspires me. Now we must see to it that all sides stick to their commitments and implement their part of the deal. This is only the beginning. I think we have no time to lose in developing a broader EU agenda in relation to Iran, and human rights should be top of that agenda. For too long, quite frankly, they have been overshadowed by these – albeit important – negotiations. Executions; torture (which is systematic); censorship of the media, the internet, academia and art; repression of minorities; no fair trial, and lawyers like the brave Sakharov Prize winner Nasrin Sotoudeh, who are banned from practising law and have faced imprisonment. The Iranian people deserve better. Also, economically the risk is that the deal and the lifting of sanctions will only strengthen the already very strong position of a few: the Revolutionary Guards and those close to the people in power. But Iran needs a truly private sector, and I think we have work to do to make sure that EU companies do not blindly take the opportunities in the economic openings they see but are actually aware of the full picture. We must engage Iran in the explosive regional situation and talk to them in a diplomatic effort to end their support for the murderous regime of Bashar al-Assad, which continues to bomb its people, and to stop supporting terrorist organisations like Hezbollah. Our agenda is long, and we should start today.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We, as the left of the united Left Group, strongly support the conclusion of the agreement with Iran, and we thank all those involved, including you, Mrs Mogherini. Perhaps it is the most important agreement we have ever concluded in recent years. It is also because it proves that persistent negotiation is indeed worthwhile, that it is worth talking to each other again, and that escalation, war, sanctions are really not a solution – certainly not in the long term. And we need, it must be said clearly, a nuclear-weapon-free Iran, yes, of course. But we also need a nuclear-weapon-free zone throughout the Middle East.  This must also be an important objective, and I also believe that Israel in particular could benefit greatly from this. One last thing: this agreement also marks the beginning of a new phase in relations between Iran and the West. And to do this, we must immediately begin the human rights dialogue. We have promised this to all the victims in Iran who have been killed or who are still suffering under the regime today, and I think we have to start here, that must be high on the agenda, and that is what we should be pushing for now.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a clear majority of the people of Scotland are very strongly in favour of the abolition of nuclear weapons – nuclear disarmament – so it is all the more of a democratic outrage that Scotland hosts the entire UK nuclear arsenal. But that is a discussion for another day; it is a shame Mr Tannock has left us. On their behalf, I very strongly welcome this deal as an important step forward globally –as our High Representative rightly says – of an example towards nuclear non—proliferation. So we very much endorse the praise and recognition that Ms Mogherini, her team and indeed her predecessors do rightly deserve. Yes, the stars had to align in a wider context, but this was the EU acting as the EU for perhaps the first time, where we played a significant central role that nobody else could have done in bringing this deal home. I think that does deserve the recognition that we have heard tonight. We had a pressing need to bring Iran in from the cold. The cold war between Saudi Arabia and Iran is right now having grave consequences in the region. In Yemen, Iraq, Syria and elsewhere, we are seeing interference by both countries in the internal affairs of their neighbours. The global community had to find a way to reboot our relationship with Iran, a country that could, and should, be a strong ally. I do not think it is fanciful to think of Iran in those terms in a number of areas. So what does the future look like, now that we can think about a new relationship? I would strongly endorse Ms Schaake’s comments, and again the EU can play a role in this. We have a lot of experience in bringing mistrusting parties together. High Representative, what thought has been put into confidence-building measures across the Arabian, or indeed the Persian Gulf between the Gulf States and Iran, where a deep mistrust has been allowed to develop? Also, on human rights, Iran’s record – as we rightly say tonight – is poor. That is not unique within the region, of course, but this House in March 2014 called for an EU—Iran human rights dialogue. Can you assure us that that remains a central plank of our engagement? On trade, where we really do have muscle and leverage, after years of sanctions the EU trade diplomacy surely gives us real leverage over Iran and that dialogue. Is it too early to talk of an EU-Iran trade deal? If it is, perhaps we can start thinking in that direction to encourage them into that dialogue.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are agreements that go into the annals of history and others that make history. I hope that time will tell us that this agreement is part of the second category. I would like to sincerely thank the High Representative Federica Mogherini and all the staff of the European External Action Service for their great role in the negotiations. Unfortunately, as we have to say, the ultimate objective of full implementation is still a long way off, but we will assess it over time.  The reintegration of Tehran into the international community can put in crisis the sometimes too strong positions of Riad eTel Aviv and their security in considering themselves supported, regardless, by the West, even regardless of concrete actions. Let us hope that both, but above all Iran itself, can moderate their role in the conflicts over time by proxy in the region and that Israel will therefore be pushed by the agreement itself to seriously return to the negotiating table for a two-state, fair and lasting solution.  We must not delude ourselves about the actual iranian policy change, we are well aware that there is a great deal to be done on the subject of human rights and we have areas of cooperation policies – as you said earlier – that present us with ample room for growth. But I believe that Iran has the will to comply globally with this pact, it could have growth of 5% in twelve months and 7% in the next 18 months.  We must, however, have the will to make the United States understand that the pacta sunt servanda principle cannot be disavowed for electoral purposes. Keeping my word is essential in order to support the Iranian reformists and precisely to avoid a new division in the world in blocks with the triangle, Russia, China, Iran, on the one hand, and the USA, the EU and allies, on the other, we also have the opportunity to stitch up the Middle East together, with everyone's input, an objective that – let me say – historically we cannot fail.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it would appear to be an agreement reached above all in the interests of Europe. Perhaps it was mainly in the interests of the current administration in Washington to reach this agreement, given the results of the military offensive in Syria and Iraq, which did not achieve the expected results, because even centres in the heart of the Isis area, such as Mosul and Ramadi, are still in the hands of Allah's fighters and will be so for a long time to come, especially if we continue not to adopt the policy that also involves Russia in the offensive against the Islamic State.  In Washington's view, the agreement should completely change the geopolitical framework of the area, creating a balance between the four regional powers, Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Israel. For now, there is a situation that could – in the American view – allow a decouple from military commitments. For now! When the High Representative – whose optimism I share, even though I personally think with the pessimism of my modest intelligence – I see above all immediate benefits for the American arms industries, for example – because Saudi Arabia and Israel are protesting but have rushed to make big purchases from American manufacturers.  I have two questions left: will Iran, on the one hand, give this valuable aid to the balance of the region and respect its nuclear commitments for a long time to come? Secondly, will this agreement really bring benefits to the European Union, which has spent so much on this and on its interests in the area?

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, I too would like to join my voice in favour of the agreement reached with Iran and congratulate you, Mrs Mogherini, on the work done in the footsteps of your predecessors, Mrs Ashton and Mr Solana. The Agreement will ensure the civilian nature of Iran's nuclear program through a number of important limitations and restrictions that the Government of Iran has accepted and whose compliance will be closely monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency. It seems to me that the unanimous support of the Security Council, as you said, to Resolution 2231 is a sign of the positive welcome that virtually the entire international community has given to the Vienna Agreement.  Now a long and difficult stage is opened: the verification of compliance with the conditions. This dimension of verification is, of course, the essential guarantee of the Agreement.  But I believe that the scope of the Agreement goes beyond its very important security dimension. On the one hand, by lifting sanctions and restrictive measures, it will allow the progressive normalization of relations with Iran – also economically and commercially, with the effect that this is positive for all, including the Iranian population – and, on the other hand, will also lead to a normalization of political relations. This will create a new climate of Iran's cooperation with the international community that I would like to see a positive impact on the region.  We all know the activities and role Iran has been playing in the Middle East. Now, the new climate opened by the Agreement will hopefully allow Iran's attitude to be more constructive and contribute to the stability of a much-needed region. There we have, together with the deadly middle east peace process, the war in Syria, in Iraq, the terrible rise of Daesh and all the death and suffering and displacement of millions of people.  May Iran, along with other key players in the region, help bring much-needed stability and security, ending the war in Syria and also eradicating Daesh's terror. And I'm going to finish. When the Vienna Agreement was discussed with you on 20 July, they invited you to explore ways to promote a more cooperative regional framework. I wonder if something has already progressed in this study and what role the European Union could or is already playing.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, before coming to this debate, I read again the speech made by John Kerry in Philadelphia recently about the nuclear deal. I have one conclusion: if remarkable American scientists, as well as John Kerry, the President and many leading personalities in the United States, are backwardthe deal, are they wrong? I think not – because this deal is important not only for the United States but for the whole world. And this is the level at which Europe can and should always play. Like lysing for a moment where we started from in 2013 and where we are now in our relations with Iran and its capabilities to build a nuclear bomb. Reading John Kerry's words, I can say, Madam Vice President, that you and the other negotiators paid things we should be proud of. Our Union has already received the Nobel Prize for Peace, and this should be a reason for Europe to come a real global power for peace and cooperation. Allow me now to say just a few words in Romanian. This agreement is a document that is particularly aimed at nuclear non-proliferation, but it is not just about it. It opens the possibility of cooperation between the European Union, Iran and other regional actors to stabilise the situation in the Middle East, including an exit strategy for a transition to Syria. It is a document that allows cooperation to stabilise a wider area, from Iran to the Mediterranean. It's a place where Europe - and I look at Philip Hammond, I look at Deputy Chancellor Steinmeier, who go to Tehran to discuss the nuclear deal, but to talk about business as well. I look at Daniel Barenboim, who accompanies the vice-chancellor in Tehran, believing in the power of the symbol of music and multiculturalism as a message of peace. For these things, it is time for Iran and Saudi Arabia to stop the war of the proxies and Iran to change their language towards Israel in equal measure, vis-ing with the United States.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question from the removal of the blue card in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Regulation).

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Botinaru, you have given very good explanations and justifications for this agreement, but do you really believe that the statement that an American Foreign Minister cannot be mistaken is a really good one?

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – If we do not trust John Kerry, if we do not trust Steinmeier, if we do not trust High Representative Mogherini, if we do not trust others, then who are the ones to be trusted by us? It is the scepticism, the recipe and the panacea for our question marks. Negotiation is the only answer we need and the only leverage we have. This is why, through negotiations, at least we can prevent the possibility of Iran building a nuclear bomb and then, by means of verification, have a basis to work for a better world. The one we have now is not a better one.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Madam High Representative, there is a really crucial question on my lips after that Iran deal, however you feel about it, whether it is bad or good, which I would like to address to you tonight: what about strict international control of Iran's compliance with the nuclear deal - and that is the point - down to the point of detail. Because I've also talked to experts. And then I have two additions to this question, because that is really what this is all about. In the case of Iraq, there was an international committee of experts that the IAEA also monitored. That would be important for Iran, given Iran's past non-transparency. Because it's very controversial.  Secondly, it is not a question of the IAEA having secret agreements with Iran. They really all need to be made public. This even goes against the IAEA statutes. I would like to give you that above all, and above all the question: what is the state of implementation and control, a double check, given the past. That doesn't start, as mentioned here, in 2013. We've been working on Iran for several decades.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, it is with conviction that I am defending the agreement with Iran because I believe that a calculated risk in favour of non-proliferation is far preferable to the risk of nuclear escalation and the major risks that would arise from adventurous war operations.  Having said that, I also want to be clear about another issue. This agreement is by no means a label of honour that the European Union and its Member States would attribute to the ruthless regime of the mullahs. This regime that gags, imprisons, executes, hangs in turn, if I dare say it, I hope that the Iranians will get rid of it very quickly and that we will support those who are fighting for a free and democratic Iran. Madam High Representative, I must confess that I was a little embarrassed by the pitiful list of ministers who turned into trade travellers to Tehran as soon as the agreement was signed. We expect a lot more from you. You are the face and voice of Europe in the world. There are many, in Iran and elsewhere, all those who expect you to take determined action for respect for human rights, the dignity of people and the fundamental principles of democracy. You won't disappoint them.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Mr President! First of all, thank you to Mrs Mogherini for a really interesting introduction. I have great sympathy for the joy of the nuclear agreement with Iran, but I must also say that there have been some worrying comments on the part of the European Union. When it is said that the European Union and Iran are close friends and that there is mutual respect, I am therefore a little concerned. After all, Iran has major, great human rights problems. In the last few years alone, more than 2 000 executions have been carried out – not to mention the harsh punishments handed out by the regime to people who allow themselves to criticise it. In addition, there is discrimination against women in general in society. It's not something we can just ignore. On the contrary, it is an area on which we must focus much more on it, and where it is also essential that the Representatives of the European Union always bring it up and criticise it. When there are large press conferences where the many violations of human rights are not mentioned at all, it sends a bad signal. Even here, in the midst of joy, we must remember all the people who are suffering today from the Iranian regime.  Finally, I would like to thank you very much for your efforts and also for the statement.

name: James CARVER
text: – blue-card answer. – This agreement has given the European Union a chance to see itself as the arbitrator of European security and prosperity. However, in negotiating this very deal, you may well have achieved the complete opposite, due to the wide mistrust over Iran’s stance towards Israel and their influence in both Yemen and Palestine. While President Rouhani may be a moderate, we must remember that, without changes to Iran’s political and governance systems, there is no assurance that a traditionalist or a fundamentalist will not take control in the future, removing the current supreme leader’s fatwa forbidding nuclear weapons. We should respectfully bear in mind that Ayatollah Khamenei is now 76 years old. The Middle East has enough security challenges as it is, without adding a toxic mix of re—energised nuclear proliferation. Where there are now better positions to develop nuclear weapons, will we see further Middle East nations seek to become nuclear powers? Already, the Saudis have a nuclear agreement with Pakistan that potentially allows them to look towards nuclear weapons. Commissioner, I cannot see how this secures either the Middle East or the rest of the world. With this agreement comes responsibility, and I sincerely hope and pray that Iran uses this opportunity to start in the right direction by reassuring the world of good intentions, not least by removing her support for anti-government forces in the Yemen. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – What I want to simply ask, as a frequent critic of the European Union, do you agree with me that this is a great success of the European Union, that this is a great success of the High Representative, our common policy, the assumption for peace creation on our planet and the possibility, regardless of everything we know is happening in Iran, that iran is nevertheless a country that will contribute to peace on our planet? Do you agree with the great success of the European Union and the credit for peace on this planet?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Jakovčić, quite frankly, if you listen to my speech you will hear that what I was saying was that there is a danger of people counting their chickens before they have hatched. One has to look at the wider perspective. As you may well know, I am very interested in the issues surrounding the Yemen civil war, and certainly Iran’s proxy in that area – not least with support for Palestine and with continual negative comments about Israel – leads me to err on the side of caution. I think it is important that this House reflects all views from across the European Union.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, of course Iran must not have nuclear weapons, but for once it is time here to return to reality and efficiency.  The reality is that Iran can once again become a frequent nation in the concert of nations. Yes, the Geneva agreement was a good agreement because it allows Iran to implement the Non-Proliferation Treaty. Yes, Iran will be able to access civilian nuclear power. Yes, Iran can become frequent again. However, you also have to be effective, but how? By giving Iran the opportunity to play a major role in conflicts today, particularly in the Middle East. Like China and Russia, this country must now allow us to fight effectively, especially in Syria, to ensure that the Islamic State is brought to its knees, so that Iran can once again become the great regional partner that Europe needs.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Madam Mogherini’s personal contribution and dedication is to be appreciated. However, the overall result of the deal has not been so convincing, because the Iranian nuclear programme has not been cancelled, just postponed, in the best case for 15 years. The result has been buying time. The question is, who is going to use this time more efficiently? It is up to us now to answer. The essence of the Iranian regime has not changed; the same undemocratic leaders have a notorious track record of broken commitments. As there is no confidence, as Ms Mogherini admitted, the question is: will these leaders benefit from the new situation more than their partners? Asking for more concessions is impossible, because unfrozen assets will provide money for supporting Iranian proxies in the Middle East; the missile programme has been left out of the deal; part of the advanced centrifuges will be retained. But I think the central issue is our clear commitment to human and minority rights situations there. It is a basis of trust and any real progress. What alarms me most is that the human rights situation in the meantime has worsened, not improved. Under President Rouhani, there have been 2 000 executions, many of them for political motives. The European Parliament’s position has been very clear: in dealing with undemocratic partners, we have insisted that human rights should be mainstreamed in all agreements and be conducted parallel to economic and security deals, and I hope that it will be so.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the I would also like to thank the High Representative, her team. Since we do not say too much good about her too often, I would also like to include your predecessor, Lady Ashton, who has also done a great deal in this matter. Yes! It's just a start. Yes! There are still many problems. No, there is no reason for naivety. Yes! It may be too early to rejoice. And yet, this agreement offers hope, hope for détente in the region and between the West and Iran. It also offers hope for a better future for the people of Iran. I would also like to take this opportunity to make it clear that I very much hope that it can lead to a détente between Iran and Israel. I am sure that, after careful study, this insight will also increase in the Israeli Government. However, I would also like to repeat this clearly, as we have often said elsewhere: the security of Israel is still a matter of the heart of this Parliament, and it is, of no doubt, the highest priority for us. It is also a victory for diplomacy, and we do not have too many victories to celebrate in the context of diplomacy. In this respect, this is also a sign of hope. Let me conclude by thanking two of them. One is Secretary of State Kerry. I must now smile a little at your question that it could have come from me if it was not for a party friend of mine who said that. But the fact that the Secretary of State of the United States, despite considerable opposition in his country, has taken such a strict line with all of us – I believe we owe him a credit. I hope our colleagues in Congress will not unfairly leave him in the rain. Finally, I would also like to thank the Russian Foreign Minister – you would be surprised if I did not do so – to Minister Lavrov, because it makes it clear that if we act together, if we tackle problems together and if there is a serious will to solve them together, there is a chance of doing so. I very much hope that, in the case of Syria, we will soon have another example of this.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, as Chairman of the Iraq Delegation, I have been following the talks between the West and Iran with great concern. Just one day after signing this deal, and Iran is shelling our allies in Yemen. While dressed up as a peace deal, this is just appeasement. This agreement trivialises the Iranian regime’s human rights violations. More than 2 000 people have been hanged by the ‘moderate’ President Rouhani whom you, Ms Mogherini, were happy to take tea with. This is the highest level of executions for 25 years, 1 000 forecast by this year end: the highest number of executions per head in the world. The group-think mentality of the EU and P5+1 has resulted in every obstruction from the Iranians, rewarded with more giveaways. Iranian officials have described negotiations as a form of Jihad by other means. This deal frees up millions of euros for yet more sponsorship of terror. They are just laughing at us. Under the agreed framework for 10 years, Iran will never be further than one year from a nuclear weapon, and then it will get the bomb. This deal is utter folly. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Alyn SMITH
text: blue-card question. – I am grateful to you, Mr Campbell Bannerman, for giving way, and I pay tribute to your work on the Iraq delegation where we both work – and it is a pleasure to work with you – but I flatly disagree with your comments tonight. In any deal there is an element of unpalatable compromise, and we had to find a way to bring Iran in from the cold and into the global dialogue. Would you also extend the criticism which you rightly make of the human rights record and the interference in neighbouring countries to Saudi Arabia and indeed to UK Government policy, which is more predicated upon selling as many guns, tanks and bombs to the current regime in Saudia Arabia as possible?

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: blue-card answer. – Alyn, thank you for your support for the Iraq delegation. I do not think that this compromise works: I think it gives too much away and endangers peace in the Middle East; it does not actually secure it. I do not like the idea of a nuclear power in Iran, because it could become a suicide bomber state. It could actually use the bomb, and so it is more destabilising. I think it is desperately dangerous and that is why I oppose it. Regarding Saudi Arabia, yes, I do think we need to look at that more closely.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, I find it positive that the deal has been reached with Iran, and I would also like to thank Mrs Mogherini for her efforts in reaching this deal. Hopefully Iran will use this opportunity of sanctions being lifted for its own good, for boosting its economy and advancing the well-being of its people and will not engage in destabilising the Middle East region. We need to use this time and this agreement as grounds for dealing with other crises in the region where Iran could also be of help. We need to engage the Gulf countries and Israel in dialogue to try to work on reducing the tensions in the Middle East at large and also fighting terrorism. We need to commend Iran for their actions regarding refugees: they have already taken more than a million refugees from Afghanistan. But we cannot turn a blind eye to the human rights situation in Iran. Many innocent people are still imprisoned in Iran on false charges or are subject to excessive punishments, and this needs to be addressed by EU high officials in relations with Iran.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The iran nuclear deal is certainly a milestone towards normalising our relations with Tehran. Iran has come so far as to agree to inspect all its nuclear infrastructure at any time, and even military installations, in justified cases. Iran has shown that there are forces there that are very much concerned with de-escalation and peace.  Negotiations in recent years have created a climate of trust and respect that can enable Iran to be involved in a stabilisation strategy in the Middle East, and the right of every state in the region must, of course, be guaranteed. We must therefore rethink, not only in relation to Iran, but also in our foreign policy, which should be more oriented towards our own European interests and not constantly playing America's little brother.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I made my first speech in this House in January 2012, when it was about Iran, it was about sanctions. At the time, I took a position against the fact that we included a military option in our resolution. A lot has changed since then. Those who have said that we can try to soften positions by means of dialogue, dialogue and diplomacy similar to Eastern policy have been right. So not deterrence, but change through rapprochement. We have also often wrestled in this House to see whether we, as the European Parliament delegation, should make a trip to Iran. After a lot of back and forth, we did it. I am very glad that this nuclear issue is being resolved, because that was, so to speak, the Gordian knot. I would like to thank the High Representative for proving this diplomatic skill. The door is open, but no new chapter has yet begun in relations between Europe and Iran. This is not surprising after 30 years of isolation. This process is full of opportunities and full of risks. We have discussed the risks a lot today, but there are also opportunities. There are common security interests in the region, there is organised crime of drug crime, which we must fight together, there are economic opportunities, and, above all, there are opportunities in scientific cooperation. The first woman to be awarded a Nobel Prize in Mathematics was an Iranian woman. So, these chances exist. However, I also believe that we must address the issue of human rights in all openness, and I hope that we will soon see that we in this House can personally congratulate Nasrin Sotoudeh and Jafar Panahi, the two Sakharov Prize winners, on their prize. That would also be a breakthrough in further relations with Iran.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: ECR). – Mr President, Vice-President Mogherini, as Bulgarian MEP and representative of our delegation to Iran, I welcome the signed nuclear agreement – a great diplomatic success and a first step towards a lasting peace in the Middle East. Iran could be our partner in the war against The Islamic State. The refugee flow shows that new efforts and a global coalition including Iran, Russia, the United States and Europe are needed against Islamic terrorists in Syria. I believe That Iran can be our ally in the necessary military operations and on the ground against the Islamic State. Iran's return to global diplomacy enables the European Union to solve its main energy problem for a greater volume of gas supplies outside Russia to Europe. Many European countries, including my country Bulgaria, including Greece, benefit directly from the resumption of the Nabucco gas pipeline project from Iran to Europe. I hope that negotiations on this will begin immediately on our own initiative.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I have enormous respect for you and your work, but I have no diplomatic experience. Yes, some, in the field of human rights, and the truth is that the most innocent human things: dancing, laughing, speaking, loving are sin in Iran and is executed for it every day. Realpolitik sacrifices our gaze in search of as little evil as possible for international politics. Maybe there's no other chance, no other chance, and surely time will give you reason. But I want to bear witness, with all due respect, to that human rights reality that we may not want to see today. Because it is very hard for free-hearted Iranians, for conscience-free Iranians, for activists, to overcome fear every day, be outside or within Iran. We don't play our lives like them, so I beg you not to forget human rights.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, High Representative Mogherini, i thank you and your team, because the nuclear agreement with Iran is a great step towards security and non-proliferation at regional and global level. But it is also essential to encourage the Iranian authorities to take a new attitude in the region, in the world and towards their own people, particularly with respect for human rights.  We may have many differences, we have, with Iran, but we are facing a functional state which at this time in the history of the region and humanity should be encouraged to play a priority role in conflict resolution and, in particular, to end the war in neighbouring Syria and not to let Lebanon explode. To do this, the European Union must work to end the sectarian confrontation between Shiites and Sunnis, shaped by the Iran-Saudi rivalry, now also fuelled by daesh's facinous extremism, which threatens to spread armed conflict to the entire Middle East and North Africa and not only. It is Europe itself that is exposed to the murderous barbarism of Daesh if it cannot coordinate for combat and to call regional powers such as Iran, Saudi Arabia and Turkey to account, integrating them into a solution that gives peace and future to syrians and all the peoples of the region.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Mogherini, you have resolutely and successfully continued and completed the work of your predecessor, and for that you deserve all our thanks. Incidentally, as you rightly say, your team too, as we have heard from Mrs Schaake, especially a female team. It has now been pointed out in the speeches today that human rights in Iran are still being trampled underfoot, but I must also say that they are women and girls in particular. It should also be pointed out on this occasion. But I would like to raise something quite different, a different aspect here.  Part of the agreement is the gradual lifting of the economic embargo, the economic sanctions. To those who criticise this, I would like to remind you today that ideas, ideals and values are often sent with the luggage of foreign investors very often – especially when it is baggage to repressive countries. And that is the idea of a market economy, the idea of human rights and the idea of democracy, and that may be the most valuable aspect of your agreement. This is precisely what can lead to the change in this society that young people there expect today. Incidentally, and this is my ceterum censeo, I believe that the single euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – Mr President, after prolonged intense and complex negotiations, in which the High Representative and her team played a crucial role for which they deserve all our praise, a deal has been signed in Vienna with Iran. According to the deal, Iran will scale down considerably its nuclear effort and the international community will gradually lift the sanctions. However, the nuclear dimension is not the sole yardstick in evaluating the deal concluded in Vienna. I think that the real measure of success or failure for that deal is ultimately political: namely, to what extent Iran’s influence in the area will increase or decrease following the regaining of international respectability as a result of signing the Vienna deal. The question is: will Iran be more cooperative or more assertive? And even if it is cooperative, we should be fully aware that other partners in the area might feel antagonised by this newly-discovered cooperative relationship between us and Iran.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, let me remind you that Iran is a theocratic dictatorship that is fiercely scathing of domestic and exiled opposition. That it is the first state in the world in executions per population, that to consider Iran as an ally in the fight against the Islamic State is naïve, because for them the Islamic State is merely a competitor in pursuit of regional hegemony. I remind you that Iran supports Assad in Syria, supports Hezbollah in Lebanon, subverts Iraq. This treaty has been adopted with concern by Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Egypt. And if this treaty allows Iran to continue its nuclear program, there will be a round of arms in the region that we have not seen here since the end of the Cold War. I'm afraid we've opened the door to it. I am not at all optimistic about this treaty, and I must say that you yourself have contributed to this with your hasty visit to Iran and the friendliness you have shown to the regime there. I consider this a mistake, and I, Mrs Mogherini, have accused you of this place.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Mr President, let me first join all those who congratulated Mrs Mogherini and Catherine Ashton for their contribution in resolving this difficult issue of the nuclear deal with Iran. I followed the topic as a journalist at the IAEA in Vienna from the beginning of 2002 or 2003, although, of course, it goes back much further than that: the difficulties in bringing all these parties to the table have their roots in the events of 1979 – the revolution in Iran and the mistrust that followed. Now, with the negotiations over and the passing of the treaty in the US Congress almost assured, we have to look ahead. How can we in Europe use the newfound rapprochement to involve Iran in resolving the many crises in the Middle East? It is my hope that the nuclear deal was just the beginning. I know there are parties in the region which will oppose a stronger role for Iran, but without its inclusion we will move even further away from any resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, first and foremost the Iran Agreement is the triumph of diplomacy in the face of war and violence as a method of resolving international conflicts. It puts an end to 36 years of hostility between the West and Iran, and prevents Iran from becoming a nuclear power.  But it also has enormous regional implications.
