It has implications in the most devastated area in the world, where Iran is a regional power that will have the capacity to influence, or may have, stabilization, especially in four civil wars that we are seeing happening – in Iraq, unfortunately in Libya, Yemen or Syria – and also has a lot of influence over two important countries, such as Palestine or Libya. This is just the beginning. Clearly, we continue to maintain the same human rights criticisms we had a few months ago about Iran, but the difference is that this agreement is going to allow us to talk about these criticisms with them, with Iran, starting tomorrow.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, this agreement is a victory for diplomacy over confrontation. Congratulations to Ms Mogherini and her predecessor, Ms Ashton, for successfully concluding the negotiations.  However, we must not rest on our laurels. We must now breathe life into this deal by ensuring its rigorous implementation, and work towards making the entire Middle East nuclear weapon-free. It is important that we further strengthen relations with Iran as a key player within the Middle East. We must use the deal to create stability, which in turn will foster regional economic and development cooperation. We are seeing the impact of regional instability on our own borders, with hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing in search of a safe land. The Vienna Agreement therefore opens new avenues for constructively engaging with Iran on regional security issues, such as combating Isis, ending the bloody civil war in Syria and stabilising Iraq and Yemen. This agreement gives us hope for long-term sustainable peace in the Middle East.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, let me have a few facts. More than 2,000 people have been hanged during the presidency of Iran's so-called moderate prime minister, Rouhani. According to Amnesty International, 700 people were executed in the first half of this year. And their number is expected to exceed 1,000 by the end of the year. It's the world's largest number of executions per capita. The legal age for girls to marry is thirteen years, but girls as young as nine can be married with the permission of the court. And so on. Commissioner, I ask you from here, as the representative of Europe, not to forget human rights when creating the Iranian nuclear deal. How to deal with the threat of Iran's nuclear program and the regime's influence in the region is not an easy choice. However, I know with absolute certainty that the issue of human rights, the brutal increase in the number of executions and the suppression of religious freedoms must not be taboo for the European Union in its talks with the Iranian counterparty.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after about two years of negotiations, an important nuclear agreement has finally been reached with Iran. This is an historic achievement and I agree with Vice-President Mogherini in calling it a sign of hope for the whole world.  Attention must now be focused entirely on the management phase of the agreement, bearing in mind that the result achieved, important though it may be, does not lead to definitive disarmament, since it is a text for the control of proliferation that binds Tehran not to produce sufficient material for the construction of nuclear weapons for only ten years. The European Union and the international community must therefore continue to push for Tehran to change course and, after 36 years of confrontation, begin to play a responsible role in the world, carrying out the necessary reforms, in dialogue with Saudi Arabia and in promoting the settlement of the clash between Shiites and Sunnis.  I would like to thank our High Representative Federica Mogherini and her team for the work they have done and for the tenacity with which they have conducted the negotiations for the European Union. The result it has brought home shows that Europe is capable of building bridges even between powers that are not spoken of.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, respected High Representative Mogherini, it seems that the level of European commitment to the fight for human rights in third countries shows in my opinion too much dependence on the political moment. This is confirmed by your latest meetings with Iranian officials in which you failed to point out the still-present problem of women's executions and repression of women in Iran. I believe that progress in the negotiations between America and Iran has greatly contributed to this European selectivity and forgetfulness when it comes to the human rights of the Iranians. I want to know if in the future you will stand up more decisively for women's rights in Iran and more credibly implement a European human rights policy because I think now the message to Iran is left: hang, stone, kill whoever you want, you just can't have nuclear weapons.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I would like to ask you about the bloody violations of human rights. Since the start of negotiations on the Iran agreement, when Mr Rohani was appointed president, more than 2,000 executions have been carried out in the country, reaching the highest rate in the last 25 years. Women have also been condemned for speaking out against political repression. This does not seem to be an issue to which you have given priority, because in the press conference, on your visit to Tehran, you did not mention the term 'human rights' once or once. Is that part of the deal? Maybe you could tell us a few minutes about your position on that subject.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am a member of the Iranian delegation. I met the Iranian ambassador to Ireland last Friday. I came in here for one minute, to speak for one minute, and you tell me I cannot speak. You allowed my good friend behind me to give two blue cards. You allowed another speaker to speak for one minute and 45 seconds in a one-minute speech. How do you expect us to come here to sit in debates when we are not even allowed to speak at the very end in the ‘catch-the-eye’? It is ridiculous.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Look, you know very well from your experience that the timing is distributed by the political groups and the catch-the-eye procedure is a procedure at the discretion of the Presidency on the timing of the debates. If there are no objections, I shall give it to you, because I have no reason not to give you the floor. But remember next time to ask your political group to respect your priorities on the question of parliamentary debates.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I want to say firstly that the High Representative deserves great credit. One thing she did say that surprised me, however, is that this agreement was not based on trust. Well, if it was not based on trust, how was it arrived at at all? Certainly the implementation of it will need a lot of trust, for all those who are committed to it. There is a great opportunity here for the European Union to give leadership in that regard, and to show trust by helping to lift the sanctions. When those sanctions are lifted, so that the Iranian people and the regime in Iran will see the benefits, that may lead to opportunities to have a more enlightened approach to human rights and to their neighbours, particularly Israel.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, let me start by thanking all of you for this important debate. One procedural issue that I have raised once already in this Chamber is that I think I am in my 11th hour in this hemicycle today. I am very happy that this is the case, but maybe you have to reflect a little bit on the procedures of your work, for its efficiency. This is just a suggestion.  Let me say, first of all, what many of you underlined. This is first of all a security deal, a security agreement. I can never stress this enough. First of all because the scope of the agreement itself, by its nature, was, and is still, limited – even if the word ‘limited’ is maybe not appropriate because it is historical in itself – but limited to the nuclear programme. So you would not have expected this agreement to cover other aspects of Iranian political institutional life or its relations with the rest of the world or its internal roots. It is very important to stress that this is a security agreement, also and first of all for the environment, the region of Iran, which is a region that does not enjoy very high levels of security nowadays.  We normally look to Syria, Yemen, Iraq and Daesh, and we are right to do so, but I would like to mention one other security dimension where the deal could open possibilities for investing in more security. This is Afghanistan. We tend to remove issues from the agenda once they disappear from the newspaper headlines, but the fact that we could engage with Iran also on the stabilisation of Afghanistan, which is another country neighbouring Iran, is going to be no less relevant than the rest of the work we will need to do in the Middle East.  There is another important element when it comes to stressing the fact that this is a security agreement, a non-proliferation agreement. This is first and foremost an agreement for the security of the region: starting with the security of Israel, starting with the security of the Gulf, but also for our own European security because, as Europeans, we were the ones closest to Iran of all those sitting at the negotiating table. Some of you asserted that it is only ‘10 plus years’ without a nuclear weapon. Well, ‘10 plus years’ is a relatively long time and the point will be how we use these 10 years politically. I will come back to that in a moment, but I believe that we have somehow invested in the future of the region and in the future of the country too. I am surprised that nobody in this room mentioned something that has shocked me, at least, very much: the pictures of the young Iranians celebrating in the streets. My reading of the political dynamic inside Iran is that the current Iranian leadership did something that the previous Iranian leadership did not do – decided not to do – which is investing in the possibility for their country to open up to international relations of a different kind, not starting with trust, but working to build trust in the process, and also probably investing in their own younger generations.  That image of the younger generations of Iran celebrating in the streets a diplomatic victory by the current Iranian leadership which took a different political decision from the previous one is, I think, something we have to read because it is also in our political interest in Europe to invest in that kind of Iran.  So that is why I say a lot will depend on how we use these 10 plus years that we have gained. Our role does not stop here. I said at the beginning that we will keep a role – I personally will keep a role – in the implementation of the agreement. But this is not the only role that we as the European Union will have to keep. Our work has not finished with the signing of the agreement. First, because we have the implementation phase, but also because we have to work on future political developments inside Iran and outside Iran – in the region – in which we will need to invest.  Some people asked the most difficult question: will Iran be more cooperative or more assertive and what will be the reaction of the other players in the region? I do not believe we can afford to take a passive approach to this question, to sit and watch what the different players will do. We can, as the European Union, play a role in trying to shape the future of relations in the Middle East, starting from the role we have played in facilitating the agreement. It will be difficult, it will involve a lot of energy and unity and careful management, but I see this as our role. A strong role on the implementation face and a strong, active role in trying to shape a different kind of regional framework, and also in trying to make it clear for the Iranian people who were celebrating in the streets – not, I guess, strictly on the Iranian details of the agreement, but because of the symbolic and political meaning of that agreement, namely that Iran is opening up.  We have to make a political investment of that kind, and we have a narrow path on which to do so. We have to be wise enough, courageous enough, consistent enough to walk down that path together with our partners.  This also implies our work on human rights. I mentioned that in my opening remarks, maybe some of you were not here but I mentioned that very clearly. The main reason for my visit to Tehran at the end of July was obviously to work on implementation of the agreement. That was the issue on the agenda, that was a follow-up on the deal, but nonetheless I discussed the issue of human rights with all my interlocutors, from the President to the Foreign Minister to the Speaker of the Chamber of the Parliament. And we agreed in the meetings, especially in the meeting with Mr Zarif, to have a human rights dimension to our dialogues.  If you look carefully at the video of our joint press conference, you will see that he is the one making reference to the fact that we agreed to include human rights in our common dialogue, in our common work. To me, this is highly valuable. It is something new. Obviously we have to engage in this direction and you can count on the fact that I will personally do that. I think this is something that may answer the comments many of you made. Obviously this is just the beginning, this is the start of a story. It is a beginning and we need to invest in that direction. Let me say three final words: firstly on the role of the rest of the partners we had around the table. It was indeed a victory for European diplomacy, but it was also an extraordinary example of teamwork between the European Union and the others: the US, where the administration, the White House, and John Kerry personally all invested a lot of political capital; Russia, which played a key role in achieving this result; and the Foreign Minister of China. That also helped a lot.  Let me say – and this I hope this also answers your question, Mr President, – that having an international common approach of that kind, having different interests around the table, having different points of view around the table, but managing together to find a way forward and reach an agreement, did indeed also offer hope for the fact that different global dynamics could be possible if we identify common ground and common interests. A natural reflection of that was the consensus in the Security Council, which is not something that has happened very often in these past few years.  So, yes, I do not know if it is a model, but it could also be a way to work on other issues and it could be a way too of rebuilding some degree of trust within the international community.  This does not wipe out all the things that keep us far apart from one another, but if we manage to find some common ground on some regional crisis or some global issues, such as non-proliferation where we managed to act together with a view to achieving results that are very much in line with our European agenda, then I think this is positive and we should encourage it. Someone said: trust John Kerry, trust the European ministers – I do not know. What I do know is that the real point is that we can trust the international community. We did not have just Europe or just the US or just whatever around that table. Around that table we had, somehow, the international community represented on a clear mandate originating from a Security Council resolution. That is why I say that this is an agreement that also restores trust in the international and multilateral approach and we desperately need it. This is really the European approach to diplomacy.  Finally, one word on what Marietje Schaake mentioned: the fact that the majority of our team, at least, were women. That is true. Other women too were playing key roles in some of the delegations, especially Wendy Sherman, but our delegation, our team, was indeed mainly women and I want to share with you that I was really moved in those hours by the reaction of so many women and girls, and even very young girls, not only in Iran, but also in Europe.  I think that we managed to pass on a good message, one for ourselves too because sometimes – and this is obviously natural, more than natural, and obvious – sometimes we focus on the condition of women outside the European Union, but you cannot imagine – or maybe you can imagine very well – how much too we need to understand inside our own countries that women can be a powerful force, especially for our diplomacy but also for our work ahead. That also made me proud. It was a different level of being proud, but it was a very important one. I thank you very much for all the support you have shown today, but this is just the beginning. We will need to work together closely on the follow—up, both on the implementation and on all the political challenges we will keep having ahead of us, trying to find the right direction for the region as a whole.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the joint debate on the joint debate on the work of The Commission on Employment and Social Affairs , on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment (2014/2236(INI)) (A8-0247/2015) and - the report by Martina Dlabajové on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on the creation of a competitive EU labour market for the 21. Century: Adaptation of skills and qualifications to demand and employment opportunities as a way to overcome the crisis (2014/2235(INI)) (A8-0222/2015) and – the oral question to the Council on precarious employment by Thomas Handel on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000090/20 15 - B8-0751/2015) and – the oral question to the Commission on precarious employment by Thomas Handel on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000091/2015 - B8-0752/2015) (2015/2708(RSP)).

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the rest of the colleagues in the Committee on Employment for their support in such an important report. Today, there are more than two million companies in the social economy in the European Union that offer jobs to more than fourteen million Europeans, figures that have even improved during the crisis. Nevertheless, they are recognised only at national level in some Member States and in different legal forms.  Today's report stresses the importance of companies in the social economy through the European Union as a whole. These companies are characterized by having as their main objective the realization of their social object instead of maximizing their profits.  The social object is very diverse, such as creating employment for vulnerable groups or providing services to members of a specific community, but generically seeks to make a positive social and environmental impact. In fact, to this end, companies in the social economy reinvest the surplus that the company itself obtains with a long-term vision to ensure its sustainability, thus driving greater social innovation.  That is why we say that those companies are innovative by nature, and training must be a key pillar to support them. Greater promotion of the innovative spirit and entrepreneurship from school, as well as the values of the social economy, coupled with greater participation. These undertakings, in the education and training programmes of the Member States, will ultimately promote innovation and social entrepreneurship, which will also help the introduction of a European trusted mark for social entrepreneurship.  The realization of their social object and their strong local roots help these companies to help improve the economic, social, territorial and environmental cohesion of the European Union, as they know first-hand what specific needs they have to meet and help the integration of the groups further away from the labour market. In addition, the organizational model that characterizes them allows efficient, responsible and transparent management of their resources.  However, companies in the social economy need specific support in order to grow and be sustainable, and the first step must be to eliminate the false myth that they are not productive or un competitive, as many of them are leaders in their respective fields. This false conception of society at large makes them even more difficult than traditional companies in accessing finance.  To solve this problem, we must not only facilitate access to credit through European funds or other forms such as microcredits or collective microfinance, but we must also promote them at national and European level, promoting greater recognition and visibility through society as a whole. At the same time, we need to improve the environment in which they operate, promoting the creation of networks of companies in the social economy and facilitating the exchange of information or good practices. Finally, we also call for a rapid and effective transposition and implementation of public procurement and concessions directives that allow greater participation of companies in the social economy in public procurement procedures, at the same time as the primacy of tenders that bring greater economic and social value above the lowest price criterion.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I must say at the outset that interest in my report exceeded expectations. Whether it was a beneficial cooperation with colleagues, for which I thank them very much, or an exchange of views or a fierce struggle for every word with other colleagues. I'm so glad my message doesn't fit. We can see that we are not indifferent to the issue of employment and the future of employment in Europe.  At present, Europe faces many serious challenges. We all know where our future efforts will have to go. The creation of new jobs, reducing unemployment and building a competitive labour market reflecting the real needs of the present is also a key issue that we need to pay due attention to. Young Europeans, in particular, are currently affected by unemployment, which is the result of some stagnation or unwillingness of some countries to proceed with long-term labour market reforms or the modernisation of labour law, many of which date back to our grandparents' time. Together, we must try to respond much more flexibly to the needs of the 21st century. The alarming youth unemployment figures in southern Europe are a signal that the youngest generation is losing the possibility of a traditional transition from school to work, losing their professional dreams and, with them, confidence in the whole system. We're running out of time. Let's stop it, we can change it together. But progress without change is not possible. What we need is a competitive labour market. A labour market that will be modernised and that will continue to change and evolve according to the times in which we live and will not stagnate in history. A labour market that will seek to balance the skills of job seekers with job vacancies, a market that monitors and evaluates employers' real needs and adjusts the offer of vocational training accordingly. Therefore, lifelong learning is extremely important to enable people of all ages to keep up with professional challenges. Let us not be allowed to look for examples of good practice and be inspired by them. With regard to the vote on my report, we can argue on every point. Some people do not like the fact that young people should be held accountable for their lives and should actively and responsibly prepare for inclusion in the workforce. Some have reservations about the economic mobility of workers within EU countries. Others, for example, disagree with the proposed changes and procedures to stabilise and develop the situation on Europe's labour markets. But now is not the time to argue about words and numbers. Now we have to decide: Are we able to accept reality? Look at a situation without political prejudice? Do we really want to build a competitive labour market together? If we continue down the same path and do the same things in the same way, change will never come. This isn't about whether we want to go more left or more right. We all have to go forward.  Whatever happens in tomorrow's vote, I will not let up on my initiative. I will continue to look for ways to connect the education system with the needs of the labour market and to motivate young Europeans to live an active life. After all, we spend a third of our lives in the workplace – and this experience is irreplaceable to every person. We cannot think that all we need is the protection of our citizens and their labour law. We would act like an overly caring mother who lovingly cares for her children but doesn't teach them the right skills in life. We must have an ambition to educate confident citizens, modern Europeans who will be well prepared for life and who will not be afraid to take responsibility for themselves and others. We must want to educate Europeans who will have a clear idea of their future and will be able to fight for it. My report is, I believe, the first step in the right direction on this path.

name: Thomas HÄNDEL
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Minister! Ladies and gentlemen! Before I come to the oral questions, I would like to explain a few facts which underlie our oral question. We currently have 23.5 million registered unemployed in the EU and are happy that this percentage has fallen slightly. We are cheering this morning on 1.65 million new jobs created last year, but we are misbehaving that these are essentially precarious jobs, jobs that no one can live on.  Precarious employment has been the largest growth market in the employment sector for years. In Germany alone, precarious employment has increased by 70% in twenty years, while normal working conditions have fallen by 7.2%. No one can live on that! This development continues even among the young educated. Even in prosperous regions and sectors, 50% of young people are without permanent employment. We live in Europe with a quarter of the population that is poor, poor despite work. This is slowly becoming a mass experience. Ladies and gentlemen, the EU has always been a promise of social security, growing prosperity and a slow convergence of living conditions. More and more people are living the opposite. I am convinced that if people lose faith in the security of the future, Europe as a whole will lose. Employment and social affairs are not the waste of international competitiveness, but the main objective of European policy. That is why, in my opinion, and in the opinion of my committee, the Commission and the Council are called upon to step up efforts against precarious work. A detailed overview of the development of precarious employment relationships is required.  We have directives on part-time, temporary work and temporary work. What is the state of implementation in the Member States of the European Union? What can the Council report on progress in the fight against precarious work? For example, what measures is the Commission taking in the case of new zero-hours jobs, bogus self-employment, subcontracting, outsourcing and so on and so on – not to mention new forms of precarious work, such as employment sharing, casual work, crowdworking and voucher work.  I believe that we have to deal with this more intensively, with the questions: which sectoral and employment groups are particularly affected? How do the Member States ensure that, for example, the fight against youth unemployment does not lead to an increase in precarious work for young people? How does the Council intend to coordinate these efforts? For example, what support does the ILO agenda on decent work provide? I believe that we have a great deal to do in this. Can the Council tell us when this will be more on the Council's agenda? We don't know!  I would like to add a thought from this morning's discussion. The issue of migration is also an employment issue, as a result of this problem. Those who do not try to legalise illegal immigration today create illegal employment, create recipients of poverty wages and create human tools for wage dumping. That is why we should also ensure more legal immigration routes from an employment and social policy point of view.  Jean-Claude Juncker stressed this morning that the people of Europe are entitled to full employment, and he has emphasised the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place. Both are extremely welcome from the POINT of view of the EMPL. We will support these efforts. However, I would also like to add that a triple-A in Europe in the field of social issues also means: wages on which one can live, at decent working conditions and working hours, a European minimum wage level and minimum social standards. Only then will it be round. If you want a European labour market with more mobility in the future, you can no longer afford six different groups of workers in Europe with different rights. I would remind you that, in recent months, we have treated the fiscal rules in Europe as the Ten Commandments, but on the issue of working conditions, labour rights, working time rules, fundamental rights of posted workers – we sometimes treat disrespect no differently than cavalier offences.  That cannot be the case, so I would like to remind you that we need more labour inspections at European level and common regulations for them. Work and social justice cannot be waste products of economics or increased international competitiveness! They are independent objectives of a social Europe.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic and financial crisis which, in many Member States, has also become a social crisis, has led to an increase in the number of unemployed - although we are now pleased that the unemployment rate has fallen slightly, albeit very slightly - and has, at the same time, led to the reduction, in many cases , social benefits and rights to these benefits.  The crisis has also contributed to the increase in precarious work. This has serious implications for our economies as well as for stability and social cohesion, but also, in the long run, for the sustainability of our social protection systems. The ability of those who wish to enter paid employment is one of the core values of our society, as you pointed out. I believe that in the treaties, the idea of a social market economy refers to a high-level economy of jobs, but of quality jobs. It is therefore a key element for social recognition and participation in society. In the past, this amounted to stable employment and, to the extent desired, full-time employment.  In recent decades, the form of industrial relations has become considerably more diverse and, let's face it, has very often worsened. This trend continued during the crisis. More and more workers do not have indeterminate employment contracts and are struggling to obtain them. Sometimes they don't even succeed and therefore really plunge into a lasting precariousness. People in precarious jobs are, for the most part, faced with poor quality work, poor pay, poverty at work, insecurity and vulnerability. You have mentioned it, indeed. We are now seeing the development of a category of working poor, people who are employed but who, in fact, are no longer able to live off the wages of their work.  A 2012 report by the European Parliament's research department showed that almost 10% of Europe's working-age population was poor. I wonder, because we had a strategy that was the 2020 strategy, one of the major social objectives of which was a significant reduction of 20 million. It was therefore a quantified and not insignificant target to reduce the number of poor people in Europe by 20 million. We have not achieved that goal. I believe that when we are going to renew the 2020 strategy, we really need to focus on finding new avenues and new ways to achieve this poverty reduction target in Europe.  A comprehensive approach is therefore required. We need to focus on the different aspects of the quality of work. It is clear that we want to create jobs, return to a high level of employment, and even move towards full employment. But full employment is not enough. It is a question of getting closer, again, not only to full employment but also to creating quality jobs. When we talk about quality jobs, we are looking at the right pay, benefits and working conditions, and safety and health in the workplace.  Tomorrow, in Luxembourg, there will be a conference on workplace safety and health and working conditions. This debate on working conditions, particularly in the framework of the European Health and Safety Strategy, seems to us to be extremely important and europe will of course have to renew this strategy on safety and health.  As for access to education and vocational training, I must welcome the report on the competitiveness of labour markets, as it highlights the importance of vocational training and shows very well that if we want to have inclusive and even competitive labour markets, one of the keys is access to training. I believe that in the long run in Europe, in order to cope also with changes in the labour market and the technological revolution, it will be necessary to ensure that every employee and every worker has a real right to training because training is his guarantee of securing his professional careers. We know that the economy is changing and changing a great way and that you cannot guarantee that someone will be able to keep the same job for the rest of their lives, as they did thirty, forty or fifty years ago. But we must give every employee the guarantee that he will be able to follow this evolution of the labour market and find a job if his or hers disappears. Combating and preventing unreported work will also help to improve the quality of employment for those working in Precarious. In this regard, I hope that the negotiations between our two institutions on the decision to establish a platform to combat undclared work can be concluded as soon as possible. A trilogue was held this week; We have to move on. For the Presidency, the aim is to achieve this by the end of the year. Young people, as you mentioned, are a particularly vulnerable group, as are others, for example, people with disabilities, who have a lot of difficulties in the labour market. Good quality work is one of the key elements of the Council's 2013 recommendation on the creation of the Youth Guarantee. The main recommendation is to ensure that all young people under the age of 25 receive a good quality job offer, an offer of continuing education, apprenticeship or internship within four months of redundancy or after leaving formal education. I am also referring to a recommendation from the Commission on internships because, in my opinion, as important as internships are for young people and for their integration into the labour market, we must also recognise that there is an abuse in terms of internships. In Germany, we are talking about the Generation Praktikum, that is, young people who go from one internship to another without real remuneration, without social guarantees and without the prospect of finding an indeterminate contract. As a result, these young people live for many years in a real precarious situation. I would also add that Parliament, in fact, dealt a lot with this aspect of internships a few years ago, and I believe of course that there are states that have dealt with or regulated this issue of internships. It is indeed necessary, especially for young people, to find coherent solutions in this area.  I would also add that women are disproportionately represented in precarious jobs. They may have very short hours, low pay and limited access to allowances. And let's not talk about their pension rights! In reality, we are creating new sources of poverty.  Yes, there is the issue of the minimum social wage and I welcome the introduction, finally, of a minimum social wage in the country where you come from. But in Europe, I think there are 21 or 22 countries that have a minimum social wage. The minimum social wage is therefore not, on its own, a guarantee against poverty. It all depends, of course, on the level of this minimum wage.  Indeed, I believe that we must once again make the organisation of work and the labour market, as was also presented in this very interesting report on competitiveness and labour markets, a great subject in Europe to, precisely, to ensure that economic recovery also goes hand in hand with new social guarantees and with social progress.  I also see an important role for the social partners. The Latvian Presidency has made social dialogue a major issue. In my view, social partners have an important role to play. I would also like to point out that there is still a framework agreement that was concluded in Europe in 2010 on inclusive labour markets and that this framework agreement between social partners provided for a number of interesting elements to prevent precariousness, to make labour markets work better and guarantee social rights. Social dialogue must be encouraged and promoted at European and national level. It also means preserving the right to collective agreements because there is no social dialogue without a strong right to collective bargaining.  I will add a word about wage policy. Wage policy has two aspects: the social aspect, namely being able to make a living from one's work. But it also has an economic dimension. We see this today, in fact, in the sharing of value-added in Europe as in the United States — it is not for nothing that President Obama is strongly committed to raising wages in the United States. This recovery and sharing also have an important economic dimension.  Finally, the Luxembourg Presidency has made the social dimension one of its priorities. I would also like to mention in this context the social and solidarity economy, which was presented in the other excellent report, which I welcome. The Presidency has also made the promotion of the social and solidarity economy one of its main priorities, since we will be organising a major conference in Luxembourg in December on the promotion of social entrepreneurship and we will propose to the Council to adopt conclusions on the development, strengthening and promotion of the social economy in general, and social entrepreneurship in particular. Precarious employment, we must knowledge, is damaging to cohesion and to our economies. It blocks the prospects of an entire generation of young people. This risks leading to a vicious cycle by increasing inequality and generating both insecurity and instability.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, Minister, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I am pleased to contribute at this point to the joint debate on a series of essential topics related to the EU labour market. They touch upon the challenges we need to address in order to firmly anchor the EU into recovery, economic growth, job creation and social progress.  The European Commission wants a AAA social rating for the EU and the recent Five Presidents’ report makes it clear that the notion of convergence is at the heart of the economic Union.  The two own-initiative reports, the Dlabajová report and the Lope Fontagné report, focus on important topics for our labour markets and we see that their conclusions are generally supportive of the Commission’s policies. We want quality jobs and the skilled workers that we need to support recovery. We support social innovation that helps protect our societies. First, on the oral question on precarious employment: it is undeniable that the crisis has had a significant social impact on the labour market, particularly the increase in unemployment, under-employment and precarious employment. Precariousness is difficult to define and monitor statistically, but we can approach it via the evolution of temporary contracts and part-time work. Let me be clear that temporary work and part-time work do not necessarily equate to precarious work as they also introduce necessary flexibility to the labour market.  The figures confirm that temporary work follows an economic cycle. They first declined in 2008, but they also first recovered in 2013. Actually, they increased by 8.7 % during this period. That is to say part-time employment increased by 8.7 % during that period but, on the contrary, full-time employment decreased dramatically. Even though the creation of full-time jobs outnumbers the creation of part-time jobs since 2014, those figures still remain 4.6 % below the 2008 level. Hence, there are signals of recovery but serious challenges remain. Initiatives have already been introduced at EU level to determine a minimum set of rights for workers who are subject to the more precarious forms of contracts, namely the three directives on fixed-term, part-time and temporary agency work. It is worth recalling that two of those directives – i.e. on fixed-term and part-time work – are the fruit of social dialogue since they are based on a framework agreement between Europe’s trade unions and employers. They all aim to guarantee decent working conditions for the workers concerned, notably ensuring the principle of equal treatment while providing businesses with the flexibility they need to overcome traditional difficulties and ensure their development. While the fixed-term and part-time directives are being currently evaluated, the European Commission has already released a report on the Temporary Agency Work Directive. This report was published last year and it concludes that the directive has been correctly implemented and applied and that there is no need for revising it at this stage. The Commission would rather focus on ensuring its proper implementation. New forms of employment have been developed, some with a clear risk of precariousness. Undeclared work and bogus self-employment are among the most harmful forms of precarious employment. We monitor these developments and we consider action at EU level where appropriate. Furthermore, in the framework of the European semester on economic policy coordination, the European Commission recommends that Member States tackle the segmentation of labour markets and fight undeclared work. In 2014, we also proposed to create a platform to prevent and deter undeclared work. The proposal is under discussion by the co-legislators and the Commission expects an agreement to be reached in the near future so that the platform can be set up without delay. The Commission is also examining whether a strengthened set of EU social rights for the protection of those in and out of work would be needed, notably in the light of new forms of employment. The role of social partners is permanent. While consultation with social partners in the European semester is being strengthened and streamlined at EU level, the involvement in the design and implementation of national reforms also needs to be strengthened. Low-skilled workers who may be caught in a vicious circle unless we take the issues of skills seriously are more affected by precariousness. In order to fight unemployment, guarantee quality in employment and allow Europe to grow in a sustainable way, we need to ensure the right skills for our workers. We therefore welcome Mrs Dlabajová’s report, which sets out a number of ways to achieve those goals and enrich the European skills agenda which we are currently developing. We converge on three key policy needs. First, together with all labour market stakeholders, anticipating skills needs and access skills gaps across the EU. Second, developing skills with more and better vocational education and training and apprenticeships and thereby bringing skills closer to the labour market’s needs. Finally, improving recognition of skills formally or informally acquired at any point in time across Member States and sectors, which is essential to support mobility as a factor of employability and competitiveness. On the Lope Fontagné report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation, this is another sector which helps to fight unemployment and encourage work is social entrepreneurship. Its role is rightly underscored in the Lope Fontagné report. Many good actions have been taken both at EU and Member State level, but we agree that there is room and need for further concrete initiatives. We need a comprehensive approach as it is especially important for social enterprises to combine better access to finance with better visibility and to develop a vision and enabling regulatory framework. Finance is not enough if visibility and proper recognition by policy makers at all levels are not ensured. The Commission provides several channels of financial support but it is also taking initiatives, for instance with the OECD, to better understand the sector and support Member States in their efforts to build up an environment conducive to social enterprises. Moreover, I agree with the rapporteurs that we need to promote social innovation since it plays a critical role in modernising our social protection systems. Social innovation is also financially supported both in the European Social Fund and in the employment and social innovation programme. I look forward to a fruitful and interesting discussion.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! I am delighted that, on the day the President of the European Commission delivered his speech on the state of the European Union, we have the opportunity to have a comprehensive discussion on the labour market and employment in Europe. I will fully believe, after Jean-Claude Juncker, that the economic crisis will end if we succeed in full employment. Today, decisive steps and bold, well-thought-out structural reforms in the labour market are needed to unambiguously improve efficiency and safety.  Recently, together with Martina Dlabayova and colleagues from the political groups, I had the pleasure of working on a very good report by the Committee on Employment on the need to adapt the skills and qualifications of workers to job vacancies. If we want to have a competitive labour market in Europe in the 21st century, we must first of all teach young people starting their careers responsibility for their own decisions and prepare them for the need for continuous education and requalification. Despite high unemployment, entrepreneurs are too often unable to find a candidate with the right experience and skills. This continues to show that curricula have not been adapted to employers' requirements. In this area, immediate concrete action is needed. It must be standard practice to cooperate efficiently between universities, businesses and public and private employment services, as well as the employees themselves. In addition, there is a need to constantly monitor future trends in labour markets and anticipate the need for skills and qualifications. Incentives are needed for small and medium-sized enterprises to be willing to invest profits in training for workers. These and other valuable recommendations are contained in the report on which we will vote tomorrow. The Group of the European People's Party is determined to combat inequalities in the labour market, unfair abuse and circumvention of European legislation in order to lower social standards. We are responsible for the use of fixed-term contracts, self-employment institutions. These are instruments that should not be abused in order to reduce labour costs. It should be remembered that they are necessary for flexible labour markets. (The President has taken the vote of the Member)

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the "Poor despite work" is not a myth, this is bitter reality and no longer the exception. This has nothing to do with the crisis alone, this development began long before. This applies not only to the low-skilled, but also to engineers and highly qualified people. More than 2.3 million part-time jobs have been created since 2011. Many people in Europe work part-time on forced part-time because they do not get a full-time job. The proportion of fixed-term contracts also remains consistently high, and the sole dictates of competitiveness mean that for more and more people, if they work full-time, they will no longer be able to make a living, that the general public will pay to be able to afford housing, heating and food. The European reality is: posted construction workers or drivers, working for a starvation wage or without social protection, companies, for example in the logistics sector, whose regular workforce consists of temporary workers or employed subcontractors, contracts without working time guarantees, so-called zero-hour contracts, workers on call, for example in the fast food sector, or pilots who, like many other professions, are forced into bogus self-employment, newcomers to the profession, university graduates who go from one unpaid traineeship to the next – that is the reality of Europe! And these are very few examples. This is really pure exploitation under the guise of the flexibility of the labour market. Precarious and illegal employment must not be the rule. For a social triple-A in Europe, we need new legislation, and we need clear definitions of workers. We do not need to observe the long-known loopholes, we need to plug them. We must also ensure that we get work inspections suitable for Europe. I appeal to the Council and the Commission: do not observe, act! The facts are on the table.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I want to thank Martina Dlabajová for her excellent report on creating a creating a competitive EU labour market for the 21st century. This really deserves our support. The progress of the report has not been easy, and I would like to pay tribute to the rapporteur for her constructive and positive enthusiasm to reach agreement. It is a good example of why, just because something is difficult, we should not give up. It is worth fighting for, and it has produced very worthwhile ideas which are concise and targeted and can add real value to the employability and prosperity of people. I will focus on just a couple of areas in particular: entrepreneurship and work—based learning. The report highlights the need to remove bureaucratic obstacles with which SMEs are confronted and enable them to achieve their full job—creation potential. It highlights the need to promote an entrepreneurial mindset in Europe: the need for institutions to be more business—friendly and to support young people in transforming their ideas into successful business plans. It also recognises the importance of fostering work—based learning – apprenticeships – as the alternative route to employment. I was very privileged to visit the Goodwin Group in Stoke-on-Trent last Friday. It is an engineering company established in 1883, and they believe that a radical new approach is needed to raise the level of the individual worker to the standard required for the future. So they have built their own state—of—the—art training school with a centre of excellence for 125 engineering apprentices. The majority of training is in the form of one-to-one placements, and it leads to a variety of worthwhile and fulfilling careers within the group – a great example of matching skills with demand and creating really good job opportunities.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, three points. First of all, I want to thank Ms Lope Fontagné for her excellent cooperation and congratulate her on her very comprehensive report on social entrepreneurship and social innovation in combating unemployment. We have heard that these enterprises employ 14 million people and contribute to social inclusion, rural and regional development and environmental protection. Crucially, these jobs cannot be outsourced. Yet in my opinion, these enterprises deserve greater support than at present. I fully support the recommendations in this report, in particular the need for a legal framework.  Secondly, precarious employment: Commissioner Dombrovskis has told us that it is difficult to define and monitor precarious work. I say to him that this may be true, but equally what most people want is a decent job that will enable them to support themselves and their families. You quoted figures from the Commission’s own social and economic report for the last quarter. But there is another statistic from that report which tells us that in the final quarter of 2015 two thirds of the jobs created were permanent, one third were temporary. The question is: will that one third support families? Probably not. We can and must do better.  Finally, a comment on the excellent report from my colleague Martina Dlabajová on matching skills and qualifications with demand and job opportunities. Her report contains all of the pieces of the jigsaw puzzle that are necessary to match skills and jobs.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, as a Left, we have in the past supported social enterprises with all our might, for example in the context of cooperation. We therefore know and appreciate the potential of these businesses, which focus on people and social development rather than maximising their profits. The report on social enterprises that we are called upon to vote on contains positive elements, such as the definition of those enterprises characterised by the primacy of individual and social objectives over the interests of capital and such as democratic control by their members and the defence and application of the principles of solidarity and responsibility. There is a clear reference to the inability of any undertakings to replace the social state, which was, after all, our amendment. As a Left, however, we cannot tolerate the abolition of the principles of social entrepreneurship and we cannot allow these companies to enter the stock markets and be used by the financial funds either for tax avoidance purposes or to multiply profitability. We believe that social enterprises should remain committed to their social work and should not be used as a gambling vehicle by stock market groups. The European Union must change course and move away from the beaten-up of neoliberalism and unbridled capitalism. We have experience of the current economic crisis, which was precisely caused by this thirst for big profits from banks, the construction industry and other businesses. Social enterprises must stay out of any profit race.... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time for Europe to turn a blind eye to an indisputable fact. The social and solidarity economy has done much better than resist the crisis, it is one of the best antidotes to the crisis. In ten years, the social and solidarity economy has created 23% of jobs, while the traditional economy has created only 7%. There are already 14 million employees in Europe today. It is this producer of milk and yoghurt that produces for the canteens of its territory, for retirement homes and for families. It is this entrepreneur who organizes meetings between young parents and nannies via an internet platform. It is this marketing company that employs 100% of disabled workers and gives them the place they deserve in society.  We are talking about an economic model that makes sense to those who work and benefit from it. What for? Because human beings take precedence over profit, because they allow their members to become employers, employees and, tomorrow, responsible consumers. We are talking about an economic model that provides jobs that cannot be relocated, open to all, and that is not a detail especially for the younger generation. It is up to us only to really extend this model to our entire territory, including by facilitating their access to financing. Let us introduce social and environmental criteria into public procurement to give priority to works that bring them the highest added value, not only economic, but social and environmental, rather than those who simply play the low-cost card. So, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commission, I am sending you a solemn appeal. We are three months away from COP 21. You are able to send that message today. Reconciling the climate with the environment, reconciling the climate with the economy, reconciling the climate with the social, reconciling the climate with well-being but above all reconciling the climate with solidarity. It's that opportunity that you have to seize.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Lope Fontaignèr, I thank you because here in Europe we sometimes see ideas and realities that seem to us to be science fiction, because the social economy is, it is true, the driving force from which we should restart a devastated welfare state, a devastated economy, a mass of European citizens in absolute poverty. These are golden occasions that I see miserably wrecking in my country, because here I hear talk of crowfunding, I hear talk of collaboration, of projects, of young people who receive vigour and impetus, and I in Italy see red cooperatives, which are the pool of votes exchange of votes between politics and employment "I give you a job, if you offer me a vote If you bring me your vote and your family's."  The scandal of the capital mafia is based on the social economy, on red cooperatives and on this shameful way of dealing with a state, a condition that is on the edge of bearable. I am ashamed, every time I speak here in this plenary, I am ashamed to report a situation, that of my country, which is on the edge of decency, indeed it is indecent.  So, I thank you for your work and I agree with you and I tremble at the idea of having to encourage a situation once more that then I know that when you arrive in Italy – do not give me the card, Mr Benifei, because you know very well what I am talking about, so I do not accept your card this time. , because you must have the courage to be self-critical in your country, because we come here and you, like me, should be ashamed of what is happening in our country, of what has been done with the red cooperatives and of those who have benefited, who should benefit. It could have been an opportunity for those who receive the service and those who provide the service to increase and give opportunities, and instead not, we exchanged and gave votes and jobs. It's shameful, I don't accept the card! (The speaker refused to accept a blue card application (Rule 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to the few people here, I have heard about employment, I have heard of the right things, which affect our Europe. But they run counter to what we have heard this morning, with the jersey that I am wearing this evening, and that is the fact that we are with a lot of unemployment and we are going to pick up and continue to think about forfeiting all the refugees and all the illegal ones who are around the world.  It's okay to help the refugees, we'd miss it! It's okay to help the people of Africa, but let's help them at home! Let's help them at home! How many Europeans do not have the job? How many Italians don't have jobs? How many people in the Netherlands, France and Spain are unemployed? Like all other states! How many people in Greece have big problems? So I think that in this Europe there is only one person in charge, who is in charge in Europe, it is not Junker who is a butler, it is Merkel, it is she who says.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Buonanno, I would like to thank Mr Buonanno for his work on I call you to order. You have just said that there are only a few left. If you do not stop this, then there will be even fewer, and Then I will refer you to the Chamber. Incidentally, I rebuke you for using this T-shirt. I believe that it is contrary to Annex 15 of our Rules of Procedure. I will bring this matter to the attention of the President.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, remember how many other resolutions that would supposedly solve the chronic problem of unemployment have been voted for by this Parliament. Consider how many times the Commission has announced initiatives that would solve the Union's economic problems. The truth is that every initiative that has been taken has failed in practice. The measures taken usually exacerbate the problems rather than solve them. It is thought that mobility will solve the problem of unemployment, but all it will do is turn certain countries of the Union into economically dead zones producing only internal migrants. In the last five years of the Memorandum of Understanding, thousands of young people with a high level of training who could contribute to its development have emigrated from Crisis Greece. It is, of course, logical that you should not be concerned about this, since they are now contributing to the development of Germany and other European states. Only a radical change in attitudes and approach to the problem would be a solution, by incentivising workers to stay in their countries of origin. Otherwise, we will soon experience the end of this Union which hypocritically claims to be based on solidarity between nations. Thanks.

name: David CASA
text: – Sur President. Għandna quddiemna aġenda li qed titkellem, fuq il-prekarjat fost ħafna affarijiet oħra, u naħseb din il-kwistjoni ilha, fuq l-aġenda ta' dan il-Parlament issa għal ħafna żmien, u smajna ħafna llejla. Jiena qrajt dwar l-effetti tal-prekarjat, kemm hemm nisa, fl-Unjoni Ewropea li qed jiġu affettwati b'dan it-tip ta' xogħol. Kemm hemm żgħażagħ li qed jiġu affettwati b'dan it-tip ta' xogħol. Minoritajiet oħra li qed jiġu affettwati b'dan it-tip ta' xogħol. U llum smajna flower-Gumsjoni u flower-Kunsill b'mod partikolari jgħidilna, li hemm stat ta' fatt u jiena ngħid flower-Kunsill, iva dana nafuh. Ilna nafuh li jeżistu dawn l-eżempji tant tajbin li użajt inti, fosthom pereżempju, ta' ħaddiema li għadhom qegħdin jgħixu fil-faqar minkejja li għand xogħol. U allura jien irrid ikun, iktar ħert, iktar moħħi mistrieħi mistrieħi li dak li qed ngħidu hawn illum ma jibqax biss stat ta' fatt, imma rridu nimxu issa għall-azzjoni tagħna. Qbilt ħafna mad-discors illi għamlet Laura. Irridu noqogħdu attenti, irridu noqogħdu attenti li meta jiġu l-elezzjonijiet f'pajjiżna mhux inwiegħdu mod imbagħad meta nkunu fil-gvernijiet naġixxu b'mod ieħor. Għandna quddiemna hawnhekk sitwazzjoni reali, sitwazzjoni taħraq, u jiena m'inix kuntent għadni bil-mod ta' kif qed jaġixxi l-Kunsill u qed taġixxi l-Gumsjoni, jiena naħseb illi sar ftit wisq. Irridu definizzjonijiet aħjar ta' x'inhu prekarjat u x'mhuwiex prekarjat. Irridu naraw fejn verament hemm abbuż, għaliex, u fejn hemm abbuż, x'se nagħmlu biex inwaqqfu dan l-abbuż, għaliex mhux biss niġu hawn u ngiduħ jeżisti l-abbuż, dan nafuh. Illum il-kwistjoni li għandna quddiemna mhux jekk għandniex abbużi jew le. U żgur li jeżistu abbużi. Imma x'ser nagħmlu flimkien biex naqtgħu darba għal dejjem dawn l-abbużi. Ma rridux ninsew ukoll il-prin大ipju tas-slipperjarjetà, u hawnhekk nixtieq ukoll nara x'ħa jgħid il-Kunsill u l-Gumsjoni fuq dan l-issue tas-slippersjarjetà, is-slippersjarà huwa valur importanti illi ma jistax jiġi minsi. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I would like to thank you for your support. I absolutely agree with you that there are a pletra of low-paid jobs in the European Union, and in many places we have come to the point where many people do not even make a living from work. But what do you think, and I would ask your opinion, what do you think about the fact that in today's statistical system, if someone is employed for one to two hours a month, they are already fully employed that month?

name: David CASA
text: tweżiba karta blue. – Eťe, fil-fatt ma kenitx domanda, imma naqbel illi fl-aťťar rapport illi gťandna dwar is-sitwazzjoni soèjali u tal-impjiegi wriet li hemm żieda fl-impjiegi permanent u full time, qabżet iż-żieda tal-impjiegi temporanji u part time gťat-tielet darba konsekuttiva fuq perjodu ta' tliet xhur. Imma affirmed il-fatt li gťad jeżisti faqar kif gťedt diżà fost dawk impjegati u fl-aťťar mill-aťťar din tista' tkun bťala sejf li jaqta' miż-żewż naťat, peress li 50 % ta' dawk li qegťdin ifittxu xogťol, gťadhom sfortunatament jgťixu fil-faqar, dan mhux tip ta' xogťol, gťandu rażun.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Europeans have a right to honest and good work. I am therefore very pleased that President Juncker has also stressed this morning the importance of good quality work. But in the light of unemployment, and in particular long-term unemployment, zero-hours contracts, the mini-jobs, flexing up to retirement, seem to be becoming a rule rather than an exception in Europe. A large group of young people have little perspective and they have too much uncertainty. If you don't know if you have a job next year or next month, how can you ever start your own family? However, the Commission continues to prescribe the medicine of flexibility in its recommendations to the various Member States, while it is clear that it has not improved the patient much. Europe's labour market is not doing well and the crisis has added to the uncertainty. I would say, now is the time to invest extra in good, honest and confident work, with the opportunity to develop yourself and with the opportunity to develop your talent. Because we want Europe to become a competitive knowledge-based economy.  It is high time that the Commission took the lead by encouraging Member States to invest in good work, because when they invest in good work, they also stimulate the European economy. My appeal holds not only job seekers responsible, but also the Member States and also the European Commission. They must take responsibility for helping 24 million Europeans to do a good job, and I sincerely hope that my colleague Martina Dlabajová shares this view.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – The inclusion of people with disabilities in the labour market is absolutely economically essential. It's not just about our social or ethical responsibility. No. It's the economy, stupid. In comparison with other job seekers, there are twice as many people with disabilities looking for work. This while their specific skills and talents could contribute to more diversity in teams and companies. Employers need to realise that if they make full use of this unused potential, their businesses can build a competitive advantage.  As long as vulnerable groups such as people with disabilities are excluded, there can be no real competitive and inclusive labour market. After all, so many talents are lost. Taking into account the ageing wave coming at us, that is a real shame.

name: Ulla TØRNÆS
text: – Mr President, the European labour market faces a dilemma. Some 24 million Europeans are unemployed, 12 million Europeans are long-term unemployed and 5 million unemployed Europeans are under the age of 25. At the same time, there are two million jobs in Europe which cannot be filled due to a labour market mismatch and insufficient labour mobility. It is exactly this mismatch that Mrs Dlabajová has addressed in her report which we are discussing tonight. This mismatch is unfortunate for many Europeans who are out of work. It is unfortunate for the businesses which cannot fill their vacancies. It is unfortunate for our societies which miss out on wealth and prosperity. This mismatch in the European labour market causes an uncompetitive European labour market. If we want Europe and Europeans to prosper in the 21st century, we must create a competitive European labour market, and part of this is to avoid this mismatch.  In too many places in Europe, the labour market is rigid, even static. Too many overly strong protectionist measures have blocked initiative, flexibility and opportunities. ‘Good intentions’ can sometimes lead to bad results. We, the representatives of the people of Europe, need to rethink labour market policies; we need to promote flexibility; we need to anticipate future needs as regards skills; we need to ensure that when young Europeans graduate their skills meet the demands of the labour market.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, work is a basic pillar underpinning the exercise of social rights and yet the European Union is not fighting for full employment. It only tries to adapt workers to market demands, so that the employment generated is of poor quality, low wages are perceived and is no longer a guarantee to get out of poverty. This has been helped by the labour reforms imposed, undermining workers' rights for the benefit of enterprises. Today we are debating a competitive labour market that is incompatible with a democratic conception of labour, as workers are treated as goods, numbers in the game of supply and demand. Speaking of individuals, we forget to talk about structures, institutions that condition the volume and quality of employment. It is not a problem of will, capacity or individual initiative. It is even indecent to suggest this when so many are forced to migrate or work in precarious conditions, while the numbers of poverty and inequality continue to grow. Individualization of industrial relations has been encouraged rather than collective bargaining strengthened. Any model changes in the productive structure have been abandoned and, as a measure of employment promotion, business contributions are reduced or rewarded, which also impair a fundamental mechanism to combat poverty, such as pensions. Zero-hour contracts, part-time deregulation, abuse of fellows are other examples. To be sure, there are many challenges of work in the 21st century and everyone is moving away from the neoliberal framework. This report is a missed opportunity to reflect on employment, from structures, and to recover the objective of full quality employment and as a source of rights.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, the EU has a massive problem with youth unemployment, we all agree on this. But there is a myth going around about how to solve this problem. This myth says that all we need to do is provide young people with skills, adjust them to the needs of the labour market and adjust the labour market to the needs of the employers and ‘voilà: problem solved’. I wish it were that easy to solve this problem, but it is not. In fact, if we say that there is just a lack of incentives for young people to find jobs this is placing the blame on these unemployed people for not finding jobs. This is individualising the problem while, actually, we are facing a structural problem.  So what we need is much more and goes beyond what is suggested in the report. We need immense funding for educational systems; we need more investment in order to create jobs, and we need a labour market that serves the needs of the employees rather than employers. We need to put an end to the myth, because the situation as it is now in the European Union is placing the blame on the unemployed people. This is not the way to go, we need to work together to solve this crisis.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate Mrs Dlabajová on her report. The labour market situation in Europe is worrying, as we all know, a level of unemployment of 10%, peaks of 20% for youth unemployment, without taking into account the disparities between the various Member States – I would remind you that in Italy, where I come from, we are well over 40% – and to all this is added the great contradiction of some States that have shortages of workers. , while others have high unemployment.  My colleague's report places great emphasis on the fact that the mobility of workers in Europe is low and I agree that a united Europe cannot afford 0-point mobility. Our task as representatives of european citizens is certainly to encourage it, and we in the 5-Star Movement believe in the importance of labour mobility in Europe, but only if this represents a voluntary opportunity for personal growth and not the obligatory consequence of the lack of work in some countries and relocation, because this would make some countries even poorer and others even richer. , contributing to European disintegration rather than integration.  The creation of a strong and stable labour market certainly depends on investment in education, the fight against early school leaving and the creation of a new entrepreneurial culture. That is why I also very much appreciated the strong reference to small and medium-sized enterprises, which is at the heart of economic productivity and job creation. The creation of a labour market suitable for the 21st century also involves incentives for start-ups, micro-enterprises and, above all, greater dissemination of the entrepreneurial culture among young people.  For these reasons and despite a number of points with which I perhaps do not entirely agree, I believe that this report deserves our overall support. I would also like to stress that this report is the result of collective work carried out together with the shadow rapporteurs. For this reason, I believe that it is preferable to an alternative motion tabled by a single group, a motion whose message I certainly support but whose method I absolutely cannot appreciate.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – Many of the findings in the reports on entrepreneurship and the labour market are correct. The differences in unemployment rates are huge in the European Union, more pronounced still in monetary union.  In Spain and Greece, more than 25 out of 100 people are on the side of that labour market. Youth unemployment still hits 50 percent. Betting on a competitive labour market is a good thing. However, you ignore the cause of these problems, and that is and remains the whole euro story. The south is being billed for this today, and since the euro is a straitjacket around these countries, it is impossible to regain competitiveness and therefore employment cannot be structurally restored. A single-currency zone requires strong labour mobility. It is small to non-existent in the euro area, because we speak other languages, we are different peoples and the EU is inevitable and Thank God it is not one country. So you can still talk about entrepreneurship and social innovation as much as you like. As long as the foundation, namely the failed euro construction, is not reversed, all this remains a measure of nothing.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as I said, there is no clear definition of what precarious work is. The commonly accepted definition is related to the worker's perception of safety at work, a focus that is wrong. If, on the one hand, forms of undeclared, informal or irregular work, or even false green receipts are undoubtedly forms of precarious work and are, first of all, illegal, the Commission has a duty to untangle other forms of work which are currently defined and which are of the free choice and interest of the worker.  For example, it should be considered that part-time work may correspond to a parental right to accompany a child or even to a form of employment of a student worker. This confusion of criteria leads to a difficulty for the European Union in tackling precariousness at work, which is therefore exploited by various employers who abuse the most vulnerable for their own benefit. I would therefore like to know whether the Commission has taken this diversity into account and that there is a need for some mechanism to be objective, a necessary condition for us to be effective in this fight. On the other hand, the Commission needs to be in line with the effects on the labour market of its policies in other sectors, such as the end of the reader quota system. In this row, we are witnessing the decline in employment, as a result of the continued and abrupt fall in milk prices, with a particular impact on the most vulnerable regions, such as the outermost regions, including the Azores, which is my region. Commissioner, my question is very simple in this case: does the Commission expect to compensate agricultural workers thrown into a precarious employment situation and if so, with what mechanisms?

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: – Mr President, I wish to thank the Commissioner and Minister for their responses to the oral question, but unfortunately it is just not enough.  There is a worrying trend developing in the EU and one which is rapidly undermining our existing standards in creating a race to the bottom. The spread of zero-hours contracts, mini jobs and bogus self-employment is becoming a real threat to existing rights and it needs to be stopped. It is very easy to pass the buck and say it is an issue for national governments; something to be resolved at national level. But the truth is that it is just not happening.  Nothing is being done and the situation is getting worse. For example, recent statistics have shown there are now an estimated 1.8 million zero-hours contracts in the UK, an increase of nearly 20% in the past year alone.  Given that the majority of people on these contracts have been with their current employer for over a year working on average 23 hours a week, does the Commission not understand that these contracts threaten the standards created to protect workers? Why are we allowing a system where people – often young, often women and often close to the poverty line – are expected to work full-time hours when it suits the employer but given no protection or guarantee of employment in return?  It is not sustainable, and it certainly is not fair. They still have to feed their kids and pay their rent. We constantly hear, and we did tonight, about the need for flexibility in the employment market. But, Commissioner, this is outright abuse and the problem is spreading. So let us not pass the issue off by saying it is just a problem for Member States to deal with. Let us look at action that can be taken at all levels. I fear if we do not address this issue now it will continue to spread and our achievements to bring social justice and employment rights for all will sadly be a thing of the past.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, speaking of the unequal development of Member States in the context of cohesion policy and unemployment, most colleagues have a mouthful of commitment to reducing disparities between Member States.
