On the other hand, when it comes to reducing unemployment, the same MEPs are the biggest advocates of mobility. I can't help but wonder how you're going to reduce the differences between member states if all young and qualified staff go the way of more developed members from those currently underdeveloped. Who will be the carrier of future development and growth in these poorer countries? Retirees? Civil servants? For cohesion policy to have any chance of delivering any results at all, we need to keep young and qualified people in their home countries. Not with coercion or administrative barriers, but by deircuing each country separately and helping it overcome specific problems and implementing structural reforms that would open up an opportunity for young people to put their knowledge, skills and ideas on the market in their home country at too little cost.

name: Renate WEBER
text: – Mr President, we are living in difficult times and in difficult times we must be creative and innovative. For me the social— and solidarity—based economy is one such measure. It now provides employment for more than 14 million people in the EU and between just 2009 and 2013 created 1.3 million new jobs. Maybe for some this is not much, but if we are smart enough we should capitalise on the huge potential here, considering their diversity, the services they provide and the methods that they use. Since they often employ the socially excluded and many young people, their capacity to enhance cohesion within communities by creating jobs and minimising social inequalities should be duly taken into consideration. Unfortunately, up to now only a few countries already have in place national legislation concerning the social and solidarity based economy. The Commission should be tougher in this direction. Other Member States should follow this example and I am glad to say that my own country, Romania, is close to adopting it. At the same time, appropriate support should be provided for the establishment and development of small and medium—sized enterprises, the backbone of our economy. We cannot ask for new jobs and quality jobs without helping those who can provide them by creating the proper environment.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Mr President, in several countries, behind much data on falling unemployment rates, there is another reality which is precarious employment, insecurity and the misery of many workers. In my country, Portugal, it has been called that the so-called occupied are not part of the unemployment rates, they are not unemployed. The so-called employed are workers who, instead of enjoying an employment contract that corresponds to the permanent job they often occupy - often even in public institutions - are workers who have the so-called employment and insertion contract, attend an internship or a vocational training course and are not unemployed.  Last June, in Portugal, there were already more than 150,000 workers who had this kind of precarious bond, about 50,000 of them with such a contract called employment and insertion, in which workers work like any other worker but earn below the minimum wage. Now, how does the European Union want to combat precariousness if it is the European Union itself that finances this type of labour exploitation? In the previous financial framework there were more than EUR 95 million from the European Social Fund for this type of contracts. It is certainly not with the increased flexibility of industrial relations that you repeat so much that you will build the competitive labour market that will improve the lives of workers. Flexibility is precisely the precariousness that disrespects workers' rights. On the contrary, it is respect for these rights that will lead to increased employment.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Social business is undoubtedly good for society. It increases the country's economic competitiveness, promotes smart growth through social innovation, promotes social cohesion and reduces exclusion. I therefore support the report's idea that the European Union must support all types of social enterprises. We need to encourage the development of these companies, because they create long-term jobs. A good example is the restaurant in the Capital of Lithuania, which aims to enable non-users of psychotropic substances to reintegrate into society and the labour market. After successfully completing the rehabilitation programme, 70% of the cafeteria staff work as waiters, bartenders and cooks. We would like to see more of these examples, so we need to create incubators for this business, ensure that entrepreneurs from different countries share their experiences, enable young people to participate in training and help to create this type of company financially.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: – Mr President, I am sure we all are familiar with the Harry Potter film in which the goblins speak gobbledygook. Well, I note with interest that the rapporteur has adopted that language in drafting this document. Has the EU also adopted it as its official language? It seems so. How else can we explain the desire for a return to Luddism that is reflected in the policy proposals we see here? Technology – or to use the new word that has been invented ‘automisation’ – is to be kicked to the kerb in order to keep people in menial jobs. We have all experienced the frustration at a self-service checkout, but is that sufficient to warrant European legislation stopping technological progress? These are the very industries and start-ups that are often helped via EU funding. Economic growth is not achieved by the ‘stop the world, I want to get off’ attitude which the EU seems to embrace. Already we have seen global market output predicted to fall to 14.2% – down from 30.9% in the 1980s. Under the European employment scheme EURES, only 25 jobs have gone to British applicants out of a total of 3 887 placements. That works out at EUR 45 400 per job to the British taxpayer and highlights once again why EU membership is not in Britain’s best interest. Now we have the proposals for the European minimum wage framework – further hammering home how many of the powers that should be in the hands of our MPs in Westminster have been passed on to the unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The report by my colleague, Véronica Lope Fontagné, puts the spotlight on players in our economies who, wrongly, often lead a shadowy existence: social enterprises. Yes! They are set up for social goals, not profit maximisation. Cooperatives, foundations and associations employ 14 million workers across Europe, and they have mastered the crisis better than many traditional for-profit companies. For example, more than one million new jobs were created in the healthcare sector, where many of them are represented, between 2009 and 2013 alone. Their corporate governance is characterised by democratic structures and great transparency. This makes it all the more important that they are more widely recognised in politics, society and the media at local, regional, national and European level. The European Commission, Commissioner, should consistently implement all the measures taken under the 2012 Social Entrepreneurship Initiative and, in my view, also promote them in the future through national programmes of the European Social Fund. And banks should do more, as social enterprises often have far too little access to finance. The reason is that this type of company is not sufficiently well known by many banks. That is why the creation of a special European fund for the banking sector has a particular signalling effect. In addition, we are encouraged by the Employment and Social Innovation Programme, in which we have a sub-programme for social entrepreneurship. Let us place these companies where they belong: in the awareness of the public of the European Union!

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the report on social entrepreneurship, social innovation and the fight against unemployment, which will be voted on tomorrow and which I was able to follow as rapporteur for my group, we have included important indications for the future and that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for employment must be added; It is essential, in order to do this, to support social economy enterprises in achieving these objectives, given their better ability to retain jobs during the crisis and to create new ones.  We must fight for EU funds to be disbursed more effectively and to really reach those who need them on the ground. We must ensure that even the groups most excluded from the labour market, in particular people with disabilities, are reached and guaranteed in their inclusion. In the report we have made clear the need for full and fair access to contracts by social enterprises.  In some countries such as Italy, but not only, it is precisely the cooperative movement that is making a mass mobilization, with petitions and legislative proposals to combat abuses, exploitation and even criminal events in the world of the social economy, precisely because in the history and values of the international cooperative movement, the fight against those who exploit workers damages society. I believe that this should be given credit for, it should be remembered, valued and not denigrated.  In conclusion, I want to say that the labour market in Europe is changing rapidly, reacting and adapting to the demographic challenges of technological innovations. It is impossible and perhaps even pointless to oppose this, but it is our task to ensure that this change is not done at the expense of the protection of fundamental social rights that make the European social model unique in the world and are the basic condition for a fair and sustainable economy for the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, 'Merce' austerity has filled Europe with armies of unemployed people now amounting to 24 million. Unemployment rates are moving at high levels. At the same time, however, there are large differences in unemployment rates from country to country. In impoverished Greece the figure is 26%; in Germany is only 5%. Youth unemployment in Greece has exceeded 53%; Spain is following it. At the same time, two million jobs remain vacant in the European Union and cannot be filled due to mismatched qualifications and labour market needs. However, in order to create a competitive labour market, a direct correlation between education, training and the labour market is needed. More public and private investment is needed. Investment in innovative sectors and strengthening of social services are needed. But first of all, we need to stop austerity and erase the shameful debt that is the main source of poverty and unemployment in the European Union.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: – Mr President, I am very pleased that the debate is joint because, at the heart of the matter, the two texts — which I am sure will be adopted tomorrow — speak of the same thing. That is, they talk about the future, about adapting to the future, of looking to the future without fear in the world of work, in the world of initiative, and this is important. I think we've all learned that there's not going to be that old industrial model of big companies with a lot of hardworking, highly skilled, very mechanized. This is gradually changing and it is inevitable and, moreover, beneficial for labour markets to adapt to these new technologies, to these new flexibilities, but also to these new potentials. And so he does very well the excellent text of my colleague Martina Dlabajová in talking about education, which is much more than training in mobility, in a spirit of initiative, in great agility to move from academia to the productive world and vice versa, to adapt schools, a new model of social dialogue or a new social dialogue adapted to the circumstances , also participating in the training, in the individual projection of the workers' initiative, which does not mean, in any case, giving up our social model or the rights they have, including strengthening them. It has nothing to do with it. We are drawing a labour market adapted to the new circumstances.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: "Mr President, Bertold Brecht said that when the people above talk about peace, the plain people know that there will be war. Something like this suggests this report to us. There are good intentions in it that we clearly share, but all these good words contrast with the repetition of old recipes such as the easing of the labour market, the results of which we already know: more job insecurity and 8% of poor workers in the European Union.  There are many nice words, but not a single mention of the dire economic, social and environmental repercussions that TTIP can have for Europe. Is this support compatible with small and medium-sized enterprises, which the report contends, with a Treaty strengthening the power of multinationals? Encouraging labour mobility, as is insistently proposed, i.e. emigrating the regions with the most unemployment to the most prosperous, means condemning the territories most hit by the crisis to ageing and losing a human capital and skilled workforce that has been very hard for them to form. The solution to the problem of unemployment cannot be reduced to a question of labour recycling courses, to design education systems based on fluctuations in the labour market or to instill from childhood entrepreneurship. We need as soon as possible a change of root in the economic policies of the European Union, breaking with austerity and the contraction of public investment and enhancing from the sustainable development political states based on progressive fiscal reform.  We cannot continue to generate precariousness in Europe. We can't keep mortgaged the future of ours.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, as far as jobs go, there is an elephant in the room, although not – unless I blinked and missed it – in the rapporteur’s report: the disastrous currency zone of the euro is surely a major factor behind high unemployment in the EU.  Unemployment is highest and job creation lowest in the countries least suited to being in a currency zone dominated by Germany. Countries like Greece and Spain needed their own currencies so they could depreciate to protect activity levels in the worst of the crisis. The euro meant they could not do that, so activity levels collapsed, taking jobs with them.  Thanks in part to the recent application of quantitative easing (QE), there has been some softening of the euro, but there is, of course, no chance of Greece or Spain depreciating against Germany. When the German economy is going full pelt again, no doubt there will be pressure for QE to end, interest rates to rise and the euro to rise again in value. For southern Europe the era of mass unemployment is here to stay for as long as the euro is.

name: Marek PLURA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. At the outset, I would like to congratulate my colleagues Lope Fontagné and Dlabayova on preparing thorough and comprehensive reports and thank them for their openness and willingness to cooperate. The economic and financial crisis is a painful lesson for us. It clearly demonstrates the crucial importance of building a cohesive, inclusive society in which everyone has a role to play and in which the potential of every citizen is developed, valued and supported regardless of their gender, age, disability or education. By rebuilding the European economy, we must strive to restore citizens' trust in public institutions and to build social capital. Strategic partnerships between the public sector, educational institutions, business and NGOs are needed to achieve this ambitious goal. Better preparing young people for labour market requirements requires changes in the education system, in particular the introduction of a dual model and entrepreneurship education. As my colleague Šojdrová pointed out yesterday, when presenting her report, entrepreneurship is the ability to put ideas into practice, and entrepreneurship education triggers creativity, initiative, innovation, independence of thought and many other important characteristics, both professionally, socially and civicly. I also fully support the reporting demands for removing barriers to the development of the social and solidarity-based economy and promoting this important sector with huge economic, social and innovative potential.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: – Mr President, Minister Schmit and Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent In fact, most of it has already been said in this debate. We may not be entirely in agreement, but there is a very broad consensus on an agenda that means that we are going to fight unemployment. We will ensure that we have a labour market with just conditions. It is order and solidarity and dignity.  Mr Juncker made me happy already this morning because he was talking about this in this House. He did it very well, just as most of us have spoken here tonight. Then I am pleased when Minister Schmit, who is the Council's responsible representative, reiterated this, and also with the support of the Commissioner. I believe that there is hope, but what I intend to do now is to be involved in ensuring that this can be realised. I think it's been spoken. There's been enough talk. Now we have to get to work.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking today about the enormous unemployment in the European Union. It averages ten per cent, young people over 20 per cent and in some Member States more than 50 per cent. This is absolutely appalling. And what does the EU think about this? Ad 1: It wants more government investment. This is the wrong way to go, the state is not the better investor. And ad 2: She wants a Europe-wide minimum wage. That, too, is the wrong way to go, and I would like to say that it is even more wrong. This does not work in Germany. But the worst thing is that it hits the most vulnerable in particular. In Germany, the average hourly wage is 25 euros, in Bulgaria it is 3.20 euros. How can this be lumped together? We currently have 24 million unemployed in the EU, seven and a half million of whom are young people. The minimum wage will multiply this problem. What we need: less red tape for businesses, taxes down, abolishing the minimum wage. In short, we do not need more EU and more state, the solution is less EU, less state, much less state, in fact, much less state.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Mr Minister, the unemployment figures in the European Union are overwhelming, especially for the most vulnerable social groups, 24 million unemployed, i.e. about one tenth of the working population, 6 million unemployed have been unemployed for more than two years, youth unemployment between 16 and 25 is twice as high as , in some cases three times as many as the adult unemployed, the employment rate of women is 10% lower than that of men. On the other hand, 123 million Europeans, a quarter of the working population, are at risk of poverty. Mr Minister, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, unemployment and poverty are neither a curse nor a fatality. They result from policies that can be corrected and, if they can be corrected, it is mandatory to do so, do so!

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Thank you very much, Mr. President. The crisis will only end when unemployment in Europe is over, President Juncker said this morning. Agree. Only the end of unemployment is not consistent with what the report calls a 'competitive labour market' or with the tools and policies it proposes. It is not the lack of training for unemployment experienced by 23 million citizens in the EU, nor is unemployment a disease for which the unemployed, who must become even more flexible and mobile, are to blame. We agree with certain ideas in the report, such as the self-evident need for apprenticeships, the improvement of workers' skills and synergies between all actors in production. However, in Greece, one in two young people is unemployed, while the majority of children, although they have degrees, skills, postgraduate degrees and speak more than two foreign languages, are forced to do footwork, with a month's age of 300 euros. Training alone does not solve the problem if the economy cannot harness people's skills. Instead of advice and advice, a brave programme of public and private investment is needed first and for all to make way for the qualifications and skills that are currently being discredited. Thanks.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, the precariousness of employment is an increasingly worrying reality. It has plural origins. First of all, there are the effects of the crisis we are going through, but it is also the result of changes in our economies and the evolution of management methods, especially in larger companies. Lack of economic predictability and flexible work are an important component. This precariousness takes various forms, such as the development of part-time work, fixed-term contracts and the use of temporary jobs. It also takes an illegal form, illegal through unreported work or the proliferation of false independents. These fraudulent practices must be firmly combated, including through the effective establishment of the platform to combat undclared work, by strengthening social inspections and their coordination, and by setting up and setting up a social Europol, a European social inspection.  As far as atypical contracts are concerned, it is essential to provide measures to secure career paths. Lifelong learning is, from this point of view, a determining factor. Finally, the fight against job incarisation, the fight against fraud and measures to secure career paths must be an integral part of the social basis mentioned this morning by the President of the Commission. If the European Union wants to qualify for a triple A, and it must do so, it must rise to this challenge.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, today we are talking about one of the phenomena that are taking place in our labour market, about the deterioration of our labour market and the precariousness that it has been experiencing in recent years, something we probably do not devote enough time to. We talk a lot about the nearly 25 million parades we have. We talk a lot, too, and sometimes about the emigration that is taking place. Mobility is very positive in Europe, but when it is voluntary, not when it is a generational obligation, as is happening in some places in Europe. And we don't spend enough time to see what the situation in our labour market is. As for the labour market, we can say in general terms that where wages have been reformed have been lower, no doubt. Overtime is being paid less and less. It is clear that collective bargaining in many countries has been deteriorating. The temporality has gone up a lot. Bias in contracts, not beloved on many occasions, has been increasing. And above all, within this logic of internal devaluation that has occurred in recent years within the euro. Our debate is about the reforms we have to make. It is clear that structural reforms need to be made, something we agree on, changes need to be made, it is clear that changes must be made in labour markets. The problem is that the changes can be good, bad, positive or a disaster. The question is what changes need to be made. Either we weaken our labor market, as has been done so far, or we are committed to added value, to education, to a more competitive economy in knowledge, not wages, in a world where, due to globalization, we will not be able to compete with low wages.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The European labour market is currently facing a number of problems, including skills mismatch with the needs of the labour market and low labour mobility of the European Union, which, despite the twenty-five million unemployed, we still have two million vacancies in the Union. Statistics illustrating the details of this phenomenon are atomised, collected and analysed at regional level, while meta-analyses are needed to create a coherent European Union policy in this area, giving a picture of the whole of Europe. Adequate market monitoring at European Union level is therefore another urgent task that would build a healthy and competitive labour market. The main barriers to european mobility identified in the research are, paradoxically, ignorance or poor knowledge of foreign languages, cultural differences, lack of guaranteed housing and complex administrative procedures. The rationale needed to modify existing anti-unemployment programmes, such as Eures, can be inferred from them. In order to increase mobility, clear procedures for recognising the qualifications of citizens from different European Union countries, emphasis on foreign language education and training and training to improve intercultural communication are also needed. Matching skills with market needs, in turn, requires changes in the education system, in particular the rehabilitation of vocational training, close cooperation between schools and the labour market, the popularisation of dual education at all levels of education, taking into account social and humanities fields, and a meaningful apprenticeship programme and the presence of professionals in higher education. Many European Union countries have positive experiences in the above-mentioned areas, such as Germany in dual education and in school-market cooperation. So it's worth taking advantage of and taking inspiration from those systems that produce good results. They are based on cooperation between schools not only with large workplaces, but also with the communities of craftsmen and small family businesses, which are a pillar of the European economy.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, I would like to refer you to two points that President Juncker particularly stressed this morning regarding employment that are of direct relevance to this debate. Firstly, that refugees must be given the chance to work, which – besides letting them earn money – is a matter of basic human dignity. Secondly, it is actually full employment that we should be striving to achieve.  The report on a competitive labour market has the severe impediment of proceeding from the assumption that people are inclined to remain idle or passive behind rigid protective social and labour barriers, since they supposedly lack the necessary entrepreneurial spirit and impulse to be mobile: a deeply flawed defining proposition, since it is at odds with the basic human preference for a life in dignity and the accompanying desire to engage in productive work given the chance to find meaningful and rewarding jobs.  Conversely, and quite correctly, the other report highlights the need to enable social- and solidarity-based enterprises to grow, and urges Member States to promote the cooperative enterprise model, precisely as contributing factors so that the social- and solidarity-based economy may fulfil its defining mission to provide full, high-quality employment. In this regard, I would like to urge Commission Vice-President Dombrovskis to personally commit himself to ensuring that the Commission responds positively to the call, contained in the report, for the Commission to come forward with a legal framework codifying a dependable specific status for such enterprises, defined as having other objectives than simply profit for shareholders As to the platform on undeclared work, just a word to assure you – since I am the rapporteur on behalf of Parliament – that we shall do everything in our power to enable the inauguration of this platform before the end of the year.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, the 23 million unemployed people in Europe are the result not only of the economic crisis of the past years, but also the result of structural shortcomings within EU labour markets. We have to tackle these if we are to create more employment in Europe in the years to come.  Therefore I advocate three solutions: firstly, facilities for labour mobility, secondly, an improved entrepreneurial environment and, thirdly, a better way of matching the education system and employers’ needs, mainly through vocational education. On the first point, labour mobility: nowadays citizens have to move to where the jobs are. Therefore, cities need to provide enough affordable housing for people from rural areas who need a second house in the city for working days during the week. A further point on labour mobility: we talk a lot about people moving between EU Member States, but we also need to talk more about people moving within an EU Member State. There are still significant discrepancies between regions in terms of employment opportunities within a country. I therefore call on the Commission to establish a catalogue of best practices to stimulate mobility within a Member State and to share these experiences with Member States which still have work to do on labour mobility. Secondly, on improving the entrepreneurial environment, we all know the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme established by the Commission. It is a good programme, which I fully support, but it needs to be complemented by a similar programme at national level. The Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme obliges you to move from your home country to another country to undertake a traineeship paid by the Commission with an already established entrepreneur. It is a good programme and I give it my full support, but Member States should also launch and publicly finance such programmes at national level in order to stimulate mobility within the Member States. The Commission could assist, based on its experience with Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs at European level.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister Schmit, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I would like to say straight away that we are not used to having the representative of the Council here at such a late hour, especially in this important debate on the labour market. Therefore welcome here at this time! "A competitive labour market". If I only read the title of this report, I tell you, I really put my hair up, I get goosebumps. It sounds to me as if social dumping, precarious working conditions, the whole range that we know so much – zero-hours contracts and so on and so forth – are the panacea for making the labour market competitive. I know countries – and these are certainly the richer ones in the European Union – where it has already become a system for wages to not be enough, namely that taxpayers will eventually have to shell out so that people can get by on their incomes. An absurd situation! This has nothing to do with competition, it is unfair competition and it has nothing to do with it in the European Union. The free movement of workers and mobility are, of course, important principles that we should defend. However, the mobility of workers is an instrument in our internal market that can be used by workers, which is intended to give them an advantage, but which does not need to be used. And it is up to us to do everything we can to create jobs for people, wherever they live, and not just to cart them around wildly in the area.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: PPE). – Mr President, Honourable Vice-President of the Commission, when we talk about competitiveness, we are talking about high levels of productivity, quality staff and added value, namely the ability to be faster, more successful and more profitable than others. This formula of success is as simple as it is complex, because the foundation of a prosperous Europe is in quality human capital.  It is really time to invest in our people, in our young generation and especially in our talents. The number of young people out of training or employment is indeed too high. There is also an increase in the number of dropouts from school. Even young people with a high level of education fail to find a professional realization. However, this does not mean that our young generation is incapable, it simply means that the knowledge and skills being promoted do not meet the needs of the labour market. Unemployment has been a key word in Europe for too long and this negative trend needs to change. Therefore, we need to direct young people to the professions of the future, those that do not even exist, to create quick-thinking, creative staff with excellent digital skills and analytical abilities. I really strongly believe in the need to build an ecosystem of strategies at European level, including measures such as education reform, supporting entrepreneurship, improving working mobility, as many of my colleagues have mentioned, within Europe, in order to be really much better prepared for the challenges not only for the 21st century, but also for the 22 century. By promoting business through quality staff and innovative products, we will finally stop talking about unemployment and mention the word competitiveness much more often.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the authors of these reports because discussion about labour markets is urgently needed. In my minute of speaking time I want to concentrate on one topic, which is also referred to in many articles of the report: still not enough is being done to develop a real strategy concerning the effects of the digital single market on the labour market. That is a major challenge. Not only do we have to teach computer skills to children, as is mentioned in this report, but we also have to address the structural changes in the labour market which will be a consequence of the digital single market in Europe in the coming years. They need very thorough analysis, and I call on Commissioner Dombrovskis, together with Commissioners Ansip and Oettinger, to present very soon their comprehensive analysis of structural changes on labour markets which will demand new skills. The skills in question are not just simple computer skills, but also more complex skills, which will have to be taught to children and young people. So please come to us with such a strategy, Commissioners. The Social Democrats will help you because this is high on our agenda.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Work is man's highest good.  Its availability is more important than any other human need. The life and health of a person and the development of his family depend on work. Member States and the European Union should work towards the best and most effective solutions to create new jobs. This is combined with multiple directions of activity. On the one hand, entrepreneurs, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the largest source of jobs and at the same time the companies that are able to adapt most flexibly to the situation, should be supported. Without the promotion of entrepreneurship, without reducing financial costs and bureaucracy, it is impossible to effectively increase the number of new jobs. On the other hand, we should increase the mobility of society in Europe, especially for young people, because mobility is one of the conditions for responding to the needs of the labour market, also from an international point of view, and not just from a local, regional or national level. Most importantly, education, including vocational education, must be supported and modernised. It needs to be improved and adapted to the requirements of the modern knowledge economy. Practical vocational training and planning strategies for the development of education must be subordinated to the future needs of the labour market and not only to the present. Today we have a paradoxical situation in many countries. On the one hand, there is a significant demand for workers on the economic side and, on the other hand, there is a shortage of skilled workers. This harmful paradox of the European labour market must be eliminated.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that we have precious human capital in Europe, in my country, in Italy, animated by civil passion within a path of new communities that today gives meaning to a market idea that puts sustainable growth before profit, especially from a social point of view. In a modern vision of welfare, the social economy today becomes a lever of new and good employment, especially for the most fragile and vulnerable people; differences and the regulatory framework for the various Member States are sometimes an insurmountable obstacle.  We must therefore promote the different regulatory framework – finally of a European scope – which will enable the company system, associations and foundations to overcome the current fragmentation in order to compete throughout the European market. It seems to me that the decision by Parliament and the Commission, Commissioner, to recognise the fundamental role of the social enterprise system as an important player in the 2020 strategy to strengthen cohesion and economic growth policies can no longer be postponed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I would like to support the reports by our colleagues Martina Dlabajová and Verónica Lope Fontagné. I am convinced they are important and I am glad that our group, the EPP Group, is ready to support them. I am in complete agreement with the main points of the reports. Skills mismatch is a major problem in terms of a competitive workforce and a flexible labour market in Europe. If Europe wants to fight unemployment, especially youth unemployment, and if it wants to continue to play a crucial role in the world economy, it needs to adopt policies which will focus on good skills and competencies. I agree that we should work on increasing the mobility of workers and on cooperation between schools and the productive sector, providing practical experience to students. I am delighted that yesterday Parliament approved my report on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training. Parliament called for entrepreneurship skills to be included in school curricula, and this is precisely the right step for increasing the competitiveness of young graduates in the labour market. Entrepreneurship skills, such as a sense of initiative, risk taking, resilience, and financial and ICT literacy, are quite universal and can be used both in entrepreneurship activity and by employers. I am happy to see that the report by my colleague Ms Dlabajová mentions the importance of fostering entrepreneurial spirit among European youth, and I also see great potential in providing more opportunities for women, who form the majority of university graduates.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – In the European Parliament, we have repeatedly called on the Commission and the Council to pay attention and take measures to increase the spread of precarious jobs, as atypical employment contracts, including contracts which do not specify working hours, are often abused and self-employed in order to avoid compliance with employment and social security obligations. There are a number of cases where temporary or part-time contracts are concluded with workers, although people actually work continuously and full-time. Unfortunately, workers in this type of job are the most vulnerable, the most vulnerable to job losses and social guarantees. In addition to high unemployment, the EU is also spreading non-standard forms of employment. I therefore ask you, Honourable Commissioner, should we not take action in this area as soon as possible and initiate consultations on a possible European legislation on forms and treaties of atypical employment? Because that's the only way we can curb precarious work.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, what the financial crisis has done is inflict trauma on the labour market. It's an injury that young people suffer the hardest. What the crisis has done is push these young people into the "emergency movement lane." This tape, which provides an eternal circle of unpaid internships, temporary employment and a gray economy. It's something we have to stop. We need to stop it with concrete action so that we don't let this debate stay here alone or just in some publication. I have such a specific proposal. The first is to reduce subsidised employment and use the money saved to fund the dreams of brave European entrepreneurs. They're going to reveal the jobs we're looking for. Moreover, Erasmus for entrepreneurs only operates within the European Union, let's expand it. Let young European entrepreneurs draw on experience in the US or in Brazil.  I am sure that this will help us overcome the fact that there is currently a labour market for young people and a labour market for everyone else. That's unacceptable.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to draw attention to social entrepreneurship. It plays an undeniably positive role in the economy. Strong rooting and good knowledge of local social and economic realities make these companies better respond to regional challenges and, as a result, contribute to greater social and economic cohesion. Unfortunately, although the overall climate around social enterprises is favourable, there is still insufficient knowledge of them, both among decision-makers at all levels and in society. I agree with the rapporteur that we need more education on social entrepreneurship both in schools and through social campaigns and adult training. It is also important to ensure that such companies receive administrative support and access to finance. In cohesion policy, we already have instruments that these companies can use. It is important that they are aware of these opportunities and receive appropriate support during application and implementation. I am convinced that this will benefit our economy as a whole.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to relaunch the labour market, we need, first and foremost, support measures for the European industrial system, removing bureaucratic obstacles to businesses and lightening the tax burden, transferring it from work to other sources of taxation. Young people have always been a particularly weak segment of the labour market and the economic crisis has contributed to the worsening of their situation. It is essential, for example, that the Commission strengthens the monitoring of national plans for the implementation of youth guarantees and constantly monitors their effective implementation.  Particular attention should be paid to education and training, making them more functional to the labour market, perhaps through specific programmes for innovation and entrepreneurship. We are experiencing a great contradiction: we have impressive levels of unemployment in some countries and about two million jobs are vacant on the continent. New mechanisms must be identified to allow greater mobility of the workforce, and I stress in this regard, the importance of Erasmus + and eures cross-border partnerships.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, social entrepreneurship can contribute to growth, with the main objective of benefiting the community and creating social value and not selfish gain. Social innovation seeks answers to social problems, through the recognition and provision of services, which improve the lives of people and communities, by recognising and implementing new processes of integration into the labour market, aiming at the well-being of individuals and communities, as consumers and producers, and in connection with local development. We therefore need arrangements to provide support mechanisms, both in the start-up and in the operational phase of social enterprises, and we need specialised funding for them and ways of representing and publicising their work. Skills in the fields of management and business ideas need to be strengthened and recognition of the sector improved, both in the public administration as a whole and in the wider public.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So the European Union, the Commission and parliament must decide at some time which way the European Union will go in the future in the field of labour market. Will this labour market flexibility be supported in particular, or will the conditions for more sustainable jobs be created? For young people, of course, this precariousness is a curse, because in fact they cannot shape their future, and of course sometimes they are not helped by education, because we know cases where highly educated people cannot find a job when they are actually forced into precarious work. In some cases, they also carry out so-called volonter work in Slovenia, i.e. without pay, only to have a period of service in some way or to be able to provide opportunities for it. One thing else: with this way, of course, the middle class is slowly disappearing, which cannot be ignored. And speaking of economic growth, I think it is time that, of course, economic growth and employment relations, more permanent employment relationships, go hand in hand. Not that, on the one hand, economic growth is increasing and, on the other hand, precarious employment ratios are increasing.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, we have had a lengthy debate about the EU labour market, but in my opinion there is no such thing as an EU labour market. We have 28 diverse countries with very different needs. We cannot have a ‘one size fits all’ approach to all those countries. Right-wing economics might work in Germany but if we try to apply that to Greece, as we are doing, then it is doomed to absolute failure and disaster.  We are told that there are 25 million unemployed across Europe but there are two million job vacancies. Why, though, is the assumption made that somehow immigration will solve all of this problem? Jobs may be unfilled for many reasons, and cross-border migration does not necessarily solve that and, of course, in most countries there are more unemployed than jobs available.  I suspect so many in this Chamber are desperate to defend the indefensible that they will claim more immigration is the solution for absolutely everything. Free movement of workers will pass no national test but is welcomed here with a quasi-religious fervour as almost an article of faith.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, unemployment continues to be one of the main challenges in the European Union, especially among young people. The unemployment rate is still alarming, as are the significant differences of unemployment rates between Member States.  I agree on the emphasis given to the need to achieve a competitive labour market, to the implementation of reforms that can increase labour market and personal career flexibility, and to the better matching of skills and jobs, including stronger synergies between education systems and labour markets. The issue of skills mismatches, however, should not hide the real problems of the labour markets, the need to fight precarious employment and social inequalities, to invest in human capital in order to prepare the labour markets for the future, and to foster a comprehensive approach regarding labour mobility based on the free movement of citizens and workers and the principle of equal pay for equal work.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for this very interesting debate despite the late hour.  I can assure you that from the Commission’s point of view we are ready to promote all measures at EU level which may contribute to fostering quality and socially innovative jobs and ensure appropriate protection and skills development for all workers in the EU. It is essential to work hand in hand with the Member States and with social partners towards achieving these goals, thus ensuring a sustainable recovery, economic growth and social progress.  I wish to thank in particular the rapporteurs Ms Lope Fontagné and Ms Dlabajová for their important contributions. The Commission looks forward to continuing to work with Parliament on all those topics.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I would also like to thank you for this very rich debate and all these ideas that have been developed. I will limit myself to four ideas since I have already been long enough in my introduction. Firstly, we need real socio-economic governance that gives social and employment a real place and that corresponds to the treaty's objective, namely a social market economy. Second, we need to adapt The 2020 strategy with innovative approaches to promote quality employment, to combat poverty and exclusion, and to focus on training in all its forms. In this context, I believe that social entrepreneurship also has an important place. In fact, Madam, I was in Madrid, Spain, a few months ago, to see the dynamism of the social economy in this country.  Third, there are major technological changes, and I think we need to take very seriously what has been said about digitization and its impact on the labour market. In fact, during the last Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumers Council, the Presidency will address the issue of labour market, skills and skills implications. This point was addressed in the report. Fourthly, it should be known that the competition of social systems without a minimum of rules ultimately leads to the least social. I would remind you that, in this context, we have an article 9 in the treaty that may have to be made operational.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I would like to reiterate my thanks to the colleagues who have contributed to the amendments to improving the text and to all those who have surgery this afternoon. In conclusion, I would just like to ask the Commission and the Council to take into account the conclusions of the report which we will vote on tomorrow.  I have listened with satisfaction to Commissioner Dombrovskis and Minister Schmit, and I am convinced that they will support social enterprises. Minister Schmit spoke of the 2020 Strategy and, as we know, the crisis has taken us away from its objectives, but we need to do everything we can to achieve them, or at least to get as close as possible. Of course, I can't think of a sector that contributes more and as directly as the social economy.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you all for your inspiring comments, questions and opinions. Let me ask you a few comments in the closing speech, as well as questions. For me, mobility does not mean that we are forcing young people to move elsewhere, as has been said here. And motivation and an active approach for me does not in any way mean blaming young people. I would like to live in a Europe where my children know that learning is not torture and that the time spent studying and expanding horizons makes sense. That there is no shame in doing crafts and manual labor if we enjoy it. That children can study at home and abroad. And that when they get home, they'll find a job that matches their abilities and fantasies. What kind of education do you want for your children? I would like to live in a Europe where my children could find inspiration and understanding in the people they will be surrounded by. Whatever their professional plans, they should not be afraid to take risks to fulfill them and to always follow their dream. What friends, teachers, bosses, colleagues do you wish your children? I wish my children would learn responsibility for their lives and not let anyone, not parents, the state, or the authorities decide on it. So that they never passively expect the system to take care of them and not to resign themselves to their desires and wishes and professional dreams. To let them know that honest work can be made a decent living and that change is an integral part of life.  What kind of life do you wish your children? By voting on my report, you can answer these questions. Of course, you can answer me, but especially yourself.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 10 September 2015 (The meeting was suspended for a few minutes) Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – The economic and financial crisis has led to an increase in poverty and social exclusion, as well as long-term unemployment, which has increased the risk of poverty for disabled people throughout the European Union, while at the same time dramatically increasing the number of European citizens unable to find employment for more than a year.  In addition to employment incentives, more attention should be paid to solutions that can facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of even those with the most basic skills and competitive knowledge in the short term, so that the benefits of more innovative solutions in the social economy can be exploited later. Any improvement in the economic and financial situation in the Member States should go hand in hand with intensive support for inclusive and sustainable growth and quality job creation.  In order to transfer them to the social economy, Member States should promote lifelong learning among older workers and the long-term unemployed, including people with disabilities, who continue to face physical, information and communication barriers. Member States should take into account best practices in adjusting national tax systems for the benefit of social enterprises and socially conscious investments and, where appropriate, increase tax incentives and incentives for this type of undertaking dealing with vulnerable groups, such as persons with disabilities.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Creating a European labour market requires ensuring the parallel development of several interconnected processes. The first is the realisation of the European economy while ensuring an innovative level of production. The second covers the proper treatment by the governments of the Member States of science and research and development. Adequate investment in science and the stimulation of research and development through appropriate solutions in tax systems are needed. The proper educational process, conducted with a concern to guarantee the full range of theoretical knowledge and the provision of traineeships and traineeships, is of paramount importance for the development of the labour market. I also stress the importance of a dual education system which, by combining theory and practice, allows for the development of competences that meet the needs of the labour market, thus fostering its smooth development. Finally, the development of the right skills for workers, which are essential on the European labour market, requires investment in education. There is also a need for greater synergies between countries and European programmes aimed at developing the labour market and improving the skills of workers.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Making the European labour market competitive is a major challenge when you consider the EU unemployment figures. One word often comes up: flexibility. Labour market reforms must promote flexible pathways and training, flexible labour markets and greater mobility of workers. The main idea is therefore to make the workforce malleable to comply with the requirements of the market: in other words, it is the market that decides and men only have to obey. The widespread use of the EURES network and immigration must complete this process. Thus, in order to adapt European labour markets to the context of globalisation, the EU opts for the displacement of populations: too bad for the social dumping that is organised! However, competitiveness according to the EU could suffer from national specificities, as states must also be flexible and accommodating in order to undertake the necessary reforms. In short, everything must converge to meet the sirens of ultra-liberalism. But employment policy remains the competence of states, not the EU, and the complicity of states remains necessary to organise the flexibility of the workforce...

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Social entrepreneurship and social innovation in the fight against unemployment, as Parliament is doing today, are among the most important challenges facing today's EU. The economic and financial crisis has exacerbated poverty and social exclusion. Long-term unemployment has increased, especially among young people. For these reasons, it is worth considering developing a more sustainable economic model for the European Union, which would pay greater attention to the creation and development of social and solidarity-based economy enterprises. Social and solidarity-based economy enterprises have demonstrated their adaptability to economic and social circumstances and offer more flexible and innovative working conditions. This is influenced by the fact that social economy enterprises are well established at local and regional level, and this gives them an advantage because they know the specific needs and can offer the right solutions. In the meantime, their main objective is not just profit-making, but, above all, making a positive impact on society, namely the fight against unemployment, poverty and supporting education. The reporter also highlighted the record, highlighting the european Union's growing problems ˗ an ageing population and the world's lowest population growth rates. The Commission and the Member States are therefore encouraged to develop long-term plans that will help to strengthen social and territorial cohesion in the Union and help to meet demographic challenges. Supporting social and solidarity-based businesses will help to solve many problems and, above all, strengthen the labour market position of the most marginalised and disadvantaged groups.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – The labour market is constantly changing. Knowledge, competence and education requirements are also changing. Europe's financial and economic crisis has slowed the economy and led to a high unemployment rate. Aligning skills with labour market demand certainly brings a challenge for the union as a whole. That is why this report is so important. The fact is that many times the education system does not meet the needs of the economy. This requires fundamental reforms, both on the economic policy side and on the labour market. Data for Slovenia also show that we have more and more high school students and graduates of social sciences, and professional professions are dying out. Such a solution must be found so that there is synergy between supply and demand. It is also important that we introduce a dual education system as soon as possible in Slovenia. The fact is that safe jobs are gone today. There are false expectations that without constant training and upgrading their knowledge, someone could spend the same job from their first job to retirement. It is important that we are aware of this as individuals, and the state must also be aware of this and create an encouraging environment for acquiring the skills and competences that are most in demand on the market.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the sustainability of health systems in Europe: future challenges.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission acknowledges that healthcare systems need to be reformed in order to ensure quality healthcare through efficient structures. Furthermore, the Commission is addressing sustainability challenges in healthcare systems in the EU by including relevant criteria in various actions – as has been the case, for example, in previous exercises of the European Semester – and by using a variety of policy tools. The Commission shares the general concern about the affordability of new medical products and the related risks of inequalities arising in access to care, and it is committed to helping Member States respond to this challenge. This commitment was highlighted in the Commission’s communication of April 2014 on effective and resilient health systems, which, among other things, focuses on increasing the accessibility of health systems. The communication stressed the need for improved cooperation, increased transparency and better coordination to minimise any unintended effects that current national pricing systems may have in terms of accessibility throughout the EU. The Commission has no competence to regulate the level of prices of medical treatments: these are determined by Member States individually. The Commission could, however, explore other avenues, for example by pursuing improved exchanges of information among Member States on their pricing policies, with a view to minimising negative effects on the accessibility of medicines in the EU. Another way in which the Commission could assist would be through further exploring the use of the Joint Procurement Mechanism to encourage more advantageous price offers from the pharmaceutical industry. The transposition deadline for the directive on patients’ rights to cross- border healthcare was 25 October 2013. A number of Member States were either late transposing the directive or transposed it incompletely. Where necessary, the Commission launched infringement proceedings against these Member States. As a result, nearly all Member States have now transposed the directive in its entirety. There is a small number of cases outstanding, which will be resolved in a near future. The next stage for the Commission is to assess whether Member States have transposed the directive correctly. The Commission and the Member States are exploring the possibility of producing a joint EU health technology assessment (HTA) report to inform decision makers about clinical outcomes of new health technologies. Member States will continue to work under the remit of the upcoming European Network for Health Technology Assessment (EUnetHTA) joint action to implement the HTA strategy adopted in October 2014, cooperating together on joint assessments of technologies and addressing methodological challenges. Joint forces and expertise will help decision-makers to make more informed and faster choices on access to innovative treatments. There is, however, no willingness to harmonise decisions on either the uptake of technologies or pricing and reimbursement. Cooperation on HTA is complemented by discussions in the Commission Expert Group on Safe and Timely Access to Medicines for Patients (STAMP), which looks at ways to make the best use of existing instruments.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the sustainability of health systems is an issue of decisive importance, in fact, even if it is based on the same values, common values, there are profound differences between twenty-eight countries, so often we have talked about a Europe of inequalities.  Despite this, there are some cross-cutting problems that unite all systems, even those of the richest countries: the data tell us that, for example, as many as 86% of European hospitals suffer from a shortage of medicines, often these are very serious deficiencies, which even concern essential drugs such as those for basic chemotherapy therapies. This is a real paradox! Medicines are approved at European level, but the Eu ropean Union does not have a coordinated action plan to tackle the shortage of medicines. Parallel imports, as the Commissioner mentioned a few days ago, are also often the cause of inequalities in access to essential medicines. In this context, I believe it is necessary to create a complete European framework in order to have a picture of the shortcomings. EMA's efforts to put together a European catalogue of shortcomings are laudable, but unfortunately they have not so far borne fruit.  There is also no framework for the cost of medicines at European level, today each Member State has its own procedures, which means that the same drug is evaluated 28 times, resulting in waste of resources, time, and lack of access to life-saving medicines. Let me give you an example, Trastuzumab, a powerful breast cancer drug that is included in the World Health Organisation's list of essential medicines, has not been distributed fairly in Europe and in some European countries it has taken more than 7-8 years for the drug to be made available to patients. So how many European citizens have died?  In order to move towards harmonisation in the definition of prices between countries at European level, it is necessary to define a Health Technology Assessment at European level, which applies as a reference for all countries. We have also made a written statement with other colleagues. I'm going to stop there, but we really need to deal with this emergency all together.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I am pleased with this debate as convenient and as important. To argue that health competences do not fall within the competences of the European level is commonplace, or too common, even though health protection is a fundamental right in the European Union and that it has not been spared the ideological treatment that has been done from the crisis, as is a fundamental right to health care for third-country nationals on European territory.  However, the Spanish Government has taken 800,000 foreigners out of the Spanish health system and broken the principle of universality, while the Commission has just published that universality and health care for immigrants are not only a moral duty but also more efficient than refusing to lend it to them. Mr President, I ask you: is it true that the Commission is examining sanctions on the Spanish authorities , as the Spanish Health Minister has threatened the regions which have not taken this injustice? On the other hand, to a question from me, the Commissioner recently replied that possible compensation for the migration of health professionals was being examined. What's new about it? And finally, the price of the pharmacy, the sustainability of the health system is key. Do you not also think it appropriate, in addition to the measures announced, to review the patent system and its relationship to a possible abuse of legalized dominant position?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, mass unemployment and poverty affecting European society as a result of the economic and public debt crisis lead to social exclusion, marginalisation and ultimately to the restriction of the right of equal access for European citizens to health care and health services. The disastrous policy of the Memorandum and the Troika in Greece has torn apart public health and hospitals. In order to have sustainable healthcare systems in the European Union, there must be increased public spending. Also, sufficient resources can only come from growth, which will lead to an increase in the state's tax revenues and the consequent increase in public health spending. Growth will also lead to the creation of new jobs and so the social partners themselves will be able, to their fair share, to secure resources to maintain the sustainability of healthcare systems in the European Union. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would first of all like to thank the Commissioner very much for his comments. However, I think that we should go to the core of the issue. The core is that our healthcare systems were developed in a previous century when people mainly died from malnutrition and infections. But now we see people suffering from chronic diseases, requiring years of innovative treatment. Healthcare spending in the EU has grown by nearly 50% since 2000, to almost 12% of European GDP, and it will continue to rise. Nor is it only drug pricing which is to blame. This means that we have to look fundamentally at how we run our healthcare systems if we want to keep them open, qualitative and affordable for everybody. I have heard many good proposals coming from the Commissioner’s side. The Commission is trying to coordinate, invest and exchange information, setting up networks and sharing best practices, but this will not result in the changes that we really need.  Therefore, I would like to make three concrete proposals. First of all, there are major differences in healthcare spending between Member States. The European Semester could serve as a tool to monitor healthcare quality, organisation and spending. Recommendations per Member State and follow-up of implementation of best practice by the Commission would then be key.  Secondly, the World Health Organisation (WHO) has estimated that 20% to 40% of healthcare budgets are wasted due to inefficiencies. So we have to keep a competitive edge when it comes to innovation. This means creating a simplified, stable and favourable environment for investing in healthcare, ranging from drug development to e-health applications to prevention strategies, bringing down the cost for the whole system. Thirdly, I want to make a very concrete suggestion as to where the EU can really provide added value. It is in the field of rare diseases and orphan drugs. I call for the establishment of a European rare disease fund which would harmonise the health technology assessment procedure, making it easier for companies to enter all European markets and obtain reimbursement. The combined Member States would have a stronger negotiating position over the price and the fund would guarantee access for all patients suffering from a rare disease to the most novel and innovative treatments. The Rare Disease Regulation is a decade old so let us finish this work. We have to change our thinking about healthcare and the way that we look at European healthcare systems, so I count on the Commission to lead the way. I think that we will support you in many aspects.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is a very opportune time to have this debate, in particular for my constituents and the people of my home county. When it comes to the sustainability of the Irish Health Service it is quite clear that it is not sustainable, and one of the reasons is because we are haemorrhaging money paying for the collapse of a banking system, a system that collapsed but for which we – and not the speculators – paid the price. EUR 11 million is all that is needed in funding to keep the 90 residents in place at this home that helps our health system, but we cannot afford to pay for it.  I heard today Mr Juncker say that we made sure taxpayers never again have to pay for the greed of financial speculators. Well that is wonderful, Mr Juncker, but the reality is that people in Ireland are still paying for this every day, and the EUR 11 million that the people of Roscommon need, instead of it going to healthcare, well last year EUR one billion was borrowed and destroyed, and Ireland got nothing for it. This year EUR 500 million will be destroyed and we will get nothing for it.  How can you have a sustainable healthcare system when the taxation that is paid for our health and for our education is spent on paying back a debt that was never ours? In 2016, we will have to pay EUR 500 million a year again and burn it, same in 2017, same in 2018. How the hell can that be sustainable? I thought you were here to help us. You are haemorrhaging us. You are destroying us. You are killing us.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, exactly one year ago, at the September 2014 plenary, our House was debating access to vital medicines in Europe, at the initiative of the Green/FTA Group. The vast majority of parliamentarians present then made the same observation as the one that brings us together today, namely that the health care systems in Europe are on the verge of asphyxiation and that their viability is threatened.  If access to care for all is threatened throughout Europe it is above all - compared to my colleague who intervened - because innovative medicines are very expensive. The case of sovaldi, which we discussed, this hepatitis C drug sold in France costs about 41,000 euros, but as another drug must be added, it amounts to 100,000 euros per patient per year, and it will cost the social security 700 million euros per year. When you add all the new drugs that are very expensive, it certainly blows up the social security accounts. One wonders why they are so expensive, especially since, when we make a precise analysis - already made in the case of sovaldi by associations - we realize that there are large doses of public money that have precisely allowed their invention directly or indirectly. This is mainly because our pharmaceutical research and development model is severely affected by chronic perversion.  Net margins and profits for some companies range from 10 to 40%, you see it's incredible. The pharmaceutical industry is the most lucrative right now, so conditionality has to be introduced. I am in for help to pharmaceutical companies, but only if there is public money. There must be no patent, that is, the following idea is submitted: OK innovation, but no patent and the price of drugs may be accessible to all. That is what needs to be redesigned in the case of this monopoly in relation to companies.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this seems to be the tip of the iceberg. This clearly looks like EU harmonisation of healthcare systems by the back door, but using pricing of drugs as the mechanism. I would like to point out that there is a huge difference between the insurance- and privatised—based model of healthcare prevalent in most of Europe and the contributory taxation—based National Health Service model that we have in the United Kingdom. I am not at all sure that this step, which seems to be being launched, will not represent a disastrous threat to the quality, cost and provision of UK healthcare services. My voters and my citizens do not want that. We have got stop blaming the elderly. Many of the chronic healthcare conditions that create the demand are coming about because of lifestyle choices by patients and by individuals of all age groups. We need to do more – if we are going do anything at all – to tackle the source of those problems and start talking about the business interests and the lobbying companies that push the products and create the environmental factors that create the illnesses and the problems for the EU. I would finally like to point out that if you cannot control your borders, cannot control your population and cannot control demand, you will never, ever be able to meet supply. So if healthcare systems cannot plan because they do not know the number of patients, they do not stand a chance.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – The state of health and health systems is one of the key challenges facing the European Union, which is exacerbated by an ageing population and a surge in refugees. I welcome the decision of the Commissioner for Health to set up an expert group to assess the functioning of member states' health systems. It is necessary to systematically address ensuring greater sustainability of health systems and reducing disparities in their quality. The creation of an expert group is a step in the right direction. Only the European Union can have an overview of the differences in the functioning of member states' health systems. The action can only be led by one who has an overview of the whole. I am convinced that the European Semester model, as we know it in the economic or financial sphere, could also be useful in the field of health, and I am pleased that the number of those who share the same thought is increasing. This could establish an annual cycle of health policy coordination and develop a framework for reforming and convergence of health systems. We could also develop common standards regarding the attitude towards public funds spent in public health. The Commissioner said that there is no will of harmonisation in the Member States, not in technology or in prices. Both go to the expense of patients who don't like inequality. I have nothing against diversity when it guarantees progress, but I oppose it when it is an expression of unwillingness to cooperate and it is to the detriment of patients. It is important that patients feel health cooperation as an added value of the European Union. The Treaty of Lisbon does not prevent us from doing more.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr. President, European health systems will face the same problems as today in the future, but the scale of the problem will be far greater. The epidemic of obesity, chronic non-commulies, and an increasingly elderly population are just some of them, all underlined by the fact that healthcare is increasingly in the hands of economists and fiscal policy, and less and less in the hands of the profession. The fact that antibiotics are becoming less effective, vaccination is declining and that geopolitical instability in the European Union's neighbourhood is fuelling mass population movements lead to the conclusion that pressures on health systems will increase and increase. On average, Member States spend around 10% of GDP on health. In most countries, around 80% of the cost of health systems is covered by public money. This is sustainable as GDP grows strongly and the demographic picture goes towards increasing the working age of part of the population. But as we know, reality is different. The European Union does not have broad powers on health, but some of the tools at its disposal, such as the European Semester, can make a difference. At the beginning of his mandate, Commissioner Andriukaitis spoke about the Health Union and indeed, European health systems will have a better future if they unite human and material resources. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – We’ve discussed migration in some detail, but one issue that hasn’t been raised very often is that, in the UK and a number of other countries within Europe, we bring in doctors and nurses from the Philippines and from very poor countries like Malawi. We’re actually depriving some of the poorest countries in the world of much needed professionals, and I believe that’s because we’re not training enough doctors and nurses in the UK and the rest of Europe. Do you agree with that assessment?

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – This is the reality of the European Union as long as it is, and thank God it is, one safe harbor for many of the world's poor.
