So, it is to be expected as long as the European Union is as rich and prosperous as it is today that people from poorer countries will come to us, and of course it is up to our health systems to deal with how they know and educate a sufficient number of their doctors.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Developed healthcare, high standards and universal accessibility to public health services must remain a key component of what is the merits of living in the Union: a high quality of life. The strategy leading to these objectives must take into account the following facts: that years of crisis have put an additional strain on the functioning of health systems, particularly in terms of lowering costs in public health supplies, and that countries that have also had to deal more harshly with the consequences of the crisis have been more at the fore. Then that demographic change is a key factor in influencing the functioning and development of the health system. And that prolonging life also means that the period of time a person needs permanent medical care is being increased. Public health affects many other spheres of social life. On lifestyle, nutrition, housing conditions, working conditions and safety at work, the pharmaceutical dimension of treatment and even tax policy. Finally, efficiency, accessibility and sustainability also depend fatally on the pervasiveness of European science, research and technological development, which we must support.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – (The Member starts talking in Catalan), the future challenges for European health systems are many and we could be discussing here, in this House, whole weeks on this issue. In this regard, I would like to thank the European Commission for the intervention today.  Health systems are the "crown jewel" of the welfare states we built after the end of World War II. In recent years the situation of economic crisis has strained this system of well-being and the transit to the welfare society is done to us somewhat higher. And we must be aware that Europe is facing a general ageing population, which will lead to greater use of health systems. We must therefore be prepared for it.  Even so, we have been able to ensure the preservation of the quality of health services when our citizens have asked us to do so. In this regard, I would like to value health professionals, both care professionals and researchers.  The challenges of the future are many, as I said, but I believe that the ways of dealing with them can be reduced to two aspects: research and investment.  Research that guarantees us the highest quality of our health systems, research that requires public investment and private investment to succeed, and also investment to maintain decent working conditions for all health professionals. We must maintain trust in them and provide stability that is subsequently reflected in the quality of service received by our citizens and perhaps move as far as possible to coordinate the standards of these health systems at European level. This is critical.  We must do everything in our power to ensure not only the viability of health systems in Europe, but also the best quality of service for our citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Commission President Juncker today called for more unions in Europe, and I think many of us agree. We have common policies in many areas, but let's face it, especially in areas where we favour the needs of capital. It is as if we have forgotten the idea of 'Social Europe', social Europe, so it is time to revive it. Let's go one step at a time. We have standards and standards in the field of animal health, for example, but we have hardly any attention on human health. To put it a little more sharply, our livestock may already be in the union, and it seems to us humans that we're going to have to wait a little longer. It is a good sign, however, that at least our food that fundamentally determines our health can be found in the union. We can list the challenges. You don't have to be a fore man to say that their weight is now so great that no Member State can meet them alone. I see the future, the answers of the future, in the common European health policy.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: PPE). – Mr President, Commissioner, I am delighted that we have the opportunity to discuss the issue of the sustainability of health systems in Europe. Despite the European Union's limited powers in the field of health, it must become our priority not only in words but also in deeds.  It is difficult to explain to European citizens why we deal more with farm animal health than human health. The challenges in the future will become greater due to demographic changes, an ageing population, the increase in chronic diseases. This reality must be reflected in the preparation of recommendations to Member States in the framework of the European Semester.  Concrete commitments are needed to implement structural reforms to ensure not only financial sustainability, but also equal access for European citizens to quality healthcare adequate for the 21st century. There are still major health inequalities in Europe between different Member States that hamper economic and social cohesion.  I believe that overcoming these problems requires the European institutions to engage even more deeply in assessing the functioning of our health systems, monitoring their outcomes and– very importantly for me – measuring access to quality healthcare within the European Semester by introducing new health indicators. This will help Member States learn from each other, exchange good practices and identify effective solutions. It will also allow an assessment of compliance with patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.  Let me, Commissioner, finally ask the Commission a question, and it is: the report published last week states that the lack of information is a major reason why patients cannot make the most of their rights under European legislation. What specific measures could the Commission take so that all European patients know their rights as European citizens?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, making healthcare sustainable is a very important part of the political agenda in Europe and it is crucially important for a safe and sound European population. Something needs to be done in order to face the great challenges that are putting too much pressure on our healthcare systems – including our ageing population and the rise of chronic diseases on which we spend most of the EU healthcare budget. Through the use of digital tools, fundamental improvements to our healthcare systems become possible. Service will improve, science will develop and a great quantity of financial resources can be saved to be used for something else within the healthcare budget. We must agree on a practicable common vision, and use innovation and technology to find effective solutions. Through our efforts we will be able to enact positive healthcare transformations that can adapt and, over time, produce high-quality and universally accessible health services in a financially sustainable way.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, the healthcare systems in many European countries are suffering. New medical technologies, new medicines, and an ageing population are driving the continued increase in medical spending. I believe that a major factor for the sustainability of healthcare systems is the strengthening of preventive actions: to turn more to incentives. People respond to incentives. If a person, for example, does not make the annual medical visit, poses an increased risk to health insurance companies and will have to pay a higher health insurance premium. I appreciate that more analysis can be done at European Union level, more attention needs to be paid to the health economy, which is necessary for the health of the economy. It is unacceptable that a newly emerged drug that cures hepatitis C, until recently unhealable, costs tens and tens of thousands of euros. Here we have something to do.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, it is hypocritical to talk about the sustainability of health care systems in Europe in general and vaguely, when there are huge differences between states, depending on their economic situation. To give an example, according to the information provided by the Commission itself in its Communication No 1/ 215, 2014, deaths that could be avoided if there was timely and adequate healthcare are in Lithuania and Latvia about 15 times more than deaths in France. In Romania there are about 10 times as many. Over time, the differences get worse rather than smaller. For example, we have in Greece over the last 5 years, due to the murderous austerity programmes, an increase of at least 10% in the total number of deaths. In order for European solidarity to be genuine, it must, clearly and above all, manifest itself in this area if we are really interested in the supposed European cohesion.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, my brother worked as an aid worker in Malawi, and at that time that country had the lowest number of medical professionals per capita in the world. He saw massive, massive queues – he ended up working actually as a surgeon’s assistant out there – and the conditions were horrific. Yet even though that country had so few health care professionals, we still imported doctors and nurses from those countries to come and work in the British health care system, and the same happens in other countries in Europe. That has a massive, negative, profound impact on those countries, and I just wanted to raise that issue – that problem – and to say that we need to think about the ethics of what we’re doing when that happens.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank you for this discussion and for the views expressed here tonight. I can assure you that the Commission will continue to work hard in support of Member States to address future challenges as regards the sustainability of health systems. Europe’s ambition is to have a social ‘triple A’. One way to achieve this could be through ensuring effective social protection systems with universal access to good-quality healthcare. The Commission will naturally continue to actively support Member States in their endeavours to attain this goal. Long—term challenges exist in this area, which is one of the areas constituting a significant part of public expenditure. At the same time, we need to ensure broad access to affordable and high-quality health services. So the Commission will continue to monitor Member States’ reforms in healthcare and pension systems. Let me close by thanking Parliament once again for its interest and its activities in support of our common objectives in these important areas.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate
